description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Gregory Aaron as the Nutcracker Prince in The Nutcracker, 2004
(Photo by Keiko Guest, courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)

Gregory Aaron
(Photo courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)

text:
AARON,GREGORY ( Gregory Rodge Gehring ) b. Andrews Air Force Base, Maryland 13 Sep 1959. Dancer, ballet master, artistic director. He is the son of Louis Joseph Rodge Gehring and Barbra Ann Dee Lee Martin Rodge. He trained with Susan Francis of Dance Dimensions and at Ballet El Paso, University of Texas, El Paso. On scholarship at Houston Ballet Academy, he studied with Ben Stevenson, Clara Cravey, Eve Pettinger, and Frederick Stroebel.

In 1979, he joined Hartford Ballet, and in 1982 he joined Boston Ballet with E. Virginia Williams and Violette Verdy. As principal dancer with Ruth Mitchell Dance Company, he danced in Sal Aielo’s Nocturno at Riverside Church Theater. In 1986, he joined Pacific Ballet Theater (now Oregon Ballet Theater) where he danced the Nutcracker Prince in James Canfield’sThe Nutcracker, and in The Third Stage.With Hartford Ballet he danced in Romeo and Juliet, The Nutcracker, and Kurt Jooss’s historic The Green Table, touring much of Europe. He danced with Rudolf Nureyev and Boston Ballet in Don Quixote.Beginning in 1989, he directed the Atlanta Festival Ballet with Nicolas Pacaña. In 2001 he danced, taught, and choreographed for Fe Sala-Villarica’s Ballet Center in Cebu. In 2006, he became codirector of Ballet Center. He is also artistic associate for the Royeca School of Ballet in Davao City and General Santos City and the Lipa Ballet School. He runs an International Summer Series that draws dancers from all over the Philippines. He has taught for Ballet Philippines, and all over the USA. He has danced in ballet classics and works of Pacaña, George Balanchine, Rudolf Nureyev, Michael Uthoff, James Canfield, Dennis Nahat, Maxine Mahon, Ron Forella, and Anthony Salatino, among others.

He has danced principal roles in Cebu, Davao, Tagum, and General Santos. Among his own choreographies are The Little Mermaid, The Nutcracker, Cinderella, Eclipse, Eagles Path, Somewhere in Time, Tuscany Pas de Deux, Barber Adagio, Rain Dreams, Dances in the Pavilion, Ragtime Trio, The Jungle Book; and with Nicolas Pacaña, Alice in Wonderland, Beauty and the Beast,and their own versions of Swan Lake and Coppelia —a number of these presented in the Philippines. He spans a long and leading career as dancer, teacher, choreographer, and artistic director in the United States, Europe, and the Philippines. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Maribel Aboitiz and Eddie Elejar in a production of Giselle staged at the UP Theater, Quezon City, 1964

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Maribel Aboitiz, 1957

(Photo courtesy of Sandy Higgins)

text:
ABOITIZ,MARIBEL b. Manila circa 1940. Dancer. Her parents were Dr and Mrs Jose Aboitiz. She trained in ballet with Kaethe Hauser, LuvaAdameit, RemediosdeOteyza, AnitaKane, and RicardoCassell. She also took classes with Alexandra Danilova, Michael Maule, Leon Danelian, and Lew Christensen. Abroad, she trained with Olga Preobrajenska, Felia Doubrovska, Anatole Oboukoff, Pierre Vladimiroff, Boris Kniaseff, Jarijs Plucis, Edward Caton, Mesdames Nora Kiss and Rosanne. With EddieElejar, she performed in Madrid, Barcelona, Hong Kong, and Zurich with the Juan Tena company. She also performed in Manila in the full-evening productions of Giselle, 1961, and Swan Lake, 1962. She danced in the Philippine premiere of “The Shades” Act of La Bayadere in 1961. She was the elegant Princess Aurora and the fiery Kitri in the grand pas de deuxof The Sleeping Beauty and Don Quixote, respectively .

During her brief dancing career in Manila, Aboitiz was considered a dancer of great flair and attraction. After her marriage, she retired and lived in Spain where she died. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
ACUÑA, RUPERT ( Rupert de los Santos Acuña )b. Manila 15 Jun 1951. Dancer, costume and set designer. His parents are dancer Emiliano Acuña and Alita de los Santos. He graduated with a degree in interior design from the University of the Philippines College of Home Economics in 1975. He trained in ballet with Vella Damian and Eric V. Cruz whose Dance Concert Company (DCC) he later led as premier danseur. He also trained with William Morgan, and with guest teachers Jean Deroc, Tina Santos, Gary Wahl, and Mannie Rowe.

He performed with DCC in Guam and with Dance Theater Philippines, of which he was a frequent guest, in London, Aberdeen, and Hong Kong. With DCC, he danced in several productions, including Le Corsaire (The Pirate), Don Quixote, Paquita, Swan Lake, and La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), and in Eric V. Cruz’s ballets as Don Jose in Carmen, Jason in Medea, Conde de Luna in La Gitana (The Gypsy Woman), and Armand Duval in Camille. He also danced feature roles in Remedios de Oteyza–Eric V. Cruz’s Haunted Ballroom, and in Spartacus and Panaginip (Dream). He has teamed up with many leading ballerinas, including Vella Damian, Felicitas Layag-Radaic, Irene Sabas, Gina Katigbak, Marivic Mapili-Vela, Heidi Domingo, Shirley Halili-Cruz, Sophia Radaic, Mary Anne Santamaria, Toni Lopez Gonzalez, and Anna Villadolid. As a designer, he did the sets and costumes for Tony Fabella and Ryan Cayabyab’s Limang Dipa (Five Arm Stretches); Eddie Elejar, Ramon P. Santos, and Virginia Moreno’s Masks; Basilio and C. Reinecke’s Ode to Botticelli; and William Morgan and R. Strauss’s Herodias.After he stopped dancing, he worked with the Philippine International Trading Corporation. He continues to do interior design for various clients. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Luva Adameit

(Photo courtesy of Rosalia Merino-Santos)
Luva Adameit

Luva Adameit’s production of Temple of Nai Hei Ta Sy

(Photo courtesy of Rosalia Merino-Santos)

text:
ADAMEIT, LUVA ( Lubov Adameit ) aka Madame Adameit. b. 27 Sep 1895. d. 7 Jan 1948. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She was a Polish woman who first came to the Philippines in 1922 as a member of Anna Pavlova’s company. She settled in Manila in 1927, and with her manager-impresario G. Leibovitz and pianist Ivan Sitnik, she set up the Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School on San Marcelino Street in Manila. She also taught ballet at the Philippine Women’s University.

Adameit trained the first generation of Philippine ballet teachers and choreographers, including Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Remedios de Oteyza, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Joji Felix-Velarde, Chloe Cruz-Romulo, and Pacita Madrigal-Warns. One of them, Fely Franquelli, made a name for herself abroad as a professional solo artist in the 1930s. Also among her pupils were Mitos Sison, Cecile Yulo, Mita Pardo de Tavera, Helen McMicking, and the Perfecto sisters.

She taught many international character dances, then very much a part of ballet theater presentations. Annually she took a theme—a nature motif or a geographical focus, like the fad for pseudo-orientalism—for her recitals. Later this approach was followed by her pupils in their own school recitals. She also initiated the balletic stylization of Filipino dances, presenting dances inmaria clara(upper-class gown of the 1880s) and regional costumes, as in Planting Rice and Cariñosa (Loveable).Aside from venues like the Manila Grand Opera House, the Metropolitan Theater was a center of her annual recitals before World War II. During her retirement, she was cared for by one of her faithful pupils, Esperanza Santos, aunt to dancer and teacher Edgar Valdez. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Candice Adea performing the Kitri Variation from Don Quixote, USA International Ballet Competition, 2010

(Photo by Victor Ursabia, courtesy of the artist)

Candice Adea in Swan Lake, Ballet Philippines, CCP, 2017

(Photo by Konrad Ong, courtesy of the artist)

text:
ADEA, CANDICE ( Candice Cabrera Adea )b. Manila 9 Nov 1986. Dancer. The daughter of Romualdo Manaois Adea and Cielo Cabrera, Candice Adea is the younger sister of dancer and choreographer Carissa Adea. She is cousins with dancers Timothy and Luis Cabrera, and second cousin to dancer Camille Ordinario-Joson. A dance major from high school to college, Adea graduated from the Philippine High School for the Arts in 2003 and from De La Salle College of St. Benilde with a bachelor of performing arts in 2008. She trained with Josette Salang and Pamela Ortiz in Goldcrest Dance School, Makati, from 1990, then with Brezhnev Larlar at Bodypointe (later Dance Theater Arts). In 1995, she trained briefly with Perry Sevidal, before accepting a scholarship with CCP Dance School, under Noordin Jumalon. The latter led to another scholarship at the Philippine High School for the Arts from 1999 to 2003, where she trained with Nonoy Froilan, Victor Ursabia, Veronique Duma-Berdin, and Ronilo Jaynario. She joined Ballet Philippines in 2003, and trained with Jumalon, Ursabia, Ida Beltran-Lucila, Jeffrey Espejo, Ramon Victoria, Alan Hineline, and Max Luna III.

Known initially as a precise technician, Adea shone in abstract ballets such as the brown pas de deux from Vicente Nebrada’s Our Waltzes, William Carter’s Concerto, Michael Vernon’s Opus 25, Alvin Ailey’s Night Creatures, and Luna’s Kati-Taog. Her expressiveness was nurtured by her mentors, and she blossomed in the title role in Alice Reyes’s Amada, for which she won her first Gawad Buhay Award for Best Female Lead in a Modern Dance Production in 2009. She was promoted to principal in 2010, the year she won the silver prize at the USA International Ballet Competition, performing the Don Quixote, Diana and Actaeon pas de deux, and Augustus Damian III’s Evacuation. Other roles include the title role of Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress), Kitri in the full-length Don Quixote, Princess Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty,Swanilda in Hineline’s Coppelia, Clara in The Nutcracker, Juliet in the balcony scene from Alice Reyes’s Romeo and Juliet, Wendy and Tinkerbell in Peter Pan, and the title role in Effie Nañas’s Snow White. She created her role in Dwight Rodrigazo’s Moving Two, and Maria Clara in Paul Morales’s Crisostomo Ibarra,for which she received a second Gawad Buhay Award for Best Female Lead in 2011.

Adea and Jean Marc Cordero participated in the Boston International Ballet Competition in 2011, where she won the Outstanding Artistry Award, leading to her performance of Flames of Paris at the World Ballet Stars Gala in Riga, Latvia, 2012. She also won the bronze medal at the Seoul International Dance Competition, 2011. In 2012, she won first place at the 7th Helsinki International Ballet Competition. Later that year, she joined the Hong Kong Ballet, which featured her as a demi-soloist in George Balanchine’s Theme and Variations, the Courage Fairy in Cynthia Harvey’s The Sleeping Beauty, a cygnet in the pas de quatreof Swan Lake, and as Clara in Terence Kohler’s TheNutcracker. Written by Joelle Florence Patrice Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Carissa Adea

(Photo by Jojit Lorenzo, courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Carissa Adea as Moyna in Giselle, 2014

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

text:
ADEA, CARISSA ( Carissa Cabrera Adea ) b. 13 Oct 1983. Dancer, choreographer. Carissa Adea is the older of two daughters of Romulo Adea and Cielo Cabrera. She is the sister of dancer Candice Adea, the first cousin of dancers Timothy and Luis Cabrera, and the second cousin of Ballet Philippines (BP) alumna Camille Ordinario-Joson. Through a scholarship granted by BP, she studied dance at the College of Saint Benilde School of Design and Arts.

Adea began dancing ballet at the age of three with Jinggay Formoso and Josette Salang. She underwent intensive training with Lisa Macuja, and passed a number of Royal Academy of Dance (RAD) exams with flying colors under RAD teacher Raul Sauz. She later joined Brezhnev Larlar’s Bodypointe Dance Studio, and in Jun 1998, trained with Christine Walsh in Australia, on a scholarship to the Australian Conservatoire of Ballet. She joined the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School in 1996 and trained with Noordin Jumalon, Gina Katigbak-Garcia, Toni Lopez Gonzalez, and Victor Ursabia. From being a member of the corps de ballet of the CCP Dance School scholars, she became a BP apprentice in 2001, and was promoted to company member in 2012. Upon joining BP, Adea further trained with Denisa Reyes, Augustus “Bam” Damian III, Alan Hineline, and Max Luna III.

Known for her technical prowess, she has performed many lead roles, such as the Sugarplum Fairy in The Nutcracker, 2009; and title roles in Snow White, 2007, and Giselle, 2013. She shone in character roles such as Tinkerbell in Edna Vida’s Peter Pan, 2001; Carmen in a version by Alice Reyes in 2001 and another version by Bam Damian in 2004; Swanhilda in Alan Hineline’s Coppelia, 2008; and Kitri in Don Quixote, 2011. Adea was also seen exuding a sense of daring in neoclassical dances such as Damian’s Evacuation, 2004; and in the “Brown Waltz” of Our Waltzes, 2009. She premiered Max Luna III’s The Hurt We Embrace, 2008. She also appeared as Tatarin in Alice Reyes’s Amada, 2009; Babaylan in Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress),2011; Sita in Alice Reyes’s Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 2012; and Sisa in Paul Morales’s Crisostomo Ibarra, 2010. This earned her the Outstanding Featured Female in a Dance Production Award at the Philstage’s 2010 Gawad Buhay Awards. Adea also choreographed ReySing (Racing), inspired by hip-hop movements. In 2011, Adea’s ReySing won first place in the National Commission for Culture and the Arts National Dance Competition. Written by Anna Camille Fabella

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Mylene Aggabao-Salgado in Ballet Manila’s Le Corsaire, 2013

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Manila)

text:
AGGABAO-SALGADO, MYLENE ( Mylene Honculada Aggabao-Salgado ) b. San Juan, Manila 5 May 1982. Dancer. She is the daughter of Rosmito Aggabao and Elizabeth Honculada. She is married to dancer Harold Salgado, with whom she has one child. She finished high school at St. Paul College, Parañaque in 1999. Aggabao holds a bachelor’s degree in computer system design in programming from AMA Computer University. She also took a second course in accountancy at the Philippine Christian University. Aggabao trained in classical ballet from age three at the CCP Dance School, with Noordin Jumalon, Gina Katigbak, and Annie Divinagracia, from 1985 to 1997. She was mentored by Perry Sevidal in 1998, and then was invited to become a member of Ballet Manila (BM) in 2008 to be mentored by Lisa Macuja-Elizalde and Osias Barroso, and visiting Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet teachers Tatiana Alexandrovna Udalenkova, Serguei Vikulov, and Natasha Raldugina. With BM, she performed in the United States, Scotland, South Korea, Russia, Cambodia, Taiwan, England, Ireland, and Singapore.

She danced technically complex roles, particularly as Gamzatti in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), and the Sugar Plum Fairy in The Nutcracker, for which she received the Gawad Buhay Award for Most Outstanding Female Performance in a Classical Role in 2011. She also performed Nikiya in La Bayadere, and various lead roles, including Kitri in Don Quixote, Juliet in Romeo and Juliet, Medora/Gulnara in Le Corsaire (The Pirate), Lise in The Naughty Daughter ( La Fille Mal Gardee ), and the peasant pas de deux in Giselle. She danced other roles in Tatlong Kwento ni Lola Basyang (Three Stories of Grandma Basyang), 2008; Agnes Locsin’s Arachnida; Alamat: Si Sibol at si Gunaw (Legend: Sibol and Gunaw), 2009; Tony Fabella’s Dalagang Pilipina (Filipina Maiden); Hazel Sabas’s Deconstructing Gershwin and Green; Augustus Damian III’s M.A.Z.N.; Maynila ni Juan (Juan’s Manila), 2010; and Max Luna III’s Embraceable You. She was invited by Philippine Ballet Theatre to perform the dual role of Odette/Odile in Swan Lake in 2010. Written by Elka Krystle Requinta

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
AIKO, JESS (Jesus Ramos Ayco) aka Jess Ayco. b. Pasig, Manila 8 Aug 1916. d. Bacolod 2 May 1982. Painter, choreographer, director. He was the son of Leon Conde Ayco and Encarnacion Ramos. He adopted an artistic name ( Jess Aiko ) in 1967. He obtained his early schooling at Ateneo de Manila. He took courses in painting at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts in 1935-36. He also studied architecture at the University of Santo Tomas. He traveled to Europe and studied in London and Paris for some time. He held his first one-person show at the Philippine Art Gallery in May 1956, which was followed by group and solo shows in Bacolod, Cebu, Iloilo, and Dumaguete cities. In his shows, he displayed an avant-garde sensibility borne out by his experiments in enamel and tempera. He was instrumental in the formation of the Art Association of Bacolod. He lived in Bacolod City for most of his life.

Well-traveled and well-read, Ayco witnessed the vigor of abstract painting in Paris. His canvases were covered with splatterings of enamel paint. The density and tensility of his medium became the very subject of his paintings. An early work of Ayco, Young Widow by the Church, 1947, showed his expressionistic tendency, quite advanced for the period in the context of Philippine art history. However, he also used the patterns formed by the medium to evoke shapes derived from life as in Sylvan Idyll, 1956.

Ayco designed for dance and drama presentations, and choreographed dances in Bacolod, Iloilo, and Cebu. He was involved in the Kayumanggi FolkDance Troupe from the 1950s through the 1960s, the Negros Occidental Dance Troupe (NODT) in the 1970s, and in the KaanyagPilipinasDanceCompany, formerly the West Negros College Dance Company, in the 1980s. As artistic director of the NODT, he worked with dance directors Elsie Yelo-Enriquez and Virgie Gallespen. Under his direction, they strung together Philippine folk dances into theatrical programs like The Lost Earring and Fiesta, which included another original treatment of AlejandroRoces’s story “The Cockfight.” In 1965, he staged Scintilla, which fused Philippine folklore, stories, music, and choreography, and in 1966, the dance drama Igpat sang Bulawan (Glow of Gold), about the barter of Negros and Panay that antedated the Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: Golden Salakot) in Manila.

He was also involved with Visayan theater groups in plays and musicals. He staged Oklahoma in Bacolod, The Sound of Music and Carousel in Iloilo, and The King and I in Cebu. He produced and directed Medea and Oscar Wilde’s Salome, among others. He also designed for most of the dance productions of Bacolod’s choreographer LydiaMadarang-Gaston, and for the first Asian tour of the BaranggayFolkDanceTroupe in the 1960s.

Aiko won the following prizes in the Art Association of the Philippines art competition: honorable mention in photography, Pitang, 1952; second prize in non-objective painting, Anterean Dance, 1958; and second prize in non-objective painting, Plutonian Passage, 1962. Written by Santiago A. Pilar and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Airdance

(Photo from airdance.com.ph)

Airdance

(Photo from facebook.com/AirdancePH/)

text:
Founded in Aug 2001, Airdance is one of the country’s leading dance companies focused on contemporary dance. The core members of the group when it first started—Julie Alagde, Avel Bautista, Joseph Laforteza, Christine Maranan, Vinia Pamplona, and Lynley Teng—were from Powerdance. Dwight Rodrigazo also helped to establish the company and clarified its vision and thrust as a contemporary dance group. Based in Quezon City, Airdance appears in some of the major dance festivals in Manila including the WiFi Body Dance Festival, Contemporary Dance Map, and International Dance Day.

In 2004, Airdance produced its first full-evening production, Indios Bravos (Brave Natives), with choreography by Dwight Rodrigazo and Paul Morales, premiered at Teatro Aguinaldo, Armed Forces of the Philippines Theater. Since then, it has put on full-scale productions each year, including R-18: Bold Contemporary Dance, 2004; Carmen de la Cruz,2006; Love Potion No. 9,2007; and Adarna,2011. These works are often choreographic collaborations between members of Airdance, curated by the group’s current artistic director. Airdance started the series Body Politics and A Season of New Dance in 2006, Declaration in 2011, and In|Stall|Ment in 2013.

Airdance has been home to many prominent dancers, teachers, and choreographers in the country. Paul Morales was its first artistic director from 2003 to 2009, followed by Ava Maureen Villanueva-Ong since 2009. Among the teachers and choreographers who grew with the company are Jed Amihan, Ma. Elena Laniog-Alvarez, Hazel Brendia, Sharon Brendia, Mia Cabalfin, Fredrick Fernandez, Nina Hayuma Habulan-Gelladuga, Proceso Gelladuga, Ernest Hojilla, Ernest Mandap, Clarissa Mijares, Christine Maranan-Novales, Jethro Pioquinto, Rhosam Prudenciado Jr, and Rodrigazo. The group has also done several collaborations with choreographers Raul Alcoseba, Herbert Alvarez, Myra Beltran, Novy Bereber, Christine Crame, and Jay Cruz.

Apart from its involvement in local commercial and corporate productions and festivals, Airdance has represented the country in various international dance events: World Expo in Japan, 2005; (E)motion Dance on Screen Festival in Indonesia, 2005; the 7th Asia Arts Festival in China, 2005; and MAU: Japan-ASEAN Dance Project, which toured Southeast Asia in 2013. The company won the grand prize in the 2004 Mindanao Modern Dance Competition in South Cotabato, with the title “Best Young Contemporary Dance Theater Company.” Airdance also won Best Dance Modern Company in 2007 and 2008 at ALIW Awards. Written by Chantal L. Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Patrick Alcedo

(Photo by Christian Ryan, courtesy of the artist)

text:
ALCEDO, PATRICK ( Russ Patrick Perez Alcedo )b. Roxas City, Capiz 10 Jan 1972. Dancer, scholar, filmmaker, teacher. He is the son of Peter Alcedo and Lynet Perez, and older brother of University of the Philippines (UP) Filipiniana Dance Troupe director Peter Alcedo. Patrick is currently a permanent resident of Canada. He graduated with a bachelor of arts degree in English from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1992. He finished a doctorate degree in dance history and theory at the University of California (UC) Riverside, under the auspices of the Asian Cultural Council (Ford Foundation Grant), 2003. For his dissertation titled “Traveling Performance: An Ethnography of a Philippine Religious Festival,” he received the Graduate Research Award from UC Riverside for excellence in doctoral research.

He was instructor with the Department of English and Comparative Literature, UP Diliman, 1992-94, and with the Department of Communication, UP Manila, 1995-96. From 2003 to 2007, Alcedo was lecturer in different departments of UC Riverside and Irvine, teaching under the Southeast Asian Studies Program and the Department of Religious Studies in Riverside, and the Asian American Studies Department in Irvine. He became associate chair of the Department of Dance in York University in 2011-12, and has been assistant professor in the same department since 2008. He is also faculty associate of the York Centre for Asian Research and faculty of Graduate Studies in Theatre Studies. He is currently the director of the MA and PhD programs in dance and dance studies in York, a position he has kept since 2014.

Alcedo writes, produces, and directs films on the interweaving of dance and ritual in the Philippines. In 2010, he did Ati-atihan: Mother of Philippine Festivals, which was published in InTensions, a refereed electronic journal as a 22-minute multimedia project of still images, music, and ambient sounds. This was distributed by Alexander Street Press. In 2012 he also did Ati-atihan Lives, a 55-minuter, and Panaad: A Promise to the Santo Niño, an 18-minuter, both distributed by Alexander Street Press.

He completed several works on dance, performance, religious rituals, and festivals. In 2014, he published “Emotional Landscapes and Religious Landscapes: The Making of the Documentary Film A Piece of Paradise” in the book Theatres of Affect: New Essays on Canadian Theatre, 2014,edited by Erin Hurley and published by the Playwrights Canada Press in Toronto, and “Introduction to Nanay: A Testimonial Play” in the book Once More with Feeling, 2014,also edited by Hurley for the same publishing house.

Alcedo has been a recipient of various scholarships and fellowships. In 2005, as a Freeman Artist-in-Residence at the University of Hawaii in Manoa, he conducted lecture demonstrations on Philippine folk dance. In the same year, he was a postdoctoral fellow in the Southeast Asian studies program of UC Riverside. In 2007 he was recipient of the Rockefeller Humanities Fellowship from the Smithsonian Institution’s Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage in Washington DC. In 2014, he received the Selma Jeanne Cohen Award for Dance from the Fulbright Association in Washington DC. That same year he was also a visiting scholar of Choreomundus International Master in dance knowledge, practice, and heritage. In 2012 Alcedo was given the Outstanding Kalibonhon award by the Provincial Board of Aklan for his invaluable contribution to cultural research on Aklan. That same year, he was also proclaimed Outstanding Aklanon by the Aklan Governor’s Office for his promotion of Philippine culture to the international community, and Most Outstanding Aklanon by the Aklan Mayor’s Office for his exemplary contribution to research on Aklanon culture. Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jamin Alcoriza, center, Inday Mañosa, left, and Joji Felix, right

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Jamin Alcoriza, 1969, on a brief stint with the erstwhile Philippine Dance Company of New York

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Jamin Alcoriza, 2004

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
ALCORIZA, JAMIN Active in the Philippines from 1950 to 1960. Died in New York. Dancer, choreographer. He trained with RemediosdeOteyza and danced in her productions as well as those of PaulSzilard and TrudlDubsky-Zipper. Noted for his “Bluebird” in Sleeping Beauty,he was acknowledged as a ballet virtuoso in the 1950s.

In association with AlQuinn, Jack Jacinto, Arturo Zamora, Rally Calvo, Chito Feliciano, and ShirleySantosLang, he was a member of the Modernaires. The group danced mostly his choreographies for television, stage shows, and charity shows. He also choreographed for the movies with SampaguitaPictures. He was chosen to dance as the male attendant to the princess in Singkil for Steve Parker’s Philippine Festival in Las Vegas in 1961. Staying on in the United States, he continued to dance for the PhilippineDanceCompanyofNewYork and other groups, and later turned to painting and book designing. Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
ALCOSEBA, RAUL ( Raul Custan Alcoseba ) b. Prosperidad, Agusan del Sur 26 Aug 1961. Choreographer and dancer. The son of Maximo Alcoseba and Julieta Custan, he comes from a family of painters and musicians, including the Cebuano painter Martino Alcoseba Abellana. In 1986, he enrolled in the Southwestern University in Cebu City for a bachelor of science in medical technology but eventually decided to concentrate on the arts.

He was trained as a folk dancer of the Southwestern University Dance Troupe in Cebu City in 1980-86 under Mych Gonzales, and simultaneously with the APO-Banoansaka Dance Company of Mabolo, Cebu, in 1982-88 under Al Evangelio. He also took classes in classical ballet with Fe Sala-Villarica, and in jazz with Mike Gonzales and Joe Galleon. Moving to Quezon City in 1992, he joined workshops in modern dance by Jojo Lucila. In the same year, he joined Lucila’s Chameleon Dance Company and was appointed artistic director in 2005.

Alcoseba’s choreographic works were impressive to many, including those he did for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) summer workshops, and at the University of the Philippines (UP) where he joined the workshop of Gerri Houlihan of the American Dance Festival in 1994. At the end of the latter workshop, he presented En Croix (Crossed) and Terra Cotta Pass.These led to commissioned sections in Basilio’s War Requiem, 1994, for UP Dance Company’s participation in the World Dance Alliance’s Wudao (Dance) Festival, in Beijing, China.

Among his works for Chameleon Dance Company are Subic Bay, 1993; Waters through My Hair, 1995; Ego Has Me, 1996; Prefrontal of Cortex, 2001; Joyride, 2002; Der Karnival der Tiere (The Carnival of Animals) and Father, 2004; Speaking with My Own Voice, 2005; House for Sale, A Stone and the Obliging Pond, and Dark Tar Kitchen, 2006; Stories Written on My Skin, Chord Theory, and Rite of Spring, 2007; Hemline, Heavyside Layer, and My Funny Valentine, 2008; and Amidst My Negative Spaces, 2009. As former artistic director of the company, he mentored other choreographers such as Rudolph Segundo, Oliver Palad, and Mark Rosaroso.

In 2003, Alcoseba was commissioned to choreograph Tisyu (Tissue) and Cita’s Own for Ballet Philippines’s (BP) Arkilahan (Rental) production. For BP’s Neo-Filipino series 2003, he did Uma-Amen (Acquiescence). In the same year, he collaborated with Jose Jay Cruz and Butoh artistKo Murobushi, presenting Pine at the CCP Tanghalang Huseng Batute. He also choreographed Omertà, 2004, for International Dance Day. In 2012, he choreographed Loro (Parrot) for the UP Dance Company and Topak (Crazy) for Airdance. He continues to collaborate with Contemporary Dance Network Manila for its Contemporary Dance Map projects and the WiFi Body Festival.

National Artist Leonor Orosa-Goquingco singled out Alcoseba as a discovery in 1993 for his recklessness in exploring and creating movement. Written by Joelle Florence Patrice Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Reynaldo G. Alejandro

(Photo from Tahanan: A House Reborn by Reynaldo G. Alejandro and Vicente Roman S. Santos, Duende Publishing, 2003)

text:
ALEJANDRO, REYNALDO ( Reynaldo Gamboa Alejandro ) aka Ronnie Alejandro.b. San Juan, Manila 11 Oct 1944. d. 7 Aug 2009. Dancer, choreographer, essayist. His parents are Jacinto Alejandro and Arsenia Gamboa. He graduated with a bachelor of arts from Ateneo de Manila University in 1963, and earned a master of arts in library science from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1966. In 1969, he left for further studies in the United States.

He performed, choreographed, and taught throughout the Philippines and had a stint with Filipinescas in 1964. He won awards for Best Choreography in the Philippine National Songfests of 1967 and 1968, and was resident choreographer of the Philippine Educational Theater Association Kalinangan Ensemble. His works done in collaboration with Roberto Caballero include The Legend of Sarimanok for Hariraya Dance Company, Sisa, and Kay Selya (To Celia).

In New York, Alejandro became artistic director/choreographer of the Philippine Dance Company, 1969-81; founder, artistic director, and choreographer of Reynaldo Alejandro Dance Theater, 1974-81, and in 1991; and, at various times, choreographer for the All Nations Dance Company, founder of Dance Pantomime Theater of the Philippines, artistic director of Pagsamba Dance Ensemble, and cofounder and choreographer of the Asian New Dance Coalition. Alejandro also served in the council of advisers for foreign countries of the Congress of Research in Dance. He contributed to the International Dance Encyclopedia and to various journals on dance and theater in the United States. He was a member of the board of the Dance Perspectives Foundation, New York.

In the United States, he published the Sayaw Silangan (Dances of the East) series 1-6, 1975-80, and the Bagong Salta (The Immigrant) dance series, 1980-81. His other books on dance are Sayaw Silangan, 1972, Philippine Dance: Mainstreams and Crosscurrents, 1978, and Sayaw: Philippine Dance, 2002. He also authored, coauthored, edited, and published around 38 Filipiniana titles on architecture, food, stamps, restaurants, and various Philippine traditions, celebrations, and locations. Some of these are Restaurant Design, 1993; Pasko: The Philippine Christmas, coauthored with Maria Y. Chorengel, 1998; Lamesa: The Filipino Table, coauthored with Josephine Labrador Serrano, 1999; Food of the Philippines, coauthored with Doreen Fernandez, 1999; Pasig: The River of Life, coedited with Alfred A. Yuson,2000; Selyo :Philippine History in PostageStamps, coauthored with Rosa M. Vallejo, 2000; Flowers of Baguio, 2001; Laguna: The Living Lake, 2002; Philippine Christmas: Art & Form, 2002; Tahanan: A House Reborn, coauthored with Vicente Roman S. Santos, 2003; Pabalat: Pastillas Wrappers, 2003; Authentic Recipes from the Philippines, coauthored with Luca Invernizzi Tettonni, 2004; The Adobo Book :Traditional & Jazz-Up Recipes,2004; Magandang Filipina: Beauty for Life, 2005; Authentic Recipes from the Philippines, 2005; Manila Bay: Crossroads of Asia, edited with Vicente Roman S. Santos and Alfred A. Yuson, 2006; The BeautifulFilipina, 2007; and Estilo Ilonggo: PhilippineSouthern Lifestyle, coauthored with Vicente Roman S. Santos, 2009.

His fellowships and awards include the Asia Foundation fellowship in dance, 1969; the Creative Artists Public Service Fellowship in choreography, 1974; Ten Outstanding Young Men or TOYM, 1974; COR- MOSEA grant, 1975; Outstanding Filipino Overseas Award in Arts, Manila, 1978; Distinguished Service Award, New York Jaycees, 1978; and a New York Council on the Arts grant, 1979. He was named one of the Outstanding Young Men in America in 1980 and cited in Who’s Who in the East, 1986; Who’s Who of Emerging Leaders in America, 1987; and in the Encyclopedia of New York City. He was the recipient of the Parangal ng Lahi–Medal of Excellence and the Outstanding UP Alumnus Award, both in 1987. He received the Dakilang Pilipino Award, Philippine Consulate General of New York in 2009. As a tribute to his work, his publications were on display at the Asian Reading Room, Library of Congress, Washington DC, on 20-28 Aug 2009. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
AlunAlun Dance Circle, 2016

(Photo courtesy of Rosalie Matilac)

AlunAlun Dance Circle performing at the Tanglaw ng Lahi Award ceremony, Ateneo de Manila University, 2005

(Photo courtesy of Rosalie Matilac)

AlunAlun Dance Circle Board, 2016

(Photo courtesy of Rosalie Matilac)

text:
ALUNALUN DANCE CIRCLE ( ADC ) Founded in 1999 by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa and her students Cecilia B. Garrucho, Nannette S. Matilac, Matthew Santamaria, and Sarah Lumba-Tajonera, the AlunAlun Dance Circle is dedicated to the preservation and conservation of pangalay as intangible cultural heritage. The first Board of Trustees was composed of the founding members with the inclusion of Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Elmer del Rosario, Grace F. Amilbangsa, and Dalisay F. Lumba. In 2009, Mariel N. Francisco and Pacita C. Gavino joined the board.

Alun-alun, meaning “gentle wave,” characterizes the flowing, undulating movements of pangalay and its variants, as researched by Amilbangsa since 1969. Also known as igal among the Sama and pamansak / pansak among the Yakan, it is the dominant indigenous dance form of the Sulu Archipelago, antedating Islam and Christianity in the Philippines. The ADC combines preservation with innovation and experimentation. Its repertoire consists of traditional pangalay choreography as well as creative pieces accompanied by pop, classical, rock, and folk music and poetry. ADC has staged performances in formal and informal venues in Manila and the provinces. Stillness in Motion,2000,the first major choreography of Fernando Amilbangsa, utilized puppets and masks to the avant-garde composition of Isha Abubakar. Bangko ni Billy (Billy’s Bench), 2002, featured the sculptured bench of Napoleon Abueva and the novelty songs of Yoyoy Villame. Other performances include Pangalay at Musika ng Bayan (Pangalay and Music of the Nation),2010; Alay sa Kalayaan (In Praise of Freedom), 2011; Konsiyerto ng Pangalay, Tula, Salinawit at Musika (Pangalay Concert in Poetry, Adapted Songs and Music), 2011 ; Alay sa Kababaihan (Tribute to Women), 2012; Alay sa Kalikasan (An Offering to Nature), 2012; Dance, Music, and Prayer for Mother Earth, 2012; Celebrating Eid’l Fitr through Dance, 2012; and Pangalay and Icons of Philippine Culture, 2013. Other artistic collaborations were with the Philippine Madrigal Singers, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, Lutgardo Labad, Marra PL. Lanot, Benilda Santos, Jose F. Lacaba, Cooky Chua, and Joey Ayala.

The ADC links with other Asian dance cultures in classical dances of Cambodia, Thailand, Indonesia, and India. It propagates pangalay through the Amilbangsa Instruction Method (AIM) based on the breath and nonlinear rhythm common to Asian movement disciplines. Weekly training sessions at the ADC studio in Antipolo City have made pangalay accessible to researchers, filmmakers, choreographers, dancers, and dance students. On the other hand, their outreach training has introduced pangalay to public school teachers of Pontevedra, Negros Occidental; theater artists of Teatro Talyer, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), and PETA-Metropolitan Teen Theater League; members of Kaloob Philippine Dance Ministry; students of Emilio Aguinaldo College; and overseas Filipinos sponsored by the Philippine embassy in Paris. In 2008, the workshop for the Punta Cruz Cultural Collective in Maribojoc, Bohol, culminated in Tawag sa Bantawan (Call of the Watch Tower), a dance drama depicting the heroic struggles behind the Punta Cruz Watch Tower. A pilot project at Manila Boys Town in 2012 culminated in Pangalay sa Manila Boys’ Town (Pangalay at Manila Boys’ Town) performed by resident children and seniors.

In 2007 ADC convened the International Conference on the Conservation and Popularization of Pangalay and Related Asian Dance Cultures in Metro Manila. Filipino academicians, teachers, cultural workers, dancers, and choreographers interacted with colleagues from Cambodia, Thailand, Japan, United States, Indonesia, and Malaysia. In 2009, a dance exchange workshop between ADC and Indonesian dancers marked the 60th anniversary of Indonesia-Philippine bilateral relations. At the 4th Asian Performing Arts Festival in Taipei in 2006, the ADC presented two full-length shows, Offering and Shoeperb-Superb! For the 60th anniversary of Franco-Philippine relations in 2007, the ADC held a series of performances in Paris. In 2009, the Philippine ambassador to Vietnam hosted the ADC’s performance at the vin d’honneur for the 111th Philippine Independence Day in Hanoi. Written by Ma. Eloisa Francisco and Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Herbert Alvarez

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
ALVAREZ, HERBERT ( Herbert Española Alvarez ) b. Iloilo City 21 May 1978. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Alvarez is the son of Roger Alvarez and Margarita Española, and husband of dancer and choreographer Ma. Elena Laniog. He majored in dance at the University of the Philippines (UP). Alvarez first trained in ballet, modern dance, and folk dance in Iloilo with Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company, directed by Edwin C. Duero, 1992-2000. In 1997, he joined the UP Dance Company, directed by Basilio Esteban Villaruz. He also trained with Ramon Obusan, Corazon Iñigo, Brezhnev Larlar, Raul Nepomuceno, Liza Fernandez-Punzalan, Christine Maranan-Novales, Judell de Guzman-Sicam, Angela Lawenko-Baguilat, Paul Morales, Nicholas Rowe, Kristin Jackson, Kazuo Kamisawa, Shanti Sreedhar, Nikmatul Kowim, Tatiana Balashova, and Denisa Reyes.

His important roles include the Paubari and Saragnayan in Agnes Locsin’s Hinilawod, Father in Steve Villaruz’s Tinagong Dagat (Hidden Sea), Father in Liza Fernandez-Punzalan’s Ang Kasal (The Wedding), and the Prince in Mosque Baroque.He also performed in Ramon Obusan’s Palanublion and Denisa Reyes’s Undress the Icon.

He has participated in several international tours as liaison, performer, and choreographer with Dagyaw Theater and Dance, Edwin C. Duero Dance Company, UP Filipiniana, and the UP Dance Company. He joined the World Dance Alliance Collaborative Choreographic Project in Indonesia, 2005, where he collaborated with Rasmida Raras in Perdikan Kami / Our Glimpses. He participated in the Taipei Dance Elite Academy: Asia Young Choreographers project in Taiwan, 2007, where he choreographed Leaving Behind.

As a teacher, Alvarez has worked with the UP Dance Company, Edwin C. Duero Dance Company, Airdance, Ava School of Dance, Center for Music and Movement, and the Dance Conservatory. He has been a member of the World Dance Alliance–Philippines and Asia-Pacific since 2005, a core member of the Contemporary Dance Network–Manila since 2008, and a member of Association of Ballet Academies of the Philippines from 2009.

He has showcased works for the WiFi Body Dance Festival, Contemporary Dance Map, and several other events in the country and abroad. Among them were Pedro Kusinero (Peter the Cook) and Chichester Psalms, his collaborative choreographies with Laniog that garnered him the UP Student Achievement Award in 2004. His solo for Laniog, Lamentations,won him second place in the New Choreographer’s Competition in the 2nd WiFi Body Dance Festival, 2007. In 2009, he received the Outstanding Young Alumni Award from his high school, Iloilo National High School. Written by Ma. Eloisa Francisco and Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jed Amihan

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
AMIHAN, JED ( Jed Jumilla Amihan ) b. Bacolod City 29 Jul 1979. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. Amihan is the eldest son of Vicente Serio Amihan and Margie Jumilla. He has a degree in mass communication from the University of Negros Occidental Recoletos.

Amihan was a member of Kasadyahan Dance Theater and Teatro Amorseco from 1996 to 2001. During these years with the community-based theater group, he started choreographing folkloric and contemporary works for local festivals while serving as the group’s president and assistant choreographer in2008. Among his teachers were Rudy Reveche, Dwight Rodrigazo, Ruel Calansingin, Lydia Paz Umali, and Rene Hinojales.

From 2003, he trained with Ballet Philippines in Manila, and later with Paul Morales and Myra Beltran. In 2005, he joined Airdance and has since then performed with and choreographed for the company, such as in the productions Vital Statistics, Malakas at Maganda (Strong and Beautiful), Deus Ex Machina, Highway 54, Indios Bravos (Brave Natives), Carmen de la Cruz,and Love Potion #9.He also danced with Myra Beltran in several works, notably her Nostalgia: Le Grand Tango,2007, and Betrayed by Martha,2008. In 2009, he became associate director of Airdance under Ava Villanueva-Ong.

As a dancer, his style and movements have been described as fluid and organic, qualities that translate as well to his choreography. His interest in lines, space, and patterns has long been expressed in his works. He choreographed for Contemporary Dance Network–Manila and the WiFi Body Dance Festival, and was a finalist at the 2008 New Choreographers Competition. The following year, he was featured at the New Choreographers Platform: 2nd Step. His other significant choreographic works with Airdance since 2006 include Monolove I and II,2009;“Proverbs” for the production In Between Tenses,2009; Greyline for Declaration,2010; Acts 1 and 2 of the full-evening work Adarna,2011; I-saw-metric,2011;and Alone or Two, 2012, a poignant solo about having the courage to dance even without a partner.

In 2010 and 2013, he worked with Jose Jay Cruz and his Transitopia Dance Commune as a resident artist of the research project Hyper CorpoReality. In 2013, he was part of the Mau: ASEAN-Japan Dance Project, which toured Southeast Asian countries, including Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines. Written by Nicole Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa

(Photo courtesy of the Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation)

Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa

(Photo courtesy of the Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation)

Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa

(Photo courtesy of the Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation)

text:
AMILBANGSA, LIGAYA FERNANDO ( Ligaya Flores Fernando Amilbangsa )b. San Juan, Rizal 9 Oct 1943. Scholar, choreographer, dancer, teacher, cultural heritage conservationist.The daughter of Gil Estanislao Fernando, former mayor of Marikina, and Remedios Constantino Flores, a businesswoman. She is the mother of Dayangdayang Grace Amilbangsa who was a dancer, stage and film artist, and later a child development teacher in the USA; and Datu Gil Amilbangsa who is an industrial engineer and president of an international steel building company. She graduated in 1963 with a bachelor of arts degree in English from Far Eastern University (FEU). After she married her schoolmate Datu Punjungan Amilbangsa in 1964, she moved with him to the Sulu Archipelago where she first saw the dance called pangalay aka igal, a pre-Islamic dance tradition among the ethnic groups in Southern Philippines.

Captivated by pangalay, Fernando Amilbangsa began researching not only on the dance but also on related fields such as music, architecture, and visual arts of the Sama and Sama Dilaut (Badjao), Jama Mapun, and Tausug. Her groundbreaking work is the documentation, deconstruction, and codification of the pangalay/igal dance style, also known as pamansak among the Yakan. Aside from pangalay, she also documented two other dance traditions: the langka style, a martial dance tradition, and the lunsay, a song-dance tradition. She was also the first to record and translate the ritual dances of the Sulu Archipelago into choreographic works. Her decades of research led her to conclude that these dances are linked to the classical dance traditions of Southeast Asia. As a dance teacher, she devised a formal method of instruction called the Amilbangsa Instruction Method (AIM), which allows children and seniors to learn the dance in a scientific and systematic way. The AIM ensures the transmission of the dance form with fidelity to tradition. In 1983, she published Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions, which won the Best Art Book award from the ManilaCriticsCircle. Her second book, titled Ukkil: Visual Arts of the Sulu Archipelago, was published in 2005.

Aside from doing research, she actively promoted Tawi-Tawi’s rich culture. In 1974, she founded and became the first president of the Tawi-Tawi Cultural and Historical Society. In the same year, she organized the Tambuli Cultural Troupe, the first dance group in the province, which she directed until 1978. She became a consultant for a film documentary on the Sama Dilaut (Badjao) in 1975, and initiated and administered the First Tawi-Tawi Arts and Crafts Exhibit in 1976 through the Mindanao State University (MSU), Sulu College of Technology and Oceanography, and the Tawi-Tawi provincial government. From 1977 to 1987, she was the movement consultant and guest artist of the Philippine Educational Theater Association. In 1978, she organized the Integrated Performing Arts Guild at the MSU-Iligan Institute of Technology in Lanao del Norte.

Fernando Amilbangsa’s return to Manila did not extinguish her enthusiasm for the work that she began. In 1992, she staged the pangalay and lunsaydances for the Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center. Then in 1999, she cofounded the AlunAlun Dance Circle, which aims to promote pangalay through performances, comprehensive dance training, and research.She has been the dance troupe’s artistic director since then. She is a member of the Tawi-Tawi Cultural and Historical Society, Marikina Valley Heritage Foundation, Philippine Association of Museums, Cultural Planners Association of the Philippines, Philippine Council for Culture and the Arts, Kasibulan (Women Artists’ Group of the Philippines), and the Asian Dance Association.

Her dedication to preserve the dances and allied arts of the Sulu Archipelago has been richly rewarded. A leader in cultural research and development, she has been cited by numerous local and international institutions, including the Asian Dance Alliance for the International Dance Festival at the 24th Seoul Olympics, 1988, and the UNESCO, 1989. Her pangalay choreography won the silver award in the folk dance category at the International Dance Competition in Seoul in 1994. Distinctions in 1994 were the FEU Green and Gold Artist Award for dance, the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan for Dance Research on the 423rd Foundation Anniversary of the City of Manila, and the Ginintuang Parangal sa Bayani ng Marikina. In Jun 1996, the Philippine booth that she designed and created at the Malay World Traditional Costume Exhibition during the 12th Independence Celebration of Brunei Darussalam was adjudged the best booth in the exhibition. Succeeding awards include the Philippine Folk Dance Society’s Parangal Sayaw Bulawan for dance research in 1999, the Ateneo de Manila University’s Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi in 2005, and FEU’s Most Outstanding Alumna in 2007. During the 38th Anniversary of the Founding of Tawi-Tawi Province in 2011, she was given the honor of being the Most Outstanding Artist of Tawi-Tawi Province.

In her senior years, Fernando-Amibangsa relentlessly pursued her crusade for the preservation of tangible and intangible cultural heritage. In early 2015, Fernando Amilbangsa opened the Handog Center in Marikina City. Acquired in 2013, she restored the postwar Art Deco structure to serve as an arts center for local communities. Her unwavering pursuit of her life mission was acknowledged in 2015. She was recognized as one of the Most Outstanding Citizens of Marikina City and was given the Lifetime Achievement Award as an Adopted Daughter of Tawi-Tawi Province. She received international accolade with the 2015 Ramon Magsaysay Award, considered Asia’s Nobel Prize, for her single-minded efforts to preserve and promote the Sulu Archipelago’s indigenous dance. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, updated by Sarah Lumba and Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
APPIANI aka Maestro Appiani. Choreographer, teacher. An Italian, Appiani taught European dances in Manila from the mid-1800s. He formed the Compañia Infantil de Baile, which performed in the TeatrodeBinondo, providing intermission numbers for the Compañia de Teatro del Valon of Manuel Lopez de Ariza in the Teatro de Tondo, and in the 1850s, in the Teatrito de Sibacon.

At first he taught ballroom dancing routines, among them quadrilles, like the gavotte and rigodon or rigaudon, the redova and the schottische, and character dances like the Polish cracovienne or krakowiak. He established a dance school where he taught, for free, young pupils who later joined his company. It was said that he knew fully the techniques and theories of dance and theater. Among the numbers or ballets he choreographed were El Cornetin y la Grizeta, El Paso Stirio, El Sargento Marco Bamba, and his most successful finale, La Mariposa Encantada, for which he received a long standing ovation. It was said that his productions could run from 20 to 30 performances, and these were with plots developed into acts and provided scenic designs by the reputable Jose Honorato Lozano. Unfortunately, Teatro Sibacon collapsed in 1853, a few hours after a performance. Because of ill health and “due to some insidious grief encountered in the country,” Appiani returned to Spain. Some years after, he was reported to be running a dance company in Granada, headed by the celebrated Pitteri, “Queen of the Wind.” Atayde (1982) acknowledged Appiani’s great and as yet unprecedented contribution of sowing “the seed of choreographic art,” after which “his students became the comic, lyric, and choreographic artists of Philippine theater.” Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Prosperidad Arandez, right, with Basilio Esteban Villaruz and Adina Rigor-Ferrer, 1999

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
ARANDEZ, PROSPERIDAD M. ( Prosperidad Mijares Arandez ) b. Kalibo, Aklan 1 Jan 1924. d. in Valenzuela City. Dancer, teacher. Born to Cornelio Arandez and Francisca Mijares, both of Capiz, she showed interest in dancing while still in elementary school. She learned to dance the pukol, tinikling (Capiz version), cariñosa, and escotis from the old folks of Capiz through her Grade I teacher. She finished her elementary teacher’s course at the Philippine Normal College (now University) in 1947. She obtained a certificate in Physical Education from the National College of Physical Education (NCPE) in 1955, a bachelor of science in education from the Centro Escolar University in 1956, and a Master of Arts in Education from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1978 on a UP-Bureau of Public Schools scholarship.

Arandez rose from being an elementary school teacher to become supervisor and chief of the Elementary Physical Education Services of the Division of City Schools of Manila. Through her leadership of the division’s Teachers Dance Group, she helped promote appreciation for Philippine dances in Metro Manila, Bulacan, Laguna, Rizal, and Baguio City. She worked on a series of books on physical education, health, and music for secondary schools. She retired in 1989 after a stint of teaching at the NCPE, PNU, and the University of the East.

Arandez was very active in the PhilippineFolkDanceSociety, which she served as secretary, vice-president, and president. Continually involved in the group’s national workshops, she helped document dances and conducted lectures and seminars. She was the first chairperson of the National Committee on Dance of the Presidential (now National) Commission for Culture and the Arts. As past president of the International Association of Physical Education and Sports for Girls and Women (IAPESGAW), she represented the Philippines in the Council of Representatives of the said organization. She was also an active board member of the Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, and the World Dance Alliance-Philippines.

Arandez received numerous awards and grants, among them the Teacher of the Year Award from the Manila Division of City Schools, and enjoyed observation grants to Japan, Germany, and the United States. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
Araneta Coliseum Dance Group ( ACDG )Founded in 1959, the group made its debut on 4 May 1960. It was a dream of businessman J. Amado Araneta who envisioned the group to serve as an exchange program for professional folk dancers. After a month of auditions, it was organized by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo with 50 members. Most of its principal dancers were from established dance companies, such as the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, University of the Philippines Filipiniana Dance Troupe, Manila Ballet Company (later Hariraya Ballet Company), Pamana Ballet (of Anita Kane), Studio Dance Group (of Ricardo and Roberta Cassell), Opera House Dancers, and the Far Eastern University and University of the East dance groups. Many of these dancers joined the company, wishing to explore other possibilities for movement expression after ballet was banned by the Roman Catholic hierarchy in 1955. The ACDG was acknowledged as the first professional and legitimate dance theater group. (Previously, professional dancers were with the bodabil of the Opera House and Clover Theater.)

In its inaugural show, highly applauded were TheMuslim,a suite of Mindanao dances like “Kuntao Silat,” “Pangalay,” “Tiruray,” and “Kapiil sa Munsala,” and the finale, the “Planting Rice Suite.” In the second production with the Zugspitz Artisten, a company of 20 German acrobats, the group danced a Bavarian folk dance together with a suite of Spanish-influenced dances, staged arena style. This format was continued in Pageant of World Beauties with “Binasuan,” “Bali-Hai,” and “Show Business.” The group later veered toward dances in Western theme and style. When Generoso-Iñigo moved to Davao, the Coliseum staged dances with other director-choreographers (notably, Alcuin Pastrana aka Al Quinn) on a contractual basis. After a while, dancers were just hired on call until 1966. Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Pamela Asprer, portrait for  Ballet Manila

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Pamela Asprer as Odile in Swan Lake, 1998

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Pamela Asprer as Kitri in Don Quixote, 1999

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
ASPRER, PAMELA ( Pamela Briones Asprer-Espejo ) b. 9 Aug 1975. Dancer, teacher. The daughter of Felix Asprer and Milagros Briones, she is married to dancer Jeffrey Espejo. She holds a degree in BS Education from University of the East (UE).

Asprer started dancing at the age of nine with Vella C. Damian and passed the Royal Academy of Dance senior grade children’s exam with honors. At the age of 19, she was accepted as a Company Member of the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). It was with Ballet Manila (BM), however, that Asprer essayed all her lead roles. She was among the 12 pioneering dancers of the company in 1995.

She portrayed the principal roles in BM’s Les Sylphides, 2000; Don Quixote, 1997 and 1999; The Nutcracker,1999 and 2001; Le Corsaire (The Pirate), 1998, 2000, and 2002; Swan Lake (Odile), 1998; and Paquita Divertissement, 2000. She was also the lead in Sergei Vikulov’s La Fille Mal Gardee, 2000 and 2001, and Jean Paul Comelin’s Firebird, 2001.

In non full-length Russian pieces, she was notable as Vahhanka in Vikulov’s Walpurgis Nacht (Walpurgis Night), 1998, and as the Doll in Nicoli Legat’s The Fairy Doll, 1996. She also performed the Diane et Acteon pas de deux, 1997, for the company. With BM, she established an international presence by dancing key roles with the Buryat State Ballet and Krasnoyarsk State Ballet all over Russia. She retired from the performance scene in 2003.

What she has learned from mentors Vella Damian, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, and Osias Barroso in the Philippines, and from the Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet under Sergei Bykov, Tatiana Udalenkova, Sergei Vikulov, Viktor Saveliev, and Ira Stinkova, she has passed on to the next generation. For seven years, from 1996 to 2003, she taught at the BM School. In 2004, she taught at the Ballet School in Brunei, and in 2010 to 2012, at the CCP Dance School. She has been teaching at the Academy One Music and Dance since 2003, and was their head coach for the Asian Grand Prix in 2012.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
BALCENA, JOSE ( Jose Borro Balcena )b. Loctugan, Capiz 19 Dec 1926. Dancer, teacher. He was born to Pedro Balcena and Ana Borro. He is married to Consolacion Alovera with whom he has two daughters. He finished his elementary and high school in Roxas City, then went to the Far Eastern University and the National College of Physical Education. In 1967, he received a University of the Philippines Bureau of Public Schools scholarship. Rising through the ranks in public education, he became the physical education and school sports supervisor in the Division of Roxas City, Department of Education, Culture, and Sports (DECS) Region VI. He is now retired from government service.

An industrious researcher on dances from his province, Balcena discovered 19 dances in Roxas City and Capiz alone. The timawa,one of the most popular, is included in the sixth volume of FranciscaReyes-Aquino’s Philippine FolkDances. The others in the same series are pukol (Vol. III); escotis and tinolabong (Vol. V); and binhi, dagit-dagit,and saad (Vol. VI). He has also contributed dances to the annual folk dance workshops of the Philippine Folk Dance Society, the Folk Arts Theater, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines. These are: palominta coquitaña, habanera capiceña, hoy alibangbang, and pahid, 1985; pamurong-surong and despedida, 1986; pitik mingaw, 1987; beneracion, 1990; and cachucha capiceña and karansa, 1991. In 1999, his Handuman ( Recuerdos ) Capiz Folk Dances was published. The book featuring more than twenty dances from the province includes their provenance, meaning, steps, costumes, and music.

As director and choreographer of the Kasadyahan Teachers Dance Group of Roxas City, Balcena also participated in the cultural projects of the Rotary Club of Roxas City and in the Halaran Festival of Capiz, held every Dec. He also worked with the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company as consultant on folk dances from Capiz.

For his efforts to promote Philippine dances, he has been honored with the Datu Puti Award, the DECS Region VI Award (for his researches and co-authorship of Bulawanon nga Panublion,one of the Bayan Muna series), and the Halaran Award of Capiz. Written by Prosperidad M. Arandez,updated by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ballet Arts Studio Dance Group’s production of Giselle, 1961

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Ballet Arts Studio Dance Group’s production of Giselle, 1961, with Sony Lopez-Gonzalez

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
BALLET ARTS STUDIODANCEGROUP This performing arm of the Ballet Arts Studio was run bySonyLopez-Gonzalez and JojiFelix-Velarde, later solely by Lopez-Gonzalez, in the early 1960s. It had associations until 1964 with the Manila Metropolitan Opera and Ballet Association, and with the BalletPhilippines.

In 1961, it staged Giselle,and in 1962, Swan Lake (the first full Philippine production), both with MaribelAboitiz and EddieElejar, and both at the University of the Philippines Theater. In 1962, it presented Nora Kovach and Istvan Rabovsky in two programs that included Laurencia, Giselle (Act II), and Swan Lake (Act II). Laurence Siegel conducted the Metropolitan Philharmonic Orchestra. These productions also drew dancers from other schools, including that of FeSala-Villarica in Cebu. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Ballet Federation of the Philippines (Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Ballet Federation of the Philippines (Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
BALLET FEDERATION OF THE PHILIPPINES ( BFP ) Immediately after the success of the First National Ballet Festival in Mar 1976, cochaired by VellaDamian and BasilioEstebanS.Villaruz, the heads and dancers of the participating groups formed the federation and elected their officers, with EddieElejar as president.

The annual festival continued until 1978 and grew to include regional participation. It produced full-length ballets like Giselle with ManiyaBarredo and Burton Taylor, 1977; Coppelia with Irene Sabas/Josette Salang and Benjie Toledo/LutherPerez; Cinderella (choreography by William Morgan and music by Serge Prokofiev) with TinaSantos and Gary Wahl, both in 1978; and La Fille Mal Gardee (choreography by Fernand Nault and music by PeterLudwig Hertel) with Maniya Barredo and Joseph Carman, 1979. It also produced Filipino ChoreographicConcepts in 1978, featuring original works by EricV.Cruz, TonyFabella, and Eddie Elejar.

The BFP published until 1979 the bimonthly Sayaw Silangan (Dance of the East) that started as a newsletter and was edited by Villaruz. It also launched Reynaldo Alejandro’s book Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents in 1978. With the German Cultural Center, British Council, and United States embassy, it presented visiting artists and held seminars and exhibitions in the provinces. The seminars were conducted by Jean Deroc, Tina Santos, Gary Wahl, Florrie Sinclair, Benjamin Reyes, and Josefa Arnaldo-Reyes.

The federation has formally recognized the achievements and contributions to Philippine dance of Luva Adameit, Ricardo Cassell, Anita Kane, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Remedios de Oteyza, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper, Manolo Rosado, Fe Sala-Villarica, Paul Szilard, Ruben Nieto, and Rosalia Merino-Santos.

Within its short period of existence, BFP unified attention and efforts for the promotion of ballet in the Philippines. Its membership was national in scope. It was supported by the Folk Arts Theater of the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the Philippine National Bank. It disbanded in 1980. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ballet Manila

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Ballet Manila's Alamat: Si Sibol at Si Gunaw, 2009, ALIW Theater

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Manila)

text:
BALLET MANILA(BM) Led by Lisa Macuja and Osias Barroso, Ballet Manila was established in 1995 with a core of 12 dancers and with Eric V. Cruz as adviser and artistic director. The other dancers in the core were Pamela Asprer, Kristin Dabao, Ianne Damian, Elline Damian, Aileen Gallinera, Sandralynn Huang, Eileen Lopez, Eduardo Espejo, Jeffrey Espejo, and Christopher Mohnani. The company’s mission is to promote ballet among the people and to bring mass audiences to appreciate the art form. BM’s principal ballerina, Lisa Macuja, is the moving force behind the company, especially during its formative years when she functioned as ballet teacher, associate artistic director, and business manager, among other tasks. In keeping with its avowed mission of popularizing the classical dance form, BM during its first year completed 71 performances in the Philippines, including 16 shows in Russia.

The training and education curriculum of the group is based on the method of the Vaganova Choreographic School which later became known as Russian Academy of Dance. In the next two decades since its establishment, BM grew to become a professional company with a corps of 65 artists. The regular venue of its performances is the Aliw Theater located beside the Manila Broadcasting Company and Star City in Pasay City. BM has mounted classics like Swan Lake, Don Quixote, The Nutcracker, Giselle, La Bayadere, Romeo and Juliet, Carmen, and Le Corsaire. Contemporary dance pieces were also part of BM’s repertoire, created by leading dance choreographers such as Bam Damian for Reconfigured, Agnes Locsin for Arachnida, Ernest Mandap for Reve, and Manuel Molina for Love Beyond Goodbye.

To continue its mission of bringing ballet closer to the masses, BM has produced original Filipino works such as Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, 2009. The success of Severino Reyes’s stories for children rendered in ballet led to the production of Tatlo Pang Kuwento ni Lola Basyang in 2013 with radio personality Luz Fernandez as Lola Basyang. The successful Lola Basyang shows enjoyed repeat performances in succeeding years. Another original ballet was Ed Maranan’s Alamat: Si Sibol at Si Gunaw premiered in 2009. BM coproduced a concert series titled Ballet and Ballads with Manila Broadcasting Company. The show which combined pop music with classical ballet was shown in schools and venues within and outside Metro Manila. BM also implemented an effective strategy to endear ballet to the masses with Star City’s free ballet shows for park-goers on weekends.

In 2008, BM launched a dance scholarship program called Project Ballet Futures(PBF) that offers free ballet training to deserving public school students. The training has a nutritional component to prepare potential ballerinas and danseurs for the intense mental and physical regimen of the Vaganova syllabus. To date, PBF has been training 25 dancers from the Philippine Christian Foundation in Tondo and public schools in Pasay City, Makati City, and Manila.

Since 1995, BM dancers joined international ballet competitions such as the Asia Pacific International Ballet Competitions, the Helsinki International Ballet Competition, the Beijing International Ballet Competition, and the Asian Grand Prix IBC. The participants to these competitions reached the semi-finals or finals, and some even gained medals of honor. BM was awarded Best Classical Dance Company by the Aliw Awards from 2012 to 2014. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
The cast of Ballet Philippines’s Don Quixote, 2018, with National Artist for Dance Alice Reyes

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Ballet Philippines in Valse Fantaisie, 2017

(Photo by Justin Bella Alonte, courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

text:
BALLET PHILIPPINES ( BP ) Founded in 1969 as the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company (ARMDC). In 1970, Reyes worked with Eddie Elejar and they both expanded it into the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Workshop and Company. The company was renamed the CCP Dance Company in 1974, and finally as Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1981.

Returning from the United States in 1969, Alice Reyes proposed a modern dance concert to CCP president Jaime Zobel de Ayala and artistic director Lucrecia Kasilag. It was produced on 19 and 21 Feb 1970 at the CCP Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo), with 16 members including Reyes as artistic director. After its Manila performance, the company toured the provinces, initiating its outreach program. In Jun 1971, Reyes and Elejar organized the first CCP summer dance workshop. Its success encouraged them to form a small but full-fledged dance company. With the help of Ma. Teresa Escoda-Roxas and Sixto Roxas of the Bancom Development Corporation, the CCP Dance Workshop and Company acquired a management staff and an artistic staff. Shortly thereafter, the CCP Dance School was also established.

Also in 1974, BP became the CCP’s first resident dance company, receiving an annual partial subsidy and the free use of CCP facilities. The CCP Dance Foundation, now the BP Foundation, was set up to provide a more solid financial and organizational base, with Reyes as its first president in 1977, succeeded by Nestor Jardin in 1989 and Maan Hontiveros in 1993. The foundation’s chairpersons were Jaime Zobel de Ayala, Bea Zobel, Escoda-Roxas, Ching Montinola, Ernest Escaler, and Antonio Cojuangco Jr. Its programs included the CCP Dance School, the summer dance workshop, outreach program, BP II, the scholarship program, the Society for BP, the Friends of BP International, and the School Parents Association.

In 1983, the company formed BP II, headed by resident choreographer Agnes Locsin. Composed of young and talented scholars and company apprentices, the junior group’s mandate included training young talents for the main company, developing new works, and performing the company’s repertoire pieces not presented in the season through touring programs, lecture-demonstrations, and workshops. To date, the group has had numerous provincial workshops and special performances.

BP’s summer dance workshops continue to invite dance teachers and choreographers from all over the world. The roster includes: Norman Walker, Pauline Koner, Alfred Rodrigues, Mikhail Kukharev, William Morgan, Armin Wild, Luminita Dumitrescu, and Vakhtang Chabukiani. Aside from developing the technical and artistic proficiency of the dancers, they also expanded the company repertoire with works performed by major companies. Among these are Koner’s Concertina, Doris Humphrey’s The Shakers, Walker’s Songs of a Wayfarer, Balanchine’s Pas de Dix, and the ballet classics such as Swan Lake, The Nutcracker, The Sleeping Beauty, Don Quixote, La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), Paquita, Raymonda Variations, Giselle, Coppelia, The Firebird, Le Carnaval, Les Sylphides, Romeo and Juliet, and Napoli Act III.

For six years, ballet master William Morgan helped in the technical progress of the dancers and the acquisition of a large classical repertory. BP’s rootedness in the classical dance discipline, while making statements in modern dance, developed artists who became principal dancers abroad. Among them are Manuel Molina who was with Ballet Nuevo Mundo in Venezuela, Rey Dizon with Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, and Elizabeth Roxas with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Those who chose to stay, like Ester Rimpos, Nonoy Froilan, Effie Nañas, Edna Vida, and Cecile Sicangco were likewise accorded the same distinction. Leading choreographers such as Elejar, Basilio, Locsin, Tony Fabella, Denisa Reyes, Gener Caringal, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, Brando Miranda, and Hazel Sabas enjoyed support to develop a unique Filipino dance expression.

The company also welcomed as guests noted Filipino dancers abroad: Maniya Barredo, Tina Santos, Anna Villadolid, Andre Reyes, Enrico Labayen, gracing the stage with such notables as Lisa Macuja and Toni Lopez Gonzalez. The reputation of the company is also evident in the number of foreign stars it has attracted, most notably Dame Margot Fonteyn, Rudolf Nureyev, Alicia Alonso, Natalia Makarova, Fernando Bujones, Yoko Morishita, and Julio Bocca.

The biggest contribution of the company to Philippine dance is its collaboration with various Filipino artists. Leading composers were commissioned to create musical spectacles based on Filipino folklore and legends. The company also presented a series of tributes to dance pioneers and choreographers such as Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, Remedios de Oteyza, Julie Borromeo, Felicitas Layag-Radaic, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Alice Reyes, and Froilan. All these set the momentum for future collaborative works of choreographers with composers, among them Kasilag, Ryan Cayabyab, Nonong Pedero, Joey Ayala, Alfredo Buenaventura, Antonino Buenaventura, Rodolfo Cornejo, Jerry Dadap, Bayani Mendoza de Leon, Ruben Federizon, Francisco Feliciano, Jose Maceda, Manuel Maramba, Fabian Obispo, Eliseo Pajaro, Hilarion Rubio, Lucio San Pedro, Ramon Santos, Restie Umali, and Miguel “Mike” Velarde; with scenic, costume, and lighting designers, among them Salvador Bernal, Ray Albano, Arturo Cruz, Santiago de Manila, Christian Espiritu, Jaime Lim, Toto Sicangco, Napoleon Abueva, Roberto Chabet, Jose Joya, Leandro Locsin, Johnny Manahan, Jaime de Guzman, Luis Araneta, Jaime Zobel de Ayala, Teodoro Hilado, Monino Duque, Katsch Catoy, Alex de Guzman; and with librettists, among them Rolando Tinio, Bienvenido Lumbera, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, Joven Velasco, and Nicanor G. Tiongson.

The company also provided training for its administrative and artistic staff. Starting out as performing artists, Denisa Reyes, Noordin Jumalon, Cecile Manikan, Jardin, Sicangco, and Vida rose to leadership while still pursuing the vision of its founders. Artistic director emeritus Alice Reyes directed the company from 1969 to 1991, with Elejar as codirector from 1969 to 1976, and Vida as associate artistic director in 1983. From 1991 to 1994, Denisa Reyes was the artistic director, with Sicangco as associate director; Reyes became artistic director again from 2000 to 2004. Sicangco took over from 1996 to 1999, followed by Jumalon from 1999 to 2000, Alden Lugnasin in 2004, Augustus Damian III from 2004 to 2008, Alan Hineline and Max Luna III from 2008 to 2009, and Paul Alexander Morales from 2009 to the present. Through time, Jardin served as company manager, administrator, and president. Salvador Bernal was the company’s resident production designer since 1973, and served as its artistic consultant as well. Rudy Vidad, who had been with the company since its inception, served in numerous capacities as photographer, archivist, researcher, and artistic consultant.

In 1972, the company went on its first international tour to London and Spain, reaping accolades for its repertory that combined American modern dance and Philippine traditions. In 1974, BP toured Australia and Southeast Asia, making the same strong impression with what was becoming the company’s hallmark—the definition of Filipino culture through dance with the use of Western forms and technique. Succeeding tours were to Germany, 1975; Thailand, Hong Kong, Malaysia, the United States Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, 1977, and the American Dance Festival, 1984; the USSR, France, and Italy, 1978; Taiwan and Hong Kong, 1979; the USSR, Taiwan, Greece, Germany, 1980; Hong Kong, Singapore, and Malaysia, 1981; Taiwan, 1982; Venezuela and Thailand, 1983; China, Germany, 1985; USSR, Indonesia, Czechoslovakia, and Singapore, 1988; Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan, 1989; Hong Kong, 1990; Spain, Germany, and India, 1992; Japan, 1993; Australia, 1995; Singapore, Indonesia, and China, 1997; Germany, Portugal, United Kingdom, Switzerland, Japan, Canada, and United States, 1998. The group also participated in several international dance festivals, such as the “Rencontre Internationale de la Danse” in La Baule, France, in 1990 and 1992; the 1989 International Festival of Dance Academies in Hong Kong; the 1st Asian Arts Mart, Singapore, 2001; Festival of ASEAN Culture, Angkor Wat, Siem Riep, Cambodia, 2002; the 6th Asian Arts Festival, China and Nanning Folksong Arts Festival, China, 2004; World Expo, Aichi, Japan, 2005; and the World Expo, Shanghai, China, 2010. These tours provided the opportunity for foreign audiences to evaluate Asian dancing at par with its Western counterparts, but speaking a language of dance that was uniquely Filipino.

Among BP’s awards are: Best Dance Group, 2005; Outstanding Dance Production, Gawad Buhay, 2008 for La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution); Gawad Tanglaw Lifetime Achievement Award, 2008; Outstanding Dance Production, Gawad Buhay, 2009 for Masterworks; Outstanding Ensemble Performance in a Dance Production, Gawad Buhay, 2009 for Masterworks; Outstanding Ensemble Performance in a Dance Production, 2010, for Peter Pan; Best Dance Group (Contemporary Category) NCCA National Dance Competition, 2011; Outstanding Modern Dance Production and Outstanding Ensemble Performance for Dance, Gawad Buhay, 2012, for Rama, Hari (Rama, King). Written by Edna Vida, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido
