description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
BALT, SAMO b. Balindong, Lanao del Sur 29 Dec 1959. Researcher, choreographer, director. Her parents, Hadji Mohammed Bampang Esmael and Hadji Sitti Rachman Decampong Sarip, are both members of Maranao royalty. Her father, who has occupied positions of public authority, is an orator, abayoksinger, and a musician. Balt finished high school at the Palindong Islamic Institute, 1972, and obtained a bachelor’s degree in elementary education at the Mindanao State University (MSU) in Marawi, 1978.

Her work as a researcher at MSU resulted in the Buklod ng mga Kabataang Kawani and the Kalilang Festival, participated in by Mindanao tribes, both in 1979. In 1986, she designed the Cultural Exchange Exposure Journeys or CEEJOURN, a project to reorient tourism so that it promotes the mutual benefit of visitors and visited, induces positive post-travel responses, and upholds respect for different religious cultures as well as the social and physical environment. In 1987, Balt initiated an Alternative Crafts project to popularize indigenous crafts and show these as products of a unique sociopolitical and economic-cultural context. Also in 1987, she produced Sindao (Shadow), whose cast was composed entirely of elderly people, as old as 80, from five municipalities. The following year, she organized the Maranao cultural troupe, SiningPananadem, which has toured Mindanao and the rest of the Philippines. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Veda Bañez-Alonso

(Photo from facebook.com/veda.banez)

text:
BAÑEZ-ALONSO, VEDA ( Veda Borbon Bañez-Alonso ) b. Abra 23 May 1952. Dancer, choreographer, director. The moving spirit in the growth of the Metropolitan Dance Theater Company (MDT), she is the daughter of Antonio Bañez and Vesta Borbon. She is married to actor Ramon Gil “Chinggoy” Alonso with whom she has three sons who are all performers: Ralion, Altair, and Mako. Ralion, a professional dancer, actor, singer, and TV host had a seven-year stint with Hong Kong Disneyland as vocalist for the Golden Mickey Show that featured excerpts from Disney movies. Bañez-Alonso studied high school at the St. Theresa’s College in Quezon City, and then took broadcast communication at the University of the Philippines College of Mass Communication.

She started dancing at an early age and when she turned eight, she was tutored by Benny Villanueva Reyes. She then acquired more professional training under Sony Lopez-Gonzalez, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, and Remedios “Totoy” de Oteyza. In the early 1970s, she took modern dance under Alice Reyes and Tony Fabella at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. She also studied a variety of other dance forms such as Hawaiian-Tahitian, Asian, Philippine folk, Spanish, and tap. Since 1965, she has been teaching ballet, Hawaiian-Tahitian, Spanish dance, folk dance and interpretative folk dance, jazz, and modern ballet since 1965. Her training with the Hariraya Dance Company from 1965 to 1969 developed her on more classical lines. She was a member of the UP Filipiniana Dance Company, 1970-72, and member and soloist of the UP Concert Chorus for which she choreographed some productions from 1972 to 1975. She was a representative to the ASEAN Dance Conference in 1986. She is the artistic director and choreographer of the Theresian Alumnae Chorale, St. Theresa’s College QC Alumnae Association.

In 1980, Bañez-Alonso was appointed dance director of the MDT Company by Conchita Sunico, executive director of the Metropolitan Theater. The MDT grew from a group merely accompanying major musical productions from 1979 to 1985, to a group performing on its own. The change began in 1986, when it developed a varied dance repertoire including Broadway, classical ballet, jazz, modern, and folk dances. In 1990, Bañez-Alonzo was appointed MET production and artistic director.

Bañez-Alonso choreographed some of the major productions of the Metropolitan Theater: Juan Tamad vs. Paltos V, Batibot (Small But Strong), Kapinangan, The Great White Way I & II, The Sound of Music, My Fair Lady, and The Flower Drum Song. She choreographed Mutya ng Pilipinas USA, 1987 and 1988, held in San Francisco. In 2004, she directed One by the Theresian Alumnae Chorale of the St. Theresa’s College QC Alumnae Association as their first anniversary concert. She also conceptualized and directed Hearts of Fire: 100 Years ofFire and Grace, a musical drama about the life of the foundress of the Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary or Immaculati Cordis Mariae. Written by Malou L. Maniquis, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Raoul Banzon as Jose in Basilio’s La Lampara, 1991

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
BANZON, RAOUL ( Raoul Hernaez Banzon )b. Manila 17 Jul 1959. Dancer. He is the son of Philippine Air Force colonel Leonardo Garcia Banzon and Merced Hernaez; two of his brothers, Rene and Gregory, were professional dancers, trained by their brother-in-law, Eli Jacinto. He has a son with dancer and teacher Melanie Motus. Banzon is also a registered architect, with a degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas.

Banzon began his dance training at the age of 21 at Jacinto’s Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement (TEAM) Dance Studio, where he performed notable roles in Jacinto’s choreographies, such as the lead protagonist in The Emergence, 1980, opposite Eloisa Enerio, and Bacchanale, 1980. He freelanced for Hariraya Dance Company, Ben-Lor Ballet Company, and Dance Theatre Philippines until 1987, when he joined the newly formed Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). As one of PBT’s pioneer dancers, he trained further with Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Eddie Elejar, Noordin Jumalon, Vella Damian, and Gener Caringal. In PBT, he also learned much from the mentoring of international guest ballet masters Rinat Gizatulin and Robert Barnett.

PBT productions usually featured him as the lead character in the classical ballets because of his strong characterization and virtuosic dancing. He was Franz in Coppelia, 1989 and 1992; Don Jose in Eric Cruz’s Carmen, 1989 and 1991; and Rizal in Basilio’s restaging of La Lampara (The Lamp), 1991. Banzon is mostly remembered for his inspired portrayal of the reckless Mercutio in Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, 1990 and 1994, and as the first Filipino to perform the Lavrovksypistolée(toy gun) incorporated in Pazik’s choreography. As character dancer, Banzon portrayed Espada to Wes Chapman’s Basilio in Don Quixote,1993; and Prince Yamadori in all stagings of Tom Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, from 1990 to 2005.

He also portrayed the idealistic and foolish James in La Sylphide opposite Anna Villadolid; and as Solor in “The Kingdom of the Shades”from La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer) opposite Lisa Macuja, both in 1991. He has also portrayed the roles of Pinkerton in Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, and the Waltz Boy in George Balanchine’s Serenade. Banzon played the lead role in the premiere of Gener Caringal’s Vinta in 1989, and in the restaging and the tour of this work from 1990 to his retirement in 1996. Written by Joelle Florence P. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Maniya Barredo as Odette in Swan Lake, 1970s

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Maniya Barredo with Nicolas Pacaña in The Nutcracker, 1988

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
BARREDO, MANIYA ( Josephine Carmen Imutan Barredo ) aka Honey Barredo. b. Manila 19 Nov 1951. Dancer, trainor. Born to Grizelda Imutan of lloilo and Eugenio Barredo of Manila, Barredo belongs to a family of artists. Her sisters Vicky and Rhea sing and dance, and her brother Gabriel is a visual artist; her uncle Manuel Barredo is a tenor, and her cousins Lea and Gerard Salonga are international musical artists. Her aunts include actor-singer Carmen Barredo and dancer-choreographers Julie and Rose Borromeo. She graduated from St. Paul College high school in Manila and trained with the Hariraya Dance (later Ballet) Company. In 1970, she attended Robert Joffrey’s American Ballet Center in New York, joining Joffrey Ballet in 1972. For a time, she also danced at the Radio City Music Hall. In 1974, she joined Les Grands Ballets Canadiens in Montreal, becoming a full-fledged ballerina. In 1976, she guested at the International Dance Festival in Cuba organized by Alicia Alonso. In 1977, she joined the Atlanta Ballet where she became prima ballerina and a senior coach and teacher. In 1979, she joined Margot Fonteyn’s Stars of the World Ballet tour. She retired from Atlanta ballet after 20 years. She is the director of the Metropolitan Ballet Theater, Georgia, USA; artistic consultant, Ballethnic in Atlanta; and cultural attache for the Philippines. She was the artistic director of ASB Performing Ensemble.

Barredo has danced most of the ballet classics, including Swan Lake, The Nutcracker, Coppelia, La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), and Paquita, and contemporary classics like Cinderella. While in Manila, Barredo created the roles of the Sarimanok in The Legend of Sarimanok by Reynaldo Alejandro and Roberto Caballero in 1965, and the Girl in Cesar Mendoza’s Difficult Years in 1968. She created roles in the ballets of Brian McDonald, Fernand Nault, John Butler, Bruce Wells, Robert Barnett, Mannie Rowe, Thor Sutowski, and Thomas Pazik. Choreographer Mikhail Lavrovsky chose her for the TV film Ali Baba in the USSR. Barredo’s periodic homecomings in the 1970s and 1980s were always major events. In 1977, she danced the title role in Giselle, and went on a provincial tour for the Ballet Federation of the Philippines. In 1979, she premiered Nault’s La Fille Mal Gardee in Manila. In 1980, she performed The Sleeping Beauty. Two years after, she did her first full-length Swan Lake with Ballet Philippines, which was repeated in 1989. In 1990, she premiered in Manila Thomas Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet.

Barredo’s awards include the JDR III Fund Grant; Aliw Award, 1977; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award, 1978; Atlanta Pacesetter, 1979-80; Ten Outstanding Young Men or TOYM award, 1987; the Bruna P. Seril Advancement of Philippine Culture Award, New York, 1988; and Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, 1992. She is listed in the Who’s Who in America, 1980 to the present; Who’s Who in the Worldof Women, 1983; and Who’s Who in Music, USA, 1984. She received the Presidential Medal of Merit from former Pres Fidel V. Ramos and the 2011 Lifetime Achievement Award from Aliw Awards. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Osias Barroso with Lisa Macuja in Swan Lake, 2003

(Photo courtesy of the artist)
Osias Barroso (Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
BARROSO, OSIAS JR ( Osias Gepilano Barroso Jr ) b. Manila 23 Feb 1965. Dancer, choreographer, director. His parents, Anita Gepilano and Osias Barroso, were amateur musicians. He graduated with a degree in Mass Communications from the University of Santo Tomas (UST). He trained in ballet with Vella Damian and soon joined the Dance Concert Company (DCC) under the artistic direction of Eric Cruz. He became company soloist, and guested with Quezon City Ballet and Dance Theater Philippines (DTP).

With DCC he assumed many principal roles in the ballets of Cruz, Damian, Basilio, and Teresa Cutaran. With DTP, he danced the role of Tasmi, the hero, in the 1979 revival of Julie Borromeo and Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s Mir-i-nisa. In 1987, he joined the newly formed Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) where he became a soloist, dancing many principal parts. With PBT he danced Carmelo, the young gipsy lover of Candelas in El Amor Brujo; the Bluebird in The Sleeping Beauty; the Peasant pas de deux in Giselle; the Drummer Boy in Graduation Ball; Frantz in Coppelia; the Poet in Les Sylphides; Don Jose in Carmen; Jasper in Pineapple Poll; Sharpless in Madame Butterfly; the waltz in Serenade; and the grandspas de deux in The Nutcracker, Don Quixote, and Paquita.

In 1987, he attended the Balanchine and Fokine seminar in Varna, Bulgaria. In 1990, he guested in Tokyo, and cities in Cuba in the course of the 12th International Ballet Festival organized by Alicia Alonso. In 1992, he joined the First Diaghilev Ballet Competition in Moscow. In these places, he partnered Lisa Macuja in the grands pas de deux and Basilio’s Oriental Fantasy. He is the only Filipino danseur so far who has performed Don Quixote and Giselle in Russia, opposite Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, his partner for 16 years.

He first learned the Vaganova ballet method from Macuja-Elizalde who was trained in Russia. In 1996-2003, he attended the Vaganova Method Master Class program conducted by Tatiana A. Udalenkova of the Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet. He has also worked with Russian ballet masters Sergey Vikulov, Viktor Saveliev, and Evgeny Scherbakov.

As a choreographer, Barroso’s works include In Quest, 1995, Ballet Manila’s (BM) debut performance ;Gabriela ng Vigan (Gabriel of Vigan), 1998, in celebration of the Philippine Revolution centennial; Pinocchio, 2002; Sonata,2007, based on Sonata in E minor for the 150th year celebration of composerEdward Elgar; Ang Prinsipe ng Mga Ibon (Prince of the Birds), 2008, as part of the Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Three Stories of Grandma Basyang) trilogy and Alamat: Si Sibol at si Gunaw (Legend: Sibol and Gunaw), with Gerardo Francisco, based on a children’s story by Palanca Hall of Fame writer, Ed Maranan. In Aug 2013, BM premiered three new tales of Lola Basyang, Tatlo Pang Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Three More Stories of Grandma Basyang). Barroso choreographed with Michael Divinagracia one of the three tales, Anting-anting (Amulet). He has also choreographed and directed popular ballet productions for the Star City theme park such as Princess of the Moon, Munting Anghel (Little Angel), Can Can, and Belen (Bethlehem).

As principal dancer for BM, he performed the lead roles in local and international productions of major full-length ballets such as LaFille Mal Gardee, Petrushka, Le Corsaire (The Pirate), Swan Lake, LaBayadere (The Temple Dancer), Carmen, Romeo andJuliet, and Firebird. In 2004, Barroso and Macuja celebrated their 16 years of dance partnership with a farewell performance of their signature piece, Don Quixote. In 2005, Carmen was his last performance before his retirement. As of this writing, he is the coartistic director and ballet master of BM.He was the first Filipino danseur to reach the semifinal round of the First International Ballet and Modern Dance Competition in 1993 in Nagoya, Japan. In 2006, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan for dance from the City of Manila and the AB Gantimpala Award for Arts (Dance) from UST, his alma mater, in 2010.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

article_title: Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company performing the tinikling

in Pulso Filipinas Filipino Dance Gala 2018, CCP Main Theater

(Photo by Laurence Catalan)

Bayanihan postcard, 1970s
(Photo courtesy of Bobby Roces)

Bayanihan at Tokyo Expo 1970
(Photo courtesy of Bobby Roces)

Bayanihan dancers performing at the Ceremonial Hall of the  Malacañan Palace, with President Carlos P. Garcia 

and President Dwight D. Eisenhower, among others, in the audience, 15 June 1960

(Photo from LIFE Magazine)

Bayanihan at Tokyo Expo 1970

(Photo courtesy of Bobby Roces)

Bayanihan postcard, 1970s
(Photo courtesy of Bobby Roces)

text:
BAYANIHAN PHILIPPINE NATIONAL FOLK DANCE COMPANY Founded in 1957, the company started from the pioneering efforts at the Philippine Women’s University’s (PWU) Filipiniana folk music and dance committee of the 1930s to collect and preserve Philippine folk dances, music, and costumes. In 1954, PWU sent a group to the Asian Folk Dance Festival in Dacca, East Pakistan. It was headed by Dean Lucrecia Kasilag and included Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, Violeta Bediones, Lourdes Villaflor, Celia Martinez, Ester Cornejo, Ricardo Reyes, and Castro Palacio. This experience spurred further field research.

“Take it from the people” became the PWU researchers’ guiding principle as they braved forbidding terrain, bad weather, and austere living conditions in their search for authentic dances, music, and costumes. Various parts of the country were scoured for years by Kasilag, Urtula, and Isabel Santos. Their work became the basis for Bayanihan’s choreography which adapted ethnic and folk dances to the conventions and demands of theater. It provided materials for regular recitals by PWU’s Physical Education Club, organized by Leticia de Guzman and Urtula, and led by Victoria de Guzman and Henrietta Hofer. The club gave its first major performance at a joint celebration of civic organizations in Oct 1956, with the theme “Magbayanihan Tayo” (Let’s Help Each Other) suggested by Helena Benitez. In Feb 1957, the club presented Bayanihan: Philippine Music and Dance Festival before delegates to the World Confederation of Organizations of the Teaching Professions’ meeting in Manila. The Bayanihan Folk Arts Center was formally organized soon after, and in Sep 1957, it started giving monthly recitals for tourists and foreign missions.

Bayanihan’s first major theater production, Glimpses of Philippine Culture, was at the Brussels Universal Exposition in 1958. It was an astounding success. Immediately after, it was invited to appear on Ed Sullivan’s TV show in the United States, followed by tours of America and Europe. It was the first Philippine dance company to perform on Broadway, New York City, and in international stages. In 1959, its performance at the Winter Garden Theater in New York City was met by a standing ovation. The same year it won the critics’ award for folk ensemble at the Fete des Nations in Paris. For more than 50 years, Bayanihan has unfolded before the Filipinos and the world, the beauty of Philippine culture. It has not only preserved but also ensured the creative growth of ethnic culture. Artists who have worked with Bayanihan as dancers are Alice Reyes, Ramon Obusan, Eddie Elejar, Antonio Fabella, Robert Tongko, Rose Borromeo, Hannah Gomez Trinidad, Lito Calzado, and Rosky Balajadia. Other artists who designed for Bayanihan are Jose Lardizabal, Leandro Locsin, Rodrigo Perez III, Teddy Hilado, Monino Duque, and Jun Gomez. Its second-generation directors include Suzie Benitez, executive director; Ferdinand Jose, dance director and choreographer; and Melito Vale Cruz, music director.

In 1965, Bayanihan received the Ramon Magsaysay Award. In 1998, Republic Act No. 8626 designated the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company the national folk dance company of the country. The following year, May 27 of every year was declared Bayanihan Day. The company started joining world dance competitions in 2002. In 2005, it participated in the 60th Sagra del Mandorlo in Fiore and the 50th International Festival del Folklore in Agrigento, Sicily, where it won the Golden Anniversary Gold Temple Award. Two years after, it won the grand prize and best in choreography award in the same festival with their dance narrative, The Voyage for Love and Peace. In 2013, it won the Golden Bridge Award (thegrand prize) at the 14th World Folklore Festival, Turkey, for the second time.Written by Lucrecia R. Urtula, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe)

Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte 
(Photo courtesy of Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe)

Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte and Ricardo Reyes performing  the kandingan, a Muslim wedding dance

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe)

Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte with colleagues at the 1st Philippine Floating Expo to South East Asia, 1959

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe)

Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte with husband Ramon Belmonte Sr receiving an award

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe)

text:
BELMONTE, PAZ CIELO ANGELES b. Daet, Camarines Norte 24 Jan 1916. d. Oct 2013. Dancer, teacher, choreographer, director. She married Ramon Dinglasan Belmonte, pianist of the University of the Philippines (UP) Folk Song and Dance Troupe. She obtained her bachelor of science in education from UP in 1936, a master’s degree in physical education (PE) from the Illinois State Normal University in 1953 as a Fulbright scholar of the US Educational Foundation, and a doctorate in Philosophy from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1975.

While studying at UP, she was a principal dancer of the UP troupe headed by Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino), from 1933 to 1939. At the outbreak of the war, she started teaching at the Philippine Normal School (later College, now University) where she later headed the PE department. During World War II, she organized dance numbers for the vaudeville productions of Jose Climaco in State Theater and Fernando Poe Sr in Avenue Theater. In 1946, she organized the mixed dancing class in the college, which became the Philippine Normal College (PNC) Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe. The adopted name came with the performance for the first Philippine Floating Exposition to the Southeast Asian countries in 1958.

When the group became independent of PNU, it modified its name to Baranggay Folk Dance Company. As chairperson, Belmonte promoted the course in Physical Education in all levels, to the BSE, major in PE in 1970, to the master’s degree in PE, major in dance and sports in 1976. She also became “Mommy Bel” to PE majors in the National College of Physical Education (for a time the Marcos Sports Academy, and later, the Philippine Institute of Physical Education and Sports), UST, and the Baguio Vacation Normal School. She was leader and president of various associations such as the Philippine Association of Physical Education and Sports, Leisure Education and Recreation of the Philippines, and the Philippine Folk Dance Society. She was director-general of the 22nd world congress of the International Congress of Health, Physical Education, and Recreation, held in Manila in 1981.

Through the Baranggay troupe, she continued the work of Reyes-Aquino in promoting Philippine folk dances. With the support of her husband and family, she led the group in winning international fame and recognition as ambassador of goodwill. It visited Southeast Asian countries, Europe, Great Britain, United States, Canada, Australia, China, and the USSR.

Among her awards are the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the City of Manila and the Presidential Medal of Merit from the Republic of the Philippines, 1971; the PNC Hall of Fame Award for National and International relations, 1974; the Dance in Education Award from the Dance Education Association of the Philippines, 1987; Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, 1990; CCP Centennial Honors, 1999; PAMA-AS Gintong BAI Award for outstanding works in the field of Philippine dance, 2005; and Outstanding Alumna in the field of Philippine folk dance by UP Alumni Association, 1989.Written by Larry A. Gabao, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ida Beltran

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
BELTRAN, IDA ( Ida Genevieve Castro Beltran-Lucila )b. Manila 3 Jan 1964. She is the daughter of Pedro Beltran and Patria Castro, sister of dancer/choreographer Myra Beltran, and wife of dancer/choreographer Jojo Lucila, with whom she has three children. She graduated cum laude in Theater Arts from the University of the Philippines (UP), 1987. She later took master of education in Special Education in UP, 1994-96, and the Managing the Arts Program at the Asian Institute of Management, 2003. She trained under Vella Damian at the School of Ballet and Dance Arts from 1973, and also at St. Theresa’s School of Ballet, where she participated in the Royal Academy of Dancing examinations up to the Advanced level.

She was a member of Dance Concert Company (DCC) under Damian and Eric V. Cruz, and performed in Ballet Federation of the Philippine’s full-length The Sleeping Beauty as Little Red Riding Hood. She was cast as the Ballerina in DCC’s Paquita in 1982, and portrayed Olympe in Cruz’s Camille, 1983.

She joined Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1983, training under Agnes Locsin, Alice Reyes, Denisa Reyes, Edna Vida, Gener Caringal, Noordin Jumalon, William Morgan, Alfred Rodrigues, Jean Deroc, Lane Gifford, Laura Alonso, Maniya Barredo, Mannie Rowe, Mikhail Kukharev, Miro Zolan, and Norman Walker. As a soloist and later, principal dancer, Beltran was cast in several ballets, playing roles like Princess Florine in the Bluebird pas de deux, 1983 and 1987, and Violente Fairy in The Sleeping Beauty,1987; a soloist in William Morgan’s Nuances, 1987; Gamzatti and the first Shade in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer),1988; the Sugar Plum Fairy in The Nutcracker, 1988; Odette/Odile in Swan Lake, 1989; and Hermia in Alice Reyes’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1989.

From 1989, she collaborated with her husband’s independent Chameleon Dance Company as associate artistic director. She was active in organizations such as Association of Ballet Academies, Philippines, as founding member and later president; the National Commission for Culture and the Arts where she was vice chair of the Committee on Dance; and a member of World Dance Alliance Philippines. She was also associate artistic director of Teatro Silencio Pilipinas from 1995 to 1997.

From 1998 to 2000, she served as associate artistic director of Philippine Ballet Theatre and restaged the Kingdom of the Shades from La Bayadere, the full-evening Don Quixote, and Tom Pazik’s Madame Butterfly. In 2003, she returned to Ballet Philippines as associate artistic director, and executive director in 2004. For BP, she restaged Alice Reyes’s Cinderella and Carmina Burana, and Edna Vida’s The Nutcracker.

Upon migrating to Canada with her family, she was invited to teach at the Edmonton School of Ballet in 2005. From 2006 onwards, she became a member of the Edmonton Arts council, and artistic director of the Edmonton Festival Ballet in 2007. Jojo Lucila established his Chameleon Dance Edmonton in 2007, where Beltran was co-artistic director until 2010. She taught ballet for the Ukrainian Shumka Dancers beginning 2010.Written by Joelle Florence Patrice Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Myra Beltran in Frida, 2007

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Myra Beltran in Star Maiden, 1995

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Myra Beltran in Itim Asu, 2009

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Myra Beltran and Paul Morales in Sigh, 2006

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
BELTRAN, MYRA ( Myra Victoria Castro Beltran )b. Manila 7 Nov 1960. Dancer, teacher, choreographer, critic. Myra Beltran is the daughter of Pedro Nanquil Beltran, an ex-navy captain, and Patria Antonietta Castro, a master’s degree holder in literary criticism. Her sister is dancer Ida Genevieve Beltran-Lucila who was a former executive director of Ballet Philippines. Beltran holds a bachelor of science in business economics and a master’s degree in comparative literature, both from the University of the Philippines. She trained with Vella Damian and Eric V. Cruz of Dance Concert Company from 1972 to 1979 and William Morgan of Ballet Federation of the Philippines from 1978 to 1979. In 1979, Beltran attended Indiana University as a dance major, training with Nicholas Beriozoff and Marina Svetlova. Later, she also trained with Jovanka Bjegojevic and Milica Jovanovic of Yugoslavia, and Enrico Labayen of The Lab, Projekt-Philippines.

In her search for her form, body, and self, Beltran discovered contemporary dance as her medium, and has since explored dance in very specific sociopolitical and cultural terms, propelled by physical and intellectual imperatives. She pursued a dance career in the United States in the late 1970s and early 1980s, after which she went to Eastern Europe, and worked with Ballet Oldenburg in Germany and Ballet of Prishtina in Yugoslavia. Back home, performing with Ballet Philippines and The Lab, Projekt-Philippines, she discovered that her practice is deeply embedded in a specific context that cannot be considered universal.

In 1994, she produced Women Waiting. A year later, sheformed her company Dance Forum. In 1997, the group’s studio became an alternative performing space, foundational in the creation of an independent contemporary dance community in the Philippines, providing opportunities for presentation of works and collaborations with artists of different fields, opening dance to a more inclusive relationship with the arts community.

Beltran is known for singularly pushing the solo form: Ritual for Taking Leave,1995; At the Heart of the Rose and Becoming (originally parts of Birdwoman ), 1996; Star Maiden, 1997; Poeme and Unbearable Lightness, 2002; Scarred Is Beautiful,2004; Tau-tao, Meditation on an Event Foretold and, Not Mine,2005; The Spell of Myrtha, 2006; Frida en el Espejo and Portrait of a Wallflower,2007; Also has Nine Lives and Prelude for Unaccompanied Dancer (with Ruelo Lozendo, video), 2008;and Mi Ultimo Adios ("My Last Farewell," excerpt from Itim Asu: 1719-2009 [Onyx Wolf: 1719-2009]), 2009.

Some of Dance Forum’s early productions conveying its intimate aesthetic style include Women Waiting, 1994; Dances of Dreamweavers, 1995; Folds of Midnight, 1999; Song,1999; Choreographic.discourse.Moment in desire, 2000; and Trace of a Trace from 2002 to 2003. The Romeo and Juliet Project, 2001, and The Spell of Myrtha,2006, also articulate Beltran’s engagement with and deconstruction of dance history.

Beltran produced work with other choreographers: Damas.con Furia with Enrico Labayen, 2002-3, Truth con Furia with Dancing Wounded, 2004, Order for Masks with Paul Morales and Sharon Brendia, 2005, Betrayed by Martha in partnership with Airdance, 2008,and Fragile Circle, also with five women visual artists, 1998, and curated others’ works, such as Daughters of Necessity,2000, with solos by women choreographers. For Philippine Ballet Theatre, Beltran created Imprint of Memory to music by Ramon Santos, 1997, and Bachianas Brasilieras No. 1,2000.

Beltran has also been productive as a choreographer and codirector of plays: Hugo: Gargoyle’s Whisper and Dance,2002-03, Shadows of the Reef,2004, Tatarin, the Summer Solstice, 2004, all with Anton Juan; Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others) directed by Alex Cortez, with libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera, 2002-03; and Ang Oresteyas (Oresteia ), choreographed and codirected with Ricardo Abad, 2013.

Beltran collaborated with filmmakers, starting with Sari Lluch Dalena in Puting Paalam (White Funeral),1996. She integrates the film medium in her choreographies, as seen in Payatas: Point counterpoint (video by Carlos Siguion-Reyna), 2001; Pandanggo (video byWilfred Galila), 2006;and Itim Asu: 1719-2009 (video by Sherad Anthony Sanchez and Ruelo Lozendo, cinematography by Albert Banzon), 2009.

With Alfonso Bolipata and the Pundaquit Chamber Players, she produced Quartet for the End of Time, 1998, and Nostalgia: Le Grand Tango, 2007. The year after, cellist Ramon Bolipata performed Bach’s Cello Suites 1 and 4 for Beltran’s Song.For Mc2(dance = musicconstructed2), a collaboration of contemporary dance and new music, Beltran premiered Tra-ver-sing,2009, with music by Christine Muyco and video by Sherad Anthony Sanchez.

For independent artists, and as coordinator of the World Dance Alliance-Philippines Choreographers Network, she initiated and coordinated the groundbreaking series Contemporary Dance Map 2005, for alternative spaces. She then led the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. This led to public performances at the Light Rail Transit Stations as LRT Dance Express, 2010, and the Belmonte Underpass in Quezon City as Underground, 2011.

Beltran has participated in national and international conferences on dance and literature, historiography, and women. The first conference on dance and gender, spearheaded by Basilio Esteban Villaruz and sponsored by National Commission for Culture and the Arts Committee in 1998, gave Beltran the opportunity to further express her deep concern for the interlocking issues of dance and gender.

For her range of collaborative works, vision for dance, and discourse, Beltran has received the Alab ng Haraya for Individual Recognition in the Performing Arts from the NCCA in 2001, the Tanging Parangal from the City of Manila in 2007, and an Asian Cultural Council Grant in 2012.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

photos.photodesc:
Franklin Bobadilla in PG Suite

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Franklin Bobadilla, 1982

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Franklin Bobadilla in a scene from Pinocchio

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Franklin Bobadilla in Once Upon a Village 

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
BOBADILLA, FRANKLIN ( Franklin Mariano Bobadilla )b. Manila 1 Jul 1950. Dancer. Bobadilla is the son of Florentino Cruz Bobadilla and Paulina Mariano. He studied in San Beda College and Ateneo de Manila University where he received a degree in Mass Communications. He did graduate studies in Library Science at the University of the Philippines and Frederick Mueller Academy in Amsterdam, Netherlands, 1982 to 1985. He also trained in ballet and in moderndance.

In 1970, he entered the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School and joined the CCP Dance Company until 1975. He guested with DanceTheatrePhilippines, HarirayaBallet, and Movement Men (later Movement Manila) which he helped found. In 1976, he joined the Scapino Ballet in Amsterdam where he danced for the next six years. He also danced with the Hermia Park Ballet School in Zaandam and the Petit Ballet Theatre in Amsterdam.

Bobadilla’s performances include those as major or lead dancers in AliceReyes’s The Emperor’s NewClothes,1970, the rock opera ballet Tommy,1972, and Dugso,1972; RemediosdeOteyza’s Bolero,1973; LuisLayag’s rock opera ballet The Survival of St. Joan,1973; EddieElejar’s Trio Con Brio,1972; Pinocchio,1975, choreographed by Dragutin Boldin in Heidelberg, Germany; Layag’s Back to Bach,1976; Elejar’s Once Upona Village,1982; Basilio’s Paean to Pavlova,1982; Rodrigues’s Souvenir; and the Manila and Amsterdam productions of TheNutcracker.

Bobadilla was noted for his fluent pirouettes, neat beats, and remarkable ballon;he was also considerably intense in dramatic roles, a number of which were made specifically for him. He has since worked as librarian at the Ziekenforndsraad in Amstelveen, the Stichting Runstzinnige Vorming, and the Anne Frank Foundation Library in Amsterdam.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
BOHOL, ANTONIO AND JOSEFINABACALSO Cebuano balitaw performers, popularly known as the husband and wife team of Tonyo and Pasing. Tonyo and Pasing were the most popular practitioners of the balitaw after the famous pre-World War II pair of Indiong (Pedro Alfafara) and Colasing (Nicolasa Caniban).

Tonyo was from Banao, Cebu, while Pasing was from the Pardo district in Cebu City. It is said that it was Pasing’s parents, Mariano Bacalso and Gregoria Sabandeja, who inspired and trained the couple in the balitaw. Tonyo was a stage actor and playwright while Pasing played roles in Cebuano radio plays. As balitaw performers, they popularized the art through the medium of radio and stage performances. They also starred as balitaw dancers in the Cebuano movie, Garbosa (Vain Woman), 1956. Radio programs that featured the couple included Visayan Troubadours directed by Ben Zubiri, Mga Haranista (The Serenaders), Asan Ka Inday? (Where Are You Miss?), and the popular Balitaw Hour, aired over Cebu radio station DYRC from February 1948 to June 1950. They continued to be featured on radio programs until the 1970s.

In 1989, the couple left the Philippines to join a daughter in Australia where they performed before Filipino communities.They subsequently returned to the Philippines.Josefina Bacalso-Bohol died on 1 Jun 1991 and so did Antonio Bohol whose date of death is unknown.Written by Erlinda Alburo

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Julie Borromeo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
BORROMEO, JULIE ( Julie Barredo Borromeo-Roche ) b. Cebu City 21 Feb 1941. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She is the daughter of Tomas Borromeo of the Cebu theatrical family and singer Carmen Barredo, both art patrons, and granddaughter of Celestino Borromeo,sarsuwelaplaywright; sister of dancer-choreographer Rose Borromeo; niece of piano jazz virtuoso and Father of Philippine Bodabil Luis Borromeo, aka Borromeo Lou; cousin of stage actor Carmen Barredo; mother of dancers Maricar, Annamarie, and Gigi Aragon; and aunt of prima ballerina Maniya Barredo and musical artists Lea and Gerald Salonga. Her husband is David Roche.

Borromeo started training in ballet with American teacher Ricardo Cassell in Manila. She later studied with and performed for New Zealander teacher and choreographer Anita Kane, who arranged a scholarship for her, Tony Llacer, and Israel Gabriel in New York. There, Borromeo studied with Vladimir Dokoudovsky, Nina Straganova, and Lisan Kaye, then considered the best dance teachers in the USA. Aside from dancing ballet, she also took jazz with Matt Mattox. After returning to the Philippines in 1957 at the age of 17, she established the Dance Arts Studio, which would later be renamed Julie Borromeo’s Performing Arts Foundation. In 1971, she received an Asia Foundation Grant to study again in the US, training with Robert Joffrey in ballet, Martha Graham in modern dance, Luigi in jazz, and Herbert Bergoff, Lynn Simonson, and Hagen in musical comedy.

Borromeo, together with Felicitas Layag-Radaic and Eddie Elejar, founded Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP) in 1968. DTP had its premiere at the Rizal Theater with a production of the Danish Poul Gratt, artistic director of Royal New Zealand Ballet. She became its president, lead dancer, and choreographer, well-known for her wide-ranging work in ballet, jazz, and stylized ethnic dance. After the first EDSA Revolt of 1986, DTP, along with the Hariraya Ballet, Dance Concert Company and the Manila Metropolis Ballet, altogether formed the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). She would then become its artistic director in 1990 and later the chair of the company’s Artistic Council.

Her major works include Mir-i-nisa, 1969, the first Filipino three-act ballet, which she co-choreographed with Layag-Radaic; Babae at Lalake (Man and Woman), Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila ) and Kalingan, 1968; Bamboo Fantasy, 1976; Philippine Revue, 1986; Merry Widow, 1987; and Graduation Ball, 1988. Borromeo also ventured into musical productions, producing, choreographing, and/or starring in them.Written by Mary Jane L. Globio, Mena Ojeda, and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Rose Borromeo with Ruben Nieto

(Photo courtesy of Paquito Dela Cruz)

Rose Borromeo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
BORROMEO, ROSE ( Rose Barredo Borromeo ) b. Manila 23 Jul 1943. Dancer, choreographer. She was born to Tomas Borromeo and singer Carmen Barredo. Dancer-choreographer Julie Borromeo is her sister. Belonging to a theatrical family on both sides, she is the granddaughter ofsarsuwelaplaywright Celestino Borromeo, niece of the piano jazz virtuoso and Father of Philippine Bodabil Luis Borromeo, also known as Borromeo Lou, and cousin of stage actor Carmen Barredo. Prima ballerina Maniya Barredo, sculptor Gabby Barredo, and musical artists Lea and Gerald Salonga are her nieces and nephews.

Borromeo trained in ballet with Ricardo Cassell and Anita Kane, in tap dance with Roberta Cassell, and in Spanish dance with Ruben Nieto. From 1958 to 1961, she studied in New York at the International Dance School, Ballet Arts Studio, and the Jun Taylor Dance School. In the late 1970s, she trained further with Luigi and Ben Forella in jazz, and Amelia Gilmore and Robert Andy in Spanish dance in New York.

Borromeo later danced with the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company and worked as assistant choreographer and dance leader at her sister’s Julie Borromeo’s Dance Company. With Ruben Nieto as partner, she also taught Spanish dance. In 1961-62, she was with the Philippine Festival of Steve Parker and Shirley MacLaine in Las Vegas, Nevada, USA. When she returned to Manila, she danced for television and from 1966 to 1988, acted in musical comedies like Flower Drum Song, Promises, Promises, Gypsy, Man of La Mancha, and Chorus Line. She also choreographed for Repertory Philippines productions, like Hello Dolly, Mame, The King and I, What’s New Charlie Brown, and I Do, I Do; for television shows like Changes; and for movies, like Blue Jeans and Sinta (Darling).

While doing choreography for shows and productions, she taught ballet, Spanish dance, jazz, Polynesian dance, and slimnastics at the Dance Arts Studios in Mandaluyong, the Academie for the Performing Arts in Makati, and at her own school in Zamboanga City. Borromeo was a trustee and manager of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines, 1976-79.

Borromeo moved to Singapore in 1982 to direct the studios of Dance Arts. She stayed in Singapore for almost 30 years, working with the Singapore Broadcasting Company, and eventually becoming Artistic Administrator of the American Club of Singapore. During her stay in Singapore, Borromeo also choreographed musicals such as Singapore Repertory Theatre’s Godspell, 1993; and co-choreographed with Filomar Tario Singapore Lyric Opera’s staging of La Traviata, 2008. She also founded her own dance company, the Rose Borromeo Spanish Dance Company, in 2005.

In recognition of her efforts to introduce Spanish dance and promote Spanish arts and culture in Singapore, she received the La Cruz de Isabela La Catolica, cruz de damas (Order of Isabella the Catholic, Dame’s Cross) in 2013. Borromeo returned to the Philippines in 2013. She currently teaches at the Julie Borromeo Performing Arts Foundation. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

article_title: Bulacan State University-Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Troupe
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
BSU Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Troupe, 2014

(Photo from facebook.com/LahingKayumanggisince1988/)

BSU Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Troupe, 2017

(Photo from facebook.com/LahingKayumanggisince1988/)

text:
BULACAN STATE UNIVERSITY-LAHING KAYUMANGGI DANCE TROUPE ( BulSU-LKDT )Formed in 1979 and recognized in 1988 as the official folk dance group of the Bulacan State University of Malolos, Bulacan, the group is composed of students under the supervision of Jovita E. Meneses, a former member of the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe (BFDT) of the Philippine Normal University. She shaped the group according to the values and skills she learned from Dr Paz Cielo A. Belmonte, founder of BFDT.

BulSU-LKDT’s repertoire includes a variety of occupational, courtship, festival, social, and war dances that depict the rich Filipino customs and traditions. Their most applauded performances are the skill dances from Pangasinan such as sayaw sa bangko with a couple dancing on top of a wooden bench, and binasuan with dancers balancing glasses while turning and rolling on the floor; the mock battle dance from Laguna, maglalatik; the famous dance with bamboo poles from Leyte, tinikling; and the dance with castanets from Tarlac, la jota moncadeña.

BulSU-LKDT has performed on campus and other outreach performances in Bulacan and the nearby provinces. Its performances include A Valentine to Remember,1988, Sayaw (Dance),1995, Yakis (Youth in the Street),1996, Bisperas (Eve),1997, Pagdiriwang (Celebration),1998, Saludo Bulawenyo (Salute to the Dancer), 1999, Ritwal (Ritual),2000, Daloy (Flow),2001, Ugnayan (Link), 2003, Sentinaryo (Centennial),2004, Kunday (Swaying),2006,and Beinte Anyos (Twenty Years), 2008. The group danced in the annual Cultural Center of the Philippines’ Pasinaya (Inauguration) : CCP Open House Festival,2004-14, and Filipiniana Sunsets, 2011-12

BulSU-LKDT joined regional and national dance competitions and garnered top awards. The group holds the record of being champion 13 times in the Regional Folkdance Competition of the Development Council of State Universities and Colleges in Region III / Center for Interinstitutional Research and Policy Studies from 1988 to 2014. BulSU-LKDT was also the champion in the National Literary—Cultural Festival Folk Dance Category Competition of the Philippine Association of State Universities and Colleges in 2008. In the same year, it received the Gintong Kabataan Award for Folk Dance by the Provincial Government of Bulacan. It also won in the National Commission for Culture and the Arts’ Sayaw Pinoy National Folk Dance Competition in 2009, 2011, 2012, and 2014.

BulSU-LKDT celebrated its Silver Anniversary in 2013 held at the Malolos Convention Center with the show Pilak (Silver), featuring their best known repertoire and alumni, in a tribute to their founder-adviser, Ms Meneses.Written by Josefina B. Guillen

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
CALZADO, LITO ( Feliciano Dilo Calzado ) b. Manila 20 Jan 1946. d. Quezon City 11 Nov 2011. Dancer, choreographer. Calzado is the son of Miguel Calzado, a dancer in Samar, and Iluminada Dilo. He was married to Mary Antonio Ussher with whom he has two children, Iza, an actor, and son Dash, a member of a rap group. He studied at the University of the East (UE) and then at San Beda College where he received his degree in marketing. While a student at UE, he joined the university folk dance troupe under the direction of Maggie Shea. From 1961 to 1969, he danced with the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company and the Ballet Folkloric Filipino, which he helped form in 1966. In 1967, he danced for television with Alice Reyes’s group for Time Out with Lynn (Madrigal) and with Amelia Apolinario’s group. He also danced briefly for the stage.

From 1965 to 1968, Calzado was assistant choreographer for the Insiders, a group he helped form for Laura Danao’s shows on Channel 9 and later, on Channel 4. In 1969, he was choreographer for Joey Lardizabal’s show Swing-In on Channel 4, and in 1970 for That Young Image with Jeanne Young for which he won the Citizens’ Award for Television (CAT). Later he became dance director of the ABS-CBN Dance Company. He directed shows including Marilen, Buhay Artista (Artist’s Life), On with the Show, and the Nestor and Nida Show. He did specials for Lita Gutierrez and choreographed for The Sensations and An Evening with Pilita. He was involved in People, Tony Santos Presents, and Student Canteen.

For popular shows, Calzado formed the Lito Calzado and His Dancers, also known as The Body Machine. He also directed the Larawan Dance Company, the Bureau of Customs’ folk dance troupe. He trained dance groups for clubs and other venues in Japan, and ran an entertainment and management center. He was the stage director of 12 Gawad Urian productions and the 57th Famas Awards Night in 2009. He was the director of the late-night TV show Walang Tulugan with the Master Showman (No Sleep with the Master Showman), formerly named Master Showman, from 1997 to 2011 on GMA 7. He was a member of the Philippine Entertainment Managers Association and the Chamber of Industries in Music Entertainment. He received the Posthumous Award from the PMPC Star Awards and the Metro Manila Film Festival Lifetime Achievement Award, both in 2011.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Gener Caringal with Gina Mariano in Ang Sultan

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Gener Caringal

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
CARINGAL, GENER ( Gener Arguelles Caringal ) b. Ibaan, Batangas 17 Jul 1947. Dancer, choreographer. He is the son of Daniel Ramos Caringal and Paulina Arias Arguelles. He obtained a degree in business administration from the University of the East (UE). He started dancing at 16 with the UE Dance Troupe under Corazon Generoso-Iñigo. As a student, he also joined off-campus productions, like Maureen Tiongco’s Flower Drum Song and Dance Theater Philippines’ (DTP) Mir-i-nisa, 1969. He became one of the original members of Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1970. All these companies enabled him to train in folk dance, with Generoso-Iñigo and Eloisa de Leon; in ballet, with Anita Kane, Eddie Elejar, Mira Zolan, Jan Stripling, Luminita Dumitrescu, Garth Welch, William Morgan, Vakhtang Chabukiani, and Mikhail Kukharev; in jazz, with Generoso-Iñigo, Julie Borromeo, and Matt Mattox; in modern dance, with Generoso-Iñigo, Alice Reyes, Manolo Rosado, Takako Asakawa, Pauline Koner, and Norman Walker; and in Spanish dance with Ruben Nieto and Rose Borromeo. With the UE and BP troupes, he toured Asia, Australia, Europe, and the USA. In 1979, he observed German dance companies under the auspices of the Goethe Institut and the German International Theater Institute. As a dancer, he excelled in works by Alice Reyes, among them the lead roles in Tommy, Company, Tales of the Manuvu, and Rama,Hari (Rama, King).

From 1974 to 1985, Caringal was the director of the UE Dance Troupe (now the Silanganan Dance Troupe). Soon after he also became director of the Philippine National Bank Dance Group, 1970 to 1975; the Yeh Shian Folk Ballet Company, 1975 to 1984; BP’s Repertory Company (predecessor of BP II), 1981 to 1984; and his own Gener Caringal Dance Repertory, 1983 to 1986. In 1985, he led the Philippine delegation to the 15th Asian Festival of the Performing Arts in Singapore, featuring his work Labaw Dunggon. He also led some of these groups to festivals in Europe and the United States. He is one of the founders of the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), was chair of its artistic council, and artistic director from 1995 to 2008. In 1988 and 1989, he choreographed for the Singapore Dance Theater. He has been dance director of the UE Silanganan Dance Troupe since 1998 and chairman of the University Committee on Socio-Cultural Activities that became part of the Office of Cultural Affairs from 2002 until the present. He strengthened the training program of the Troupe, revised and created a repository of Philippine folk and modern dances and increased the Troupe’s membership to more than 70 dancers. In 2007, Caringal’s initiative of performing original works for PBT by inviting choreographers was revived, and was known as the Philippine Choreographers Showcase. He was head of the National Committee on Dance of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts from 2005 to 2007 and a founding member of the Association of Cultural Offices of Philippine Educational Institutions (ACOPEI), 2010.

For Palikhayaw (Paglikha ng Sayaw / Creation of a Dance), Caringal created Likha (Creation), his take on the Malakas/Maganda creation myth. In 2009, this work was performed as part of Turning … Turning 40, CCP Dance Gala for CCP’S 40th anniversary. His other choreographic works include Ang Sultan (The Sultan), 1973; Glimpse ofParadise, 1974; Tomaneg at Aniway, 1975; Judith and Paglalakbay (Journey),both in 1977; Rite of Spring,1977, for the Far Eastern University (FEU) and 1978, for BP; Diversions and Atlantis, 1978; Jazz Moods and Ibong Adarna, both in 1979; Recuerdos (Memories), 1980; Vermillion Scarf, 1983; Ta-o (People), 1985; The Rite of Spring, 1977, for UE and 1978, for BP; Vermilion Scarf, 1982; Valse Brillante, 1983; Maligaya Maligaya (Happy Happy), 1984; Sanggumai, 1986; Haram, 1987; The Tribe, 1988; Harami! (Forbidden!) and Chameleon Scarf, both in 1987; Souvenir, 1988; Vinta, 1989; The Offering, 1990; Prism, 1991; Filipino Komiks, 1993; Andres KKK, 1996; Vinta and Fiesta, 2004; Darangen ni Bantugen,2008, an interpretation of the Maranao epic Bantugan; Libretto, 2008; Andres,2009; Hudhud, 2010; Fire,2010, for the culmination of UE’s 64th Foundation Anniversary celebration; Ako Gamo Gamo (I, The Moth),2011, as part of 150th birth anniversary celebration of Jose Rizal.

Among his awards are the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan, 1997 and the Distinguished Achievement Award from UE, 2006.Written by Mary Jane L. Globio, Mena Ojeda, and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Bayani Casimiro tap dancing

(Photo courtesy of Cesar Hernando)

Bayani Casimiro with Nieves Manuel in Sumpaan, 1948

(Photo courtesy of Cesar Hernando)

text:
Bayani Casimiro (Bayani Gutierrez Casimiro) was a dancer, singer, and a stage, film, and television actor. He was born in San Pablo, Laguna on 16 Jul 1918. He died in Manila on 27 Jan 1989. He was the son of Trinidad Gutierrez and Paulino Casimiro, a comedian of the sarsuwela and komedya. He finished elementary school at the Caloocan Elementary School. He married choreographer Nieves Manuel, with whom he had two children. His son Bayani Jr. is also an actor. 

At age seven, he entered show business as a clown and comedian, earning 50 centavos for his act. He loved to dance, particularly tap, and won in a song and dance contest at the Teatro Zorrilla. He also won in an amateur singing contest in 1928 for his rendition of “Rainbow on the River.” In 1936 he visited Hawaii as part of a performing troupe headed by Sarsuwela Queen Atang dela Rama. By the late 1930s, Casimiro’s tap dancing had earned him the nickname “The Fred Astaire of the Philippines,” as he was often dressed up in top hat and tails like Fred Astaire. During this time, he headlined numerous bodabil productions in Manila.

In 1938, Casimiro appeared in his first movie, Excelsior Films’ Bayan at Pag-ibig (Country and Love). After some time he transferred to Filippine Films and later became part of Lou Salvador’s stage shows. During World War II, when local film productions ceased, bodabil productions became the primary source of entertainment in Manila. Along with many other actors such as Rogelio de la Rosa and Norma Blancaflor, Casimiro became very popular. It was also during this time that Casimiro met his stage partner Jose Cris Soto, and the two performed at the Life Theater in Manila. Because of the success of their team, they came to be known as the “Oliver and Hardy of the Philippines.”

After the war, Casimiro went back to his film career. In 1947, he met Rodolfo Vera Quizon Sr, better known as Dolphy, who performed at the Orient Theater under the stage name “Golay.” The two became comic dance partners. Casimiro also continued to play small roles in more than a hundred films, such as Pilipino Kostum, No Touch (Filipino Custom, No Touch), 1955; Captain Barbell, 1973; Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977; and Titser’s Pet (Teacher’s Pet), 1981. In his old age, Casimiro would still perform as character actor in film comedies, playing the role of an eccentric old man prone to ridicule, such as in E.T. (Estong Tutong), 1983; Horsey Horsey Tigidig Tigidig, 1986; Buy One Take One, 1988; and Magic to Love, 1989. His most popular role in his later years was in the sitcom Okey Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), as the father of Vic Sotto’s character, Enteng Kabisote.  Written by Marge C. Enriquez, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ricardo and Roberta Cassell in a pas de deux, 1949

(Photo courtesy of Vivian Cassell)

Ricardo Cassell

(Photo courtesy of Vivian Cassell)

Ricardo Cassell

(Photo courtesy of Vivian Cassell)

Roberta and Ricardo Cassell in Manila

(Photo courtesy of Vivian Cassell)

text:
CASSELL, RICARDO and ROBERTACASSELL Ricardo (b. Chicago, Cook County, Illinois, USA 26 Nov 1921; d. Millville, Cumberland County, New Jersey, USA 19 Nov 2005; dancer, choreographer, teacher). Roberta (aka Roberta Lee Cassell, born Roberta Lee Applegate in Saint Maries, Benewah County, Idaho, USA 30 Nov 1923; d. USA 26 Jun 2012;also a dancer, choreographer, and dance teacher). Roberta's parents were Washington Applegate and Grace Ann Sowell. She studied with Cassell, graduated in dance, and the other arts from the Cornish School in Seattle, Washington, and appeared in musicals in New York like Oklahoma and Hello,Dolly! Ricardo married Robertain 3 Dec 1943.

Ricardo Cassell studied with Gladys Height, Nicholas Tsoukolas, Lee Foley, Ivan Novikoff, Prideaux, Vicenzo Celli, and Bentley Stone. He danced with the opera companies of San Carlo, the Seattle Civic Opera, and the Bentley Stone-Ruth Page Ballet Company, and became ballet master of the Seattle Civic Opera.

He first came to the Philippines in World War II with the US Army Air Corps. He became chief of the facility at Janic Tower (now Nichols Tower). After the war, he returned to instruct Philippine air traffic controllers at the Manila (now Ninoy Aquino) International Airport.

Because of Roberta Cassell’s part-time teaching in Anita Kane’s School of Classic Dance, he started teaching ballet in Manila. They were both invited to establish the Manila Ballet Academy by one of their pupils, Pacita Madrigal-Warns. In 1950, it presented the Philippine premiere of Giselle with Pacita Madrigal-Warns as Giselle, BenjaminVillanuevaReyes as Albrecht, and GretaMonserrat as Myrtha.

After teaching for a while at the Young Women’s Christian Association (YWCA), the couple established the Cassell Dance Studio around 1952. In YWCA, they founded the StudioDanceGroup in 1953. The Studio Dance Group aimed to professionalize ballet dancing in the Philippines. It sent Villanueva to New York on a scholarship. It also built a repertoire which helped to develop dancers. Among their ballets were: Tchaikovsky’s FifthSymphony,1954, by Ricardo and Roberta Cassell; Street Scene, Lost Generation and Lament,between 1954 and 1955, all to Gershwin and by Ricardo Cassell; Adagietto,1954, to Mahler and by Ricardo Cassell, based on a poem by JoseLardizabal; The Transgressor, 1954, to Gould and by Ricardo Cassell; Ballet Blanc,1954, to Luigini and by Roberta Cassell; SketchClass,1954, to Offenbach and by Ricardo Cassell; GraduationBall, 1955, to Strauss and by Ricardo and Roberta Cassell; Backstage,1953/1954, by Ricardo Cassell; and MerryWives of Windsor,1954, and Divertissements,1955, to several composers and by Ricardo Cassell. Around this period, he also choreographed Beauty and the Beast to Ravel, and Peter and the Wolf to Prokofiev. Cassell also choreographed a Filipino movie production of Lady Be Good.

In 1955, the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy banned girls in Catholic schools from studying ballet. This had a grave consequence on the efforts of the Cassells such that they decided to return to the United States in 1956. Ricardo Cassell worked with the Federal Aviation Administration and occasionally taught as a guest teacher.

He visited Manila in 1981 and again, with Roberta Cassell, in 1983. A tribute performance was held at the Colegio de San Agustin in Makati. Ricardo taught master classes at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) Dance School, the University of the Philippines College of Music, and the Elejar-Fabella School of Dance. In 1988, Philippine Ballet Theatre paid tribute to him in its season titled Homage at the CCP. The Cassells are credited with having brought the art of ballet to a certain level of professional competence with the seasons of the Studio Dance Group, which brought together the most outstanding dancers in the Philippines at the time.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
CASTILLO, CARMELITO ( Carmelito Adviento Castillo )b. Alcala, Cagayan 10 Oct 1949. Dancer, choreographer. The son of Luz Adviento and Felix Castillo, he is a qualified physiotherapist with adiploma from the University of Salford in England, 1985. As a dancer he trained with RosaliaMerino-Santos, TonyLlacer, Julie and RoseBorromeo, Basilio, FelicitasLayag-Radaic, Robin Haig, and Gerard Sibbritt in Manila; and with David Blair, Peter Schnitzler, and Peter Clegg abroad.

He was a member of the FarEasternUniversityExperimentalDanceGroup of Merino-Santos, 1969 to 1971; Dance Arts Studio, 1970 to 1973; DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP), 1972 to 1975; and Movement Men (later Movement Manila). He danced principal roles in Nan-Pangkat, Maho-no-ken, The Prey, and Japonsina by Layag-Radaic; They Came “Jorking” In and Survival of St. Joan by LuisLayag; Elements, Mosque Baroque,and Between the Sky and Sea by Basilio; Lenore and Triptych by Haig; In the Beginning and LesPatineurs by Llacer; ZagalasdeManila (Young Maidens of Manila) and Sweet Charity by JulieBorromeo; and Gypsy Rose by RoseBorromeo. In Hong Kong, he danced Franz in Coppelia (Act III), partnering with Muñeca Aponte; with DTP he partnered with Australian ballerina Robin Haig. Castillo also performed in television like the June Keithley Show, and film in Ay Naku Tatay na si Erap (Oh No, Erap Is Already a Father) with Nora Aunor and Joseph Estrada.

He choreographed Solitaire,1973, and The Creation,1973 and 1974, in Manila. In 1974, Castillo was invited to perform in Hong Kong together with Dame Margot Fonteyn, David Blair from England, Heinz Bosl from Germany, Robin Haig from Australia, Sui Kan Chang from China, and Muñeca Aponte from Puerto Rico.

In 1976, he choreographed the Filipino version of Jesus Christ Superstar in Oberhausen and Essen, Germany. In the same year, he guested in Aachen, Germany and joined Northern Ballet Theater in Manchester, England, the only Filipino who became a member of a British ballet company. For six years, he was soloist and later principal dancer, appearing as Pierrot in Geoffrey Cauley’s Miss Carter Wore Pink, Piccolo in Cinderella, Bottom and Puck in AMidsummerNight’sDream, both by Robert de Warren, Harlequin and Chinese Dance in Ande Prokovsky’s TheNutcracker, Bonze in Madame Butterfly and Swan of Tounela,both by Jonathan Thorpe, Eros in Richard Glasstone’s Sylvia, Newsboy in Kurt Jooss’s The Big City, Walter Gore’s Eatersof Darkness,and the ballets of Charles Czarny, Jack Carter, and Royston Maldoom.

Castillo has been awarded by the Philippine Independent Church, 1972, and Pope Pius Catholic Center, 1973 to 1975, in Manila. He represented the Philippines in the 1976 Congress of the International Theater Institute in Finland.Written by Basillio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
CATOY, KATSCH SJ ( Virgilio San Juan Catoy ) b. Manila 1 Apr 1954. Lighting designer, technical director, stage manager, director. He is the son of Juan M. Catoy Sr and Patricia San Juan. He is married to Laura R. Aloba. Their son Virgilio II, aka King, is a filmmaker. He studied at Santa Ana Elementary School and graduated from Araullo High School. He then took courses in broadcast communication at the University of the Philippines (UP) until his sophomore year in 1975. He also finished grade 6 in the German language course at the Goethe Institut in Manila. From 1994 to 1996, he studied business management in the University of the East. He began his theater training at the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) as a member working in various capacities from 1969 to 1977. In 1976, he received a grant to observe technical theater in Germany through the International Theatre Institute, Goethe Institut, and PETA. He proceeded to New York City in 1977 for apprenticeship at the La Mama Experimental Theater Company through a John D. Rockefeller III Fund grant.

He returned to the Philippines and to employment at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) as technical assistant for theater, later also serving as stage manager for the CCP Dance Company, now Ballet Philippines. In 1981, he became technical director for CCP, supervising all its backstage aspects. From 1981 to 1988, he served as technical director and lighting designer for Ballet Philippines. In 1987, he was appointed deputy director of the Theater Operations Department of the CCP. From 1994 to 1996, he was the theater director of the University of the East (UE) Theater. He also served as chairman of the University Committee on Socio-Cultural Activities, which supervised and coordinated UE’s arts and culture-related activities. Catoy has taken up several theater consultancy posts in various colleges and universities from 1992 to 2005. He was the resident lighting designer and technical director for the 2011-12 season of Tanghalang Pilipino. He has been serving as technical consultant for the Perry Sevidal Ballet and Steps Dance Studio since 1994.

Catoy’s skill in lighting design was further honed by the numerous workshops and seminars he attended. These include the Duk Hyong Yoo Stage Lighting Workshop held by PETA in 1972; the UNESCO International Theatre Institute World Theatre Congress held in Stockholm, Sweden in 1977; the specialist’s course in lighting design and technology in London through a British Council grant in 1991; the Jennifer Tipton Lighting Design Workshop held by the Asian Cultural Council at the CCP in 2005; and the International Symposium for Lighting Designers held in Shanghai in 2011. He went to China and France in 1991 and 1992, respectively, as a visitor of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Catoy is noted for his lighting design for numerous stage productions. He did lighting design for Ballet Philippines’s Rama, Hari (Rama, The King), 1980; La Lampara (The Lamp) and Recuerdos (Memories), 1981; Giselle, Isaiah, Swan Lake, Yerma, and Vision of Fire, 1982; Carmina Burana, Photography: A Gentleman’s Honor, Muybridge/Frames, Sleeping Beauty, Tapestry, Lawang Paoay (Paoay Lake), and Peter Pan, 1983; Romeo and Juliet, Les Sylphides, and Carmen, 1984; Te Deum, Firebird, Coppelia, Misa Criolla, Misa, For the Gods, and Ta-O, 1985; Don Quixote, Dugso (Swordfish), Kulam (Hex), Made in the Philippines, Love Lies Bleeding, Chichester Psalms, and Sisa , 1986; Nijinsky, Nuances, Bayanihan Remembered, La Bayadere, Amada, and Mga Babae (The Women), 1987; Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), Ang Pilya (The Mischievous), The Kiss, Song of a Wayfarer, Undertow, Change Gonna Come By, Snow White, 1988; and Menage-a-Trois, 1994. He also did the lighting design for the 2008-9 season productions of Ballet Philippines such as New Beginnings, La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), Coppelia, and Neo-Filipino. Catoy toured with Ballet Philippines as its technical director and lighting designer for performances in various festivals in different countries.

Catoy did the lighting design for Repertory Philippines’s Little Shop of Horrors, Amador, The Woman in Black, and Les Miserables, 1993; La Cage aux Folles, My Fair Lady, It Runs in the Family, Jack and the Beanstalk, Jake’s Women, The Wiz, Tartuffe, Enter Laughing, Camelot, Chapter Two, Scrooge, New Year’s Gala, and East Meets West / Rep with Powerdance, 1994; and Celebration, Snow White, Evita, A Funny Thing, and Forum, 1995.

Other notable productions in which Catoy took charge of lighting and technical direction are Dulaang Kabataang Barangay’s Santa Juana ng mga Kural ( Saint Joan of the Stockyards ), 1978; Manila Hotel’s Doon Po sa Amin ( Our Town ), 1978; Bulwagang Gantimpala’s Biyaheng Timog (Trip to the South) and Likha Mangarap (Creation-Dream), 1984; Poulenc-Cocteau’s Les Maries de la Tour Eiffel, 1984; Singapore Dance Theater’s inaugural concert, Beginnings, 1988; and Tanghalang Pilipino’s Botong, 1989, Larawan ( Portrait of the Artist as Filipino ) and Lusak ( Lower Depths), 1990, American Hwangap, 2010, Zsazsa Zaturnnah ze Muzikal (Zsazsa Zaturnnah The Musical) and Noli Me Tangere : The Musical (Touch Me Not: The Musical), 2011, EYEBALL: New Visions in Philippine Theater, Walang Maliw (Unfading), Walang Kukurap (Let No One Blink), Stage Show, 2012, Sandosenang Sapatos (Dozens of Shoes) and Ibalong: The Musical, 2013, and Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior), 2015.

He also designed the lights and provided technical direction for Dulaang UP’s M. Butterfly and Mga Bakasyonista (Summerfolk), 1990; the Lab. Projekt dance in performance and video choreographies of Enrico Labayen, 1991-92; PETA’s Miserere Nobis (Have Mercy on Us) and Sebiong Engkanto (Enchanted Sebio), 1992; Drama tis Personae’s The Physicists and Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), 1994; the opening dance performance of the Asian Cultural Council’s 35th Anniversary Conference, Song of the Warrior Woman, 1998; and Steps Dance Studio’s The Nutcracker, 2010. For the CCP Women’s Desk, he designed both the lighting and the set of Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), 1992, and the lighting of Trilohiya (Trilogy), 1993. He also did the lighting design for Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Company’s Magkabilaan (Both Sides), 2014. Aside from stage productions, Catoy has done lighting design and technical direction for several fashion shows.

Catoy also directed Unang Alay (First Offering), 1975, and Bodong, 1976, an improvisational piece, both for PETA; Rizal@Concordia, 1999, co-written with Virgilio A. Catoy II for Dulaang Concordia; and The Tao, 2000. He wrote the lighting design manual Some Thoughts on Lighting and Performance: The Making of a Salt Solution Dimmer Prototype, 1992. He won the Outstanding Lighting Design award in the 2010 and 2015 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay! for Neo-Filipino and La Revolucion Filipina, respectively.Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Athena Angela A. Aquino, with notes from F. Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Cebu Ballet Center’s Schindler’s List (Photo courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)

Cebu Ballet Center’s Romeo and Juliet, 2012

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)
Cebu Ballet Center’s Colors of Life, 2018 (Photo courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)

Cebu Ballet Center’s Swan Lake, 2013

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)

Cebu Ballet Center’s Summer Spectacular, 2017

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)

text:
CEBU BALLET CENTER (later known asBallet Center Cebu)Founded in 1951 in Cebu City by FeSala-Villarica, the Center subscribes to an educational program that will “produce artists, not automatons; teachers with high artistic standards; and choreographers who are responsive to modern trends yet are respectful of history and tradition.” Since 2006, it has been called Ballet Center Cebu.

In 1963, dancers from the Center formed the QueenCityJuniorBalletCompany as its performing arm. The Center has provided training in classic dance to students, some of whom like NicolasPacaña and NoordinJumalon, have earned scholarships abroad and embarked on successful careers in dance or dance teaching. Pacaña became the premier danseur of Honolulu City Ballet, Boston Ballet, and Atlanta Ballet.

When Pacaña and Gregory Aaron started to run the Center in 2006, they launched the International Summer Series in Cebu. Both continue to be codirectors of their Atlanta Festival Ballet in Atlanta which has mounted full-length ballets for more than 20 years. In Cebu, they offer classical ballet and contemporary dance classes. In its regional tours, Ballet Center Cebu has performed popular pieces such as The Nutcracker, The LittleMermaid, Alice in Wonderland, Peter Pan, Beauty and the Beast, Swan Lake, and Sleeping Beauty; andneo-classical balletslike Eclipse, Bella Amore, Paganini, Outcast, Tchaikovsky, Sing Sing Sing, Symphony in C,and Back to the Fifties.

Aside from its regular scholars, the Center has outreach programs that have taught ballet to almost 200 students. Its dancers participated in the National Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA) and the Asian Gran Prix Ballet Competition in Hong Kong. In 1977, the Center was given recognition during the National Ballet Festival in Manila. During its 30th anniversary celebration in 1981, the Center launched a series of lecture-demonstrations, performances in classical ballet and folkloric theater, dance-film showings, and an alumni gathering.Written by Erlinda Alburo, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jean Marc Cordero

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
CORDERO, JEAN MARC ( Jean Marc Ledesma Cordero )aka JM Cordero b. 4 Jun 1986. Dancer. Jean Marc Cordero is the son of Asuncion Ledesma and Manuel Cordero, and hails from Talisay City, Negros Occidental. An alumnus of the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA), major in theater, he graduated in 2008 from the bachelor of performing arts program of the De La Salle College of St. Benilde School of Design and Art. Cordero began his formal ballet training at the late age of 18 as a male scholar with the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School under Noordin Jumalon. After only a year of training, he was promoted to apprentice with Ballet Philippines (BP) in 2005. His technique was further honed under Augustus “Bam” Damian, Monette Victoria, Candice Adea, Victor Ursabia, Alan Hineline, and Max Luna III. In 2007, he earned company membership and has danced in all of the company’s productions since then.

He made his debut as a soloist in Alan Hineline’s Coppelia, 2008, as the male lead Franz. His theatrical background and ability to effectively convey a story have enabled him to take on a variety of lead roles for the company, including Mabini in Agnes Locsin’s La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), 2008; the Prince in The Nutcracker,2009; the title role in Edna Vida’s Peter Pan, 2010; Basilio in Don Quixote,2011; Estranjero in Encantada (Enchantress),2011; Rama in Alice Reyes’s Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 2012; Albrecht in Giselle, 2013; and Ebenezer Scrooge in Edna Vida’s A Christmas Carol, 2013.

Cordero has won several local and international awards. In 2010, he was awarded Gawad Buhay’s Outstanding Male Lead Performer in a Modern Dance Production for his portrayal of Ibarra in Paul Morales’s Crisostomo Ibarra. A year later, he won the Gawad Buhay Award for Best Male Featured Performance in a Classical Dance Production for Sleeping Beauty,2011, where he danced in the Bluebird pas de deux. In 2007, Cordero braved his first competition at the New York International Ballet Competition, with his partner Candice Adea and coached by Victor Ursabia. Cordero and Adea also participated in the 2010 USA International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Mississippi, and the 2011 Korea International Ballet Competition in Seoul. Cordero was the first Filipino to qualify for the semifinal round of the Boston International Ballet Competition in 2011, and to win a lead role in a special performance in Russia. Through pas de deux competition pieces Don Quixote, Diana and Acteon, and Bam Damian’s Evacuation, he also won the Special Jury Award for Best Pas de Deux Technique in the 2012 Helsinki International Ballet Competition.Written by Anna Camille Fabella

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Joy Coronel and Steve Villaruz in CCP Dance Workshop’s Doxology, 1970

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
CORONEL, JOY ( Joy Geronimo Coronel )b. Manila 9 Nov 1951. Dancer, actor, choreographer. The daughter of business executive Pacita Geronimo and architect Leopoldo Coronel, she is married to dancer-actor James Gregory Paolelli. She holds a bachelor of arts in English from Assumption Convent and another degree in fine arts, major in advertising, from the University of Santo Tomas. Her dance training was wide-ranging: ballet with JojiFelix-Velarde, EddieElejar, CesarMendoza, and IsraelGabriel; moderndance with AliceReyes, TonyFabella, Norman Walker, and Pauline Koner; and Polynesiandance with Nati Bass. In New York, she trained in the schools of Martha Graham and Alvin Ailey, with Douglas Wassell, Lawrence Rhodes, Richard Thomas, Ron Forella, Jojo Smith, Nat Horne, Chuck Kelly, and Luigi. She studied acting with Chuck Golden and Aida Limjoco, and singing with David Brooks and Edna Meesek Mason.

Coronel has performed with DanceTheaterPhilippines, Ballet Philippines, and the Julie Borromeo Dance Company. In New York she danced with Saeko Ichinoche, Flower Hujer Dance Theater, Philippine Dance Company of New York, Folklorico Filipino, All Nations Dance Company, Kanikapila Polynesian Company, and the Radio City Music Hall. These troupes brought her to Europe, Central America and the Caribbean, the Middle East, Asia, Australia, and all over the United States. As an actor, she performed in Broadway presentations like Wuthering Heights, Helen of Troy, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, and Orpheus Descending.

She founded and choreographed for the Philippine Contemporary Dance Ensemble in New York, creating ethnic-derived dances like Handurawan (Reverie), Salip, Itik (Duck), Fandango, Yakan, Muslim, Kulintangan (Gongs), Hatinggabi (Midnight), and Pag-ibig (Love). She staged Philippine dances for the Asian-American Dance Theatre and the All Nations Dance Company. For the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) Summer Dance Workshop, she choreographed Old Avenue, Cabaret, Dancin’, Tango Argentino,and for the Metropolitan Dance Theater, Kulintangan.

Since her return to Manila in 1989, she has taught for the Metropolitan Dance Theater, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP Dance School, ShoeMart Dance Studio, Dance Arts Studio, and the Dance Alliance in National Choreographic Endeavor (DANCE), and is artistic director for Prima Modarina.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
The ballet pupils of Luva Adameit at the Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School in Manila, including Leonor Orosa-Goquingco,

Remedios "Totoy" de Oteyza, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Maria Luisa "Inday" Gaston-Mañosa, Chloe Cruz-Romulo,

Joji Felix-Velarde, Pacita Madrigal, Fely Franquelli, Esperanza Santos, and Elsie Uytiepo Torrejon

(Photo courtesy of Rosalia Merino-Santos)

text: COSMOPOLITAN BALLET AND DANCING SCHOOL It was founded around 1927 in Manila by LuvaAdameit, with her impresario-manager, G. Leibovitz, and pianist Ivan Sitnik.
