The school produced annual recitals that displayed a number of international character dances and some stylizations of Philippine folkdances into ballet. Although there were other schools, such as those of Kay Williams, Carmen MacLeod, Olga Donstsoff, Vladimir Bolsky, Katrina Makarova, and Mara Selheim, Adameit’s school produced the distinguished dancers of the time and pioneer choreographers and directors who founded their own schools and companies. Among these were LeonorOrosa-Goquingco, Pacita Madrigal-Warns, RemediosdeOteyza, RosaliaMerino-Santos, IndayGaston-Mañosa, JojiFelix-Velarde, ChloeCruz-Romulo, Elsie Uytiepo Torrejon, and Esperanza Santos, who founded the Adameit Ballet School. With Adameit as choreographer, the school presented recitals at the Manila Grand Opera House and Metropolitan Theater. She is credited with pieces that used Filipino folk dances in the ballet idiom.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Arturo V. Cruz

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
CRUZ, ARTURO ( Arturo Valera Cruz ) b. Pasay City 20 Apr 1933. d. 11 Nov 1998. Dancer, costume and set designer. He and choreographer Eric V. Cruz are sons of Juan Cruz and Natividad Valera and nephews of fashion designer and National Artist Ramon Valera. He studied fine arts at the University of the Philippines, where he obtained a degree in business administration. Later he took commercial arts at the University of Santo Tomas while studying ballet with Leonor Orosa-Goquingco and then with Remedios de Oteyza. Cruz first worked in a bank, then with couturier shops, before starting to create his own designs and joining Karilagan International. He first designed costumes and sets for Orosa-Goquingco’s production of Firebird and The Clowns, both in 1957, at the Far Eastern University (FEU) auditorium. Later he designed for the Hariraya Dance Company, the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, and still later, for Conchita Sunico’s productions at the restored Metropolitan Theater.

For Reyes’s company, which became Ballet Philippines, Cruz designed costumes for Amada, Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), Noche Buena (Christmas Eve Celebration), At a Maranaw Gathering, Jewels, and Negro Spirituals, 1970; Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), 1971; Kulas na Batugan (Kulas the Lazy), Anting-anting (Amulet), Ang Sultan (The Sultan), Orpheus Descending, 1973; Prince of the Pagodas and The Nutcracker, 1976; Prelude, 1977; Mir-i-nisa Act II and Tchaikovsky Piano Concert No 1, 1979; and Snow White, 1988.

Cruz also did set and costume designs for Philippine Ballet Theatre’s Paquita,1993; Camille,1991; Merry Widow, and Coppelia, 1989; and Filipino ballets Vinta, Ritual Bonds, The Offering, and La Lampara (The Lamp), 1991; and Company,1991. In 2014, he created the costume design for Andres KKK: Ang Buhay at Pag-ibig ni Andres Bonifacio (Andres KKK: The Life and Love of Andres Bonifacio).

For the Manila Metropolitan Theater, he created the designs for Kismet, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), Taghoy ng Troya ( Trojan Women ), Turandot, My Fair Lady, Camelot, Best of Broadway, and Carisma Filipina (FilipinoCharisma).Written by G. Castro, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Eric V. Cruz

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
CRUZ, ERIC ( Eric Valera Cruz ) b. Ermita, Manila 6 Jun 1940 d. Alabang, Muntinlupa City 12 Feb 2003. Dancer, choreographer, and designer for costume, lighting and scenery. His parents are Juan Cruz and Natividad Valera. Dancer and costume and set designer Arturo Cruz is his brother, and fashion designer and National Artist Ramon Valera is his maternal uncle. He holds both a bachelor’s and master’s degrees in fine arts from the University of the Philippines (UP).

Cruz started dance training with Leonor Orosa-Goquingco as a member of the Filipinescas Dance Company in 1958. By 1961, as its principal dancer, he was touring internationally with the company. He continued training with Remedios de Oteyza and Inday Gaston-Mañosa as a member of the Hariraya Dance Company, where he danced leading roles. In 1970, Cruz and Vella Damian founded Dance Concert Company (DCC), for which he started to do choreography.

As artistic director of DCC, Cruz choreographed in the 1970s and 1980s Minkusiana, Panaginip (Dream), originally to “Reverie” by Jules Massenet, then to A. Molina; Ang Katipunero (The Katipunero), originally The Spartacus pas de deux to A. Khatchaturian; Visions in Blue to Antonio Vivaldi; Mir-i-nisa to Eliseo Pajaro; and the full-evening The Interior Castle about Saint Theresa of Avila, to Manuel Maramba. Cruz created most of Damian’s roles in Don Quixote and Carmen, Medea, and the full-evening La Gitana, and Camille, both to music by Jeffrey Ching. He and Damian took DCC to Guam and Beijing with artists from Ballet Philippines (BP) and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). He designed most of the costumes, sets, and lights for DCC, and later lighted for PBT.

Cruz was a UP artist-in-residence for theater production design, 1980-83, while he was faculty in design and clothing technology at the College of Home Economics. The college gave him the Golden Jubilee Professorial Chair, 1989-90 and published his book titled The Terno: Its Development and Identity as the Filipino Women’s National Costume.Written by G. Mary Jane L. Globio, Mena Ojeda, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jose Jay Cruz

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Jose Jay Cruz

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
CRUZ, JOSE JAY ( Jose Jay Belga Cruz )b. 2 Jun 1970. Choreographer, dancer, theater director, playwright, acting coach. Cruz is the son of Alfred Cruz and Yolanda Belga. He majored in film and audio-visual communication at the College of Mass Communication, University of the Philippines, from 1987 to 1991. He later turned to theater, major in performing (directing) from 1993 to 1995, and was influenced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s (PETA) mode of production.

Cruz trained in a summer program with Ballet Philippines, and as dance minor at the UP College of Music Dance program under Basilio Esteban Villaruz, and with Myra Beltran’s Dance Forum. He decided to explore the emerging form of solo dance after the First Asia-Europe Dance Forum in Singapore in 2001. As a solo dancer, he joined festivals in Hong Kong, Copenhagen, Barcelona, Korea, Shanghai, and Japan. In 2009 he was the recipient of the Asian Cultural Council’s Josie Natori Award in New York, where he studied choreography and dance composition. In the same year he became guest mentor for the OMI International Dance Collective residency, NYC, and was featured under the Visiting Artist program of the Bates Dance Festival. He started Dancing Wounded Contemporary Dance Commune in 2003, later renaming it to Transitopia, where he acts as artistic director and curator.

Among his important choreographies are Love is Pretty Ugly, 2006; HomoSentimental, which he performed at festivals in Copenhagen and Barcelona, 2002, and Hong Kong, 2006; Gestures of the Flesh — A Dance Meditation on the words of Jaime Gil De Biedma, which was selected as finalist under the solo/duo category of the 2007 Yokohama Dance Collection; and his solo work Contemporary Investigation Number One,which premiered in New York, 2009, and brought him to the 35th International Festival of Dance in France, 2013. This work initiated the project Contemporary CorpoReality - Reconfiguring the “Dancing Body” for the New Reality of the 21st century, a grantee of the Prince Claus Fund in 2011, and again in 2013, for the second dance residency of the CorpoReality series, HyperCorporeality Colab.

He was awarded second prize for his one-act play, Ang Mahabang Patlang (A Mile Gap) in the 1996 Carlos Palanca Awards for Literature. In 1997, for his Kuwentong Asyano (Asian Tales), which he directed, PETA was given the NCCA Alab ng Haraya, Best in Theater Performance award. In 1999 he became a fellow at the UP Writers Workshop. Cruz has also coached actors for some of GMA Network's primetime drama series.Written by Chantal Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Chloe Cruz-Romulo (Photo from The Lopez Family, A Photo Album)
Chloe Cruz-Romulo in the December 1963 issue of The Asia Magazine

text:
CRUZ-ROMULO, CHLOE ( Chloe Hizon Cruz-Romulo )b. Manila 6 Feb 1932. Dancer, teacher. Born to concert pianist Caridad Hizon and Cornelio Cruz, Cruz-Romulo is the widow of Gregorio Romulo, with whom she had three children. She had her early education at St. Theresa’s College and Assumption Convent. At Georgian Court College in New Jersey, she studied music, major in piano, and dance. She began ballet at age four with LuvaAdameit, and during World War II took lessons with PaulSzilard, continuing with RemediosdeOteyza after the war. In New York, she studied at the Ballet Arts Studio at Carnegie Hall. She also specialized in Spanishdance, having trained with Josefina Sabater and Teresa Ecusias at age 8 to 12. She went to Madrid, Spain, and performed there with Puro Reyes and the Sevillas.

In 1952-56, Cruz-Romulo taught ballet and Spanish dance in Silay, Bacolod, and Iloilo cities. Later, in 1964, she developed a specialized program using dance as therapy for patients recovering from surgical operations.

She also got involved in stage musicals. Her longest-running performance was as Eliza Doolittle in My FairLady (16 performances) directed by James B. Reuter,SJ.

She also served as president of the ManilaSymphonySociety and took charge of its concerts at the Luneta Park. She worked with Teodoro Valencia to get sponsors for the free concerts and to give regular salaries to the orchestra members. As a director of Friends of the CCP, she has handled its special events since 1989.Written by Malou L. Maniquis

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
CULTURAL CENTER OF THE PHILIPPINES (CCP) The CCP is the leading institution in the country that plans and implements programs for the development and promotion of the arts—music, dance, theater, visual, literary, cinematic, and broadcast arts. Since 1969 when it was created by Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, it has sponsored programs and activities such as festivals, exhibitions, competitions, and publications to preserve, promote, and enhance the artistic and cultural heritage of the Filipino people, and to develop audiences that will appreciate and support artistic and cultural work. It is home to nine resident companies that present regular seasons of productions, workshops, and outreach performances: Ballet Philippines , Bayanihan Philippine NationalFolkDance Company, Philippine Ballet Theatre, Philippine Madrigal Singers, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Tanghalang Pilipino, and UST Symphony Orchestra.

Sitting on a 60-hectare complex on Roxas Boulevard in Pasay City, the CCP is part of a vast international network of arts and culture organizations that provide exchange opportunities between Filipino artists and artists from all over the world. This network also brings in performances and exhibitions that allow local audiences to experience arts and cultures from elsewhere. These organizations include the Association of Asia Pacific Performing Arts Center, the Conseil International des Organisations de Festivals de Folklore et d’Arts Traditionnels, the World Dance Alliance, the International Theater Institute, the Asian Theater Alliance, the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, and the ASEAN–Korea Traditional Music Orchestra.

The CCP is composed of several departments that promote arts education, direct outreach and exchange programs all over the country, mount productions and exhibitions, manage cultural holdings, and develop its assets. In its first two decades the CCP focused on what were later perceived as elitist performing arts—theater, ballet, opera, and similar shows—a bias that was shaped by its first board of trustees chair, then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos. Following the successful EDSA revolt against Marcos and his martial rule and the subsequent change in the country’s leadership, the CCP expanded its scope to include literature, film, and broadcast arts, among others. It also reoriented its direction to emphasize original Filipino artistic and cultural expressions rooted in the Philippines and the participation of the regions in the definition of a national culture.

Music. The CCP is home to the country’s premier symphonic orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). Established in 1973, the PPO (then known as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra) initially accompanied local and foreign performing artists at the CCP. It later evolved as one of the best music ensembles in the Asia-Pacific region, premiering works by Filipino and foreign composers, and promoting music appreciation throughout the country. Past conductors and musical directors of the PPO include Luis Valencia, Oscar Yatco, Ruggero Barbieri, Olivier Ochanine, and Yoshikazu Fukumura.Among the internationally renowned conductors who have performed with the PPO are Mendi Rodan, Piero Gamba, Enrique Batis, Sebastian Bereau, and Nicholas Koch. Some of the world’s best Filipino and foreign artists have also performed with the PPO, including Van Cliburn, Renata Tebaldi, Judith Engel, Anthony Camden, David Benoit, Cecile Licad, Raul Sunico, and Lea Salonga . The PPO is now on its 34th concert season. It has toured in Europe, Asia, and more recently, the United States, when it performed for the first time at the Carnegie Hall. Aside from its regular concert seasons at the CCP, the PPO also participates in the CCP Outreach Program by performing in public spaces and conducting workshops in the provinces.

Another resident company of the CCP is the Philippine Madrigal Singers. Organized in 1963 by Andrea O. Veneracion, later National Artist for music, the choir is composed of students, teachers, and alumni from the various colleges of the University of the Philippines. Performing a wide repertoire of various styles and forms, the ensemble has consistently won all the top prizes in most of the world’s prestigious choral competitions. The choir also maintains an active outreach and concert schedule every year and is regarded as one of the country’s most active ambassadors of goodwill and one of the world’s most traveled choirs.

The UST Symphony Orchestra is also a resident performing group of the CCP. It holds regular concerts at the CCP and participates in the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program. It also serves as a pool for additional players as the needs of the PPO dictate.

In 1987, the CCP launched the Filipino Artists Series (FAS), a monthly program featuring solo performances of acclaimed and emerging Filipino musical artists. Among those featured in the FAS were bass baritone Jonathan Zaens; flutist Antonio Maigue; cellist Wilfredo Pasamba; pianists Corazon Kabayao, Mariel Illusorio, Peter Porticos, and Rene Dalandan; violinists Gilopez Kabayao , Gina Medina, and Denise Huang; and sopranos Clarissa Ocampo and Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro. FAS was discontinued in 2009 but was later revived in 2012 as the Special Concert Series. Some of the performing artists in this series are pianist Charisse Baldoria, soprano Katrina Saporsantos, cellist Antoni Josef Inacay, trumpet player Raymond de Leon, percussionist Aimee Mina dela Cruz, and flutist Sarah Mae Gabuyo.

The CCP also embarked on the production of Filipino operas as well as Western operas that were adapted to a Philippine setting. In 1970, it partnered with the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines in producing El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the operatic adaptation of Jose Rizal ’s novel, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon and libretto by Guillermo Tolentino. De Leon and Tolentino’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), first staged at the FEU Auditorium in 1957, was also restaged at the CCP in 1974, with Don David as Ibarra, Ruby Salazar as Maria Clara, Jimmy Melendres as Padre Damaso, and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa. In 1984, the CCP and Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines commissioned Francisco Feliciano to create the three-act opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), with libretto by Cuyugan-Asensio. In 1987, the CCP partnered with Music Theater Foundation in another restaging of Noli… this time with Nolyn Cabahug as Ibarra, Andion Fernandez as Maria Clara, and Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa (alternating with Luz Morete). Rolando Tinio’s Philippine adaptation of La Traviata and La Boheme were also produced by and staged at the CCP in 1991 and 1992, respectively. Two major opera productions of the CCP in the 21st century were Spoliarium , 2003, and Madame Butterfly, 2012. Spoliarium was inspired by Juan Luna ’s life and masterpiece, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, and co-produced by the CCP with the Opera Guild of the Philippines and Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines. Madame Butterfly was a co-production of the CCP and MusicArtes, Inc, with director Anton Juan giving local flavor to Puccini’s famous opera.

The CCP is also the organizer and main proponent of major music festivals including the biennial Andrea Veneracion International Choral Festival and the CCP International Jazz Festival which was merged with the Orchestra and Symphonic Band Festival, and the annual Flute/Woodwind Festival. It has also been actively supporting the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) since its inception in 1973. The CCP Arts Education Department also organizes masterclasses of renowned musical artists as well as yearly workshops in rondalla music, choral music, and band music.

Dance. The CCP has four resident dance companies: Ballet Philippines (BP), which is based at the CCP Main Building, and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFC) which are all based outside the CCP.

Since its founding in 1969, BP has performed over 400 works at the CCP, ranging from full-length classical ballets to modern dance and neo-ethnic pieces, under its founding artistic director Alice Reyes, later National Artist for Dance, and after her, Denisa Reyes, Cecile Sicangco , Noordin Jumalon , Alden Lugnasin, Augustus Damian III, Alan Hineline, Max Luna III, and Paul Moral es . The company has also collaborated with prominent foreign and local choreographers, dancers, librettists, actors, and set, costume, and lighting designers. Notable productions of BP include Amada, Itim Asu (The Onyx Wolf), Rama, Hari, Tales of the Manuvu, Te Deum, For the Gods, Encantada (Enchantress), and La Revolucion Filipina (The Filipino Revolution). It has also produced some of the country’s top ballet dancers who have undergone training at BP’s official school, the CCP Dance School. BP also stages the yearly Neo-Filipino, a dance showcase featuring the latest works of the best and leading choreographers in the country.

Founded in 1987 by artistic directors of different ballet companies, PBT has become one of the country’s leading dance companies specializing in classical ballet. PBT’s regular performance season at the CCP consists of such classics as Romeo and Juliet , Carmen, The N utcracker, Cinderella, Carmina Burana, and Swan Lake. PBT has been managed by a series of artistic directors, all belonging to the PBT Council, namely, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Julie Borromeo, Eddie Elejar, Gener Caringal, and Ronilo Jaynario.

The Bayanihan, under choreographer Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, later National Artist for Dance, and later, under executive director Susie Benitez and dance director-choreographer Ferdinand Jose, and the ROFG under artistic director Ramon Obusan, later National Artist for dance, and later, under Dulce Obusan, have been acclaimed nationally and worldwide for their continuing efforts to research, perform, preserve, and perpetuate Philippine folk music and dance traditions. Both companies participate in CCP’s outreach programs by conducting folk dance workshops around the country.

Dance-related festivals organized or initiated by the CCP include the Pang-alay, which featured different Philippine folk dance groups; the Fiesta Folkloriada, an annual festival of folk dance groups all over the world where the Bayanihan is an active participant; the biennial CCP Ballet Festival where various ballet schools in the country gather and perform classical, modern, and neo-ethnic works; and Dance.MNL: The Philippine Dance Festival which was held for the first time in 2016. Dance.MNL is also intended to be a biennial festival which aims to unite and celebrate the Filipino dance community.

The CCP has also given grants or financial assistance to local dance groups which represented the Philippines in international competitions or festivals. Among the grantees were the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Dureza Ballet School, Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance, and St Anne’s Dance and Music Studio in 1988; Dance TheaterPhilippines, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, St Anne Dance Theater Company (Taguig), La Salle Dance Troupe, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Odon Sabarre and the People’s Center School of Dance, and Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center in 1989; Dance Concert Company and Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in 1990; and Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement, Chameleon Dance Company, Araullo University Dance Troupe, and Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe in 1991.

In 2014, the CCP launched its first ever Ballet Competition held at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino. The biennial competition has a Junior and Senior category and requires contestants to perform both classical and contemporary pieces.

Theater. The CCP, in partnership with the NCCA, has organized the National Theater Festival (NTF), a quinquennial event that gathers theater artists, practitioners, scholars, and enthusiasts from all over the country in a 10-day celebration of the latest achievements in Philippine theater. The NTF, which started in 1992 and was last held in 2012, usually includes performances from various theater groups, a conference, exhibits, and film screenings.

During the first NTF, production and festival grants, as well as six workshop and one research grant, were given to the nine participating regional theater groups. These are Adela Community Organization of Silay City, Negros Occidental; the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc.-UHAY of Malolos, Bulacan; Cebu Central Colleges Theater Workshop Company and University of San Carlos Theater Guild of Cebu City; Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo City; Komedya ng San Dionisio of Paranaque; Kulturang Atin Foundation Inc., and Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao City; and the Salidummay Music Theater Company and Tadec Group of Baguio City. Production grants were also given to seven Metro Manila-based groups, namely Bulwagang Gantimpala, Dulaang UP, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, and Tanghalang Pilipino. Many other groups have availed of these grants in subsequent CCP National Theater Festivals.

The CCP has also supported theater groups outside Metro Manila through its Outreach and Exchange Unit. It provided financial assistance to deserving applicants for the touring of produced local productions to different sites within the region. Theater companies that received touring grants are: in 1988, the Dula Agus Ensemble of Butuan City, Salidummay of the Cordillera, and Teatro Amakan of Iloilo; in 1989, the Sining Pananadem in Marawi City, Dance Theater of Tacloban City, and Susi ng Tayabas in Quezon; in 1991, Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna and the Adela Community Organization from Silay City, Negros Occidental; in 1992, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble of the Mindanao State University and the Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao; in 2014, the community-based theater guild in Sorsogon, Teatro Ambahanon and Kabpapagariya Ensemble of General Santos City, the Youth Advocates thru Theater Arts in Dumaguete City, the Integrated Performing Arts Guild in Iligan City, and the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble in Marawi City; and in 2015, Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc. of Malolos City, Artista Sillimania of Dumaguete City, Kuntaw Mindanao of Davao del Norte, and Kaliwat Performing Arts Collective of Davao City. Meanwhile, production venue and full grants were given to Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, UP Playwrights Theater, Telon, Sining Silangan, Philippine Drama Company, UP Repertory Company, Teatro Santa Ana, and Teatro Umalohokan.

In 1994, the CCP Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts awarded playwriting fellowships to four writers, giving them cash grants to develop their full-length plays. The fellows chosen were JB Capino for his play Los Indios Bravos (The Brave Natives), Dennis Marasigan for Aves de Rapina (Birds of Prey), V. E. Carmelo Nadera for Hermano Puli, and Bebot Rodil for Datu Matu.

Prior to its reorganization after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the CCP was the home of two local theater companies: Teatro Pilipino, under artistic director Rolando Tinio, and Bulwagang Gantimpala Theater, under artistic director Tony Espejo. Teatro Pilipino, the first resident theater company of the CCP from 1976-86, staged Filipino translations of plays by William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, August Strindberg, and Tennessee Williams, as well as a few Filipino works like Francisco Baltazar ’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Bienvenido M. Noriega ’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), and Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason).

Bulwagang Gantimpala started out as the production arm of the winning works from the CCP Literary and Playwriting Contest. It staged original Filipino works like Jomar Fleras ’s adaptation of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, titled Kanser (Cancer), Bonifacio Ilagan ’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), Rene O. Villanueva ’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), and Noriega’s Bongbong at Kris (Bongbong and Kris). In 1987, it became an independent theater company and has since moved its office elsewhere.

Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) is now the resident drama company of the CCP. Established in 1987, TP has staged more than 150 productions and is now on its 30th season. Its founding artistic director was Nonon Padilla who directed the company for 17 years until he was replaced by Herbie Go, Dennis Marasigan, and Nanding Josef. Its repertoire consists of original works by Filipino playwrights, restagings of Filipino sarsuwela, and translations and adaptations of foreign plays. TP maintains a stable of professional actors known as the Tanghalang Pilipino Actors’ Company. The company regularly conducts acting workshops and has also toured some of its productions in various provinces.

TP has also partnered with the CCP, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and the Writer’s Bloc, Inc. in producing the highly successful Virgin Labfest , a laboratory festival of new, unproduced, and untested one-act plays by amateur and veteran playwrights. This yearly project which started in 2005 has now become one of the most anticipated theater events in the country and has also produced a canon of acclaimed works.

In 2011, the CCP and the NCCA organized the first Monodrama Festival, a four-day event featuring monologues and one-actor performances. In 2013, the CCP produced Triple Threats, a series of concerts featuring the stalwarts of Philippine musical theater. Among the artists who have performed for this series are Nonie Buencamino, Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, Audie Gemora, and Bituin Escalante. The series has also featured composers Rony Fortich and Vincent de Jesus in 2015 and ensemble players in 2016.

Visual Arts. The CCP through its Visual Arts and Museum Division (VAMD) implements and manages the year-round contemporary art, design, and festival-related exhibitions at the various venues at the CCP. These exhibitions provide a showcase for current directions, trends, and movements in Philippine contemporary art, including the fields of architecture, sculpture, photography, digital art, and the allied arts. Aside from managing exhibit venues, providing curatorial assistance, and organizing forums, lectures, and talkback sessions with artists and designers, the VAMD also coordinates with the visual arts community on the activities and concerns of the visual artists all over the country.

The VAMD has organized and presented exhibits featuring artworks of notable Filipino artists among them: Fernando Amorsolo, Victorio Edades, Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, H. R. Ocampo, Vicente Manansala, Fernando Zobel, Lee Aguinaldo, Constancio Bernardo, Jose Joya, Napoleon Abueva, Roberto Chabet, Arturo Luz, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Ang Kiukok, Justiniano Nuyda, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Romulo Olazo, Ray Albano, Nonon Padilla, Prudencio Lamarroza, Impy Pilapil, Ileana Lee, Danilo Dalena, Onib Olmedo, Jaime de Guzman, Julie Lluch, Solomon Saprid, Ben Maramag, Bencab, Tony Velasquez, Mars Ravelo, Francisco Coching, Roberto Feleo, Kidlat Tahimik, Mark Justiniani, Karen Flores , Claude Tayag, and Agnes Arellano. The VAMD has also presented exhibits of artists’ groups such as the Social Realists, Kasibulan Women Artists, Paete artists, Black Artists of Asia, Abstract Expressionists, Figurative Expressionists, Mabini Art Movement, Salingpusa, Baguio Arts Guild, VIVA Excon, and artists from various schools like the University of the Philippines, University of Santo Tomas, and the Philippine High School for the Arts.

The VAMD also gives recognition to Filipino artists through the 13 Artists Awards. Started by former CCP museum director Roberto Chabet in 1970, the 13 Artists Awards later became a biennial award under the management of Ray Albano, and a triennial award in 2009. The award is given to artists who take “the chance and risk to restructure, restrengthen, and renew art making and art thinking.” Since 2009, the recognition has been given to more than 170 artists in the fields of painting, sculpture, mixed and multi-media, and installation art. The most recent awarding was held in 2018 and the recipients were Zeus Bascon, Bea Camacho, Cian Dayrit, Janos Dela Cruz, Carlo Gabuco, Dina Gadia, Guerrero Habulan, Eisa Jocson, Doktor Karayom, Raffy Napay, Archie Oclos, Lynyrd Paras, and Shireen Seno. The awarding usually coincides with a month-long exhibition of the awardees’ works.

Literature. The Literary Arts division of the CCP, now known as the Intertextual Division (ID), undertakes activities that deal with literary text, performance text, and hypertext. Among its accomplishments is the publication of ANI (Harvest), a literary journal which is now on its 39th edition. The journal features short stories, essays, and poems in Filipino, English, and other Philippine languages. It also took care of other CCP special publications like Himala y Balagtas and Himalay Rizal.

In previous years, the CCP sponsored literary contests and awarded writing grants to writers in Filipino, English, and the major regional languages. It began sponsoring a playwriting contest in 1969 in both English and Filipino. The first winners of the CCP Playwriting Contest were: In Frailty’s Grace by Elsa V. Martinez, first prize; And the Day But One by Jose Ma. Hernandez, second; and The Onyx Wolf by Virginia Moreno, third; Tabak at Tanikala (Bolo and Chain) by Dionisio S. Salazar; Status Quo by Angel R. Makiling, and Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss the Sword) by Cipriano V. Ilagan, honorable mention.

A verse writing category was added in 1973. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Interior), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for “Doktrinang Anakpawis” (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The following categories were added in 1974: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel, won by Benjamin P. Pascual for “Utos ng Hari” (King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age). A biography category was added in 1979. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980 in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize when the award for the category was resumed in 1984 for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).

A new category—criticism—was added in 1984. In the English division, an Appreciation Award was shared among Nick Nicolas Jr for “Theater, Films and Others: A Compendium of Critical Reviews,” Wilhelmina Q. Ramas for “Sugbuanon Theater: From Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar,” and Soledad S. Reyes for “Criticism and Ideology.” In the Filipino division, the grand prize in criticism was given to Virgilio S. Almario for “Taludtod at Talinghaga: Mga Sangkap ng Katutubong Pagtula” (Verses and Metaphor: The Elements of Folk Poetry).

In 1987, the annual literary contest was transformed into the Gawad CCP Para sa Panatikan under the supervision of the CCP’s Coordinating Center for Literature. The contest dropped the English category in favor of an all-Filipino rule. The categories were poetry, short story, one-act play, three-act play, dance libretto (one-act dance drama), and the full-length musical drama.

The winners in the poetry category that year were Fidel D. Rillo for “Musa Insurekta” (Insurgent Muse), first prize; Teo Antonio for “Cespora Personata at Iba Pang Pagbubulay-bulay” (Cespora Personata and Other Ruminations), second prize; and Danton Remoto for “Kuwaderno” (Notebook), third prize. In the short story category, the winners were Reynaldo Duque for “Ang Gamugamo sa Lampara ni Julio Madarang” (The Firefly About Julio Madarang’s Lamp), first prize; Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez for “Kulas,” second prize; and Tomas F. Agulto for “Ang Walang Lubay na Istasyon ng Pag-asa at Paghahanap” (The Eternal Station of Hope and Searching), third prize. The critical essay category on the different arts was instituted a year later.

The winning poems and stories in the Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan have also been published in ANI, while the critical works have appeared in Kultura, the CCP magazine for critical essays. The Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan was discontinued in 1990.

The CCP has also given grants to writers who applied for writing grants for drama in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in the performing arts. Grantees in drama are Reynaldo Duque, 1988, and Jose A. Bragado, 1989, for Ilocano; Ruperto Alaura, 1988, RobertoVillanueva, 1989, and Leonilo Estimo, 1993, for Cebuano; Carlos Ojeda Aureus, 1992, for Bicolano; Julian Jagudilla, 1989 and 1990, andJose Galiza and Eugenio de Pablo, 1991, for Hiligaynon/Karay-a; and Rene O. Villanueva, 1988, and Ariel N. Valerio, 1993, for Filipino.

In 2015, the ID spearheaded the biennial event called Performatura 2015, Performing Literatures, a three-day intertextual festival held in various venues at the CCP. The event included conversations with National Artists; Chromatext Rebooted, an exhibit merging text and visual arts; performance poetry featuring young poets; and workshops on the poetic joust balagtasan, speech choir, and ventriloquism.

Film. The Media Arts Division is the main implementor of the CCP’s year-round film, broadcast, and emerging media events, which include screenings, productions, festivals, awards, workshops, and fora. It also coordinates with all sectors of the film community—both local and international, independent and mainstream, contemporary and classic.

In 1987, the CCP started to give recognition to Filipino alternative films and video. Known as the Gawad CCP Para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Bidyo or Gawad Alternatibo, this is considered the longest-running independent film competition of its kind in the Asian region. Gawad Alternatibo annually cites the best efforts of Pinoy filmmakers in four categories: Animation, Experimental, Documentary, and Short Feature. Each winner receives a cash prize and a certificate. Special citations are also awarded to the best work from the regions, as well as works on/for/by children. Many of today’s outstanding filmmakers and media practitioners are awardees of Gawad Alternatibo.

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival is one of the CCP’s most important cinema-related undertakings every year. Established in 2004, the festival has given birth to some of Philippine cinema’s contemporary masterpieces and is regarded as one of the most prestigious independent film competitions in the country, and a much awaited cultural event as well. Some of today’s acclaimed filmmakers have launched their careers via the annual festival and competition, including Kanakan Balintagos aka Aureaus Solito, Lawrence Fajardo, Chris Martinez, Jun Robles Lana, Alvin B. Yapan, Francis Pasion, and Eduardo Roy Jr. Simultaneous film-related events are also held during the festival, including the Cinemalaya Film Congress, a two-day conference that looks at all aspects of independent filmmaking and distribution; the Cinemalaya Sine Taktakan, a forum with the year’s batch of new Cinemalaya filmmakers; exhibitions that include Tributes to Past Indie Mavericks of Pinoy Cinema; a Cinemalaya Kids’ Treats; World Premieres of New Digital Works (the Cinemalaya/NETPAC Prize); and a host of other activities.

The CCP also holds annual film lectures and retrospectives on Filipino filmmakers and actors, like Gerardo de Leon, Manuel Conde, Lucia no B. Carlos , Mona Lisa, Jaclyn Jose, and Fernando Poe Jr, as well as foreign film artists like Akira Kurosawa, Isabelle Huppert, and Olivier Assayas.

Broadcast Arts. In recognition of the broad reach and powerful influence of radio and television, the CCP established in 1987 a Coordinating Center for Broadcast Arts which was one of the units of the then Visual, Literary, and Media Arts Department. While all these units have been replaced by the Media Arts Division, the CCP—then and now—has continued efforts to equip ordinary citizens with the skills to produce radio programs and videos that reflect their realities and that allow them to promote their sectoral interests through broadcasting. It conducts hands-on training-workshops on radio and television production and scriptwriting, accepts apprenticeships, and awards production grants. While bringing its training program to as far north as Batanes and as far south as Tawi-tawi, the CCP encourages the use of Filipino languages in the programs and videos produced by its trainees. Among those who complete the training programs and are given grants to produce their own radio programs are farmers, fisherfolk, social development and cultural workers, students, and local leaders who produce and host talk shows, historical documentaries, instructional programs, public service announcements, music shows, and dramatizations of Filipino myths and legends. Their productions are aired in cooperation with local radio stations.

The CCP produces television programs as well as videos. In 1990 it produced Pinoy Eh, a magazine show aired on ABC Channel 5. Directed by Marilou-Diaz-Abaya and hosted by Ces Quesada, it had 13 episodes on such topics as the Filipino language, music, cinema, architecture, literature, dance, rituals, ethnic groups, and places. Another television production is the 1992 13-episode drama series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) based on Jose Rizal’s novel, written and directed by National Artist for cinema Eddie Romero, starring Joel Torre and Chin-chin Gutierrez. The series is also available in DVD. The Red Carpet was a monthly program aired on Net 25 in 2009-12, featuring the shows at CCP and the cultural and artistic scene in the country. On Set, also on Net 25, 2009-12, highlighted the country’s top caliber artists such as Lea Salonga, Ryan Cayabyab, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

CCP is also on radio. Following the 1986 EDSA revolt, it produced the weekly radio magazine Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), aired on DZRV in 1986-92, then on DZRM until 1996. It featured Filipino music and theater, talked about arts and culture in the Philippines, and held the balagtasan on current socio-political issues. Among CCP’s current radio programs is the weekly Culture Carousel, which has been airing on DZFE since 1990. It features CCP music artists as well as visiting music artists and airs their performances. Another production is DiskArte (Artistic Strategy) which discusses social issues using the arts. It airs on DZRH in partnership with the Manila Broadcasting Corporation (MBC). The program was formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon (Fight Corruption) which aired on DZRH in 2004-08 until it was reformatted. It was awarded The Freedom Project 2013 Jury Prize and the People’s Choice Award by The Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom of Germany. Another CCP radio production was the children’s show Wan Dey Isang Araw (One Day), aired on DZAS in 2005-13, which tried to revive the tradition of storytelling in the Philippines. It featured stories by Luis P. Gatmaitan, Eugene Evasco, Augie Rivera, and Grace Chong.

In 1987-98, the CCP gave out the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon (CCP Awards for Television), annually to outstanding television programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and other content producers. Among the awardees were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You) and Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), the drama series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Lovingly Yours, Helen, the children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong), the talk show Pep Talk, the public affairs programs Probe Team, Public Forum, and Viewpoint, and the gag show Sic O’Clock News. In 1990-1998, the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo (CCP Awards for Radio) was given at the same time as the television awards, to outstanding radio programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and music and sound designers. The radio awards were henceforth given every two years. Among the awardees in 1990 were the documentary Parangal (Tribute), on DZRM; the drama series Drama Filipina on DZEC, the arts and culture show Filipiniana on DZLC in Lucena, the music magazine shows Yukbo sa Musika on DYMR and Salam in sa Kaliwat on DXWG, both in Cebu, and radio pioneer Francisco “Koko” Trinidad for his contribution to Philippine radio.

Other Programs. The CCP organizes various year-round arts-affiliated events, such as Pasinaya, the biggest multi-arts festival in the country. Started in 2010, Pasinaya is an annual one-day open-house festival which serves as a gathering of CCP resident companies, patrons, and the general public. Simultaneous events are held in all of CCP’s venues, with designated zones for dance, theater, music, literature, film, visual arts, children and family, variety, and the artists market. There are also crash workshops, film screenings, visual arts exhibitions, food booths, and activities for children. Some of the resident companies also perform excerpts from their upcoming shows or past productions.

Outreach and exchange programs include: KUTITAP: Isang Piging ng Kabataang Makasining, an annual three-day event for children and young people that started in 2009 and is aimed at raising their awareness of and appreciation for indigenous arts, culture, and traditions; Ugnayan sa Sining, an annual series of cultural exchanges and community tours featuring some of the country’s prominent regional cultural groups; Lakbay Sining, a national touring program which features performances from CCP resident companies or art exhibitions previously mounted at the CCP; Kaisa sa Sining, a program which links CCP to regional cultural groups in order to facilitate regional cultural development, exchanges, artistic programs, and collaborations; Lakbay Sine, a project of CCP Media Arts Division; and Lakbay Harana , a joint project of the CCP and Tribung Pilipino Foundation which aims to promote and reawaken the public’s, and especially the young generation’s, interest and appreciation for Philippine traditional music like the kundiman, balitaw, danza, and immortal Filipino love songs. The CCP through its Cultural Exchange Department also provides local tour grants for regional performing groups. It is also active in giving art therapy workshops—called Kalinga ng Sining—in provincial areas devastated by natural calamities or armed conflicts.

The CCP has occasionally engaged in film production. It produced two movies: Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero, and Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

A heritage project of the CCP is the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art. First published in 1994, the CCP Encyclopedia remains to be the most authoritative and most comprehensive sourcebook on Philippine art, with volumes on the peoples of the Philippines, architecture, visual arts, dance, music, theater, film, literature, and broadcast arts. Prior to the encyclopedia, the CCP also published beginning in 1989, 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, known collectively as Tuklas Sining. The first essays on the seven arts were compiled and published in a coffee table book with the same title in 1991. To encourage the staging of more sarsuwela, the CCP came out with the sarsuwela series which made available to scholars and performing groups the scripts and music of the classic Tagalog sarsuwela Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), and Walang Sugat (No Wounds) as performed and staged by Tanghalang Pilipino. The initial publication in 1991 included the cassette tapes and books for Paglipas ng Dilim and Dalagang Bukid, and in 1994, for Walang Sugat. The videotaped performances of Dalagang Bukid and Walang Sugat were released in DVD format in 2007.

The Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is the highest recognition awarded by the CCP to artists or groups of artists who have produced a body of outstanding works and excelled in their chosen artform. The award is also given to cultural workers who have helped in enriching Philippine art through their works in research, curatorship, and administration. The Tanging Parangal is given to individuals or organizations to honor their outstanding contributions to the development of the arts in the country.The first Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, then called by another name, was given in 1977 to Hubertus Kuhne (for cultural administration). The award was given annually from 1989 up to 1994, and thereafter every three years. The most recent conferment was in 2015 and the awardees were: Denisa Reyes for Dance; Fides Cuyugan-Asensio for Music; Antonio Mabesa for Theater; Roberto Chabet for Visual Arts; Ricardo Lee for Literature; Nora Aunor for Film and Broadcast Arts; Paulo Alcazaren for Architecture; and Ben Farrales for Design.Leoncio Deriada, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Talaandig School of Living Traditions, and The Missionary Society of St. Columban received the Tanging Parangal.

The Order of the National Artists, the highest state honor given every three years to individuals who have made significant contributions in Philippine arts, was administered by the CCP from 1972 to 1992, and after that, by the CCP and NCCA. The award is conferred by the President of the Republic of the Philippines upon the recommendation of the CCP and NCCA.Fernando Amorsolo was posthumously conferred the first National Artist Award in 1977. The award was most recently conferred in 2018to Larry Alcala(visual arts, posthumous), Resil B. Mojares and Ramon Muzones (literature), Francisco Mañosa (architecture), Ryan Cayabyab(music), and Kidlat Tahimik (film).Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez, Lily Grace Tabanera, and Elmer L. Gatchalian

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Yvonne Cutaran, publicity photo for La Sylphide (Photo courtesy of the artist)
Yvonne Cutaran (Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Yvonne Cutaran, publicity photo for Don Quixote (Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
CUTARAN, YVONNE ( Yvonne Cutaran Fernandez ) b. Quezon City 16 Sep 1968. Dancer. Cutaran is the daughter of Jose Cutaran and Angelita Fernandez, a dancer from Kalibo, Aklan. She graduated from high school at the Montessori School in Pasay in 1986. At seven she trained in ballet with Vella Damian. She also trained under William Morgan and Ballet Philippines. She was Princess Florine and Fairy of the Golden Vine in BP’s The Sleeping Beauty, 1983, and the Sugarplum Fairy in Dance Concert Company’s The Nutcracker Suite, 1984.

In 1986, Cutaran joined as an apprentice of the Les Grands Ballets Canadiens in Montreal, Canada, and became one of its principal dancers in 1990. She danced in a reconstruction of Balanchine’s La Chatte, 1991; Coppelia, 1992; Before Nightfall and Jooss’s Green Tales, 1993; and Tudor’s Pillar of Fire, 1995. She likewise danced in Balanchine’s ballets, Agon, 1994; Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux, 1991-96; Principia, 1995; Divertimento No 150, 1995 and 1997; The Nutcracker, 1986-98; and Raymonda, 1987; and the works of Lar Lubovitch and Nacho Duato. In 1990, she danced with Miguel Gomez in the International Ballet Festival in Cuba, and in 1991, she joined the company tour of Asia.

In 1992 Cutaran guested with the Philippine Ballet Theatre in Coppelia. She also performed in Boston Ballet’s Waterbaby Bagatelles, 1994. In 1998, she began a three-year tour with La La La Human Steps, performing in Eduoard Lock’s Exaucé/Salt. She then performed with the Washington Ballet’s Peter Pan and Coyote Builds North America, 2001, under the direction of Molly Smith. With the Tucson Regional Ballet, she danced in The Southwest Nutcracker, 2002. In 2012, Cutaran joined the Ballet Classique de Haut-Richelieu.

Cutaran currently lives in Montreal, Canada, where she spends her time teaching dance and ballet at the L’École Des Axées Danse.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Augustus Damian III

text:
DAMIAN, AUGUSTUS III ( Augustus Fontanilla Damian )aka Bam Damian. b. 7 Mar 1964. Dancer. Damian is the son of Augustus Damian and Naomi Fontanilla, nephew of dancer-choreographer Vella Damian, and the brother of dancer/stage manager Ianne Damian. From 1981 to 1983, he studied architecture at the University of the Philippines. He first trained in ballet with his aunt Vella and then with prominent teachers in the Philippines and abroad. In the Philippines he danced principally with DanceConcertCompany (DCC) and was a member of the UPFilipinianaDanceGroup and of BalletPhilippines. Abroad, he was principal dancer with the ballet in the opera houses in Kiel, 1984 to 1986, and Theater am Gartnerplatz in Munich, 1986 to 1987, both in Germany, and with Maurice Bejart’s Ballet of the 20th Century from Brussels to Lausanne, 1987 to 1992. In 1992 he joined the Basle Ballet in Switzerland.

His roles with DCC include the Cavalier in Paquita,Escamillo in Carmen,Manrico in La Gitana,and Gaston in Camille;with Ballet Philippines (BP), Mercutio in Romeoand Juliet;with DanceTheaterPhilippines, Peter in TchaikovskyFantasy and Mercury in OdetoBotticelli;in Kiel, the title roles in Dorian Gray, PeerGynt, Romeo and Juliet,and the Prince in TheNutcracker;with Bejart’s company, Gunther in Ring umden Ring,Shiva in Malraux ou la Metamorphosedes dieux,the title role and the Phoenix in Firebird,and the (male) Chosen One in Rites of Spring. His pas de deux“Evacuation” was one of the featured works during BP’s 40th anniversary which opened the season with Masterworks, 2009.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Elline Damian in Giselle (Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Elline Damian (Photo courtesy of Escola Ballet David Campos)

text:
DAMIAN, ELLINE ( Elline Christine Montano Damian-Espejo ) b. Quezon City 27 Jun 1976. Dancer. She is the daughter of Edwin Caracta Damian and Diana Trinidad Montano, the niece of dancer and teacher Vella C. Damian and cousin of dancers and choreographers Augustus F. Damian III and Ianne F. Damian. She is married to dancer Eduardo Espejo Jr.She started training at a very young age with her aunt at the Vella C. Damian School of Ballet in Quezon City. In 1992, she joined the Philippine Ballet Theatre as a company member and started training intensively with Lisa Macuja and Osias Barroso Jr. When Macuja started Ballet Manila (BM) in 1994, Damian became one of the pioneering members of the new company. With BM, she further trained with Tatiana Udalenkova, Serguei Vikulov, and Viktor Saveliev.

She was a soloist with BM from 1994 to 2003. In 1995, Damian portrayed the role of Myrtha, queen of the wilis in Giselle, on tour in Russia. In 1999, she reprised her portrayal of Myrtha in Ballet Philippines and BM’s joint production of Giselle, featuring Jose Manuel Carreño. She eventually portrayed Giselle in 2002, and this became one of her signature roles. Other works of note include a role in Asaf Messerer’s abstract ballet Melody Adagio, 1996; Lucy Westenra in Paul Vasterling’s Dracula, 2000; Carmen in Eric V. Cruz’s Carmen, 2000; and Juliet in Sergei Vikulov’s Romeo and Juliet, 2001. In 2004, Damian joined Ballet David Campos in Barcelona, Spain. Between 2004 and 2014, she played important roles in Campos’s ensemble works, such as Neh Nehledej, Rock Requiem, and En Clau de Jazz (In Jazz), as well as leads in Volveré a Nacer (I Will Be Reborn), and Eurasia. She was memorable in Campos’s deconstructions of classical ballets, portrayingClara and the Snow Queen in El Cascanueces (The Nutcracker);Kitri in Don Quixote; Aurora in La Bella Durmiente (The Sleeping Beauty); and the title role in Giselle.Damian performed Campos’s Giselle and LaBella Durmiente on tour with Ballet David Campos in the Philippines in 2012.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Vella Damian, 1969
Vella Damian in a scene from Paquita
Vella Damian (Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
DAMIAN, VELLA ( Eva Estrella Caracta Damian )b. 8 Nov 1938. Dancer, teacher. She is the daughter of Augustus Damian Sr and Isidra Caracta. She finished two bachelor’s degrees in music, the first a major in music education at the St Joseph’s College, and the second a major in piano at the University of Santo Tomas (UST).

She started dancing at 15, under a scholarship with Remedios de Oteyza. In 1966-68, she studied at Robert Joffrey’s American Ballet Center and the School of American Ballet in New York City, USA. Among her teachers were Alexandra Danilova, Andre Eglevsky, Stanley Williams, Violette Verdy, Lillian Moore, Hector Zaraspe, and Dennis Nahat. At the same time, she taught music and dance at a youth center of the New York Police Department. She also toured the United States as lead dancer of La Meri’s theater group based at the Hunter College Playhouse.

Returning to Manila in 1968, she taught at the school of the Hariraya Ballet Company. She was chosen by Sulamith Messerer to do the Philippine premiere of the grand pas from Paquita in 1969. Full-length ballets have been created for her: The Haunted Ballroom by de Oteyza, and Carmen, Medea, La Gitana, and Camille, all by Eric V. Cruz. Camille was brought to Beijing, China in 1990.

Damian founded the School of Ballet and Dance Arts in 1969, and Dance Concert Company in 1970, with Cruz and Exequiel Banzali. In 1979, she spearheaded the First National Ballet Festival that gave birth to the Ballet Federation of the Philippines. She is a founder of Philippine Ballet Theatre, member of its artistic council, and its rehearsal mistress for three seasons.

Damian is one of the leading dance teachers of the country, producing many artists of note. Her commitment to dance education has led her to coauthor the National Dance Syllabus. In line with her vision of lifting the standard of ballet education in the Philippines, she became the founding president of the Association of Ballet Academies of the Philippines (ABAP) in 1993, an organization that has since grown, giving students opportunities to perform, while assuring the quality of ballet education in the country. Damian is responsible for bringing the Australian Conservatoire of Ballet Syllabus to local teachers, acting as Philippine coordinator and chair of its annual ballet examinations and assessment programs. In 2009, she was conferred the title of Australian Conservatoire of Ballet Fellow (ACBF) by Christine Walsh, author of Australian Conservatoire of Ballet Syllabus and director of the Australian Conservatoire of Ballet in Melbourne, Australia. Damian has also served as board member of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts Committee on Dance, 1998-2001, acting as artistic director of the 1999 International Dance Day celebration.

Damian received grants to attend a choreographer’s workshop in Indonesia, 1986, and to observeschools and companies in the United Kingdom and New York City, both in 1988, and France, in 1991. In 1982, she was named outstanding alumna of the University of Santo Tomas (UST). The following year, she also received the UST’s Joven Tupas Award for Excellence in Arts and Culture. In 2001, the City of Manila awarded her the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award in dance. In 2013, dancers and friends honored her with a tribute program titled “Viva Vella!” at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Written by Cherish M. Garcia, with notes from Myra Victoria C. Beltran

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Vella Damian with Ricardo Ella in Dance Concert Company’s Medea

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
DANCE CONCERT COMPANY ( DCC )Founded in 1970 by VellaDamian, EricV.Cruz, and Exequiel Banzali, the DCC was the performing arm of the School of Ballet and Dance Arts, which was started in 1969 by Damian. It participated in the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines’ (CCP) Festival Four and Balletfest, the MetropolitanTheater’s Sayaw Sining (Dance Art),and seasons of the Puerta Real Evenings. It also had its own concert series at the Metropolitan. In 1980 the company performed in Guam for the Philippine Independence Day Celebration and for the “Spirit of America Celebration” in July.

Its repertoire is made up of ballets by its resident choreographer and artistic director Eric V. Cruz, as well as the works of other Filipino choreographers such as RemediosdeOteyza, Damian, Basilio, FelicitasLayag-Radaic, and TonyFabella, and standard classics by Petipa, Ivanov, Coralli, Corsky, and Bourmeister. Among its significant productions, all choreographed by Cruz and featuring Vella Damian in the title roles, are Carmen,1976, to music by Bizet; Medea,1978, to music by Bartok; La Gitana,1982; and Camille,1983, the last two with music by JeffreyChing.

In 1990 selected dancers of the company joined with members of BalletPhilippines and Atlanta Ballet in a performance at Beijing of La Gitana,together with theCentral Ballet of China. In the same year, DCC was a recipient of the dance venue grant from the CCP.

Its dancers have included AugustusDamianIII, Cesar Ongkingko, RicardoElla, Vivencio Samblaceño, YvonneCutaran, Myra Beltran, Ida Beltran, Gina Katigbak, Jinn Ibarrola, Ramon Victoria, OsiasBarroso, Robert Policarpio, and Rosalie Carreon. The DCC merged with other companies in 1986 to form Philippine Ballet Theatre.Written by Ma. Cherish M. Garcia

article_title: Dance Education Association of the Philippines
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
DANCE EDUCATION ASSOCIATION OF THE PHILIPPINES ( DEAP )Founded in 1982 by the Philippine Normal College (PNC), the DEAP was organized during a seminar-workshop on dance at the PNC which was spearheaded by CarmenT.Andin. The association set the following objectives: to promote cooperation and understanding among teachers, experts, and enthusiasts in the improvement of the quality of life through dance; to professionalize the teaching and administration of the dance and related fields; to provide a forum for local, national, and global issues in dance; to foster research activities in the field; and to support the formation and development of national policies and programs in dance.

In coordination with the Department of Education, Culture and Sports (DECS), the DEAP conducts national seminar-workshops every summer supported by the school which provides the venue, and sometimes with the Commission on Higher Education (CHED). The convention-workshops cover a range of topics geared towards teachers, supervisors, and administrators from public and private elementary and secondary schools, dance directors and instructors, choreographers and dance enthusiasts. In the past years, some of the issues discussed were globalization and its effects on dance, in particular folk/ethnic dance; preservation and dissemination of dance; and the implications on dance of the 2015 ASEAN Integration. These events have been held around the Philippines.

Membership has expanded from 57 in 1982 to over 500 in 1991. DEAP conducts annual folk dance workshops held in various parts of the Philippines. Written by Carmen T. Andin, with notes from Ruth Jordanan L. Pison and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Dance Forum’s Star Maiden, 1995, featuring Myra Beltran

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Dance Forum’s Itim Asu: 1719-2009, 2009, featuring Myra Beltran

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
DANCE FORUM Dance Forum studio at 38 West Avenue, Quezon City started in 1977 as a venue for a judo club. It was later converted into a dance studio which the Dance Concert Company, under Eric V. Cruz and Vella Damian (the first teacher of Dance Forum’s artistic director, Myra Beltran) used. It eventually became the rehearsal studio of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines, where ballet master William Morgan conducted classes.

In 1995, independent choreographer/dancer Beltran established Dance Forum as an alternative performing venue. The studio was opened with the performance of Star Maiden, her first full-length solo. The idea behind this solo articulated the path of Dance Forum and its director, who at that time, felt “alone, seemingly pushing a big rock up a mountain or placing a stone one in front of another to step unto in a sea of nothingness.” As an independent artist, she kept her faith, believing that she “belonged—a Filipino, child of a farmer and a star maiden” (Message, Nostalgia: Grande Tango, 2007). In 1997, Beltran, together with Chameleon Dance Company, initiated the conversion of the space into a studio-theater. With the difficulties of espousing nonmainstream choreographic practices, Dance Forum embarked as a space for collaborative projects among artists in different fields. The word “Forum” in the name indicates Beltran’s idea of dance as discourse, an art worthy of discussion among scholars, dancers, and choreographers.

With Alliance Francaise Manille, Dance Forum presented Quartet for the End of Time, 1998, with the Pundaquit Chamber Players, one of its first successful collaborative projects. This was followed by productions with other artists, like Folds of Midnight, 1990, The Romeoand Juliet Project, 2001, and Itim Asu: 1719-2009 (Onyx Wolf: 1719-2009), 2009.

Over the years, independent artists in the Philippines became visible as the Dance Forum studio offered itself as a clearing for discussions and creations with dancers/choreographers/companies. Among them, Katrina Mercado, Katherine Sanchez, Joanne Dela Calzada, Enrico Labayen, Flordeliza Fernandez, Airdance, Dancing Wounded, and the UP Dance Company; musicians Jonas Baes, Alfonso “Coke” and Ramon Bolipata, Ramon Santos, and Otto Hernandez; poets and fictionists Virginia Moreno and Randy Bustamante; visual artists BenCab, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Robert Feleo, Karen Flores, Felix Miguel, Roberto Villanueva, and Katti Sta. Ana; theater performers Alex Cortez, Anton Juan, and Tian Ge Bing; filmmakers Carlos Siguion-Reyna, Sari Lluch Dalena, Sherad Anthony Sanchez, and Ruelo Lozendo; and sound and light designers Shakira Villa and Teresa Barrozo. Dance Forum has likewise produced choreographers and ensembles through their new works.

The productions of Dance Forum have been inspired by literary texts, re-readings of history, pieces on women, and discourses on the nature of dance. Dance Forum performed Payatas: Point Counterpoint during “Global Dance 2002 (The Future of Dance: Aesthetics of Diversity),” the World Dance Alliance Festival in Dusseldorf, Germany. With Beltran as the founding director of the Contemporary Dance Map Series since 2005, and of the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival since 2006, Dance Forum Studio Space has seen numerous choreographic works from both festivals.

In 2001, Dance Forum was given the Aliw Award for Best Cultural Dance Group.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Pull, choreographed by Razel Ann Mitchao, 2018, featuring, clockwise from left,

Carmela Sofia Dedel, Razel Ann Mitchao, Rita Malacon, and Akira Lydia Abao

(Photo by Potpotography, courtesy of Dance Pull Project)

Dance Pull Project's De-Ling, 2016, directed by Dwight Rodrigazo,

with dancers Chloe Therese Villagracia, left, Razel Ann Mitchao, and Ysabela Beatrice Austria

(Photo by Dwight Rodrigazo, courtesy of Dance Pull Project)

“Pamatdan,” an excerpt from Dwight Rodrigazo full-length piece, Karga-Tapas, 2015,

with dancers, from top, Akira Lydia Abao, Jonee Jabez Rodriguez, and Razel Ann Mitchao

(Photo by Reggie Placido, courtesy of Dance Pull Project)

text:
DANCE PULL PROJECT Dance Pull in Bacolod City was established by Dwight Rodrigazo in 2005. After years in Metro Manila as principal soloist of Ballet Philippines, member of Powerdance company, cofounder (with Paul Morales and Gerald Mercado) of the E-dance Theatre, and later, also cofounder and chief choreographer and associate artistic director of Airdance, Rodrigazo returned to Bacolod to establish his school and company. With the name Dance Pull already in his mind, Rodrigazo converted what used to be a club with huge TV screens into a dance studio. This included a lounging area for the students and a room for guest choreographers and friends.

Trained in classical and modern ballet and contemporary dance, Rodrigazo kept all three genres in his school, believing that a combination of ballet and contemporary dance complements the Filipino body and talent. With both paying students and scholars, the school also offers hip-hop, break dance, jazz dance, ballroom dance, and gymnastics. The scholars of the Dance Pull Kids come from all over Negros Occidental. They have also been given intensive dance workshops in popping and locking by Reagan Cornelio and Prince Paltu-ob, International Champion hip-hoppers and former members of the internationally renowned street grooves group, the Philippine All-Stars. In addition to dance training, the girls are given lessons in singing.

Rodrigazo describes the choreographic style of the company’s works as “directional motivation,” developing other movement direction. The technique the school takes is characterized by “resistance and release” – terms in ballet which have been transformed in the works of the company. In 2007, Karga Tapas (Cut and Load), a debut piece about the plight of thesakada(sugar cane workers) in Negros, premiered in Sigma, Capiz, exhibiting the synergy of dance techniques of the company, and the movements and culture of the sakada. It was also performed for the 2008 WiFi Body Dance Festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Birds of the Mind, performed at the 4th WiFi Body Dance Festival in 2009, captures the humming and tweeting of birds and their flapping and swooping in flight, which metaphysically parallel what besets and characterizes Philippine society, from serious issues to the lightest, plus the funniest Filipino eccentricities. The two works show distinct movement vocabularies emerging from the same cultural context. Rodrigazo has created several works for the company and encourages his dancers to choreograph, as well.

In 2012, Dance Pull launched the Contemporary Movement Analysis Program (C-MAP), independently organized and facilitated by Rodrigazo, which aims to be a regular workshop to be participated in by aspiring choreographers around the country. Rodrigazo envisions Dance Pull to produce more contemporary works that respond to and complement Negros’s life and landscape.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

Dance Theater Philippines’s An Evening of Dance in Worship, 30 Apr 1985, Manila Cathedral

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
DANCE THEATER PHILIPPINES ( DTP )It was founded in 1968 by JulieBorromeo, EddieElejar, and FelicitasLayag-Radaic. In July of that year, it debuted at the Rizal Theater in a production directed by Poul Gnatt. Its repertoire included Gnatt’s and Russell Kerr’s works, with the Philippine premiere of Bartok’s Miraculous Mandarin and some Bournonvillle dances. Critic AnthonyMorli called DTP as the country’s first professional dance group. One of its ballerinas was TinaSantos.

The next productions were mostly Filipino, like Borromeo’s ZagalasdeManila (Young Maidens of Manila) and Kalingan,Elejar’s Katakata Sin RajahIndarapatra (Stories of Rajah Indarapatra), Radaic’s Tanan (Elopement), and Luis Layag’s TakeFour to new music by Felix Padilla Jr. In 1969 the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) commissioned Borromeo and Radaic to choreograph Eliseo M. Pajaro and Jose Garcia Villa’s ballet Mir-i-nisa. Meanwhile, the company implemented its Cultural Outreach in Education or CORE that brought ballet to schools and communities in Metro Manila (including filling up the Araneta Coliseum), all the way to Cebu, Bacolod, and Zamboanga. This time the ballet masters were TonyLlacer and Israel Gabriel, who also danced and choreographed.

After a hiatus, DTP was revived under Radaic’s direction, with the premiere of Radaic and Pajaro’s MayDayEve and Janacek-Basilio’s The Rebels in 1971. Gradually, it based itself in Radaic’s school of dance in St. Theresa’s College in Manila and Quezon City. Resident choreographers were Radaic and Basilio. Robin Haig performed in and produced more ballets, including the classic Pas deQuatre.

In 1975, DTP participated in the International Festival of Youth Orchestras and Performing Arts in Aberdeen, London, and Cardiff with rave reviews. In 1979 they repeated the same success in Europe. They also appeared on Grampian television and were featured by the BBC.

From 1973 to 1986, DTP gave monthly performances on the Rizal Park stage under the National Parks Development committee headed by Teodoro F. Valencia. Between 1981 and 1983, it ran two fully subscribed seasons at the Meralco Theater. Between 1984 and 1989, it was the resident dance company at the University of the Philippines College of Music. All these activities developed dancers like Loulie Dalupan, Irene and Hazel Sabas, Emellie Rigonan, Sophia Radaic, Mary Anne Santamaria, AnnaVilladolid, Lisa Macuja, Eloisa Enerio, Jonathan Terry, Roberto Clemente, and Vivencio Samblaceño Jr. Between 1980 and 1987 Basilio took over as artistic director. Since 1971, Basilio did more than 40 ballets for the company. Since the Asian Arts Festival in Hong Kong in 1980, he has choreographed Bartok’s Third PianoConcerto as Testament, RyanCayabyab’s MisaFilipina (Filipino Mass), and RamonP.Santos’s Awit (Song), Aninag (Translucence), and Muling Pagsilang (Rebirth). Other regular choreographers were TonyFabella, GenerCaringal, Lucy Layag-de los Reyes, Elejar, Borromeo, and Radaic.

In 1986 the company paid tribute to Radaic at the Rizal Theater with a show, hosted by Tina Santos. In 1988 it celebrated its 20th anniversary at the Meralco Theater, featuring Giselle with Lisa Macuja and NonoyFroilan. In 1989 it revived Mir-i-nisa at the CCP, again choreographed by Borromeo and Radaic. It featured young ballerinas Mylene Saldaña, Anna Marie Tirol, Rose Miranda, Katrina Santos, and guest Melanie Motus of Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). Ballet mistress was SoniaDomingo. For 23 years, DTP existed alongside the CCP-subsidized BalletPhilippines (BP).

DTP was the only company that required its members to take an international examination through the Royal Academy of Dancing, to instill professional discipline among its artist-members, preparing them further for international careers in classical ballet. DTP preceded BP by two years, and from 1987 to 1989, was a sister company of PBT, ensuring the existence of the fledgling company with the support of its dancers and repertoire. To the end, Radaic kept the company alive and nurtured many young dancers who earned their own places in national and international dance companies.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Darangan Cultural Dance Troupe in Marawi City, 1966-67 batch

(Photo courtesy of Fe Adil)

text:
DARANGAN CULTURAL DANCE TROUPE Founded in 1966 in Marawi City by Antonio Isidro, president of Mindanao State University (MSU), it aims to preserve and propagate the indigenous culture of Mindanao, Sulu, and Palawan and in this way promote cultural integration. Its repertory covers songs, music, dances, rituals, and enactments of scenes from the Darangen epic and the folk life of the Maranao, Maguindanao, and other ethnic groups of Mindanao and Sulu, such as the Manobo, Bagobo, Higaonon, Tboli, Subanon, Tausug, and Sama Dilaut (Badjao). The group was featured in the 1968 Manila Film Festival entry titled Mindanao, an epic film starring popular stars Mario Montenegro, Bernard Belleza, and Zeny Zabala.

Its director-choreographer was HenriettaHoferEle, assisted by Judy Naga-Lastimosa in dance and Aga Khan Guinar in music. Rebecca Morales researched the songs, Emily Marohambsar wrote the storylines, and Dionisio Orellana supervised the stage designs. MSU students who perform with the troupe are rigorously trained and receive scholarship benefits. They have toured the country several times and performed in Taiwan, Japan, Canada, and the United States. The current dance director of the group is Naga-Lastimosa.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Salud Datoc, 2001

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
DATOC, SALUD ( Salud Cabanos Datoc )b. Ilagan, Cagayan 20 Sep 1930. Dancer, teacher. Datoc is the daughter of Alberto Datoc and Rosario Cabanos. At an early age, she trained in dance with Kaethe Hauser, and later in ballet and tapdance with RicardoandRobertaCassell at the Manila Ballet Academy. She received her elementary school teacher’s diploma from the Philippine Normal School (PNS), a special diploma in Physical Education (PE) from the National College of Physical Education, a degree in education from the Far Eastern University, and a master of arts in health, physical education, and recreation from the University of California in Los Angeles, USA. She also took doctoral courses at Columbia University, New York.

She taught language, arts, and PE in various schools in Manila and then took charge of student teachers at PNS. She worked closely with Francisca Reyes-Aquino, later National Artist for Dance. From 1958 to 1961, she was president of the PhilippineFolkDanceSociety and dance director of its troupe. She was chairperson for plans on regional and national workshops on PE and recreation of the Bureau of Public Schools, a member of its research team on indigenous cultural resource materials as well as director of its dance troupe. She also directed the Orchesis at PNS. In 1966 she trained Peace Corps Volunteers in Stanford University, USA, in fitness, games, music, dance, and language. In 1973 she taught dance and recreation under the Bilingual Program of the US Department of Education in Honolulu, Hawaii. From 1971 to 1978, she was an assistant director of the Young Women’s Christian Association (YWCA) in Brooklyn, New York. From 1977 to 1985, she was its program administrator over eight departments and in programs for women, nursery, after school, camps, among others. From 1985 to 1997, she was president of the Society for the Advancement of Physical Education and Recreation. She was systems administrator in a New York hospital.

Datoc is a member of the Asian-Pacific American Women in New York and was elected into the Kappa Delta Phi and Phi Delta Theta. She enjoyed several scholarships and fellowships including those from the University of California, Los Angeles, and Columbia University. She also received awards of merit from the Boy and Girl Scouts of the Philippines and from the YWCA of New York, USA. In 1991 she organized the FranciscaReyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation (FRAMF) in Manila. She was its president from 1996 to 2002 and from 2005 to 2006, spearheading the Foundation’s lecture and workshop series in Manila, Bulacan, Pangasinan, Benguet, Iloilo, Cebu, Cagayan de Oro, and Davao, from 1991 to 2004.
