In 1998, she also facilitated the showing of the film Life and Works of Francisca Reyes-Aquino on ABS-CBN, and it won the best documentary award in the station’s Ang Mga Bayani (Our Heroes) series. With Aquino’s daughter Celia-Tolentino Martinez, Datoc coordinated and was the principal author of the publication Lola Kikay: Life and Works of Francisca Reyes-Aquino, 2007, published by the FRAMF.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Judell de Guzman in Sayaw Sabel, 2010

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Judell de Guzman

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Judell de Guzman

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
DE GUZMAN, JUDELL ( Judell de los Santos de Guzman-Sicam ) b. Pasay City 28 Aug 1971. Dancer, choreographer, lecturer, and teacher. Judell de Guzman is the daughter of Felix de Guzman and Teresita de los Santos. She is married to Darrell Sicam, a photographer, with whom she has one son, Terrell.She has a diploma in creative performing musical arts, major in dance, from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1995.

De Guzman started dancing ballet at the age of seven with Marissa Aboitiz at the Amelia Apolinario Dance School. She continued to train in St. Mary’s Academy under Toni Bermudez, then with Gigi Felix-Velarde. At the age of 12, she took classes under Tony Fabella, Luther Perez, and Eddie Elejar at the Manila Metropolis Ballet.She was accepted as a ballet major at the Philippine High School of the Arts (PHSA), where she trained with William Morgan, Mercy Drilon, Corazon Iñigo, and Agnes Locsin.

Upon graduating, she joined Ballet Philippines (BP) as a Society for BP Scholar in 1988 and was promoted to Company Member in 1991.She was also a member of the UP Dance Company under Basilio during her college years.She taughtdance technique classes at UP, thendance history and dance composition at the De La Salle-College of St. Benilde from 1998 to 1999.

As a member of BP II, she worked closely with Agnes Locsin throughout her career. She performed important roles such as maiden in Moslem, 1990; the title role of Babalyan (Priestess),1994; the title role in Medea,1995; and Sisa in Elias, 1996.

In Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress), she played one of the women in 1992, and the title role in 1995 in BP’s Australian tour. In 2011, with the help of Annette Cruz-Mariano and Alden Lugnasin, she restaged this full-evening work.

In classical works, she wasGamzattis in Morgan’s restaging of La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 1993, and Myrtha in Maniya Barredo’s Giselle, 1994. She also did the title role in Effie Nañas’s Snow White, 1998, and Sugar Plum Fairy in The Nutcracker, 1999; and the title role in Alice Reyes’s Amada,2000.

For BP’s Neo-Filipino series, she choreographed Juanat Ang Bagong Adan (Juan and the New Adam), 1994; Kamote (Sweet Potato), 1996; and with Alden Lugnasin, co-choreographed Tubig at Apoy, Lupa’t Hangin (Water and Fire, Earth and Wind), 1997. She also contributed“Parol” (Lantern)for the full-length Christmas ballet Noche Buena (Good Night), which was done by several choreographers and curated by Locsin.

In 2001, she was associate artistic director of BP until she retired in 2002. She danced again in 2008 in La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), and in 2010 for Locsin’s Sayaw Sabel (Dance of Sabel), performing the solo “Kayod Kabayo”(Horse Driven). She is now a Level 4 Pilates instructor at Cecile Sicangco-Ibarrola’s Integrated Body Arts and a modern dance teacher at the Perry Sevidal Ballet.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Guada de Leon

(Photo from facebook.com/guadabas)

Guada de Leon

(Photo from facebook.com/guadabas)

text:
DE LEON, GUADA ( Maria Guadalupe Moret de Leon-Bas )b. Manila 31 Jan 1974. Dancer. Daughter of Manuel Aranda de Leon and Ernestina Moret, she is married to Juan Rader Bas, with whom she has one son. She is the grandniece of Mita Pardo de Tavera who essayed The Dying Swan for Luva Adameit’s School. She began a communications degree at the University of Asia and the Pacific in 1993. After her retirement from performance, she took further studies in Anatomy, Pilates, gyrotonic, and choreography.

She took ballet lessons with New Manila Ballet from 1980 to 1990 under Pinky Puno, Nini Mendoza, and Cecile Dioquino. She entered Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) as an apprentice in 1990, and furthered her training with local and foreign ballet masters, such as Paul de Masson, Juergen Schneider, Laura Alonso, Eddie Elejar, Thomas Pazik, Osias Barroso, Sonia Domingo, Lisa Macuja, and Rinat Gizatulin. De Leon was promoted as a full member of PBT in 1992.

De Leon was one of the company’s ballerinas who blossomed in 1995, featured as Arabian Coffee in Michael Chernov and Gelsey Kirkland’s The Nutcracker; as half the American couple in Edna Vida’s Thatness, Thereness, from 1995 to 2002; and as the lead in Gener Caringal’s Vinta, 1996 to 2001, in local performances across the country and in international tours to the United States, Mexico, Spain, Morocco, and Canada, partnered by Joey Herrera, Andrei Roslovtsev, and Quincy Jacinto.

Her stage presence and attack of movements made her memorable in several roles, particularly, as Death in David Campos’s Carmina Burana, 1995; Myrtha in Giselle, 1997, and Gregoria de Jesus in Caringal’s Andres KKK, 1997; one of the three dancers in Tom Pazik’s Trio, from 1998 to 2002; Suzuki in Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, 1999; and Kitri in Don Quixote, 2000 and 2001, as partnered by Lucas Jacinto. She was also cast as Maria Clara in National Artist Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s Noli Dance Suite, 1998; and as lyrical Nikiya in the Kingdom of the Shades from La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer),2000 and 2002. She was also partnered by American Ballet Theatre Star Marcelo Gomes in Paquita grand pas de deux and the Le Corsaire (The Pirate) pas de deux, both in 2001. De Leon also created many other roles, like the villainous Maymouna in Jean Paul Comelin’s Raymonda, 1996; lead bird in Eli Jacinto’s Magdaragat (Seaman), 1997; and Princess Urduja in Tony Fabella’s Urduja Beleaguered, 1998. She retired from PBT in 2002, but returned to perform the Waltz Girl in that year’s staging of George Balanchine’s Serenade.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Remedios de Oteyza

(Photo courtesy of Paquito dela Cruz)

Remedios de Oteyza with Paul Szilard

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Remedios “Totoy” Alvarez de Oteyza, prima ballerina and founder of the Classic Ballet Company

Remedios de Oteyza

(Photo courtesy of Paquito dela Cruz)

text:
DE OTEYZA, REMEDIOS ( Remedios Alvarez de Oyteza )aka Totoy de Oteyza. b. Manila 20 Jun 1920 d. 25 Jun 1978. Dancer, choreographer. She was born to Carlos de Oteyza, a journalist and entrepreneur, and Manuela Alvarez, a pianist and singer. Her two sisters were visual artists, and a brother was a musician. She finished high school at the Assumption Convent. At age 8, de Oteyza studied ballet in Spain and later in Manila with LuvaAdameit. Because of poor health, she had to quit the groups she had joined in Spain. In Manila, she continued studying with PaulSzilard. In 1948, she took an intensive course with visiting couple Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin, and with Mia Slavenska in 1953. Then she went to Europe, studying under Markova and Dolin in Liverpool, and Olga Preobrajenska, Lubov Egorova, Leo Staats, and Jeanne and Nelly Schwarz in Paris.

De Oteyza started to choreograph at age 12. An Egyptian suite, to Grieg, which she composed for the Manila Carnival, won first prize. De Oteyza founded the Classic Ballet Academy in 1947 that later became the Ballet and Dance Center in Makati which she ran with IndayGaston-Mañosa. They both founded the HarirayaDance Company in 1968. She had joint projects with Paul Szilard and ManoloRosado in the 1950s, BalletPhilippines (BP), and BalletFederationofthePhilippines in the 1970s. She also taught at the CCP Dance School. Many of her students made their mark in Philippine ballet.

She was noted for her abstract ballets in the neoclassical vein, among them choreography for two piano concertos by Grieg and Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff’s Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, Tchaikovsky’s Serenade for Strings, Cesar Franck’s Symphonic Variations,Khatchaturian’s Masquerade Suite,Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue, Rimsky-Korsakov’s CapriccioEspagnol,and Ravel’s Bolero.On the other hand, she also did story ballets: IbongAdarna (Adarna Bird), 1970, co-choreographed with Gaston-Mañosa, to music by RodolfoCornejo; and The HauntedBallroom, 1973, to Dohnanyi. For BP, she choreographed Spectrum,1972, to Cornejo, and Prelude, 1977, to AlfredoS.Buenaventura. Her last work was the choreography for the dances in the opera La Gioconda, 1977.

In 1976, de Oteyza was honored at the First National Ballet Festival for having “unreservedly sustained the classical tradition in dance.” In 1977, she received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila. Hariraya Ballet Company, DanceConcertCompany, and the Philippine Ballet Theatre paid tributes to her. Together with her pioneering contemporaries, de Oteyza transmitted the classical dance tradition from the first Filipino and foreign teachers to the next generation who would forge more permanent institutions in Philippine ballet.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jess de Paz

(Photo from facebook.com/jessldt)

Jess de Paz

(Photo from facebook.com/jessldt)

text:
DE PAZ, JESS b. Tacloban, Leyte 9 Jan 1947. Choreographer. De Paz graduated from the Divine Word University (DWU) with a bachelor of arts and bachelor of science in education degrees. His dance teachers included JojiFelix-Velarde, TonyFabella, AliceReyes, Martha Graham, WilliamMorgan, Agnes Locsin, and various teachers at the Joffrey School of Ballet in New York, USA, where he was a scholar. He won the Best Choreography award in the National Himig Competition several times. He lectured on dance in various symposia, focusing on ballet and moderndance.

He spearheaded cultural exchanges and linkages with other national dance companies as chairperson for dance of the Kandaya Arts Council, which he helped found. He was a member of the Executive Committee for Dance of the Presidential (now National) Committee for Culture and Arts and of the PhilippineFolkDanceSociety. He was also the Philippine delegate to the ASEAN project on “The Study of Thailand’s Traditional Dance, Music, and Architecture.” In 1989 his group was a grantee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines Outreach Regional Tour program. His major works include The Barren Flower, Oh,MgaHuyohoy, Danses Concertantes, TheNutcracker Ballet, Love,Philippine Style, Mariang Maya,and Pintados.

In 1990, de Paz founded the Leyte Dance Theater (LDT) which started in 1965 as the Danzz Corps, a student organization based at the DWU. The group was finally renamed the Leyte Dance Theater when it became a private company, and was since then directed by De Paz. Over the years, LDT has toured locally and internationally. In 2014, de Paz took the company to a two-month tour of the United States, staging a total of 21 performances in several states as a way of raising funds for the victims of typhoon Yolanda. The group also performed in hospitals, nursing homes, schools, and at the Consulate General of New York.Written by Emilie B. Capulong, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Rey Dizon

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Rey Dizon

Rey Dizon

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
DIZON, REY b. Manila 13 Feb 1955. Dancer. Dizon studied at the University of the East and danced in its folk and contemporary dance company. In 1973 he trained at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School and became a member of BalletPhilippines in 1974. Among his teachers were Garth Welch, Gerard Sibbritt, TonyLlacer, EddieElejar, Alfred Rodrigues, Armin Wild, Norman Walker, and Rochelle Zide Booth in ballet; and AliceReyes, TonyFabella, GenerGaringal, Pauline Koner, Takako Asakawa, David Hatch Walker, and Norman Walker in moderndance. While in the Philippines, he danced the lover in Gener Caringal’s AngSultan (The Sultan), 1973; as the boy in Alice Reyes’s Dugso;Harlequin in Fokine’s Le Carnaval;the central pas de deux with ElizabethRoxas in Caringal’s Rite of Spring;and as Alain/The Butterfly Boy in Fernand Nault’s La FilleMal Gardee,1969.

He joined Les Grands Ballets Canadiens in 1975 as a soloist and later became one of its principal dancers, 1981-90, performing classical and contemporary ballets. There he danced Frantz in Coppelia,Albrecht in Giselle,the Cavalier and the Russian Dance in TheNutcracker, Jean de Brienne in Raymonda, and the grand pas de deux in Don Quixote.He also danced the title role in Petrouchka and the principal parts in Balanchine’s Four Temperaments (Melancholic), Square Dance, Agonand Tarantella,in Nijinska’s Les Noces,Milko Sparemblek’s Ballade du Soldat,and Maurice Bejart’s Firebird.After casting him in After Eden,choreographer John Butler created a special solo for him in Quest. He also performed in tours in North and South America, Europe, Australia, and Asia.

Dizon was also a principal dancer of the Sarasota Ballet of Florida, director of “Dance – The NextGeneration”scholarship program, and faculty of the West Florida Ballet. He directs the Diane PartingtonStudio of Classical Ballet in Ellenton, Florida.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Sonia Domingo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz

text:
DOMINGO, SONIA ( Sonia Tandoc Domingo )b. Manila 10 Apr 1956. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. The daughter of banker Panfilo O. Domingo and Deagelia Tandoc, she studied dance in London and is also a certified public accountant, with a degree in accounting from the University of the East. She started ballet in 1968 with FelicitasLayag-Radaic and Marife Versoza at St. Theresa’s College. In 1971, she trained in London with Ruth French, Alex Morrow, and Joan Hewson, becoming French’s assistant in 1972. In 1977, she trained with Basilio, WilliamMorgan, EddieElejar, Fernand Nault, Robert Barnett, and Mannie Rowe.

She then danced with DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) and in Ballet Federation of the Philippines productions, and taught for Layag-Radaic at the St. Theresa’s College School of Dance. Between 1984 and 1989, she was ballet and rehearsal mistress for DTP, and in 1990, for Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). In 1985, she lectured on ballet for the dance degree program of the University of the Philippines College of Music and its extension program. Between 1987 and 1990, she taught in the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School. In 1992 she founded her own dance center in Quezon City, and became the Philippine organizer for the Royal Academy of Dance. She has danced major roles in Coppelia, Napoli, Fernand Nault’s La Fille Mal Gardee, William Morgan’s Czerniana and Cinderella, The Sleeping Beauty, Giselle, Swan Lake, Thomas Pazik’s RomeoandJuliet, Eric V. Cruz’s Interior Castle, Layag-Radaic’s Tanan and Oy,Akin Yan! (Hey, That’s Mine!), and Basilio’s Mosque Baroque and TropicalTapestry. In 1991, she choreographed Awit ni Pulau (Song of Pulau) for the UPCherubimandSeraphim. She also restaged Giselle for DTP, and Romeo and Juliet for PBT.

In the late 1990s, she migrated to the United States where she trained in Pilates, which she teaches along with ballet in her own school in Connecticut.Written by G. Castro, with Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Trudl Dubsky-Zipper in “Mountain King’s Daughter” from Peer Gynt Suite

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Lucio Sandoval and Trudl Dubsky-Zipper as Bastien and Bastienne

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Trudl Dubsky-Zipper

(Photo courtesy of Dubsky Family)

text:
DUBSKY-ZIPPER, TRUDL b. Vienna, Austria 21 Jan 1913 d. Los Angeles, California, USA 1976. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. As a child, Dubsky-Zipper joined Max Reinhardt’s production of AMidsummerNight’sDream and other productions in Europe. She studied dance at the State Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts, and later toured Europe as a soloist of Gertrude Bodenwieser’s dance ensemble. She then taught at the Vienna State Academy and established her own school in 1931 with Jeanette Rutherstone. At the same time, she taught special courses in England, at the Bedford Physical Training College, the Royal Academy of Dancing, and for Margaret Craske. She also choreographed for the Camargo Society, collaborating with its musical director Sir Thomas Beecham. In 1934 she rejoined the Bodenwieser group.

Invited by Kaethe Hauser to Manila in 1937, she taught modern dance at the Academy of Music and foreign dances at the University of the Philippines. Under the auspices of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, headed by Rosario Valdes, she formed Manila Ballet Moderne. In 1939 she married fellow Viennese Herbert Zipper, who had just been released from a Nazi concentration camp. A symphony orchestra conductor, Zipper took over the leadership of the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) after the death of Alexander Lippay. In Nov of that year, Dubsky-Zipper premiered her works: Petite Suite—Au Bord de la Seine by Debussy, The Iron Foundry by Mossolow, Peer Gynt Suite by Grieg, and Voices ofSpring by Strauss. In 1940 she presented Pictures at an Exhibition by Moussorgsky, PlovetskyDances from PrinceIgor by Borodin, and The Toy Box by Schubert. The 1941 concert featured one new work, The Women of Arles to Bizet.

The outbreak of World War II in Dec 1941 halted theater activities, and the Zippers joined the underground resistance. In 1942 Dubsky-Zipper conducted dance classes on the rooftop of her apartment, and her students, taking any means of transportation available, paid their fees in cash or in kind. At war’s end, she immediately revived Manila Ballet Moderne and presented dance concerts for the troops of the United States Armed Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), while Zipper conducted the MSO in 250 concerts held in ruined churches and the Rex Theater in Chinatown. Responding to a fund raising appeal from Pres Sergio Osmeña, the Zippers went to the United States in 1946 to solicit funds in 21 cities. She performed and lectured in the United States West Coast, and later joined her husband in New York, establishing a school in Brooklyn, teaching at drama workshops and choreographing for recitals and off-Broadway productions.

Upon their return to Manila in 1951, Dubsky-Zipper choreographed A Midsummer Night’s Dream and The Fateful Dress in 1952, Bastien and Bastienne in collaboration with CesarLegaspi and NickJoaquin, and Pieta to Hindemith. From 1954 to 1969, she directed operas: Strauss’s Die Fledermaus,1954; Smetana’s The Bartered Bride, 1955; Bizet’s Carmen in Filipino, 1956 and 1958; Mozart’s Abduction from the Seraglio, 1958; Handel’s Acis and Galatea and Ibert’s Angelique,1959; Puccini’s Gianni Schicchi (translated as Juancho Gancho ),1961; Stravinsky’s The Soldier’s Tale,1969; Donizetti’s Rita; Menotti’s El Campanillo and The Medium; andVon Suppe’s The Beautiful Galathea,and Charlie Brown’sSnoopy.

Dubsky-Zipper was a shaping force in Philippine dance. She was an innovator in movement technique, expressive style, and stage production. She had a creative and teaching vigor that made possible the participation of laymen in dance. She easily recognized, nurtured, and optimized the dance capability and communicability of the Filipino. On the other hand, Filipinos easily found rapport and reward in her manner of dancing. This reciprocal relationship lasted for 32 years and produced a whole generation of performers, teachers, and enthusiasts, who in turn influenced later directions and achievements in Philippine dance.Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Conrado Dy-Liacco

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Conrado Dy-Liacco

(Photo by Jaime Zobel de Ayala, courtesy of the artist)

text:
DY-LIACCO, CONRAD ( Vicente Conrado EscañoDy-Liacco )b. Quezon City 6 Sep 1962. Dancer. The son of Roberto Dy-Liacco and Carmen Escaño, he holds a fine arts degree, major in advertising from the University of Santo Tomas. He trained in ballet with EffieNañas from 1972, and later at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School, from 1979. From a company scholar, 1980, and a member, 1981, he rose to be a soloist, 1983, and principal dancer, 1987, in BalletPhilippines. In 1991, he joined the Hong Kong Ballet (HKB).

With WilliamMorgan’s staging of Napoli Divertissements and TheSleeping Beauty,and the title role in EdnaVida’s Peter Pan,all in 1983, Dy-Liacco started assuming major roles. This was in AliceReyes’s Cinderella, Morgan’s Swan Lake and Giselle, BrandoMiranda’s Ang Misa (The Mass), and DenisaReyes’s TeDeum and Love Lies Bleeding, all between 1984 and 1986. From then on, he danced other solo parts in Don Quixote, Raymonda, La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), Norman Walker’s TheNutcracker, AMidsummerNight’sDream, and A. Reyes’s RomeoandJuliet.Among his gala pieces are the pas de deux from The Harlequinade, Don Quixote, La Fille Mal Gardee by Gorsky, restaged by M. Kukharev, Gopak by R. Zakharov, and Satan’s Soliloquy,created for him by Walker. He also took the title role in EnricoLabayen’s IcarusEternallyDamned/TheDupeofTime,1991.

Dy-Liacco has also done choreography, notably a virtuosic male solo in Simplex, to music by Chick Correa, and Tatgubat, a study on the monkey dance of the Zambales Aetas, to music by Takemitsu. From dancing and choreographing, Dy-Liacco has turned to another interest—photography. Over the years, he has taken stunning pictures of dancers and dance productions, particularly those of HKB.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Eddie Elejar with Tina Santos

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Eddie Elejar with Alice Reyes

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
ELEJAR, EDDIE ( Eduardo Causin Mendoza )b. Manila 31 Dec 1934. Dancer, choreographer. The son of Sergio Elejar Mendoza, a doctor, and Felisa Causin, EddieElejar graduated from De La Salle University with a degree in commerce. While in college in the 1950s, he took ballet lessons with RicardoCassell and RemediosdeOteyza. He then trained with Olga Preobrajanska, Volkart, Karen Taft, Robert Joffrey, Maurice Bejart, and Marie Rambert in the 1960s.

In the 1950s, Elejar performed in the productions of Cassell, like Love’s Sorrow,1951, Swan Lake,1952 and 1955, Serenade for Strings, 1952, Merry Wives of Windsor as Falstaff and On Stage, 1953; of de Oteyza, like Prayer and Four Seasons,both in 1954, Four Elements and Rhapsody in Blue, both in 1955, and the grand pas de deux from TheNutcracker and Don Quixote;as well as those of TrudlDubsky-Zipper, like AMidsummerNight’sDream, The Idol,and Pieta, all in 1953. When Alexandra Danilova’s group came in 1955, he danced in the classical numbers and in The Beautiful Blue Danube. With MaribelAboitiz, he performed in Madrid, Barcelona, Zurich, and Lausanne with the Tena Ballet. Back in Manila, he danced with de Oteyza’s new Manila Ballet Company. In 1959 and 1960, he joined the BayanihanPhilippineDance Company’s Philippine and world tours. From 1963, he started collaborating with JojiFelix-Velarde at the Philippine Women’s University and School of Fine Arts at the University of the East.

He was premier danseur of Pamana Ballet from 1966 to 1968, with GretaMonserrat as his partner. He formed DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) with JulieBorromeo and FelicitasLayag-Radaic in 1968. The company was launched with a production by Poul Gnatt. In DTP, he choreographed Katakata Sin Rajah Indarapatra (Stories of Rajah Indarapatra) to music by JoseMaceda and Gates of Hell to Edgard Varese. He was artistic director for Mir-i-nisa,1969, which was in the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ (CCP) inaugural season.

In 1970 he worked with AliceReyes and Tina Santos for the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company. He directed Santos’s farewell performance at the Meralco Theater, where he partnered her and choreographed Variations for Six.

Elejar and Reyes then jointly founded and directed the CCP Dance Workshop and Company (now Ballet Philippines), for which he created Juliet and Her Romeo, for Reyes and ManuelMolina, and Jewels,both in 1970; Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris) and Who’s the Clown,1971; Trio con Brio and Kapinangan, 1972; MisangPilipino (Filipino Mass), 1974; and Rigodon Sketches,1976. For the CCP, he choreographed Look Ma,I’m Dancing, Chopin Variations and Swan ofTounela.He danced in ballets by Reyes, Tony Fabella, Miro Zolan, and Norman Walker.

He also became production director of Ballet Federation of the Philippines. Renewing ties with DTP, he choreographed Masks,1981, for Anna Villadolid; Once Upon a Village, 1982, for Franklin Bobadilla; and Mutya ng Buhay (Muse of Life), 1986.

With Fabella, he founded and directed the Manila Metropolis Ballet (MMB) from 1978 to 1988. Among his works for MMB were Mutya ngNayon (Village Muse), Rigodon de Honor, Hayop ang Galing (Fantabulous), Song Cycle, Piano, Concerto, Iago, MorningDew,and May Day Eve. With MMB’s merger into Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), he contributed a new Rigodon, 1989, and a restaged Masks,1991. In 1991 to 1993, he was PBT’s artistic director. Also with Fabella, Elejar founded the Quezon City Performing Arts Development Foundation, and later the Dance Center of Manila, both gaining successes in national and international festivals.

Elejar has had one of the longest dancing and creative careers in the history of Philippine dance. Considered the country’s danseur noble for most of his creative years, he has partnered ballerinas from IndayGaston-Mañosa and JojiFelix-Velarde to Greta Monserrat, Maribel Aboitiz, and Tina Santos. He is a member of the artistic council of the PBT and coartistic director of the Quezon City Performing Arts Project for the Urban Poor. For a time, he represented the Philippines in the International Council for the Dance (Conseil International de la Danse-CIDD). In 1972 he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila for his durable and varied contribution to Philippine dance. In 2004, he received the Gawad CCP for Dance.Written by G. Castro and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ricardo Ella

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Ricardo Ella with Mary Ann Sta. Maria in Felicitas Layag-Radaic's Tanan

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
ELLA, RICARDO b. Sipocot, Camarines Sur 25 Aug 1958. Dancer, arts administrator. Originally an actor, stuntman, and martial arts instructor, Ella began training in dance under Vella Damian in 1977 at the age of 19. He started out by taking soloist parts for Dance Concert Company and occasionally became a guest dancer with Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP), dancing in its tour of England and Scotland in 1979 and of Hong Kong in 1980. While training in Manila with William Morgan, Ella pursued a degree in theater arts management at the University of the Philippines (UP), but upon receiving a private company scholarship, he moved to the Australian Ballet School in 1981 where he earned a diploma in dance in 1984.

In 1985, Ella joined the Royal New Zealand Ballet, became one of its principal partners, and stayed on as a dancer for the company until 1987. During this period, he took on roles such as Albrecht in Giselle, Siegfried in Swan Lake, and leading roles in modern ballets like Orpheus which earned him superlative reviews. He moved to the Australian Ballet Company in 1987, serving as a coryphee, taking the role of Athos in The ThreeMusketeers and Gum in La Sylphide. From 1990 to 1992, Ella served as principal male dancer in the original Australian musical production of Sir Andrew Lloyd Weber’s The Phantom of the Opera. In 1995, with the help of the Philippine Embassy, Ella co-produced the Australian Tour of Ballet Philippines (BP) as part of a cultural exchange program and bilateral agreement with the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

In 1989, Ella, along with wife Christine Walsh, cofounded two theater companies: Onstage Artists and the Christine Walsh Enterprises Pty. Ltd. At the same time, the two were guests for the BP’s gala. In 1990, he danced with the Philippine Ballet Theatre and the Australian Stars of Ballet under the organization of Onstage Artists. In 1991, Ella and Walsh founded the Christine Walsh Dance Centre, later named the Australian Conservatory of Ballet, with Ella serving as the school’s managing director for operations. He manages the administration and the performing activities of the school, and handles the pas de deuxand all boy’s classes.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Marge Enriquez in Healed Heart, 2010

(Photo by Bobot Meru, courtesy of the artist)

Marge Enriquez

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Marge Enriquez in Being Yourself, Power Mac Center Spotlight, Circuit Makati, 2016

(Photo by Jojo Mamangun, courtesy of the artist)

Marge Enriquez in Myths About Love, Power Mac Center Spotlight, Circuit Makati, 2017

(Photo by Nelson Matawaran, courtesy of the artist)

Marge Enriquez

(Photo by Romain Rivierre, courtesy of the artist)

Lightbulb Moment is based on the teachings of the world's most stable mind Dadi Janki. This is a location shooting in 2012 at the residence of sculptor Impy Pilapil and filmed by Gino Parma. Costume by Michelle Sison. (Photo by Nelson Matawaran, courtesy of the artist)

text:
ENRIQUEZ, MARGE C. ( Mary Margaret Cruz Enriquez )b. Quezon City 17 Oct 1958. Dancer, dance critic. The daughter of Monitor Enriquez, an engineer, and Amelia Cruz, a dietician, she started ballet and jazzdance training with Josette Salang and Rene Hofileña in Dance Arts Studio. Enriquez’s dance training includes the English style from Colin Russell; the Cecchetti technique from Carol Beals; and modern dance from Lucas Hoving, June Watanabe, and Aaron Osborne. She also took special classes in Afro-Haitian dance, and the Bharata Natyam under Shankar Sangupta. An injury made her turn to dance scholarship. After receiving her degree in broadcast communication from the University of the Philippines, she pursued a master’s degree in creative arts and interdisciplinary studies at the San Francisco State University, USA. Her graduate thesis was on religious dance in the Philippines, highlighted by a dance production of DanceTheaterPhilippines in Basilio-RyanCayabyab’s MisaFilipina (Filipino Mass) at the ManilaCathedral, featured in video-film in 1985.

In 2014, her one-woman show titled Dancing in the Light was directed by Bart Guingona and choreographed by Douglas Nierras. The multimedia production on the teachings of spiritual leader and life coach Dadi Janki was a combination of theater, dance, music, sculpture, and video.

She is a dance critic and writer for the Philippine Daily Inquirer’s Lifestyle section and the Business Inquirer, and was arts and leisure editor of BusinessWorld.Written by Paul G. del Rosario, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Eduardo Espejo

(Photo courtesy of Escola Ballet David Campos)

text:
ESPEJO, EDUARDO ( Eduardo Suico Espejo Jr ) b. Makati, Rizal 24 Jun 1973. Dancer. He is the son of Eduardo Aquino Espejo Sr and Eleanor Tucao Suico. His younger brothers Jeffrey and Jerome, and wife Elline Christine Damian are also dancers.He trained under Osias Barroso Jr and Lisa Macuja-Elizalde as a scholar of Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 1990, joining the company shortly after and being promoted to demisoloist in 1993. He was part of the pioneering batch of dancers that formed Ballet Manila (BM) in 1994. Here, he had the opportunity to train further with Tatiana Udalenkov, Sergei Vikulov, and Viktor Saveliev.

His roles include the lead in Barroso’s In Quest, 1995; Happy Clown in Nikolai and Sergei Legat’s The Fairy Doll, 1996; Spanish Chocolate in The Nutcracker, 1998; th e grand pas de deux from Don Quixote, 1999; and the title role of Romeo in Sergei Vikulov’s full-length Romeo and Juliet, 2001. He performed the peasant pas de deux in BM’s joint production of Giselle with Ballet Philippines in 1999. A serious and dramatic dancer, he was consistently praised for his partnering, solid strength, clean lines, and stage presence. He also portrayed significant roles in Petrushka, 1997, commissioned from David Campos, which later led to his joining Ballet David Campos (BDC) in Barcelona.When the company went to the Philippines in 2012, Espejo performed Giselle and La Bella Durmiente.

In 2004, Espejo was engaged as a soloist with BDC until 2013. Within this period, he did the lead role and Soldier in Petrushka; the King in Faust; the Poet in Volveré a Nacer (I Will Be Reborn). In 2013, he appeared in Macuja-Elizalde and BM’s production of Stars of Philippine Ballet, performing with Aileen Gallinera excerpts from Campos’s Faust and Mask of the Red Death.Since 2010, Espejo has been teaching at the Escola David Campos in Barcelona, Spain.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jeffrey Espejo as the Nutcracker Prince in The Nutcracker, 2001

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Jeffrey Espejo

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Jeffrey Espejo in Ballet Manila 2000 calendar pictorial

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Jeffrey Espejo as Warrior in Philippine Ballet Theatre’s Banbantay, 1993

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
ESPEJO, JEFFREY ( Jeffrey Floyd Suico Espejo )b. 6 Jul 1974. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. The son of Eduardo Espejo and Eleanor Suico, he is married to dancer Pamela Asprer. His brothers Eduardo Jr and Jerome are also dancers. He has a degree in computer science from the Philippine Christian University.

Espejo was originally trained to be a swimmer, but his godparents, Tony Fabella, Luther Perez, and Eddie Elejar, encouraged him to dance at the age of 15. He trained under Lisa Macuja and Osias Barroso as a scholar of Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 1990. Three years later he became company member. That same year, he participated in the Nagoya International Ballet Competition in Japan. In 1994, as a demisoloist of PBT, he performed in the company’s tours in Mexico. In 1995, he became one of the founding members of Ballet Manila (BM).

With BM, he performed the principal roles in Le Corsaire (The Pirate), 2000 and 2002; The Nutcracker, 1998 and 2000; Don Quixote, 1998; Swan Lake, 1997; and most notably in Jean Paul Comelin’s Firebird,2000 and 2001. He was chosen to be Colas in the local adaptation of Sergei Vikulov’s La Fille Mal Gardee, 1999; and Albrecht in the joint BM and Ballet Philippines (BP) production of Giselle, 1999, and the BM production in 2002. Among the roles which he originated for BM were Jonathan Harker in Paul Vasterling’s Dracula, 2001, and Pan in Vikulov’s Walpurgis Nacht, 1996.He also performed the pas de deuxfor Diane et Acteon and Satanella, both in 1997.

He toured extensively with BM in Russia and the United States and worked with numerous ballet companies abroad. In 1998, he portrayed lead roles for the joint productions of BM and the Krasnoyarsk State Ballet, which was touring the Philippines. In 1995, he performed with the Buryat State Ballet in Russia for its joint productions with BM. In 1997 he guested with the Hong Kong Ballet, dancing in Fredrick Ashton’s TheTwo Pigeons. At the second International Music Festival of Asia-Pacific Region, 1995, he was invited to perform the Satanella pas de deux with Aileen Gallinera.

He has worked extensively with all three major ballet companies in the Philippines—BP, PBT, and BM. He was appointed Guest Ballet Master of BP from 2005 to 2007. For the company, he choreographed Latin Heat, 2007; Double Takes, with Bam Damian, 2006; and Jazzanova, 2005. He has also worked with numerous ballet schools in the country. He has been a teacher for Steps Dance Studio, CCP Dance School, BM School, and Academy One. As the official coach of the Steps Dance Studio for the Asian Grand Prix competition since 2012, Espejo has coached trainees to win a bronze medal, two silver medals, and a gold medal in their respective categories.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Mario Esperanza, right, in Ballet Philippines’s La Lampara

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
ESPERANZA, MARIO ( Mario Ayson Esperanza ) aka Butch Esperanza. b. 1 Sep 1956. Dancer, teacher. He is the son of Mariano Coloma Esperanza and Lydia Dumbrigue Ayson. Esperanza was on his second year in the preparatory medical course at the University of the East, when he auditioned for the University of the East Dance Troupe (UE Dance Troupe) under Gener Caringal. Without previous dance training, he received a scholarship as a dancer of the dance troupe in 1974. From 1974 to 1978, he trained in classical ballet and modern dance with Caringal and Manny Molina at the UE Dance Troupe; with Vella C. Damian and Eddie Elejar through private classes; and with Mikhael Kukharev, Luminita Dumetriescu, William Morgan, Tony Fabella, Alice Reyes, and Norman Walker.

In 1978, he became company member of the CCP Dance Company, now Ballet Philippines (BP), and joined the company in their first European tour. Lead classical ballet roles were created on him, including Prince Charming in Reyes’s Cinderella, 1980; Prosper Merimee in Reyes’s Carmen, 1984; and Fritz in William Morgan’s Coppelia, 1988.With the company, he also danced the pas de deux in Norman Walker’s Songs, Drones, and Refrains, 1979; Daphnis in Gray Veredon’s Daphnisand Chloeand Pan, 1980, andwas the first to perform the role of Actaeon for the company in Agrippina Vaganova’s Diana and Actaeon, 1985. In modern works, he portrayed notable lead roles which were also created on him such as Ravana and Lakshmana in Alice Reyes’s Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 1987; Jose Rizal in Basilio’s La Lampara (The Lamp), 1980; the father in Norman Walker’s Wanderings of A Wayfarer, 1981; Juan in Reyes’s Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), 1984; and the male in Denisa Reyes’s A Girl Who Left Home, 1991.

In 1988, he joined the Singapore Dance Theater where he essayed all the principal roles in pieces by world-renowned choreographers including the lead in Choo San Goh’s Beginnings, 1988, originally made for Joffrey Ballet; Graeme Murphy’s Wilderness, 1989; and Vicente Nebrada’s Electric Sequences, 1990. Other works were also premiered with Esperanza as the lead dancer including Mark Ruhala’s Introspection, 1988; Gener Caringal’s Souvenirs and Chameleon Scarf, 1989; Christopher Bannerman’s Elements of Fire, 1989;Anthony Then’s Concerto for Seven, 1989; Timothy Gordon’s Rainbow River, 1990; and Vasili Lucich’s Praying Mantis, 1990.

Broadening his span of originating roles in Philippine dance, he joined the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 1995, revisiting roles for ballets he had done with BP. With PBT, Edna Vida created for him the role of the American in Thatness, Thereness, 1995; David Campos, the principal parts in Carmina Burana, 1996; Jean Paul Comelin, both the roles of the Prince in Cinderella, 1995, and Abderachman in Raymonda, 1997; and Eddie Elejar choreographed for him Rafael in Calle Santa Potenciana, 1995, and Escamillo in Carmen, 1999. He was the male danseur in Eric V. Cruz’s Flames of Paris pas de deux, 1995.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Emerita Espiritu-Basilio, seated at the center, with officers and board members of Philippine Folk Dance Society, 2016

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Dance Folk Society)

Emerita Espiritu-Basilio, left, 2016

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Dance Folk Society)

text:
ESPIRITU-BASILIO, EMERITA ( Emerita Valerio Espiritu-Basilio )b. 6 Oct 1921. Teacher. Born to Cornelio Espiritu and Ceferina Valerio, she was married to Abelardo Basilio. She assisted Francisca Reyes-Aquino in editing and revising the six-volume Philippine Folk Dances.After graduating as valedictorian at the National College of Physical Education, she took graduate courses at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), where she later headed the physical education department. Although she taught for a while in Parañaque in 1945, she spent most of her years at the UST where she formed and directed the Salinggawi Dance Troupe in 1967.

She has been secretary, president, and adviser of the PhilippineFolkDanceSociety, and is business manager of the FranciscaReyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation (FRAMF). Most active in dancedocumentation, she published a compilation of Philippine folkdances, and implemented the video documentation of the dance oasioas for the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). She is now retired but keeps active membership with the FRAMF, and jury work for folk dance competitions.Written by Prosperidad M. Arandez, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Tony Fabella

(Photo from facebook.com/balletphilippines)

text:
FABELLA, TONY ( Antonio Limuaco Fabella ) b. Pagsanjan, Laguna 20 Mar 1941. d. 4 Jun 2009. Dancer, choreographer. Born to Ricardo Fabella, principal of the Pagsanjan Academy, and Luz Limuaco, he holds a chemical engineering degree, 1965, from the Mapua Institute of Technology. Fabella trained in ballet with Eddie Elejar, Joji Felix-Velarde, Nina Vyroubova, Natalia Mirskaya, Elvira Rone, Miro Zolan, Alfred Rodrigues, and Garth Welch. In modern dance, Alice Reyes, Norman Walker, Pauline Koner, and Takako Asakawa were his mentors. He was also a leading member of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, training under Libertad V. Fajardo and Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, and joining many of the group’s world tours.

Fabella danced professionally in ballet with Dance Theater Philippines (DTP) and took the lead role in Mir-i-nisa, 1969, during the inaugural season of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). He was a charter member, manager, and resident choreographer of the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, 1970, which became the CCP Dance Company, and later, Ballet Philippines. He danced principal parts, such as the title role in the rock opera ballet Tommy, 1972, Ogassi in Tales of the Manuvu,1977, both by Alice Reyes; and Puck in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1976, for which he was cited as Male Dancer of the Year by the Philippine Daily Express. He also performed the drummer boy in Graduation Ball, 1986, and Dr. Coppelius in Coppelia, 1978, of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines.

Among his major choreographies were those done for the Folk Arts Theater: Araw at Buwan (Sun and Moon), 1976, and Kristo (Christ), 1977; DTP; Manila Metropolis Ballet; Ballet Philippines; and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). Notable works include La Verite, 1970, to Shostakovitch; Noche Buena (Christmas Eve Celebration), 1970, to Lucrecia Kasilag; Semana Santa (Holy Week), 1971, to R. de Leon; Prince of the Pagodas, 1972, to Britten; Changes, 1973, to Bach; Orpheus Descending, 1973, to M. Colombier; Pas de Deux to a Recorder, 1974, to Dorough and Miller; Ang Konsiyerto (The Concert), 1974, to H. Rubio; That Summer Afternoon,1975, to Bach; Batuque, 1976, to Femandez-Revueltas; Siklo (Cycle), 1977, to Ramon Santos; Six for Kasilag, 1978; Mi Bandera (My Banner) and Ritmo Filipino (Filipino Rhythm), both 1979; Entrances and Exits, 1980, to Mozart; Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches), 1981, to Ryan Cayabyab; Love, Like the Moon, the Inconstant Moon, 1982, to Massenet; Ang Kasal (The Wedding), 1982, to Stravinsky, with Les Noces text translated by R. Santos; Three Tchaikovsky Waltzes, A Gift of Dance, 1983, to Chopin; Glazounov Variations, Bolling Suite, Ancestral Spirits, Philippine Sketches,and Lingon sa Nakalipas (Retrospective), all in 1985 and to Kasilag; Graduation Ball, 1986, to Strauss; A Dance Offering, 1986, to Glazounov; Dancing to Donizetti, 1987; Change… Gonna Come and Narciso, 1988; Pinoy Talaga (Truly Filipino), 1989; and Beautiful Girls, 1990, both to Jose Mari Chan. His last choreography was Mahiwagang Bituin (Mysterious Star), 2008, the finale for Ballet Manila’s Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Three Stories of Grandma Basyang), 2015.

Fabella has taught dance in many schools and directed many productions all over Metro Manila, from studio setups to college and university courses. He oversees the training of dancers for jobs abroad. He was a member of the Professional Artists Developers Association of the Philippines and the artistic council of Philippine Ballet Theatre, and former lead member of the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company and later its artistic consultant. He was a cofounder with Eddie Elejar and Luther Perez in 1994 of the Quezon City Performing Arts Development Foundation (QCPADF), a dance school for underprivileged children, and president of the Manila Dance Center, the dance arm of Hiyas ng Maynila.

In 2009, Ballet Manila (BM) opened its 14th season with Halo-Halo Extra Special, a mix of original ballets and a tribute to Tony Fabella. In BM’s World Stars of Ballet in 2012, a new dance Widmung paid homage to Fabella. He was awarded the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan by the City of Manila in 1984. He received the Alab ng Haraya in 2003 from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts for his choreography of Tambol at Padyak (Drum and Thump). In 2011, he was awarded the Natatanging Gawad Buhay Award by Philstage. In Oct 2013, Fabella’s works were showcased at a ballet festival titled Fab! A Tributeto Tony Fabella in CCP, performed by the ballet schools that Fabella worked with such as Academy One Music and Dance Center, BM, Claravall School of Classical Ballet, Ecole de Ballet, Halili-Cruz School of Ballet, Perry Sevidal School of Ballet, PBT Conservatoire, Quezon City Performing Arts, Radaic School of Classical Ballet, St. Paul Pasig Ballet School, UP Dance Company, and the CCP Dance School. The QCPADF performed the finale of the show, an excerpt from Fabella’s Shoes which he choreographed for ballet Philippines.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Libertad V. Fajardo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Libertad V. Fajardo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
FAJARDO, LIBERTAD V. ( Libertad Regalado Villanueva-Fajardo )b. Bago City, Negros Occidental 20 May 1910 d. 20 Dec 1969. Teacher, scholar, writer. The daughter of Mariano Villanueva and Mercedes Regalado, she was brought up by her aunt Maria Villanueva. She received her degree in physical education (PE) from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1933, and a master’s degree from the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) in 1960. She married Valeriano F. Fajardo, with whom she had three children: Valeriano Jr, an architect; Brenda, a visual artist and set designer; and Mary Joan, a dancer and choreographer. She first worked as a student assistant at the UP Department of Physical Education from 1931 to 1934, and as dance instructor in the Beauty and Health Center in Bacolod City in 1934 to 1935. Later, she taught at the UP, 1935-41; Araullo High School, 1941; Centro Escolar University, 1942-45; Alejandro Albert High School, 1942-45; St Paul’s College, 1942 -51; PWU, 1946-64; Arellano University, 1947-76; and the National College of Physical Education, 1951-64. In 1959 she was acting dance director of the Bayanihan Folk Arts Center. She joined the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company in Europe, the Middle East, the United States, and Canada as its assistant dance director, 1961 to 1962, and in Australia as dance director, 1964.

While on tour, Fajardo observed and participated in the programs in dance of the Pestalozzi schedule in Hamburg and the Rollie Kings schedule in Munich, both in 1962. She taught Philippine dances to Israeli choreographers Rivka Sturman, Rhaya Spivae, and Curit Kadman, and they in turn taught her their dances. She also participated in the University of the Pacific 15th Annual FolkDance Camp, Cal-Poly PE workshop in San Luis Obispo, California, and the Seventh Annual Folk Dance Conference at the University of California, all in 1962.

Between 1961 and 1975, Fajardo published Visayan Folk Dances in three volumes, and See the World in Dances in 1967. Among her important recordings and observations on dance are the sinulog devoted to San Martin, Iloilo, and the more flirtatious form of cariñosa in San Joaquin, Iloilo.

In 1999, she received the Centennial Honors for the Arts from the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Written by Brenda Fajardo, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Cyril Fallar in Ballet Philippines’s Peter Pan, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Cyril Fallar

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
FALLAR, CYRIL ( Cyril Aran Glory Fallar )b. Manila Aug 1988. Dancer. He is the son of Dioscoro Fallar, seaman, and Teresita Glory, homemaker. Fallar was a full academic scholar of Ballet Philippines (BP) and the College of St. Benilde’s School of Design and Arts. He earned a degree in Performing Arts, major in Dance in 2009.

His first exposure to performance was through the theater group of Aurora A. Quezon Elementary School. At age 12, he started his formal dance education with the Manila Dance Center under Luther Perez and was able to secure a scholarship to the Philippine High School for the Arts in Makiling, Laguna. In 2003, Fallar auditioned and became a scholar of BP. At the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), he was mentored by CCP Dance School Director Noordin Jumalon, dance teachers Victor Ursabia and Jeffrey Espejo, and then BP’s Artistic Director Augustus Damian III. He became an apprentice in 2005, and eventually earned his spot as company member in 2008. Aside from receiving more training from Tony Fabella, Eddie Elejar, and Edna Vida, he was also able to take dance classes with famous international dance teachers such as William Morgan, Frank Ohman, Yanis Pikieris, Zane Wilson, and Atlanta-based Filipino prima ballerina Maniya Barredo.

Fallar was promoted to company soloist in 2011 and has performed lead roles in BP’s original productions and classical repertoire. He was very much lauded for his portrayal of the Golden Idol in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer). Known for his spritely jumps and effortless turns, Fallar is usually cast in playful roles such as the jester in most classical ballets, Puck in A Midsummer Night’sDream, and the title role in Edna Vida’s Peter Pan in 2010 and 2015.

As a choreographer, Fallar won the grand prize in BP’s first Choreography Cup in 2010. Titled Dancers’ Crux, his piece was about the struggles of a young dance-artist. The same piece received nominations for Outstanding Choreography in a dance production from the Gawad Buhay Jury. His pieces for BP’s Sarong Banggi (One Night), 2015, to music arranged by Ryan Cayabyab, were well-received by audiences and critics.Written by Clarissa Cecilia Mijares-Ramos

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Far Eastern University Dance Group

(Photo from facebook.com/FDCofficialsite)

text:
FAR EASTERN UNIVERSITY DANCE GROUP aka FEU Dance Group Conceptualized and formed in 1957 by then FEU’s Dean of the Institute of Arts and Sciences Alejandro Roces, the FEU Dance Group was created in response to the 1958 Brussels World Fair’s request for schools in the Philippines to present the country’s folk dances. The group, coached by Corazon Iñigo, was initially composed of 100 members recruited from the university’s Physical Education Department under Alfredo Reyes. Out of 100 members, only 25 members remained for the debut performance at the Philippine Folk Dance Festival on 1 Oct 1957.

With the support of top university officials Nicanor Reyes and Josephine Cojuangco-Reyes, the FEU Dance Group was sought after for its folk dance presentations. In 1959, the French Ministry of Culture invited it to perform during the Theatre des Nations Festival at the Sarah Bernhardt Theater in Paris. With its program called Portrait of the Filipino as Seen through Philippine Folk Songs, the group was such a success that their run was extended at the Champs-Elysees Theater. They proceeded to perform in other festivals elsewhere in Europe, winning first prize at the Hispano-Americano Folklore Competition in Caceres and at the Festival de Folklore Hispano de Baleares in Palma de Mallorca, both in Spain.

In the 2000s the group participated in dance competitions sponsored by the Lyceum of the Philippines, the University of Makati, San Beda College, and the Rizal Technological University. It has also collaborated in performances with Ballet Philippines, the Flamenco group of Clara Ramona & Company, the STEPS Dance Studio, the Cho Nam Gyu Song Jong Eun Dance Company from Korea, dancers from the School of the Arts in Singapore, and ethnic artists like Grace Nono and Bob Aves. Company dancers have performed for GMA Network’s reality show, MOVE: The Search for Billy Crawford’s Pinoy Dancers and QTV’s May Trabaho Ka “Game Girls.”

Over the years, the FEU Dance Company’s Artistic Directors have included Rosalia Merino-Santos, Josefina Sison, Mila Miguel, Rebecca Morales, Asuncion Alzona-Henry, Tony Bermudez, Yek Borlongan, Irma Lopez-Escobia, Cherissa Rodriguez-Chastain, Rob Villaroya, and Gigi Felix Velarde-David. The current Artistic Director is Edward Malagkit. Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

article_title: Far Eastern University Modern Experimental Dance Group
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
FAR EASTERN UNIVERSITY MODERN EXPERIMENTAL DANCE GROUP ( FEU Modern Experimental Dance Group )Founded in 1958 by RosaliaMerino-Santos, it followed the earlier efforts of Viennese pioneers Kaethe Hauser and TrudlDubsky-Zipper to develop moderndance in the Philippines. The group made its debut on 19 Dec 1958 at the FEU Auditorium. The group was disbanded when Merino-Santos retired from the FEU.

An important part of their repertory was the lecture-demonstration What is Dance? which illustrated the elements and compositional devices of the dance as an art form. Performed all over Metro Manila, the demonstration was conceived after Merino-Santos’s master’s thesis at the University of Wisconsin. Also included in the group’s repertory were: OfCocksandKings, 1958, based on a story by AlfredoRoces, to music by LucreciaR.Kasilag, Feminine Gender, using words and movement, and Fanfare, to music by B. Bartok, all in 1958; Ugaling Pilipino (Filipino Customs), 1963; and Hunt and Storm, 1968,which formed part of the unfinished Sarimanok, Jazzletics, and Discothletics.

The group produced dancers like Amelia Apolinario, Teofila Pila, Ernesto Estrella, Delia Saguin-Javier, Jane Orendain, Mitto Castillo, Eddie de Guzman, and Jose Macaraig.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Joji Felix-Velarde

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Joji Felix-Velarde

(Photo courtesy of Isidra Reyes)

Joji Felix-Velarde

(Photo courtesy of Sandy Higgins)

text:
FELIX-VELARDE, JOJI(Josefina Freire Felix-Velarde) b. Manila 4 Oct 1935. d. 22 May 2009. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She is the daughter of Gabriel Felix and “Titang” Freire. She is married to ophthalmologist Herminio Velarde, and they have three children. Daughter Gigi Felix Velarde, a dance teacher, runs the GFV Dance Fusion Studio.

Felix-Velarde started ballet as a child with Luva Adameit and continued with Remedios de Oteyza. She was a lead dancer of the de Oteyza Ballet. In 1960, she attended the Ballet Rambert School in London and the Ballet Arts Studio in New York as an Alicia Markova scholar. She trained with Alexandra Danilova, Vladimir Dokoudovsky, Vitale Fokine, Paul Szilard, and with Karen Marie Taft in Madrid. In the 1950s, Felix-Velarde ran the Ballet Arts Studio with Sony Lopez-Gonzalez in Manila. She then directed with Eddie Elejar and Cesar Mendoza the Joji Felix-Velarde School at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), and the dance school for the University of the East School of Music and Arts.

She was the first Filipino to do the title role in Sylvia staged by Szilard. She also danced in Swan Lake and was chosen by Danilova to dance with Mocelyn Larkin, Maribel Aboitiz, and Elizabeth Guasch in Anton Dalin’s Pas de Quatre. As choreographer, she staged other productions and modelled for Giting Kayumanggi all the way to Lincoln Center, New York. She choreographed the musicals Show Boat, Carousel, Oklahoma, 13 Daughters, and several productions for the deaf-mute. In 2007 she choreographed with Enrico Labayen, Something to Crow About, a modernsarsuwelaby National Artist Alejandro R. Roces, staged in New York by La Mama E.T.C.

She and her husband put up the Pacifica Cultural Productions that worked with the Zarzuela Foundation to produce Walang Sugat (Not Wounded) and Minda Mora, both of which toured the Philippines and abroad. They also produced shows for TV. In 2005, she became a consultant to the Manila International Airport Authority and vice president for external affairs of Carousel Productions, Inc., a company that handles TV productions, events management, and beauty pageants such as Miss Philippines-Earth and Miss Earth competitions.Written by Paul G. del Rosario and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Filipinescas Dance Company, with its director-choreographer Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Jun 1961

(Photo courtesy of Rosendo E. Santos Memorial)

One of the acts in Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance 

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Leaping dancers depicting a cockfight in Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance

(Photo courtesy of Isidra Reyes from The Asia Magazine, 15 Dec 1965 issue)

text:
FILIPINESCAS DANCE COMPANY ( FDC ) aka Filipinescas Dance Group. Founded in 1958 by National Artist LeonorOrosa-Goquingco to interpret her original choreographies, it was an independent, unsubsidized group until the 1970s, dedicated to Orosa-Goquingco’s vision, as dramatized in the full-evening panorama titled Filipinescas:PhilippineLife, LegendandLoreinDance, 1961. A conflation of Philippine history, legend, and cultural practices, the work is considered to have presented many “firsts” in Philippine dance, some of which are the first choreography of local Lenten practices, the first dance staging of a fiesta, the first choreography of the Philippine gamepalo sebo; and the first choreography of thesabongor Philippine cockfight.

From the 1960s to the 1970s, Orosa-Goquingco led FDC’s seven tours abroad, each time on a cultural goodwill mission. The first trip in 1961 extended to seven months, during which FDC won the grand prize under the category “folk-inspired” at the Fourth Ibero Americana Folkloric Festival held in Caceres, Spain. FDC was also invited to the 10th International Music Festival in Santander, Spain, where it was highly praised. On its opening night in Paris, France, FDC received 15 curtain calls, 22 on the second night, and more on the third and fourth nights. It was the first dance company in the Philippines to perform in the United Arab Republic, East and West Pakistan, and Portugal. It also performed in West Germany, Norway, Washington DC, and Honolulu.

Upon its return, FDC performed with the De Lavallade-Ailey American Dance Company in the Philippine-American Dance Festival held in Mar 1962 at the Araneta Coliseum. In Jun 1962, it performed in Malaysia and Thailand, before Malayan and Thai royalty. “Asalto,” “Morolandia,” and “The Bird and the Planters” won rave notices. Similar accolades were heaped upon them in Hong Kong in 1968; in Moscow, Leningrad, and Riga in the former Soviet Union, Pakistan, Brussels, Portugal, and the United States, and Japan in 1970. The year 1974, which marked FDC’s last public performance, was memorable with another round of tours in North and South America, Europe, Russia, Mexico, Hawaii, and Asia.

In 2004, the De La Salle College of St. Benilde (DLSU-CB), under the term of its president Bro Armin Luistro, entered into a partnership with the revived-Filipinescas and committed to support the company. It was Goquingco’s wish not only to resurrect the company but also to restage the highly-acclaimed Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance.Unfortunately, the production never returned onstage.

Among FDC’s dancers were Erlinda Fernandez, Carole de la Paz, Rachelle Goquingco, Eloisa del Rosario, Rowena Aranda, Lina Javier, Violeta Neric, Violeta Manahan, Reynaldo Limcaco, EricV.Cruz, ReynaldoAlejandro, Roberto Caballero, Ramon Victoria, Pedro “Edru” Abraham (also a musician), Luis Morales, Danilo Dupaya, Dominador Correa, Emmanuel Batulan, Felipe Gaerlan, Jose Oliva, and Danilo Neri. Among its musicians were JerryDadap, Michael Dadap, BayaniMendozadeLeon, and ZenasReyes-Lozada. Its technical directors were Siebe Hartendorp and Benjamin Goquingo.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Victor Emmanuel Flor performing at the Sanriku International Arts Festival in Ofunato City, Iwate, Japan

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Victor Emmanuel Flor

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
FLOR, VICTOR EMMANUEL ( Victor Emmanuel Lopez Flor ) b. Pandacan, Manila 14 Jan 1962. Dancer, teacher, choreographer, artistic director. He is the son of Manuel Flor and Socorro Lopez. Flor finished his secondary education at Ramon Magsaysay (Cubao) High School, after which he obtained degrees from several universities and state colleges: technical education major in machine shop at the Bulacan College of Arts and Trade, 1986; bachelor of science in industrial education major in Mathematics at the Bulacan State University, 1989; and certificate in physical education (dance) at the Philippine Normal University, 1990. He received training in folk dance from Jovita E. Meneses of the Bulacan State University Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Troupe and from Teresita Valencia in ballroom dance.

Flor is known as both teacher and program administrator. He has been teaching at the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) since 1989, where he also serves as a folk dance teacher, choreographer, and artistic director of the PHSA dance group that he founded, the Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayaw (SPM). As senior faculty, Flor managed the annual graduation recital productions of the SPM; its outreach programs; and the PHSA “Buklod Project,”a residency program between the SPM and the UP Dance Company (UPDC),that began with the production of Al Bernard Garcia’s Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Surge of Life), 2011. He supervises Bisita Guro (Visiting Teacher), a mentoring program where guest dance masters share their knowledge and direct shows like the PHSA’s celebration of Andres Bonifacio’s 150th birthday, Perya ni Andres (Andres’s Carnival), 2013.

Since 2001, he has been trainor-choreographer with the University of Perpetual Help, where he founded the Bulwagan Sining Lahi Pangkat Mananayaw. As dance workshop facilitator, he has also been involved with the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) since 2002 and the Department of Tourism’s Indak Turismo (Dance for Tourism) in 2010 and 2012. He is affiliated with the Philippine Folk Dance Society, Dance Educators Association of the Philippines, and World Dance Alliance-Philippines. In 2014 he founded the Sanghirang Pangkat Mananayaw with which he works full-time.

As choreographer and director, he has collaborated with several artists, namely, Agnes Locsin, Joey Ayala, Bob Feleo, Dennis Marasigan, and particularly with Fernando Josef to stage the dance theater production of the Visayan epic Labaw Donggon, 1997. For the last, he also designed costumes when it was restaged and performed by Sanghiyas at the CCP Little Theater and at the World Festival of National Theaters in Korea, both in 2009. Other dance theater productions he choreographed include Pagbibigkis: Malayang Daloy, Matibay na Habi (Coming Together: Free Flow, Strong Weave), 1997; and Babayi: Hagod Sanaysay (Woman: Touched Narrative), 1998. SPM performed his Ethnic Craze and Dancing Delusion, 2007, as entry to the community showcase at the World Dance Alliance Conference and Festival in Singapore, 2007. He also choreographed Polka Grande and Ethnic Craze,2007; Karakas (Caracas), 2009; December 30, 2010; and Bakas (Remnant), 2011, with Al Garcia and Robert Stephen Biadoma with live music by Bayang Barrios.

His video documentation of his choreographic works for SPM, Bagong-Lumang Indak (Old-New Groove), was launched at the National Arts Center in 2011. He coached SPM during the Sayaw Pinoy Dance Competition, 2013, where the group won first place in the Folk Dance Kumakaret. In 2014 he facilitated the Makiling Arts Workshop and launched SPM as a Modern/Contemporary Dance Troupe.Written by DeborahLynn EspirituAfuang

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation Board of Directors, 2007
Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation officers and board members, 2001
Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation officers and board members, 1995

text:
FRANCISCA REYES-AQUINO MEMORIAL FOUNDATION ( FRAMF )The FRAMF was founded in 1991 by the followers of National Artist Francisca Reyes-Aquino, coinciding with a yearlong commemoration of Reyes-Aquino’s life-work by the Cultural Center of the Philippines. The founders were Adina Rigor Ferrer, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Felicitas Francisco, Maggie Shea, Salud Datuc, Emerita Espiritu-Basilio, Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte, Properidad Mijares-Arandez, Evangeline Tansingco, Remedios Villanueva-Piñon, and Carmen Tabije-Andin. From 1991 to 2014, FRAMF’s presidents have been Ferrer, Teresita Salvador, Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz.

The foundation aims to preserve and promote Philippine traditional dances, to foster national pride through such heritage, and to nurture Philippine culture by conducting workshops and seminars and by giving awards to those who contribute to folk dance and its scholarship. Among its first awardees starts in 1991 were Belmonte and Reynaldo Eleazar, members of University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club in the 1930s; Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa and Crispin Gimena of the Carlos P. Garcia High School Dance Troupe and the Philippine Folk Dance Society; and Estelita Aquino of the Philippine Normal University.

FRAMF’s workshops were wide-ranging, covering schools and communities not only in Metro Manila but also in Bulacan, Pangasinan, Laoag, Benguet, Iloilo, Cebu, Cagayan de Oro, and Davao. To further disseminate dance education and ethnology, it also held a workshop for children arranged by the “Grand Ladies of the Central Bank” of the Philippines, and another one on dance ethnology in several universities.

Among the Foundation’s most enterprising ventures are its video-films. Among them are the dance-drama O Kikay, a collaboration among the Salinggawi Dance Troupe of the University of Santo Tomas, the Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Company, and the Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe of the Carlos P. Garcia High School in 1994; Aquino’s codification of fundamental dance steps instruction, in cooperation with the Southeast Asia Ministry of Education in 1996; and the Ang Mga Bayani (The Heroes), on the life-work of Aquino, done in cooperation with the ABS-CBN network in 1998, to mark the centennial of Philippine Independence. To celebrate FRAMF’s 10th year in 2001, a Lola Kikay dance-drama was presented at the Kapitan Moy Cultural Center in Marikina, this time featuring the Barasoain Kalinangan Ensemble of Malolos, Bulacan.

The foundation holds annual meetings at the Caloocan home of Aquino’s only daughter, Celia Tolentino Martinez. A prized project came in 2007 with the publication of Lola Kikay: Life and Work of Francisca Reyes Aquino, so far the only full-length book on the Philippines’ first National Artist for Dance.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Gerardo Francisco

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Manila Archives)

Gerardo Francisco

(Photo by Jimmy Villanueva, courtesy of Ballet Manila)

text:
FRANCISCO, GERARDO ( Gerardo Gregorio Francisco Jr ) b. 7 Oct 1980. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Gerardo Francisco is the son of Gerardo Francisco Sr and Erlinda Gregorio. He is the brother of dancer Gerlin Francisco, husband of former dancer Jedette Mae Francisco, and father of dancer Jeree Angela Cassandra Francisco. He began dancing when he was 13 years old in his hometown in Iloilo City. An alumnus of Iloilo National High School, he started ballet, modern, and folk dance training with the Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company, under the tutelage of Edwin C. Duero, Agnes Locsin, Brezhnev Larlar, and Basilio Esteban Villaruz. With a great desire to learn more in dance, he went to Manila and was accepted in 2002 as an apprentice of Ballet Philippines, where he trained under Denisa Reyes, Alden Lugnasin, Victor Ursabia, and Noordin Jumalon.

Francisco’s road to professional dancing began when he joined Ballet Manila (BM) in 2003 as an apprentice. He was promoted from company member in 2003 to junior principal in 2014. In the company, he was mentored by Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, Osias Barroso, Natasha Raldugina, Tatiana Udalenkova of the Academy of Russian Ballet, and choreographer and People’s artist of Russia Sergei Vikulov. He was given lead roles that required playful energy such as Ali in Le Corsaire (The Pirate), 2004, 2008, 2010, and 2013; Golden Idol in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 2004 and 2006; Jester in Swan Lake 2003, 2005, 2007, and 2011; and Basillo in Don Quixote, 2004, for BM’s full-length productions. He also showed great strength in modern dance in Locsin’s Arachnida (Spider) and Agila (Eagle), and Ernest Mandap’s Reve (Dream). Because of his skill and vocabulary in modern dance, he was given the position of rehearsal master of BM for modern dance in 2007.

His first venture in choreography started at the Faith Dance Arts Center in Iloilo, where he choreographed his first two works titled Underwater and Dalagang Pilipina (Filipina Maiden), bothin 2002. Francisco then bagged the Trudl Dubsky-Zipper Award for Best Contemporary Choreography in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) for two consecutive years for Bulag, Pipi’t Bingi (Blind, Mute, and Deaf), 2008, and Hilas (Anxiety), 2009. He is also a first place winner in the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival New Choreographers Competition for Balikbayan,2009, and won the bronze medal in South Korea’s World Maskplay Contest for his Locsin-inspired piece Moriones in 2011. His choreographies are influenced by his folk dance background, as seen in his Pista (Fiesta), his first full-length choreography together with Osias Barroso in 2009, when he was named Resident Choreographer of BM.Written by Sarah Maria Samaniego

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Fely Franquelli as Dalisay Delgado in the 1945 film Back to Bataan

text:
FRANQUELLI, FELY b. 11 Nov 1916. d. Arlington, Virgina, USA 8 Jan 2002. Dancer, choreographer, costume designer. Her mother was Antonia Severino Devesa. She was married to Col Howard J. Hutter. Her formal education was in the Philippines and Hong Kong. She also studied at the University of Southern California. A student of Luva Adameit, Franquelli made her name in the international dance scene in the 1930s.

She did solo recitals, for which she created such dances as Hindu Temple Dance, White Eagle (Navajo), Chinese Legend (about the goddess of beauty Ming Toy from Hainan), Tabu (African), Sacro Monte (a paso doble ), Bulerias (a flamenco from Malaga), Gypsy Fortune Teller (a zambra in Granada), Jarabe (Mexican), Le Singe Qui Danse (a monkey dance), Tinikling, The Beast,and Planting Rice, the last two perhaps from her student days with Adameit.

She earned accolades not only in the Philippines but also in Europe and the US. Abroad, her kind of program could be gleaned from a Los Angeles Herald Express description: “Franquelli offers an entertaining repertoire of Philippines and South Sea dances, authentic in movement, costuming and musical atmosphere.” Salvador P. Lopez once described her thus: “In this young dancer, you could see at once that training and experience have given her the poise that one associates only with the polished professional … There was the smoothness, the grace and the skill that come with confidence in oneself and with certitude of knowledge.” At a Plymouth Drama Festival in 1942, a talent scout spotted her and she passed a movie screen test. Her first starring role was The Invisible Army, about Filipino guerillas during the war before the return of General MacArthur to the Philippines; Cry Havoc, 1943; The Fallen Sparrow, 1943; The Leopard Man, 1943; and as Daisy Delgado with John Wayne and Anthony Quinn in Back to Bataan, 1945.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz,with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Nonoy Froilan as Albrecht in Ballet Philippines's Giselle, 1982

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Nonoy Froilan rehearsing as Scrooge in Edna Vida’s A Christmas Carol, 2017

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Nonoy Froilan as King David in Le Roi David, Switzerland, 1978
(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Nonoy Froilan

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
FROILAN, NONOY ( Rafael Catalino Froilan Cabujat ) b. Calbiga, Samar 24 Oct 1950. Dancer, choreographer, actor. His parents are Fidel Cabujat and Amparo Froilan. He is married to dancer-choreographer Edna Vida with whom he has two children. He graduated from Calbiga Elementary School and Samar High School, then journeyed to Manila to continue studying at the University of the East (UE) and the University of the Philippines (UP). In 1968, he joined the UE Dance Troupe as a folk dancer, and studied ballet and jazz with Tony Llacer and Julie Borromeo. He began performing in stage productions, TV shows, and specials. He enrolled at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School in 1972 and joined Ballet Philippines (BP).

Froilan was BP’s principal male dancer from 1973 to 1993. He performed almost all the lead roles in its classical ballet and modern dance repertory, and joined the company during all its local and international tours during this period. His training was supervised by a number of top ballet teachers, including Norman Walker, Jean Deroc, and William Morgan. Ballets were created for him like Songs of a Wayfarer, 1974, and Song of Adarna, 1987, by Walker, and the full-length Roi David (King David),1978, by Jean Deroc which was reset on him at the Koenigsfleder Festival in Switzerland in 1978. He partnered renowned ballerinas like Dame Margot Fonteyn, Yoko Morishita, Muneca Aponte, Robin Haig, and Maniya Barredo. In 1983, he partnered Toni Lopez-Gonzalez at the Varna International Ballet Competition, and Lisa Macuja at the Fourth International Ballet Competition held in Jackson, Mississippi, USA. In 1990, Froilan also served as BP’s ballet master, teaching modern and classical ballet.

Froilan danced lead roles in Alice Reyes’s Company, Dugso, Chichester Psalms, and Kapinangan, all in 1974; Amada, Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), Carmina Burana, Misa (Mass), and Rajah Sulayman, all in 1975; A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1976; Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 1980; Cinderella and Romeo and Juliet,1981;and Carmen,1984.He was principal dancer in Gener Caringal’s Tomaneg at Aniway (Tomaneg and Aniway), 1975,and Recuerdos (Souvenirs), 1980, and in Antonio Fabella’s Ang Konsiyerto (The Concert),1974. Other lead performances were in Corazon Generoso-Iñigo’s Baile de Ayer (Dance of Yesteryears),1974, and Sisa, 1978; Lydia Madarang-Gaston’s Anak-Bulan (Moon Child), 1976; Denisa Reyes’s Muybridge Frames,1983, and Te Deum,1985, and Asong Ulol (Mad Dog), 1990; Edna Vida’s Romeo and Juliet,1977, and Ensalada (Salad),1981; and Anton Juan’s Yerma,1982.

He successfully ventured into choreography himself, beginning with the abstract ballet Danzas, 1986, followed by One Afternoon, 1987, Iba’t Ibang Salita (Different Words), 1988, Amparo, 1990, Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1992, and Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira) for Tanghalang Pilipino, 1994. In 1990, he received a grant from the United States government to participate in the choreographic workshop at the American Dance Festival in Durham, North Carolina.

As a teacher and mentor, Froilan was a faculty member of the CCP Summer Dance Workshop since 1977, mostly handling the partnering classes. In 1994, he took on a teaching position at the Philippine High School for the Arts, coaching the scholars of Maquiling Ballet.

After retiring from stage, Froilan ventured into videography, starting out by recording performances for BP and recitals for various dance schools. Eventually, he took the helm as a director and won First Prize in the CCP Alternative Film and Video Competition in 1997. In 2003, he also directed the documentary The Hidden Beauty of Calbiga.

Froilan also acted, both on stage and in film. He made his theater debut in the title role of Chris Millado’s Makbet, 2000. With Edna Vida, he played the major role in the romantic-comedy Hintayan ng Langit (Waiting Room in Heaven), written by Juan Miguel Severoand directed by Raffy Tejada shown during the 2015 Virgin Labfest. In film, he essayed the lead role of Ricardo de la Torre in Paul Morales’s Concerto, an entry for Cinemalaya in 2008. That same year, he also appeared as a guest actor in the film Hubad (Naked), directed by Denisa Reyes and Mark Gary.
