He also took on supporting roles in Peque Gallaga’s Agaton and Mindy, 2009, and the OFW film Fidel, 2009, by Shandii Bacolod. In 2014, he was also featured in GMA News TV’s Sine Totoo documentary Mananayaw: A Documentary on the Male Ballet Dancer, directed by his own son, Rafael Froilan Jr. He has also acted in ABS-CBN's drama series Be My Lady , 2016.

Froilan took on the role of restager for BP’s Giselle, in 2013and again in 2014, the latter with American Ballet Theater guest artists Stella Abrera and James Whiteside as Giselle and Albrecht, respectively.

His excellence in the performing arts earned him awards such as the City of Manila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinganan, 1983, the Most Distinguished Samareño Award from his home province, 1987, and the award for Distinguished Alumnus in the Performing Arts from the University of the East Alumni Association Inc., 1993. In the same year, BP gave him a tribute titled Farewell Concert, Dance Classics: A Tribute to Nonoy Froilan.Written by Edna Vida, updated by Anna Camille Fabella

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Larry Gabao at the graduation rites of Philippine Normal University, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Larry Gabao presiding a meeting as vice-president of Philippine Normal University, 2014

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
GABAO, LARRY ( Larry Alubog Gabao )b. Looc, Romblon 2 Jul 1954. Choreographer, scholar, dance administrator, and teacher. His parents are Imelda G. Alubog and Victoriano G. Gabao. He is married to Ruby Co Gabao with whom he has a daughter, Katrina Bianca Gabao. He attended the Looc Elementary School and graduated from Looc National High School, Romblon. He received his bachelor of science in elementary education and his graduate certificate, both in physical education, from the Philippine Normal College (PNC). He then took his master’s degree in education with specialization in physical education at PNC and a PhD in educational management at the Polytechnic University of the Philippines (PUP). He also received scholarship grants from the Southeast Asia Ministers of Education Archaeology and Fine Arts Training Course in Kinetography Laban/Labanotation in Jakarta, Indonesia, 1989, Singapore, 1991, Bangkok, Thailand, 1993, Hanoi, Vietnam, 1995, Paris, France, and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, 1997.

He danced with the then PNC Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe (later, the Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe) under its founder, the late Dr Paz Cielo Belmonte. As a dancer, he took part in international dance festivals such as the Asian Arts Festival in Japan, 1975, the Australia Arts Festival Continental Tour, 1976, the World Bishop Conference and Festival in Germany, 1978, West Coast Tourism Promotions, USA, 1978, Kuwait International Arts Festival, 1980, the Cultural Exchange Program Peoples Republic of China, 1981, and Peninsular Arts Festival Malaysia and Singapore, 1982. He has choreographed for the Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center, the South East Asia Dance Troupe, Hong Kong, the Dow Summer School of the Arts, Hong Kong, and the Philippine Normal University (PNU) Kislap Sining Dance Troupe.

Aside from his choreographies, he has also done field research such as the BIBAK: Ethnic Dances of Bontoc, Ifugao, Benguet, Apayao, and Kalinga, A Comparative Study, for his MA thesis at the PNU, as well as on the Manobo dances of Agusan del Sur for documentation and production use. He is currently working on his Analysis and Codification of Ethnic Dance Movement Patterns for instructional useand T’boli Dances of Lake Sebu, South Cotabato: A Documentation for Instruction. He has also contributed articles to newspapers, periodicals, and journals and edited the Philippine Folk Dance Society’s Sayaw: Dances of Philippine Islands,Vols. 1-6, of from 1999 to 2002, and 2004 to 2005.

Gabao was instrumental in spearheading major dance events and projects when he was head of the Dance Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts from 2001 to 2004 and as president of the Philippine Folk Dance Society from 1996 to 2005 and 2009 to 2011. He also served as officer of the World Dance Alliance Philippines, 1998 to 2012, and the World Folklore Festival Organization CIOOF Philippines, 1998 to 2012.

Among the awards he has received are: Folk Dancing Award, 1975, from the PNC; Best Choreography Award, 1982 given during the 10th Hong Kong Arts Festival, Hong Kong; Young Achievers Award of the Philippines for Education, 1990; Most Outstanding Alumnus award from the PUP, 1995; Outstanding Alumnus, PNU Alumni Association, 1998; Outstanding Teacher of the Year, from the PNU, 2005; Huwaran Award for Outstanding Cultural Artists, Hawaii, USA, 2006; and the Gawad Patnubay ng Kalinangan at Sining given in 2009.Written by Ronnie Mirabuena

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
El Gabriel in Palm Springs, California, 1974

(Photo courtesy of Wikimedia Commons)

text:
GABRIEL, EL ( Israel Gabriel )b. 23 Oct 1944. Dancer, choreographer. Gabriel trained in ballet with RicardoandRobertaCassell and with AnitaKane. He further trained at the American Ballet Theater School, the Metropolitan Ballet School, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo School, the International School of Dance, Ballet Arts Studio, and the School of American Ballet, all in New York. He also studied moderndance in the schools of Martha Graham and Jose Limon, and jazz from Luigi. He observed at the Vaganova Choreographic Institute in Leningrad and taught master classes in Moscow.

He danced in Broadway musical shows like Flower Drum Song,and for US television in HollywoodPalace,and became a member of the Yeichi Nimura Dance Company, 1960 to 1962. He taught in Eugene Loring’s American School of Dance, 1966 to 1968, in Los Angeles and was ballet master, guest artist, and choreographer for DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP), 1968 to 1969, and for Bat-Dor Company in Tel-Aviv, Israel, 1969 to 1973. He has been lecturer and acting chairperson for the dance department at the University of California in Irvine. He has also been conducting master classes all over the US like Alaska and Columbia, in the Bahamas, in Israel, and in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

He was artistic director of Le Ballet Pallas Dance Theatre in Los Alaminos, and associate director of California Dance Company in Los Angeles. He also taught at the Lichine Ballet Academy in Beverly Hills and the Los Angeles Dance Centre.

His works include Duetto, 1982; Jazz Piece on Ice,1982, for Holiday on Ice of Moscow; Eidolon,1983; Le Printemps Eternel (Eternal Spring) and Concerti for Four,both in 1984; Incipient, Kimberlite, and Pas de Deux, all in 1985; Isla del Encanto (Enchanted Island), 1987; and Rashomon,1989. With DTP, he choreographed Caprice,1968, and Olympiad I,1969.

Gabriel was cited the Most Popular Lecturer in Dance at the University of California in Irvine in 1982 where he has been a lecturer in ballet. He also received the International Men of Achievement Award from the International Biographic Centre in Cambridge, United Kingdom, in 1984.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Gaye Galiluyo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
GALILUYO, GAYE ( Unita Gaye Sabeñano Galiluyo )b. Pasay 22 Oct 1972. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She is one of the seven children of drummer Guillermo Maolawin Galiluyo and teacher Magdalena Celis Sabeñano. She graduated from the Philippine High School for the Arts in 1989 and went on to major in dance at the University of the Philippines under Basilio Esteban Villaruz. In 1991, she became a member of Ballet Philippines (BP) and trained under Agnes Locsin, Noordin Jumalon, William Morgan, Denisa Reyes, Edna Vida, and Alice Reyes. Among her significant mentors and dance teachers are Joji Felix Velarde, Sonia Domingo, Cora Iñigo, Mercy Drilon, Cecile Sicangco, Nonoy Froilan, and Victor Ursabia.

In the 1993 Tokyo International Choreography Contest, Galiluyo was one of the dancers in Agnes Locsin’s Babalyan (Healer), which won second prize and the Prince Takamado Award for Choreography. She was a soloist for BP until 1998 after which she moved to Europe. There, Galiluyo trained under Christine Kono, Rosangela Calheiros, Rita Lussi, and Dimitri Kraniotis. From 1999 to 2001, she became a guest dancer at Tanztheater Basel in Switzerland, under director and choreographer Joachim Schlömer. She was part of Schlömer’s opera La Guerra D’Amore (Love Is War),2000, at the Schiller Theater in Berlin. In 2001 she choreographed and danced in Split Seconds,which premiered at the Stadttheater Giessen Theater.

She also worked with Irina Pauls, Manuel Quero, and David Bolger for Tanztheater Freiburg-Heidelburg from 2001 to 2006. She was involved in the Linga Dance Project in Switzerland in 2000, 2004, and 2007, while continuing to be a freelance artist working in theaters all over Europe. She taught ballet at Profitraining Basel in Switzerland, and modern dance at the Moira Fetterman Dance School and Next Step Dance School Freiburg, both in Germany. In 2012, she choreographed and performed RE PSYCHE LING, which premiered in E-werk Theater.

In 2010 Galiluyo came home to perform in Locsin’s Sayaw Sabel (Dance of Sabel), cochoreographing a frenetic solo with her mentor. In 2012 she appeared alongside Georgette Sanchez in Puno: Pangatlong Galaw (Tree: Third Movement), part of Locsin’s Alay sa Puno (Offering to the Tree)series.

Galiluyo was awarded First Prize (Dancer) for her performance in Jasna Vinovrski’s piece Which Club?, 2005, during the 9th Solo Dance Theater Stuttgart Competition. She performed the same piece in 2006 for the Masdanza International Solo Dance Competition in Spain.Written by Chantal Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Aileen Gallinera with Jesus Pastor in Giselle, 2012

(Photo by Josep Rodenas, courtesy of the artist)

Aileen Gallinera

(Photo by Josep Rodenas, courtesy of the artist)

text:
GALLINERA,AILEEN ( Aileen Mercado Gallinera )b. Quezon City 18 Jan 1976. Dancer. Gallinera is the daughter of Bienvenido Gaurino Gallinera and Flora Mercado. Her brother Ryan Benedict Gallinera is an architect. She has a BS in Computer Science from Systems Technology Institute, 2002. Previously, she took up an AB in Child Development and Education in Miriam College, 1992-94. She trained with Effie Nañas at the Effie Nañas School of Classical Ballet; Nina Anonas-de Santos and Ladybird Castillo at Ecole De Ballet Manille; Noordin Jumalon, Jeannette Racillo, and Carmel Tan at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School. In 1992, she joined Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), and later was among the first batch of dancers that formed Lisa Macuja-Elizalde’s Ballet Manila (BM) in 1995. She danced with BM until 2003, and reached the rank of senior soloist. She resumed dancing with PBT in 2004 before joining Ballet David Campos in Barcelona, Spain, in 2005.

She performed in BM’s initial touring repertoire of pas de deux anddivertissements all over the Philippines and in tours to Russia and the United States. In Krasnoyarsk, Russia, Gallinera and her partner Jeffrey Espejo were specially invited to perform the Satanilla pas de deux at the 2nd International Music Festival of the Asia-Pacific region, where BM represented the Philippines in 1995. She gained further prominence in the Philippine premiere of Le Corsaire (The Pirate) in 1998 as the lead, Medora, and as one of the three Odalisques; as Odette and Odile in Swan Lake, 1998 and 2003; and as lead Snowflake, Spanish doll, and Arabian doll in The Nutcracker, 1998 and 2001. She performed the peasant pas de deux in Giselle in a joint production with Ballet Philippines in 1999 and reprised the role in 2002, while also portraying the role of Myrtha. In 2002, she portrayed Kitri and the Dryad Queen in Don Quixote. She appeared in several world premieres with BM, notably in Edna Vida’s Flux, 1997; Jean Paul Comelin’s Firebird, 2000; and Agnes Locsin’s Sayao sa Pamlang (Dances with Bamboos), 2001. She was noted for her glowing stage presence and secure technique.

In her year with PBT in 2004, Gallinera was given lead roles as Gamzatti and a soloist Shade in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer); as Suzuki in Tom Pazik’s Madame Butterfly; as Death in David Campos’s Carmina Burana; and as the diva, a role she originally created, in Gener Caringal’s Isang Bagong Bituin (A New Star). In Ballet David Campos, she excelled in Campos’s deconstructions of the classical ballets: Bella Durmiente ( The Sleeping Beauty ) as the Lilac Fairy, Princess Florine, and Aurora; Cascanueces ( The Nutcracker ) as the Snow Queen and Clara; Don Quixote, as Kitri; and Giselle, as Giselle, her signature title role during the company’s tour to the Philippines in 2012. She is also featured in Campos’s Turn Me On and Eurasia. Since 2006, she has been teaching at Escola Ballet David Campos.Written by Joelle Florence P. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Biag Gaongen

(Photo from facebook.com/biag.gaongen)

Biag Gaongen

Photo from facebook.com/biag.gaongen)

text:
GAONGEN, BIAG ( Biag Batnag Gaongen )b. Pangasinan 30 Nov 1982. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. He is the son of Mario Alicda Gaongen and Mary Jane Batnag. He is a graduate of De La Salle University-College of St. Benilde, with a bachelor’s degree in performing arts, major in dance. Gaongen was a theater student of the Philippine High School for the Arts in Los Baños. Since 1997, he was exposed to international festivals, particularly Le Mondial du Theatre in Monaco and World Amateur Theater Festival in Belgium. While still a student, he was discovered by Ballet Philippines (BP) Director Agnes Locsin and has since then trained extensively in dance. He was a member of BP from 2007 to 2009, where he became a principal dancer and toured with the group in Cambodia, Japan, and Germany.

He portrayed major roles for BP, including those in the restaged ballet classics Don Quixote, La Sylphide, Cinderella, The Nutcracker,and William Morgan’s Ang Pilya. He showed versatility in neo-classical ballet productions, such as Michael Vernon’s Opus 25,Allan Hineline’s Threshold II, Augustus Damian III’s Double Takes, and as Crisostomo Ibarra/Rizal in Alden Lugnasin’s Rizal Revisited,2007.He was also distinguished in modern dance pieces by Max Luna III, Darrel Toulon, James Wilton, David Russo, Alvin Tolentino, Erwin Flores, and Myra Beltran. He is best recognized as Apolinario Mabini in Locsin’s powerful La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution),2008, and in a 2009 staging of Denisa Reyes’s Te Deum.

In 2009, he joined the modern dance group Cloud Gate Dance Theater as its first non-Chinese dancer. In addition to ballet and modern dance, he further trained in Tai Chi Daoing and martial arts. He was cast in Lin Hwai-Min’s erotic and mysterious Songs of the Wanderer, Listening to the River, and Whisper of Flowers. He toured with the company in international dance festivals, performing in the Chekov International Theater Festival in Moscow, Ravenna Festival, the International Festival of Villa Adriana in Rome, and the Singapore Arts Festival. In 2011, he joined the Austria-based group Tanzcompanie Der Oper Graz.

Locally, Gaongen has choreographed for Academy One, Perry Sevidal Ballet, Tanghalang Pilipino, and for the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA), namely Beep,2009, and Moving On, 2010. He showcased his expressiveness and strength in Agnes Locsin’s series Alay sa Puno (Tribute to the Tree),that started with the solo concert Ugat: Ang Unang Galaw (Root: First Movement),2010. In this tribute to environmental advocacy, he choreographed Alagaan Mo Ako (Take Care of Me), 2013, as seen in Sanga: Ika-Apat na Galaw (Branch: Fourth Movement) in the Alay sa Puno series.

He is the recipient of Gawad Buhay’s Outstanding Male Performer in 2008, for his role as Apolinario Mabini in La Revolucion Filipina.Written by Nicole Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Inday Gaston-Mañosa’s graduation photo, Assumption College Herran, 1951

(Photo courtesy of Isidra Reyes)

Inday Gaston-Mañosa

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
GASTON-MAÑOSA, INDAY ( Maria LuisaGaston-Mañosa) b. Iloilo City 2 Sep 1928. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Her parents are Emilio Gaston and Amparo Corteza; soprano ConchitaGaston is a sister. Marriedto ManuelMañosaJr,an architect, she isthe mother of dancers Maiqui, Mia Monica, and Mimel Mañosa, and the aunt of dancers Nicole and Lydlyd Gaston.She graduated with degrees in bachelor of arts and bachelor of science in education from Assumption Convent. In dance, she studied with LuvaAdameit, RemediosdeOteyza, PaulSzilard, Mia Slavenska, and other teachers in New York.

Gaston-Mañosa was a founding member of the BalletFederationofthePhilippines in 1976, and of PhilippineBalletTheatre in 1987, of which she was also the first artistic director, 1988-89. Among her notable roles were the Black Swan pas de deux and principal parts in Paul Szilard’s Sylvia and Polovetsky Dances, and de Oteyza’s Grieg Concerto in A and Four Elements. As choreographer, she collaborated with De Oteyza on Four Elements and IbongAdarna, and with Eli Jacinto on Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra by Britten.

Gaston-Mañosa taught and worked with De Oteyza in the Classic Ballet Academy and founded the HarirayaBalletCompany with her in 1968. It was they who brought Sulamith Messerer, the Bolshoi Ballet teacher, to Manila. Hariraya was the first professional ballet group in the Philippines.Written by Globio and M. Ojeda

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
GENEROSO-IÑIGO, CORAZON ( Corazon Cristobal Generoso-Iñigo ) b. Manila 18 Dec 1930. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Her father was Jose Generoso, a theater production director; her mother was Felisa Cristobal, whose own father, Venancio Cristobal, was a renownedbombardinosoloist. She is married to Carlos Iñigo Jr. She studied at the University of the Philippines (UP), receiving a bachelor of science degree in education, major in physical education in 1951, as well as a master of science degree in physical education in 1990. Her dance training has been varied, with Trudl Dubsky-Zipper, Ricardo Cassell, Alice Reyes, and Norman Walker. She danced with Dubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne and did solo parts in the Manila Ballet Academy’s productions of Swan Lake and Giselle. She learned folk dancing from many sources, including a UP group under Luz Einsiedel and her own field researches.

Iñigo taught at the UP College of Human Kinetics, the International School, the National College of Physical Education, the Philippine Women’s College in Davao, the Far Eastern University (FEU), the University of the East (UE), the Philippine High School for the Arts, and the UP College of Music. She was guest teacher for Ballet Philippines (BP) and the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ (CCP) summer dance workshop. She conducted dance workshops and seminars in Philippine provinces, Hong Kong, China, and France. She has headed Philippine delegations to international festivals and conferences all over the world, including the Conseil International des Organisations des Folk Festivals et Folklore which she regularly attended up to 2014.

Her choreographic works for the University of the East dance Group include Lam-ang, with librettist Mig Alvarez-Enriquez and composer Jerry Dadap; and for the UP Filipiniana Dance Group, Jubilation to Bach, Brother Sun, Sister Moon and Rumors to Ryan Cayabyab, Gabriela Silang to Eliseo Pajaro, and Sisa to Pipo-Walton-Ohana. For BP she choreographed Baile de Ayer (Dance of Yesteryears), 1974, to Rodolfo Cornejo; Sisa, 1978,to Lucrecia Kasilag;and Gabriela, 1989,to Joey Ayala.

She also choreographed for and danced in the movies: Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in New Life), 1953; Waray-waray, 1954; Cover Girls and Let’s Do the Psychedelic ’68, 1967; The More I See You, 1968; and Pinokyo en Little Snow White (Pinocchio and Little Snow White) and Poor Little Rich Girl, 1972. She also acted in two movies: Adios mi Amor (Goodbye My Love), 1971, and Tatarin, 2001.

Iñigo has integrated dance researches into her standard repertoires, including “Awitan” (Singing), “Batad” (Sorghum Grass), “Ifugao Funeral Dance,” “Ilongot Festival Dance,” “Manobo Courtship Dance,” “Manobo War Dance,” “Maranaw Fan Dance,” “Tanggungo Dance,” and “Tiruray Festival Dance.”

She was awarded the Golden Kulintang by the Philippine Women’s College, Davao; the Altiora Peto Award by the Delta Lambda Sigma Sorority; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan by the City of Manila, 1975; the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Sayaw) Award, 1997; the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts Award, 1999; and the National Commission for Culture and the Art’s Dangal ng Haraya (Life Achievement) in dance, 2007. In 2011, the UP Alumni Association conferred on her the Lifetime Achievement Award.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
GOMEZ-RIVERA, GUILLERMO b. Dingle, Iloilo 12 Sep 1936. Essayist, choreographer, playwright. He is the son of Francisco Gomez and Lourdes Rivera. He is the grand nephew of Guillermo Gomez Windham, who won the first Premio Zobel in 1922 for “La Carrera de Candida.” He is married to Anna Marie Ordoñez, with whom he has two children. He holds a bachelor of science in commerce and education, bachelor of arts and master of arts from the University of San Agustin in Iloilo City and Colegio de San Juan de Letran in Manila. He earned his doctoral degree at the Real Academia de la Lengua Española in Madrid. He taught at Adamson University for many years. At present, he is a consultant for the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company. He specializes in Spanish and Latin-American dance choreography.

Among his major works are the study Filipino: Origen y Conotacion (Filipino: Origin and Connotation), 1969, the play El Caseron (The Big House), and various articles in English about Ilonggo literature and language. Gomez-Rivera also published the newsmagazine El Maestro and is editor of the Listening Poet and Tagalog Chronicle. He also edited the magazines El Nuevo Horizonte and Nueva Era.

Gomez-Rivera received the Premio Zobel in 1975. His other awards include the Premio de ManuelBernabe, 1984, and the grant from Sesiones de Trabajo de la Asociacion de Academias de la Lengua Española, 1976. A staunch Hispanist, he is a member of the Academia Filipina and the Royal Academy of the Spanish Language and fought for the preservation of Spanish in the Philippine Constitutional Convention of 1971-73. Written byLeoncio Deriada

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
GONZALEZ, TONI LOPEZ ( Antonela Lopez Gonzalez )b. Manila 11 Oct 1965. Dancer, teacher. She started ballet at the age of four with her mother, dancer-teacher SonyLopez-Gonzalez, at the Academie of the Performing Arts in Makati. She finished high school at the Assumption Convent, 1983, and studied briefly at the De La Salle University. In 1972 she was a scholar at the Richard Thomas New York School of Dance and the Ballet Arts in the United States, and again in 1977 at the American Ballet Theater (ABT) School and the Melissa Hayden School. She also studied with Jurgen Schneider, Patricia Wilde, Robert Denvers, Igor Youskevitch, Violette Verdy, David Howard, Michael Lland, John Prinz, Diane Cartier, Mary Day, Elena Tchernikova, and Gabriela Taub Darvash. In 1978, at the age of 12, she joined BalletPhilippines (BP) and eventually became a principal dancer. With the company, she performed in Asia and Europe. In 1982, she entered the ABT scholarship program and received grants from the Culpepper and Hearst Foundations. In 1983, she was a semifinalist in the 11th International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria. In 1984, she was one of five finalists in the first New York Ballet Competition.

Between 1985 and 1989, she was a soloist and later a principal dancer with the Washington Ballet, touring the United States, Europe, and Asia. From 1990 to 1991, she was with BP. In 1987 she guested in principal parts with Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in Jian Zuhui’s NewYear’s Sacrifice, in 1991 with the Hong Kong Ballet Group in La Fille Mal Gardee, for the Third China National Arts Festival in Camille by EricV.Cruz, and in 1992 with the West Australia Symphony Orchestra in Perth. She has danced principal roles in TheNutcracker, Giselle, The Sleeping Beauty, Don Quixote, Swan Lake, Les Sylphides, La Bayadere (original versionby Vhaktang Chabukiani), Napoli, Cinderella, RomeoandJuliet, and Peter Pan and in the contemporary ballets of Choo San Goh, Judith Jamison, Matthew Diamond, Norman Walker, Paul Taylor, James Ganfield, and Alonso King. She teaches for PBT and its school, and has guested in the schools of BP and the Jean M. Wong School of Ballet in Hong Kong. She runs a dance school in Valle Verde, Pasig City.Written by Nerissa S. Balce and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jesse Gotangco

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Jesse Gotangco

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Jesse Gotangco

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
GOTANGCO, JESSE ( Jesse Gilliam de Zuñiga Gotangco )akaBboy Reflex. b. Manila 4 Jul 1989. Dancer, choreographer. His mother is Jamesina Z. Gotangco. He graduated with a bachelor of fine arts degree, major in arts management, from the Ateneo de Manila University (ADMU) in 2010. “Bboy Reflex” trained in hip-hop with Ken Swift of Manhattan, New York; Karl “Dyzee” Alba and Rene “Naytron” Abalos of the United States; and the Rivers Crew of South Korea. He also took classes in hip-hop and other forms such as locking and popping, house, New School Streetdance with the Elite Crew from Singapore, Lenny Len of Canada, Salah of France, Paul Ross of Los Angeles, and homegrown Filipinos Jay “JMasta” Cambay and David “Stretch” Castro.

Gotangco is considered an icon of the Philippine b-boying scene, a form of street dancing that incorporates musical genres such as hip-hop, funk music, and breakbeats. He has made it his personal mission to promote b-boying in the Philippines for social development. His crew also organizes dance programs and performances for the less privileged within Metro Manila and nearby provinces. He teaches hip-hop dance and breaking at the ADMU and coaches dance groups in different schools in Metro Manila. He has also been invited to be a guest teacher at Studio Wu in Singapore and the International Youth Hiphop Summit in Guam in 2010.

Bboy Reflex is the founder of the Philippine dance crew Soulstice and Tha Project and has performed in numerous dance productions, television programs, streetdance competitions, and individual battles in the country and abroad. His crew members have made it to major competitions abroad such as the R16 in Korea, Radical Forze in Singapore, and Hiphop International in Las Vegas, USA.

In Jul 2013, he emerged as the winner of R16 World B-boy Championship, an international dance competition for b-boys held in Seoul, South Korea. He bested 30 other dancers from seven countries in the B-boy Masters Championship for the solo category. He was later on tapped and trained by R16 to judge its upcoming competitions and battles. New Image Productions based in Hawaii, USA, also honored him with the award Philippine B-boy of the Year in 2013. With his experience in competitions and battles, he was invited as consultant for the 2014 Aliwan Festival hosted by the Manila Broadcasting Corporation.Written by Clarissa Cecilia Mijares-Ramos

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Halili-Cruz Dance Company

(Photo from halilicruzballet.com)

Halili-Cruz Dance Company

(Photo from halilicruzballet.com)

Halili-Cruz Dance Company

(Photo from halilicruzballet.com)

text:
HALILI-CRUZ DANCE COMPANY (HCDC)/QUEZON CITY BALLET(QCB) The official performing group of the Halili-Cruz School of Ballet (HCSB), HCDC was founded in Apr 1988. Its founder and artistic director is Shirley Halili-Cruz, supported by associate artistic directors Anna Kathrina Halili-Cruz Bueno and Grace Garalde-Perez. One of the objectives of the company is to provide the dancers trained in the Halili-Cruz School of Ballet with a platform to build their dance techniques and skills and to further develop their confidence and stage presence.

The HCDC, then more popularly known as QCB, first performed in Apr 1988 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines with its first 35 young members. The repertoire included Swan Lake, “Kingdom of the Shades” from La Bayadere ( The Temple Dancer), “Bluebird Pas de Deux” from Sleeping Beauty,“Valse Engrande,” and Don Quixote Grand Pas.

The HCDC has invited dance masters, educators and choreographers around the Philippines and from other countries like Sergei Bykov, Anatoly Panassiukov, William Morgan, Miro Zolan, Christine Walsh, and Morgan Conelly to conduct master classes in various dance forms. Its company dancers attend classes at the Australian Conservatoire of Dance, American Academy of Ballet, Big Dance Co England, and Singapore Summer Dance.

The company performs classical ballet, contemporary, jazz, tap, folk, and hip-hop. Some of its performers are also theater artists. The HCDC has regularly represented the country in different international festivals and competitions in Russia, England, New York, Los Angeles, Australia, Brunei, Cambodia, China, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam, and has consistently won top prizes. In the past 32 years, HCDC received numerous local and international awards and distinctions. These include the 21st Century International Arts Festival in Malaysia,2009; the Best Performance in Bauhinia Cup in Hong Kong, 2010; the Grand Prize in the Asia Pacific Dance Competition in Singapore, Bangkok, and Hong Kong in 2013.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Shirley Halili-Cruz (Photo courtesy of the artist)
Shirley Halili-Cruz (Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
HALILI-CRUZ, SHIRLEY ( Shirley Casanova Halili-Cruz )b. Manila 18 Oct 1958. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Married to engineer Eric Almeda Cruz, she is the daughter of soprano and costume maker Rufina Casanova and businessman Rufino Halili. Her sisters Rufina and Jo are folk dancers; and another, Zenaida,is a classical ballet dancer who danced with Ballet Philippines. She graduated valedictorian in grade school and high school in Siena College, and summa cum laude in Colegio de San Juan de Letran, 1980, with a degree in business administration, major in accounting. She is the artistic director of the Halili-Cruz School of Ballet, the Quezon City Ballet/Halili-Cruz Dance Company, and the HC Conservatory.

Halili-Cruz began training in dance at the age of eight when she received a scholarship at the Weinstein School of Ballet and studied under Bonnie Weinstein Calagopi. At the age of 13, she became Calagopi’s teaching assistant and at 15, she took over the teaching at her mentor’s ballet school when Calogapi left for the US. In 1972, she began studying at the School of American Ballet under Edgar Valdez. She also trained abroad at the New York Academy and Conservatory of Music, American Ballet Center, and the Neubert Ballet Institute. She also earned professional accreditation from the Dance Educators of America and Western Kentucky University.

She also trained with Jean Deroc, Robert Barnett, Maniya Barredo, William Morgan, Burton Taylor, Tina Santos, and Gary Wahl. While in school, Halili-Cruz participated in and choreographed for the theater productions of Fr James Reuter. She trained and danced with Dance Concert Company under Vella Damian and Eric V. Cruz. She took lead roles in Cruz’s Minkusiana, 1983-85; Visions in Blue,1976-80; Carmen, 1976-85; Camille and La Gitana,1980-82; Mir-i-nisa,1982; solo parts in Swan Lake, 1974-85; Paquita,1974-85; Don Quixote, 1980-86; and Giselle, 1985.

She founded the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in 1984. She choreographed Alice in Wonderland, 1985; Filipino Suite and Variations in White, both in 1988; and Ang Aming Inay (Our Mom), 1988, to music by Ernani Cuenco; Valse Engrande (Grand Waltz); Promenade, 1990; and Konsiyerto (Concert), 1991. In 1988 she established the school’s performing arm, the Quezon City Ballet also known as Halili-Cruz Dance Company. She authored a 12-level classical ballet syllabus adapted for the Filipino psyche and physique, drawing from various forms of dance and from the techniques of mentors she was exposed to while studying abroad.

In 2007, she was elected chair of the national dance committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), spearheading projects such as Sayaw Pinoy, a touring dance concert with the participation of dance companies from all over the country. She also began NCCA projects like the National Dance Competition and the Dance Xchange. The latter is an international dance festival that brings together local and foreign dance companies with the objective of building and strengthening an international dance network. Her awards include the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan sa Larangan ng Sayaw from the City of Manila, the Asia Pacific Arts Council’s global excellence award conferred in Thailand in 2006, Dangal ng Lipi, Sining at Kultura from Bulacan Province in 2007 and 2011, Outstanding Citizen of Quezon City Award as cultural ambassador in 2007, the Outstanding Filipino for Arts and Culture in 2010, and the ALIW Lifetime Achievement Award in 2013.Written by Mary Jane L. Globio, Mena Ojeda, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan and Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Hariraya Ballet Company’s Ibong Adarna, 1970

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Hariraya Ballet Company

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
HARIRAYA BALLET COMPANY It was founded in 1968 as Hariraya Dance Company by Remedios“Totoy”deOteyza and MariaLuisa“Inday”Gaston-Mañosa. It was endowed a year’s subsidy by Jose Mari Locsin of Silay City. The company was the culmination of a series of groups started by de Oteyza from her Classical Ballet Academy, later called Ballet and Dance Center, starting with the De Oteyza Ballet in the 1950s, followed by the Manila Ballet Company, and an informally constituted Hariraya in 1967.

Its first major concert in Feb 1968 at the Rizal Theater featured Les Sylphides, Four Elements by Gaston-Mañosa and de Oteyza to music by Rachmaninoff, and Masquerade by de Oteyza to music by Khatchaturian, accompanied by the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra (MSO) with OscarYatco as conductor and Solita Gutierrez as piano soloist. In Nov, Hariraya premiered ReynaldoAlejandro and Roberto Caballero’s LegendoftheSarimanok,with music by Bayani MendozadeLeon, and CesarMendoza’s DifficultYears,with music by Menotti. In Mar 1969, it performed with soloists from the Bolshoi Ballet like Raisa Struchkova, Alexander Lapauri, Boris Khokhlov, and Vladimir Levashev, for the inaugural season of the Meralco Theater. The company supported them in Swan Lake, Act II, and it saw a de Oteyza and Lulu Puertollano-attributed Sarimanok.

Another major production in Dec 1969 was directed by Sulamith Messerer. It premiered locally the grand pas de deuxfrom Paquita with VellaDamian and EricV.Cruz, and “The Shades” act of La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer) with EffieNañas and Conrad Tiolengco.

Also in the repertoire of original works were Design and Variations No. 1 by de Oteyza-Tchaikovsky, Combat by de Oteyza-Debussy, Sisa by Alejandro and Caballero-Mendoza de Leon, and Capriccio Espagnol, featuring RubenNieto. In 1970 Hariraya premiered IbongAdarna,commissioned by the CulturalCenterofthe Philippines (CCP).

For a time in 1973, the company also composed the briefly constituted MSO Corps de Ballet. In the 1980s, Hariraya performed erratically, mostly at Puerta Real, in FestivalFour,1983 to 1985, at the CCP, and in SayawSining,1986, at the Manila MetropolitanTheater. It also performed in the provinces for a CCP outreach tour.

Hariraya acquired works from Eli Jacinto, collaborating with Gaston-Mañosa in Britten’s Young Person’sGuide to the Orchestra,from GenerCaringal in Ruben Federizon’s Sanggumai,and Rhapsody in Blue (after de Oteyza), and Harana Suite from Gaston-Mañosa in the 1980s.

Among the company’s leading members, were LuluPuertollano, Vicki and ManiyaBarredo, Effie Nañas, Vella Damian, Carmina Gutierrez, Nini and Pinky Mendoza, Nida Onglengco, Amelia Garcia-Yulo, VedaBañez, Eric V. Cruz, Conrad Tiolengco, Rene Dimacali, CesarMendoza, Jun Dalit, Teofilo Pila, Ernie Estrella, Tony Bisenio, and Rudy Seranilla. Younger ones who followed were Maiqui and Mia Monica Mañosa, Gina Katigbak, and Melanie Motus. After the death of de Oteyza in 1978, Gaston-Mañosa carried on as artistic director, until the company integrated with other groups to form the Philippine Ballet Theatre in 1987.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
HOFER-ELE, HENRIETTA ( Henrietta Tocao Hofer-Ele )b. Malabang, Lanao del Sur 28 Oct 1935. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She and folk dancer Marlene Hofer Tamano of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company are daughters of Pablo Hofer and Manuela Tocao. She received her bachelor of science in education, major in physical education (PE), from the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) in 1957, and her master of science also in PE from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1974.

As a student, she danced with the Bayanihan, working with Libertad V. Fajardo, Francisca Reyes-Aquino, and Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula. She was the company’s first singkil princess, its student dance director, and student researcher in Mindanao dances and music.

After teaching for several years in Cotabato, she became head in 1962, then director of the PE department of Mindanao State University (MSU) in Marawi City. When the department became the MSU College of Sports, Physical Education, and Recreation, she became one of its professors, and its dean from 1981 to 1986.

In MSU, she was also involved in overall curricular and executive planning, and in cultural affairs. In addition, she was consultant to the Folk Arts Theater and the UP, and chair or coordinator for festivals organized in Region XII, the rest of Mindanao, and Metro Manila. In 1966, she directed MSU’s Darangan Cultural Troupe until her retirement.

She was active in the Philippine Association of Physical Education and Sports for Girls and Women, Physical Education and Sports Association of the Philippines, National Commission on the Role of Filipino Women, International Council of Health, Physical Education and Recreation, and is a lifetime member of the PhilippineFolkDanceSociety.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Hwa-Yi Ethnic Dance Center

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
HWA YI ETHNIC DANCE CENTER A Chinese-Filipino dance group formed in 1971, the group’s main objectives are to learn and propagate Chinese and Philippine folk dances, to promote cultural exchanges, and to establish strong Filipino-Chinese ties. Its former artistic director is Jerry Sibal Ong, succeeded by Ruth Abigail King Yu. Its dance director is Carl Louie Sy, and its choreographers for Filipino dances are Larry Gabao, LigayaFernando Amilbangsa, and Francisco Lising.

The center is a nonprofit organization that has gained recognition over four decades. On its 20th founding anniversary in 1991, it also marked the 15th anniversary of the cultural ties between the Philippines and the People’s Republic of China at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

From 1972, Hwa Yi has been the cultural arm of the Chinese-Filipino community. Among its presentations were: Have a Charity Show for the City of Manila, 1972; When Flowers Bloom,1975, at the CCP; Merge ’76,1976; Gala Easter Concert, 1978, in Baguio City for the Department of Tourism and Chinatown Tour and Travel; a Cebu tour in 1978; Plum Blossom, CCP, 1980; Oriental Songsand Dances,1982; a tour of China, 1984; Vintage,1987; and Indak Awit (Dance, Song), 1988. Since the start of the CCP’s Pang-alay folk dance festival in 1988, Hwa Yi has joined the annual presentations.

In 1990, it represented the Philippines in the First China International Folk Art Festival in Beijing and five other cities. In 1991, the group represented the Philippines in the International Folk Art Festival in Utah, USA. In 1992, the group went on a performance tour in Italy upon the invitation of the Conseil International Des Organizations de Festival de Folklore (CIOFF). In 1995, it traveled to China to perform at the Peony Festival, Henan province.

Hwa Yi is active in festivals and dance events sponsored by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). One is the Araw ng Sayaw (Day of Dance) which the group joined in 1993, 1999, 2002, and 2003. Another NCCA dance tour is Sayaw Pinoy (Filpino Dance) held in Cebu in 2004 and 2008. It was an active participant in NCCA’s International Dance Xchange held in Dumaguete City, 2009; in Roxas City, 2010; and in Cebu City, 2012.

It actively promotes folk dances from the Philippines and from other Asian countries through provincial tours such as the Alay sa Guro (Gift to the Teacher) in Cagayan de Oro in 1996 and the provincial tour of Cebu City in 1998.

Hwa Yi’s full-length solo shows at the CCP were Dance Laud and Dance Laud II in 2001 and 2006, respectively. The group has garnered international awards and citations. In 1989 it won two major awards: Best in Choreography and Best in Performance during the Overseas Youth Video Song and Dance Competition organized by the Overseas Chinese Affairs in China. In 1994, it won the gold medal for group folk dance category and the silver medal for solo folk dance category during the Annual Seoul Dance Competition organized in cooperation with the Asian Dance Association.Written by Larry A. Gabao, updated by Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
INDONG-COLASING (Pedro Alfafara aka Indong and Nicolasa Caniban aka Colasing) Balitaw performers. Alfafara was born in Carcar, Cebu, in 1881. Not much is known about his early life except that an uncle, who was a balitaw practitioner, taught him the dance movements of the balitaw and that Indong quickly excelled in the form because of his natural gift for verse and rhyme and his resonant, melodious voice. Caniban was born in Mambaling, Cebu City in 1900, though other sources cite her birth year as 1906. She learned the art of the balitaw from her parents.

Alfafara was the more experienced artist, performing with other women-partners whom he helped train, before he met Caniban. The two must have teamed up first around 1920. By the 1920s, they had become extremely popular, touring the towns of Cebu as well as places in Bohol, Leyte, Negros Oriental, and Mindanao. They were invited to perform during fiestas, carnivals, and other festivities, private as well as public. The two were in such demand that they had to turn down invitations. They commanded a high price for performing and audiences would shower them with coins as they performed. There are references to other balitaw performers before Indong-Colasing, such as Hermenegildo(Amoros)Solon and his daughter Meding, ca 1916, but Indong-Colasing was the most popular pair of the prewar period.

In an interview published in The Freeman of 19 Nov 1926, Caniban said that she spontaneously composed the verses as she performed but that she and her partner would decide on a subject or theme beforehand, e.g., the unfortunate maiden, the deceitful promise, wealth breeds misery, or the patient wife. In the course of the performance, one of the partners might stray from the theme, thus testing the other’s skill in improvising without missing a beat.

Caniban possessed an amulet which she believed gave her the power to attract attention. She carried this mutya in a bottle of oil tied around her waist and anointed herself with the oil before a performance.

When the balitaw began to decline, the team split up. For a time, Alfafara continued performing with a new partner, Bebing Ybañez of Minglanilla, Cebu.

Eventually, both Alfafara and Caniban migrated to Mindanao. He settled down in Gingoog, Misamis Oriental, living the life of a farmer, while she raised a large family in Digos, Davao, where she sold fish in the market for a living. Written byErlinda Alburo

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Eli Jacinto

(Photo courtesy of Joelle Jacinto)

Eli Jacinto, right, rehearsing actor Paulo Avelino and his dancing partner for the film Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa, 2011

(Photo courtesy of Joelle Jacinto)

text:
JACINTO, ELI ( Celerino Avellaneda Jacinto ) b. Polillo, Quezon 25 Mar 1948. Choreographer, dancer, teacher. Eli Jacinto is the son of Pedro Abello Jacinto and Priscilla Avellaneda, who were both fans of the tango. His brother Antonio was a visual artist, while his sister, Emma Jean, pursued dance lessons. His uncle Jose, who taught him to play the trumpet, coconducted an orchestra with his cousin Felipe Padilla de Leon in Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija. He is married to Joan Banzon; their four children, Joelle, Quincy, Lucas, and Jacqueline, are all dancers. Jacinto’s education was often on scholarship: marching band for University of Manila; dance for Far Eastern University; and cheerleading for San Sebastian College. He trained with Tony Llacer at Julie Borromeo’s Dance Arts Philippines and Rosalia Merino Santos and her Far Eastern University Experimental Dance Troupe. He was cast as one of the warriors in the CCP’s inaugural Dularawan: Ang Salakot na Ginto (Image-Play: The Golden Salacot), 1969. He also trained with Anita Kane, Totoy de Oteyza, and William Morgan. Dance Arts sent Jacinto to New York to train at the Luigi Dance Center in 1970, and again in 1972. He returned to the Philippines and became a sought-after jazz teacher. During that decade, Jacinto also took classes at the American School of Dance in Los Angeles and the David Howard Dance Center in New York.

Jacinto was a favored jazz dancer in the 1970s, doing plum roles in Borromeo’s productions of Promises, Promises and Sweet Charity, and as the farmer in Luis Layag’s The Survival of St. Joan, 1973. He danced and choreographed at the Hong Kong TVB and Dance Festival, and for television shows and films. When engaged as a dancer, he also assisted in the choreography of dances, for Conching Sunico’s Karilagan, and Chito Madrigal-Collantes’s Bighani International, where he began his career as a fashion show director. He was assistant choreographer to Gary Flores for Imelda Marcos’s Bagong Anyo (New Image) at Nayong Filipino, 1972, and at Araneta Coliseum, 1973, where he performed the paunjalay, and from 1974 onwards at the CCP. Jacinto’s runway and corporate clients include Calvin Klein, Anne Klein, Jourdan et Cie, Philippine Airlines, and Prudential Life. He directed the Miss Asia Quest Asian Tour, and was entertainment director for the Sulo Group in the late 1970s.

He taught jazz and ballet at the College of Holy Spirit, St. Paul’s Parañaque, Hariraya Ballet Company, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, and Silid Sining. In 1981, he opened his Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement (TEAM) Dance Studio in Las Piñas. He conceptualized summer dinner theater shows at the Manila Polo Club in the early 1980s, and spearheaded the multi-art Dance and Arts Festival in 1985 at The Gallery, Alabang, and in 1986, in Parañaque.

He attended choreography workshops with Norman Walker, and was venue grantee of the CCP in 1991, producing his Dating Gawi, Bagong Anyo (Old Habits,New Image).His most significant works for TEAM are the celebrated The Emergence and Morphemes, both 1981; Manton at Abaniko (Spanish Shawl and Fan), Manukan (Chicken Coop), and Sa Panimula ng Buhay (At the Beginning of Life), 1991; Bathala (God), 1998; Giri (Strut), 2004; Pangilin (Worship), 2005; and In the Sisterhood, 2010. For Hariraya, he created Young Learner’s Guide to the Orchestra to Benjamin Britten, 1979; for Philippine Ballet Theatre, he did Magdaragat (Seafarer),1996. In 2011, he choreographed the dance sequences for Alvin Yapan’s award-winning Cinemalaya entry, Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa (The Dance of Two Left Feet). He was a founding member of World Dance Alliance-Philippines with Nestor Jardin in 1990.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Joelle Jacinto in Eli Jacinto’s In The Sisterhood, Kuala Lumpur, 2014

(Photo by James Quah, courtesy of the artist)

Joelle Jacinto, center, as Charing in Philippine Ballet Theatre’s Isang Bagong Bituin, choreographed by Gener Caringal, CCP, 2004

(Photo by Erik Roque, courtesy of the artist)

text:
JACINTO, JOELLE ( Joelle Florence Patrice Banzon Jacinto )b. Manila 20 Jun 1974. Dancer, teacher, critic, choreographer. She is the eldest daughter of dancer and choreographer Eli Jacinto and Joan Banzon, sister of dancers Quincy, Lucas, and Jacqui Jacinto, and niece of dancer Raoul Banzon. She has a BM in Dance, 1999, and MA in Art Theory and Criticism, 2007, from the University of the Philippines (UP). She is enrolled in PhD program of UP Diliman’s Philippine Studies course.

Jacinto took lessons with Eddie Elejar and Malu Rivera when she was five, until her father established the Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement (TEAM) Dance Studio in 1980. She started to teach baby ballet at the age of 13. She won a scholarship to the CCP Dance School in 1990, took classes with Rinat Gizatulin at the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), 1991 to 1992, and was a Ballet Philippines scholar in 1992, training with Gina Katigbak, Noordin Jumalon, Agnes Locsin, and Nonoy Froilan. As a dance major in UP, she trained with Sonia Domingo and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz. She performed in Basilio’s Tchaikovsky Fantasie, 1994, and Paean to Pavlova, 1995. She eventually joined the PBT in 1993 and credits Ida Beltran, Noreen Ostrea, Melanie Motus, and Anatoly Panassiukov for further enhancing her technique and artistry.

She became principal teacher of TEAM Dance Studio in 1995, restaging full-length ballets for the school’s annual recital. She performed in all of the school’s productions and in her father’s choreographies, notably his Hatinggabi (Midnight), 1991; Morphemes, 1991 and 2014; Sa Panimula ng Buhay (At the Beginning of Life), 1992; Bathala (God), 2008; Giri (Strut), 2004; and In the Sisterhood, 2011. She created the dual roles of the lead Sinisinta (Beloved)/Isda (fish), also in her father’s Magdaragat (Seafarer), 1996, for PBT. The solo of Ma’am Karen in Alvin Yapan’s film Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa (The Dance of Two Left Feet), 2011, was created on her, which she then taught to actor Jean Garcia. With PBT, Jacinto was featured as the shy girl in Tony Fabella’s Fiesta (Feast), 2004; the trio in David Campos’s Carmina Burana, 2005; Charing in Gener Caringal’s Isang Bagong Bituin (A New Star), 2005; one of the four Marys in Basilio’s Misa Filipina (Philippine Mass), 2008; Bird in Caringal’s Darangen ni Bantugen (Epic of Bantugen), 2008; cygnet and Spanish dance in Swan Lake, 2010; and in Novy Bereber’s Angel of the Morning, 2010.

While pursuing her masters, Jacinto began to write dance reviews for Malaya broadsheet in 2002, establishing herself as a dance critic. She also wrote for the National Commission for Culture and the Arts’ short-lived Indayog dance magazine, 2005-06; Goethe’s TanzConnexions, 2009-10; and Australia’s RealTime magazine, 2011 and 2013. With her brother Lucas, she produced the Runthru dance magazine in 2008, originally in print, but moving the magazine online in 2013.

She was a lecturer at the De La Salle College of St. Benilde’s dance program from 2006 to 2009. As a dance scholar, she has presented her research on ballet and contemporary dance as a heritage tool in conferences in Kuala Lumpur, Bangkok, and Manila. Jacinto stayed in Kuala Lumpur in 2014, where she taught choreography at the UMa. For the UMa Dance Company, she restaged her father’s In the Sisterhood, and choreographed Concerto and Professional Widow, 2014.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Lucas Jacinto, center, in Novy Bereber’s Angel of the Morning

(Photo by Ador Pamintuan, courtesy of the artist)

Lucas Jacinto

(Photo by Andy Samaniego, courtesy of the artist)

Lucas Jacinto

(Photo by Andy Samaniego, courtesy of the artist)

text:
JACINTO, LUCAS ( Christian Earle Lucas Banzon Jacinto )b. Manila 14 Apr 1976. Dancer, teacher. He is the son of dancer and choreographer Eli Jacinto and Joan Banzon, and brother of dancers Joelle, Quincy, and Jacqui Jacinto. He is married to dancer, Erica Marquez-Jacinto. Lucas Jacinto has a BA in Industrial Design, 2002, and an MBA in Business Administration, 2007, both from the University of the Philippines.

With his siblings, Jacinto began dancing at the age of seven with his father at their Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement (TEAM) Dance Studio. He also briefly took classes with Noordin Jumalon and Nonoy Froilan as a workshop scholar at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School in 1990, and with Rinat Gizatulin at the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), 1991-92. In 1992, he received a dance and academic scholarship from the Harid Conservatory in Florida, USA, training with Tina Santos-Wahl, Olivier Pardina, Demetrius Klein, and Marjorie Tallchief, and a summer scholarship from the San Francisco Ballet School. Although he was offered positions in several companies and universities in the US, he decided to come home for a college degree.

Upon his return to the Philippines, he continued to perform for TEAM Dance Studio. His father had long been creating work on him, including solos in his Mutya ng Pasig (Pearl of the Pasig) and Manton at Abaniko (Shawl and Fan), both in 1991; and, on his return, in Bathala (God),2008, and most significantly the lead in Giri (Strut), 2004, which he performed until 2014. He was also one of the three lead fishermen in Jacinto’s Magdaragat (Seafarer) for PBT, 1996.

From 1995, he danced for PBT as either company member or guest artist. His signature roles for the company are Basilio in Don Quixote, 2000, 2001, 2004; Solor in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 2002, 2004; and the title role in Gener Caringal’s Andres KKK, 1996-2004, 2008. He also performed the lead in Caringal’s Vinta in 2002 to 2005.

Other significant roles include Don Jose in Eddie Elejar’s Carmen, 1999; Pinkerton in Tom Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, 1999; Prince Danilo in Julie Borromeo’s Merry Widow, 2002; Romeo in Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet,2003; Dark Angel in George Balanchine’s Serenade,2003; Death in David Campos’s Carmina Burana, 2003, 2004. He also performed Sigfried in Swan Lake, and the Angel in Novy Bereber’s Angel of the Morning, both in 2010.

Jacinto served as judge for the ballet semi-finals of the National Music Competition for Young Artists from 2007 to 2009. As art director, he founded the Runthru dance magazine with his sister, Joelle, in 2008. He is now an executive in a shipping firm and runs the Hampton Court Ballet School with his wife, Erica, in Hillsborough, Alabang.Written by Joelle Florence P. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Quincy Jacinto

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Quincy Jacinto as Pinkerton in Tom Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, 1999, with Maritoni Rufino

(Photo courtesy of Joelle Jacinto)

Quincy Jacinto, center right, as The General in Gener Caringal’s Andres KKK, 1996, with Melvin Martinez, center left

(Photo courtesy of Joelle Jacinto)

text:
JACINTO, QUINCY ( Quincy Patrick Banzon Jacinto )b. Manila 27 May 1975. Dancer, teacher. He is the son of dancer and choreographer Eli Jacinto and Joan Banzon, brother of dancers Joelle, Lucas, and Jacqui Jacinto. He is married to dancer Rachel Swinsonwith whom he has three daughters. The couple is based in California, USA, where they run Riverside Dance Academy and Performing Arts. Jacinto also plays the drums and the guitar, and was in the alternative rock band, The Purplechickens.

Jacinto began training at the age of eight with his father Eli and the Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement (TEAM) Dance Studio. He also trained with Eloisa Enerio at TEAM, Nonoy Froilan at the CCP Dance School, Sergei Bykov, Anatoli Panassiukov, and Jean-Paul Comelin at Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). From 1990 to 1991, he studied at the Harid Conservatory in Boca Raton, Florida, on a dance and academic scholarship and trained with Olivier Pardina, Tina Santos-Wahl, Mark Godden, Demetrius Klein, and Marjorie Tallchief.

As a dancer, he had an undeniable stage presence, a natural command of movement, and a gift for music and timing. In TEAM Dance Studio, his father created roles on Jacinto, particularly the solo Puga (Struggle), 1991; Sa Panimula ng Buhay (At the Beginning of Life), 1991; Whims, 1993, and Bathala (God), 1998. In 1990, Jacinto guested for PBT, and in 1999 became it’s principal dancer. In Gener Caringal’s Andres KKK,Jacinto made a mark in his role as the opposing General in 1996, and in the title role in 1997 and after. He performed lead roles in various productions, notably the lead fisherman in Eli Jacinto’s Magdaragat (Seafarer),1997; Pinkerton in Madame Butterfly,1999; Basilio in Don Quixote, 2000. He holds the distinction of having portrayed the roles of Romeo, Tybalt, and Mercutio in Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, 2000.

He joined Ballet Pacifica in California in 2000, training with Molly Lynch, Gillian Finley, Ann-Marie de Angelo, Alaine Haubert, Janek Schergen, David Allan, Charles Maple, Shao-Pen Wang, Mark Lopez, and Evelyn Cisneros. Jacinto was featured as the Frog in Robert Sund’s Alice in Wonderland, in several roles like the Cavalier and Snow King in Molly Lynch’s Nutcracker, George Balanchine’s Allegro Brillante,and Choo San Goh’s Unknown Territory. He was praised for his performance as Puck in Lynch’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream.

Jacinto taught classical ballet and contemporary dance in various schools in California, most extensively for Inland Dance Academy, Temecula Valley Cathy’s Dance, Ballet Pacifica Conservatory, and Focus Dance Studio. He also coached and choreographed dancers for competitions as the Youth America Grand Prix. He established his own school, Riverside Dance Academy and Performing Arts, in 2013.

In 2003, Jacinto was a runner-up in the Best Male Dancer Award presented byBeverly Hills Outlook, a biweekly review of the Arts and Culture, in Southern California.Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Kristin Jackson performing her own piece, A Clearing, New York, 2001

(Photo by Hiroyuki Ito, courtesy of Kristin Jackson Dance)

Kristin Jackson performing her own piece, Wanla/Weave, New York, 2001

(Photo by Hiroyuki Ito, courtesy of Kristin Jackson Dance)

text:
JACKSON, KRISTIN ( Kristin Beltran Jackson-Achacoso ) b. Manila 14 Sep 1952. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Her parents were Mary Vita Beltran and Lowell Jackson. She is married to Eric Kevin Achacoso. She holds a degree in Fine Arts from the University of the Philippines (UP), 1974, and an MFA in dance, from the New York University-Tisch School of the Arts, 1985. Her master’s thesis was a comparative study of selected kabuki theater plays and 19th century ballets. She later pursued her interest in Japanese traditional performing arts to include study of the noh theater. Her studies in both traditional Japanese art forms and her transformation of these to more contemporary mediums are a thematic thread found throughout her creative career.

Jackson started ballet with Anita Kane and became a member of the Pamana Ballet. After Kane left, she trained with Tony Llacer and Julie Borromeo, in whose Peter Pan, 1974, she played Wendy. She continued her training in New York with Cindi Green, Graciela Kozak, Dana Reitz, and Lawrence Rhodes, and took lessons in voice with Leona Matthews. Between 1978 and 1981, she was in The King and I on Broadway. In 1983, she danced with Chen and Dancers, and between 1983 and 1987, with the Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians. She served as rehearsal director in Dean’s company from 1984 to 1987, and helped reconstruct five dances for its 1990 season.

After receiving her MFA in 1985, Jackson started her career as a choreographer and in 1990, she founded the Kristin Jackson Dance. She taught ballet and modern dance at Queens College, New York University, and Kane’s school in Rohnert Park, California, in the 1990s.

Since 1982, she has choreographed for the Salon Project, Daimon and Kristin Jackson Dances series. She participated in the Tiananmen Square Memorial Performance of 1989, in New York. She presented Pakiusap (Plea) in Sydney, Australia, 1989, a dance/theater/installation work inspired by the ongoing problem of mail order brides in the Philippines; The Stronger, a 1991 National Asian American Theater Co/NAATCO production of August Strindberg’s play; and a piece for the Harvard Neighbors Gallery video performance in Boston, 1990. Among her works are Field, 1982; Kolias, based on a Kalinga ritual, 1984; Arctic Archipelago, using abangko(long bench) to suggest the risks under the Marcos government, 1988; The Adventures of Momotaro the Peach Boy and Gallaun I, both in 1989; and Gallaun II and Still Waters, both in 1990. In her works, she has collaborated with poet Luis Francia, actor Ramon Hodel, and visual artist Genara Banzon.

Continuing her collaborations with other artists, Jackson created with Nagasaki composer Keiko Fujiie, the multimedia work titled In Their Shoes, 1998, inspired by lesser known stories of Japanese and Filipinos during World War II. Expanding her work from In Their Shoes and “A Clearing and Other Stories” used in the same work, she also created Wanla/Weave, 2001, a solo inspired by the Japanese-American internment in the United States. Under a Fulbright senior lecture award to teach and choreograph for the UP Dance Program, she created the group work Banwa (Community) to the music of Filipino composer Jonas Baes in Nov 2002. Her solo, A Clearing, a work that articulated her ongoing studies of the Japanese Noh theater, premiered in 2003. In 2010, Jackson premiered Aeolian, a trio performed to an original jazz composition by Cecilia Coleman for La Mama Moves Festival at the Ellen Stewart Theater Annex in New York City.

Simultaneous with her work for the dance community, Jackson has also choreographed for theater and film productions. Among these are The House of Bernarda Alba for The National Asian American Theater Company, 2000; Blue Moon Over Memphis for the Eugene Lang College at The New School, 2001; Life’s Call forTheater Et Al,2001; Lee for Happy Lady Productions, 2002; Rigodon for filmmaker Sari Dalena,2005; The Romance of Magno Rubio for the Ma-yi Theater Company, 2008; and Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) for the Filipino Artists Foundation’s production of Jose Rizal’s novel by Felipe Padilla de Leon, 2013.

Jackson has received various forms of grants for her work: from the New York State Council on the Arts, Commission for Minority Choreographers Development, 1989 to 1990, and the Asian Cultural Council Fellowship to the Philippines, 1992; the Cultural Center of the Philippines Residency, 1993; the National Endowment for the Arts/Arts International, 1993; the Arts at University Settlement Space Grant, 1996; Meet the Composer/International Creative Collaborations in partnership with the Ford Foundation, 1997 to 1998; the Japan Foundation/Performing Arts Japan Program, 1998; the NYC Department of Cultural Affairs Cultural Challenge Grant, 1998; the Joyce SoHo Performance Space Subsidy, 2001; the Jerome Foundation Grant, 2002; the Fulbright Senior Lecturer Grant, 2002-03; and the Yukie Iitomi Scholarship, 2010. In pursuit of ongoing studies in Japanese noh theater, Jackson also received a Professional Staff Congress City University of New York’s Development Grant award in 2012, subsequently performing on her return from Japan in the full-length noh play Atsumori at the Noh Training Project in Bloomsburg, Pennsylvania.

Jackson also served as administrative assistant for dance for the New York State Council for the Arts, 1988, and panelist for Dance/USA, 1986, the National Endowment for the Arts, 1991, Meet the Composer, New York, 1998, the Asian American Arts Alliance, New York, 1999, and the Arts Education Program of the New York State Council on the Arts from 2010 to 2013. She was the Director of Programs at the Dance Notation Bureau from 2008 to 2010.

As dance educator, Jackson has written syllabi, course structures, and requirements of dance programs and has been Adjunct Professor at the Queens College of the City University of New York in Flushing, New York, since 2010, rising from the ranks as Adjunct Lecturer in 1990 to her current position. She has also taught at the New York University, 1991-92, as Adjunct Associate Professor; at the Sarah Lawrence College, 2008, as visiting artist; at the University of Michigan, 2009, as visiting artist; and at the State University of New York at Old Westbury as Adjunct Professor, 2005-10, where she taught a general education studio/lecture course. For her excellence in teaching, she was given the Merit Awardby the Search for Education, Elevation, and Knowledge S.A./Unity Students at Queens College City, University of New York in 1997. Jackson published An Introduction to Dance,1996, a handbook for children on dance styles of various cultures which provides supplemental information for the Dance Classics series of performances at the Colden Center at Queens College. She is a member of the Actors Equity, Dance NYC, and the Fulbright Association.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Myra Victoria C. Beltran

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Nestor Jardin, left, as Ogassi in Alice Reyes’s Tales of the Manuvu, 1979

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Nestor Jardin as Pan in Daphnis, Chloe and Pan, 1979

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Nestor Jardin

(Photo by Chris Millado, courtesy of the artist)

text:
JARDIN, NESTOR ( Nestor Obciana Jardin ) b. Lucena City 27 Feb 1952. Dancer, cultural administrator. The son of Luis Jardin and Paz Obciana, he took a zoology degree at the University of the Philippines (UP) in preparation for medical school. Instead, he became a dancer, starting to train at age 17. He joined the UP Filipiniana Dance Company, studied jazz and Polynesian dance, and finally classical ballet and modern dance. He attended the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) summer dance workshop in 1973, and subsequently studied with Alice Reyes, Eddie Elejar, Antonio Fabella, Gener Caringal, and visiting teachers Norman Walker, Muñeca Aponte, Gerard Sibbritt, Garth Welch, Jan Stripling, and Rochelle Zide-Booth. In 1974, he joined the CCP Dance Company, now Ballet Philippines (BP). For several seasons, Jardin performed in numerous productions and tours, but later, after taking a course in AIM, moved on to become the company’s stage manager, company manager, administrator, and finally, president. He has also served as tour director for BP, and editor of Dance Philippines.

Jardin was associate artistic director for the performing arts of the CCP from 1987 to 1995, and artistic director from 1995 to 1997. In 1996, he was also named vice president of the CCP. In the same year, Jardin was also commissioner of the National Commission for Culture and Arts (NCCA), where he pushed for the creation of the Philippine Cultural Educational Plan, a comprehensive national plan for the arts and cultural education. He was likewise the chairman of the Advisory Council of the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA).

Jardin resigned from the CCP in 1999, proceeding to help BP by serving as its president and artistic director until 2001. He was then invited to be part of the CCP Board of Trustees and was elected its president the same year. He served as president from 2001 to 2009. Subsequently, Jardin served as an adviser of the CCP Board of Trustees, as well as president of the Cinemalaya Foundation, Inc, which conducts the annual Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and Competition.

Jardin has received grants from the National Science Development Board, 1969, Goethe Institut, 1983, Asian Cultural Council, for arts administration, 1984, and the US International Visitors Program, 1989. In 1992, he received an ASEAN-Canada grant to attend the Arts Administration Program at the Banff Centre for Continuing Education, renamed the Banff Centre in 2008, in Banff, Alberta, Canada. In 2008, Jardin received the John D. Rockefeller Award.Written by Paul G. del Rosario and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Ronilo Jaynario (Photo from pbt.ph)

text:
JAYNARIO, RONILO ( Ronilo Datar Jaynario )b. 18 Sep 1974. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Ronilo Jaynario is the son of Tobias F. Jaynario and Maria Arizapa, and husband of dancer and teacher Therese Arsinas, with whom he has two children. He graduated from the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) with a MARIA award and a Most Outstanding Artist Award in 1992 and after that, attended the University of the Philippines (UP) as a major in dance.

Jaynario started dancing at the age of 10 when the elementary school he attended in Sorsogon, the Casiguran Central School, started to offer summer dance workshops. Dancing at the Casiguran Festival two years later, he was advised to audition for the PHSA by a Department of Education representative from Sorsogon. He was accepted as both a ballet major and a visual arts major in 1988. After a year, he concentrated on ballet, with Merci Drilon, Nonoy Froilan, Agnes Locsin, and Enrico Labayen as his trainors. After graduating from PHSA in 1992, he joined Labayen’s Lab Project Philippines, while studying in UP. With the company, he toured in dance festivals locally and internationally for three years. In 1995 Jaynario joined the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). While working in PBT, he also played Baratha in the ASEAN Flagship Voyage Performing Arts Tour of Realizing Rama choreographed by Denisa Reyes.He also taught modern dance at the PHSA for 11 years.

As one of PBT’s finest danseurs and guided by Anatoly Panassiukov, Gener Caringal, and Jean Paul Comelin, he essayed the Cavalier in Gelsey Kirkland’s The Nutcracker, 1996; the title role in Caringal’s Andres KKK which role he originated,1996; Albrecht in Giselle, 1997; the leper in Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s Maria Clara and the Leper, 1999; Basil in Don Quixote, 2001; Prince Danilo in Julie Borromeo’s Merry Widow,2002;Romeo in Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet,2003; Pinkerton in Pazik’s Madame Butterfly; Solor in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 2004; Prince Siegfried in Swan Lake,2005; and the title role in Marius Petipa’s The Hunchback of Notre Dam e, 2006. He originated the solo in Tony Fabella’s Buklog, 1999. Retiring in 2007 because of an injury, he started teaching in schools such as Borromeo’s Dance Arts Studio and Tita Radaic’s classical ballet school in St. Theresa’s College.

He had his first choreographic venture in Nicanor Tiongson’s Sulyap Kay Gatlaya (Glance at Gatlaya)for the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ 31st anniversary, 2000. His first full-length choreographic work was as co-choreographer to Gener Caringal’s Darangan ni Bantugan (Epic of Bantugen),2008, with PBT. In 2009 he became the Artistic Director of PBT. He then staged Swan Lake,2010, Coppelia, 2012, and Le Corsaire (The Pirate),2013; choreographed Ang Pasaway ( La Fille Mal Gardee ),2009, the dance piece La Femme (The Woman), 2013, and Carmen,2014;and restaged and re-choreographed Borromeo and Radaic’s Mir-i-Nisa, 2009, John Paul Comelin’s Cinderella, and Kirkland’s The Nutcracker, both in 2011.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
JOSE, FERDINAND BAUTISTA akaBong Jose. b. Paranaque City 14 May 1953. Choreographer, dance director. He is the eldest son of politician Francisco Jose and Veronica Bautista, who comes from a musically-inclined family. Jose was keen to join folk dance activities from a young age but his father was strongly against a career in dance for his son. He graduated from Far Eastern University with a BS degree in chemistry. He worked for the Philippine Refining Company (now Unilever) as a laboratory tester.

In 1976, stranded at Philippine Women’s University (PWU) during a typhoon, Jose found himself auditioning for the Bayanihan and was accepted as a trainee. Dancing for the Bayanihan complemented his day job, until he was invited to the year-long world tour and was tapped as a researcher by dance director Lucrecia Urtula. Soon, she instructed him to assemble dances learned in the field for the stage. He was one of her five research assistants, assigned to dances in the Visayas and Southern Philippines, and Hispanic dances.

Under the auspices of the Bayanihan, Jose received a study grant for Developing Management at the Asian Institute of Management, from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, through the Ramon Magsaysay Foundation. He was also able to study Public Diplomacy and International Relations at the Helena Z. Benitez School of International Relations and Diplomacy at the PWU.

Toward the late 1990s, Jose took over as assistant dance director, consulting with the retired Urtula until she passed away in 1999. Bayanihan artistic director Jose Lardizabal then appointed Jose as dance director of the company. Over the years, Jose’s advocacy was to gradually adapt Bayanihan’s repertoire to accommodate new research and to explore creative possibilities that were also culturally responsible. While still faithful to the Bayanihan repertoire, Jose added new works such as Mga Bagong Bayani sa Ibayong Dagat (The New Overseas Heroes),Isang Panimula (A Beginning),Malagueña de Pila, Señoritas (Malagueña of Pila, Young Ladies), and Larong Bata (Child Games). His Manlulurup (Divers)depicted pearl divers’s activities, with the dancers harnessed from the top of the stage to depict an underwater scene. Mariposa Bella (Beautiful Butterfly) is a dance to show off Filipino dress, using the music of “Paruparong Bukid” (Country Butterfly). To close the performances, Jose choreographed Fiesta Extravaganza, a tribute to the country’s ubiquitous street dancing, now a favorite among local and foreign audiences.

More interested in how folk dance can be relevant to everyday Filipino life, the Bayanihan started a continuing project with several city governments called Teaching and Touching Lives, starting in Pagsanjan. Workshops were given to grade school children from the area, while Jose did research in the same area and choreographed a dance that reflected the local culture. The Pagsanjan workshop produced Bangkero (Boatman), which is now part of Bayanihan’s repertoire. Succeeding workshops were held in the town of Liliw in Laguna, Marikina City, Ilocos Sur, and with the Manobo group in Butuan City.

His Mindanao Suite won for the Bayanihan the Gold Temple Award at the 47th International Folk Festival in Sicily, Italy in 2002. At the 7th Gold Bridge Folk Dance Competition in Boyokcekmece Beledeyesi, Turkey, in 2007, the Bayanihan won first prize, while Jose was awarded Best Choreography. Jose was a member of the ad hoc committee for dance at the National Commission for Culture and Arts from 2003-06, and is an honorary member of the Philippine Folk Dance Society. He received the Patnubay ng Sining from the City of Manila in 2003.Written by Joelle Florence P. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Julie Borromeo Performing Arts Foundation

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/JBPAF)

Julie Borromeo Performing Arts Foundation

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/JBPAF)

text:
JULIE BORROMEO PERFORMING ARTS FOUNDATION aka Dance Arts Studio It was founded in 1957 and expanded to become the Julie Borromeo Dance Company in 1960. It produces and choreographs musicals, dance concerts, and television shows. Aside from producing shows, the Foundation offers training in dance and provides a base for dancers, young and old, and teachers and choreographers. It offers courses in ballet, tap, modern jazz, Spanish flamenco, musical theater, Latin dance, ballroom, hip-hop, adult fitness, belly dancing, and the Luigi and Al Gilbert Jazz Syllabi.

The dance company’s most notable production was Flower Drum Song, 1966, directed by Maureen Tiongco at the Philamlife Auditorium. The performance was able to raise the first half-million pesos used to fund the construction of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). After the Center’s inauguration in 1969, the company presented there Man of La Mancha, 1970; Promises, Promises, 1971; Mahal (Beloved), the first “electromechanical, mystical Filipino rock musical,” 1975; and Here Where the Lord Hides and The Wiz, 1981. The dance company also presented Bata Pa Si Sabel (When Sabel Was Young), 1973, at the Folk Arts Theater as a tribute to first generation bodabil artists. From 1964 to 1965, the company toured the Philippines with stylized ethnic, modern, and popular dances for the Miss Caltex contests.

With Nonoy Froilan, it did a one-hour special, Sweet Charity, for Hong Kong television in 1974. In 1975, it toured the United States with Malakas at Maganda (Strong and Beautiful), Bamboo Fantasy, and Igorot and Modern Jazz Works in its repertoire. In Singapore, it performed Apple Tree, 1979, They’re Playing Our Song, 1981, and Rhythm of Freedom, 1987. Its 1974 calendar included the Philippine Revue of music and dances at the Light and Sound Theater Lounge that ran up to 60 performances. The company participated in the National Ballet Festival in the 1970s, in the annual CCP Balletfest in the late 1980s, and in the Manila Contemporary Dance Festival in the 1990s.

As the Julie Borromeo Performing Arts Foundation based in Mandaluyong, the organization has shifted focus from performing to teaching.Written by Franz Edric Bangalan
