description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Noordin Jumalon

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Noordin Jumalon in a fourth position croisé front, par terre

(Photo from facebook.com/noordin.jumalon)

Noordin Jumalon

(Photo from facebook.com/noordin.jumalon)

Noordin Jumalon

(Photo from facebook.com/noordin.jumalon)

Noordin Jumalon

(Photo from facebook.com/noordin.jumalon)

Noordin Jumalon

(Photo from facebook.com/noordin.jumalon)

text:
JUMALON, NOORDIN ( Noordin Alcantara Jumalon ) b. Cebu 5 Jul 1949. d. 24 Sep. 2011. Dancer, teacher. He was the son of Julian Jumalon and Felicitacion Alcantara. He earned a degree in Geology from the University of San Carlos, Cebu, 1969, and worked as a field geologist in Cebu. He trained in ballet with Fe Sala-Villarica and Mario Recto at the Ballet Center, Cebu, from 1968 to 1977. As the first Filipino ballet scholar in Russia, he took the teacher’s course at the State Institute for Theater Arts of Lunacharsky or the GITIS, Moscow in 1973-75, and at the Moscow Choreographic School in 1977-79. He trained under Raisa Struchkova, German Prybylov, Yaroslav Sekh, Asaf Messerer, and Marina Semyonova. He also observed classes and performances of the Bolshoi Ballet. Further pedagogy studies followed at the Western Michigan University, Beijing Dance Academy, and with the Royal Academy of Dancing in Manila. As a dancer in Manila, he further trained with visiting ballet masters and choreographers from around the world.

From 1968 to 1977, he danced with the Queen City Junior Ballet which performed in Cebu, the rest of the Visayas and Mindanao. From 1980 to 1988, he danced with Ballet Philippines (BP), eventually rising from the corps de ballet to do solo and character roles. He also taught at the Philippine Ballet Theatre.

From 1986, he danced, choreographed, and directed for the Cathedral of Praise Dance Ministry. Between 1997 and 2009, he created six original full-length ballets that mostly have environmental themes. A Forest Tales the first one, staged for the fourth time in 2009 coincided with the 40th anniversary of the CCP. His other original works were A Garden Tale, An Urban Tale, Starzan—Gubatman, Under the Sea, and Baroque Fantasque that were staged for the annual CCP summer dance workshops. He restaged for BP the following: Les Sylphides, 1995; The Nutcracker, 1997; and Giselle, 1999; and for Ballet Center Cebu, The Sleeping Beauty, 2004.

He was the acting artistic director of BP, 1999-2000; Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School principal, from 1986 to 1996; and its school director from 1996-2011. He served as Technical Education and Skills Development Authority testing officer from 1995 to 2004; a member of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) National Committee on Dance, from 2001 to 2004. He was one of the authors of the Ballet Syllabus Volumes I and II and headed the Examination Division of the National Ballet Syllabus, Inc.

In 2004, he was a recipient of Cebu City Charter’s Individual Achiever’s Award in Art and Culture.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Ka-Anyag Pilipinas Dance Company

(Photo from facebook.com/Ka-anyag-Pilipinas-Dance-Company-and-Rondalla-191342470937081/)

Ka-Anyag Pilipinas Dance Company

(Photo from facebook.com/Ka-anyag-Pilipinas-Dance-Company-and-Rondalla-191342470937081/)

text:
KA-ANYAG PILIPINAS DANCE COMPANY ( KPDC ) Founded in 1975 as conceived by Jose “Baby” Gonzaga, an educator and Filipinist of Bacolod, it was formerly known as the West Negros College Dance Company. Its beginnings may be traced to the Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe from the late 1950s and through the 1960s, with its artistic director-choreographer Jose Burgos Magbanua. In 1981, the company was renamed Ka-anyag Pilipinas Dance Company when it joined an International exposition in Kobe, Japan.

From its official founding, the company has performedoutside of Negros Occidental at the Luce Auditorium in Silliman University, 1977 and 1979; the Portopia ‘81 Exposition in Kobe and a tour of Hyogo, Osaka, and Port Islands, Japan, 1981; the Philippine Folk Festival at the Folk Arts Theater, 1981; and the Pang-alay festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1990. In 1989 it helped host the CCP Dance Festival in Bacolod City.

From 1988 to 2005, the company engaged in cultural performance outreach programs and served private and public schools, barangays, municipalities, and religious and civic groups in Negros Occidental. Between 1986 and 2005, its cultural assistance program reached out to private and public schools located outside the city, strengthened their folk dance groups, and helped them win in folk dance competitions in the province and in the region.

Through the West Negros College, the KPDC accommodates dance scholars under its Centre for Arts and Culture. Also providing music to the KPDC is the Western Negros College Rondalla which was founded together with the KPDC in 1975.

Among its past dance directors and choreographers have been former members of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Elsie Yelo-Enriquez, Asuncion Ykalina-Belzunce, Ismael Java, Bondying Espares, Rene Hinojales, and JessAico who was also the company’s designer and technical director. From the Kayumanggi days, there were Rodolfo Medel, Ilsa Miraflores, Felisa Locsin, Maya Ramos, and Jaime Concepcion.

Over the years, the KPDC has been winning awards for its performances: National Private Schools Athletic Associations (PRISAA) Championship Awards in the Creative Dance Category in 1992 and 1993; all-time champion in the Negros Occidental Sports Competitions, folk dance category, and winner in the creative folk dance category of the same competition. It was recognized by the Negros Producers Association Publication as one of the “Best of Negros” for its efforts in promoting the Filipino identity through dance.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

article_title: Kahayag Community Dance and Theater Company
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
KAHAYAG COMMUNITY DANCE AND THEATER COMPANY Set up in 1993 by independent artist Noel Garrovillo, the Kahayag Community Dance and Theater Company is a community-based organization that aimed to nurture artistry and creativity by initiating research, training, performances, and promoting management programs that contribute to the nation’s cultural life. As the Visayan wordkahayagmeans “light” or “radiance,” the group wanted to make the arts integral to the national agenda on culture. The earlier choreographies of the company were based on the dance, music, and chants of the Tboli community in Lake Sebu and the Blaan of Cotabato. After performing at the Mindanao Theater Festival in Iligan in 1995, the group was invited to be part of the 1996 National Theater Festival at the CCP. During the festival, Kahayag was cited as one of the 10 Most Outstanding Theater Companies in the Philippines.

Kahayag’s most acclaimed and popular work is Tudbulul, 1994, a narrative dance that interprets the Tboli’s great epic. Other choreographies of the company are Bulalakaw (Comet), 1993,a dance drama of an Ilonggo myth; Sisa: Isang Ina (Sisa: A Mother),1997; Hu-do-boo: Scenes from the Last Day of General Paulino Santos, 2000; Kagat sa T’nalak (Biting the T’nalak),2004; and Ibong Adarna: Sa Muling Paglipad (Adarna Bird: New Journey), 2007. In 1996, Kahayag decided to veer away from using the movements of the Tboli, Blaan, and Bagobo, and study the everyday movements of the Visayan migrants in Cotabato. It chose contemporary dance as a way of exploring multiculturalism and complementing the different dance backgrounds of its members.

From the late 1990s to 2009, Kahayag was the most visible organization in Mindanao working with the Provincial Government of South Cotabato in holding the Mindanao National Modern Dance Competition, which began in 2001. The competition started out as the Mindanao Modern Dance Competition with a meager budget but was later given more financial support by the Provincial Government. On its third year, the competition became a Mindanao national competition that accepted entries from all over the country.

In 2005, Kahayag with its contemporary dances, together with the Me’dal Kolon Datal Dance and Theatre Ensemble, with its folk, tribal, and ballroom dances, the Cybercrew with its contemporary and hip-hop dances, and the Tboli Performing Arts with its traditional Tboli dances, came together and strengthened their efforts to carve out a niche for their art in the cultural life of South Cotabato. Together they formed a collective known as the South Cotabato Performing Arts Ensemble, which actively coordinated with the governor’s office in making culture and the arts important components of the local government’s development program.

When Kahayag shifted its thrust in 2010 and became the Kahayag Community Cultural Foundation, Inc, a non-stock advocacy organization, Garrovillo set up the Noel Garrovillo Dance Center (NGDC) with a performing arm. While the foundation, with Garrovillo as its chairman of the Board, is an umbrella organization comprised of several dance companies and performers, the NGDC is now on its own, projecting itself as a contemporary dance group that offers jazz, ballroom, hip-hop, and ballet.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

article_title: Kaloob Philippine Music And Dance Ministry
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry performing the sagayan

(Photo courtesy of Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry)

Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry with founder Dr Ed Lapiz, extreme left

(Photo courtesy of Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry)

Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry performing the dugso

(Photo courtesy of Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry)

Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry performing the tinikling

(Photo courtesy of Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry)

text:
KALOOB PHILIPPINE MUSIC AND DANCE MINISTRY Founded in 1994 by Dr Ed Lapiz of the Day by Day Christian Ministry, Kaloob seeks to use Philippine folk dance to fulfil its missions of “cultural preservation” and “cultural redemption,” allowing indigenous peoples to continue to practice their arts, music, and dances even after the dominant influence of Christianity. They stage regular performances at the Folk Arts Theater, where the ministry is based.

To accomplish their mission of cultural preservation, Kaloob has undertaken field research among over 40 indigenous peoples, recording and notating over a hundred folk dances and musical compositions which, as of 2014, were being organized for publication. Research entails studying the collected works for text and context and archiving for preservation. The works are taught to the ministry’s performing artists and staged, as well as used, in church liturgy. Kaloob is unique in its presentation of Filipinized liturgical services by utilizing Philippine folk dance and music to reach out to their congregation.

In 1998, Kaloob was appointed as the resident dance company of the yearlong Expo Pilipino, a celebration of the Philippine Centennial where the group gave more than 1,400 performances. Kaloob was also the official representative of the Philippines to the 2012 Lefkas and Earthdancers International Dance Festivals in Greece.Kaloob mounts productions all over the Philippines and has performed in Thailand, Malaysia, and Singapore. It has “daughter” companies inSaudi Arabia, Qatar, United Arab Emirates, Canada, and the United States of America.

In 2013, the group staged Kalooban: Oneness of the Filipino Soul in Dance at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, seeking to present a new treatment of the traditional suites in Philippine folk dances by categorizing the dances according to themes. For instance, all dances that featured fire were presented together, and all choreographies that employed the use of bamboo poles from north to south of the archipelago were all in one suite. The goal was to show strong commonalities among the different groups separated by geography and religion, hoping to emphasize national unity.Written by Josefina B. Guillen

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Anita Kane

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Anita Kane Dance School’s production of The Nutcracker, FEU Auditorium, 1955

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Anita Kane Dance School’s production of The Nutcracker, FEU Auditorium, 1955

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Anita Kane

(Photo from Anita M. Kane: Studio of the Classic Dance, souvenir program, 1950)

text:
KANE, ANITA b. New Zealand 1910 d. San Francisco. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Kane was the daughter of William and Ethel Kane. She grew up in Paracale, Camarines Norte, where her father was an engineer in the mining industry. She studied at St. Scholastica’s College and the American School, and pursued premedical studies in Pomona College, San Francisco, USA. She took ballet under Katrina Makarova of the Imperial Russian Ballet, now the Kirov, who left Russia during the Bolshevik Revolution and came to Manila in 1924. During her university years in America, Kane continued her dance studies under Martha Thalberg, Norma Gould, and Ernest Belcher. She returned to the Philippines in 1934 and founded her own ballet school (at first with Janet Miles) that later adopted a graded system. During World War II, she was kept in a concentration camp at the University of Santo Tomas. After the war, she reopened her School of Classic Dance. Later she also taught at the University of the Philippines and Far Eastern University. In 1950, she trained further in London at the Royal Academy of Dancing with Claude Newman, and worked with Kathleen Crofton and Harold Turner.

She worked as choreographer and teacher in the Philippines from the 1950s to the late 1960s. Among the dancers she nurtured were Elena Robles, Angelita Barredo, Shirley Santos, Julie Roxas, Felicitas Layag-Radaic, Maureen Tiongco, Elizabeth Guasch, Julie Borromeo, Serafina Guinto, Effie Nañas, Ester Rimpos, Lucy Layag-de los Reyes, Kristin Jackson, Tony Llacer, El Gabriel, Marcelino Garcia, Rene Dimacali, and Luis Layag, some of whom were members of the Anita Kane Ballet Company . She was the first to tour ballet in the provinces. Later she had Greta Monserrat as ballerina and Eddie Elejar as premier danseur in her Pamana Ballet, which carried on her earlier AKBC’s outreach performances to the provinces.

Kane created the first full-length ballet in two acts on a Filipino legend, MariangMakiling,1939, to the original music of RamonTapales. Other Filipino themes were pursued in ReconstructionBallet,1951; La Mer (The Sea),1957, which was later called MutyangDagat (Muse of the Sea), 1958; Inulan sa Pista (Rained-out Feast), 1961; Mah Jong,1962; and Aswang (Ghoul), 1969. She also did dance dramas on religious themes: The Life of St. Agnes,1949, and The Parable of theFoolish Virgins,1951. She did Masculine Suite,1948, for an all-male cast which included Solomon Arnaldo, SeverinoMontano, EliseoM.Pajaro, I. V.Mallari, RicardoReyes, and Enrique Albert. She also did Peruvian inParis,1954. She was one of four choreographers for Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image-Play: The Golden Salacot), 1969, that inaugurated the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Her classical productions were Les Sylphides, 1952, The Sleeping Beauty,1953, Swan Lake, 1954, and Giselle,1955. In 1955, Kane brought together Filipino and foreign talents in a Philippine Ballet Festival of 10 performances with Alexandra Danilova, Mocelyn Larkin, Roman Jasinsky, and Michael Maule. Among the productions were The Nutcracker Suite and SwanLake Acts I and II, accompanied by an orchestra conducted by William McDermot.

From 1969 onwards, Kane resided and taught in California where she staged new ballets and revived old works. When she visited in 1998, Philippine Ballet Theatre paid a tribute to her with a production of Giselle, directed by Felicitas Layag-Radaic.Written by Felicitas Layag-Radaic and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Gina Katigbak-Garcia

Gina Katigbak with Ricardo Ella in Mosque Baroque

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
KATIGBAK-GARCIA, GINA b. 12 Dec 1959. Dancer, teacher, lecturer. The daughter of Dr Lorenzo and Alicia Katigbak, she is married to Gilbert Garcia, with whom she has six children. Her third child, Katerina, is a dancer and studied multimedia arts. Katigbakhas a degree in AB Psychology from the Ateneo de Manila University (ADMU), 1982.

Katigbak started ballet at the age of four with Joji Felix-Velarde. She continued with Yvonne de los Reyes Herranz at St. Theresa’s College, and later with Inday Gaston-Mañosa.She joined Mañosa and Remedios “Totoy” de Oteyza’s Hariraya Ballet Company, 1977-81, where she originated a demi-soloist role and eventually performed the principal role in de Oteyza’s Tchaikovsky Piano ConcertoNo. 1.She was also the lead in the “Dance of the Hours” in the opera La Gioconda.In Dance Concert Company (DCC), 1980-83, Eric V. Cruz created for her the role of Leonora in the full-length ballet La Gitana, and that of one of the sisters in Camille. In 1985, she guested as the lead, Azucena, in La Gitana for DCC’s Beijing tour.She also danced major roles with the Metropolitan (MET) Dance Theater, Ballet Federation of the Philippines (BFP), and Dance Theater Philippines (DTP). With MET Dance Theater, she created the lead role, Liwayway, in Alamat ng Bundok Bangkay (The Legend of Bangkay Mountain). With BFP, she danced the Song Bird Fairy in TheSleeping Beauty,and the Dawn solo in Coppelia. With DTP, she took on major roles in Pas de Quatre, Basilio’s Mosque Baroque, and Borromeo’s Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila). With DTP, Basilio created for her the role of the Alienated Protagonist in his Testament.

She joined Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1983. With BP’s junior group, she performed the female role in Augustus Damian III’s Two with Wagner.With BP, she performed the title role and the Fairy Godmother in Alice Reyes’s Cinderella, 1984 and 1989, respectively; Sita in Reyes’s Rama, Hari (Rama, the King),1990; Alice in Edna Vida’s Alice in Wonderland, 1985, Wendy in Peter Pan, 1986, and Adarna in IbongAdarna (Adarna Bird), 1990; the title role in Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress), 1992; and the lead role in Denisa Reyes’s For the Gods, 1990, in Seville, Spain. In classical ballet, she was Sugar Plum Fairy in The Nutcracker, 1987 and 1991; Gamzatti in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 1987; the Dryad Queen in Don Quixote, 1990; and the lead role in Giselle, 1991.

In 1992, Katigbak-Garcia retired from dancing to teach. With Noordin Jumalon, she created the framework of the CCP Dance School recitals using cohesive story ballets. After a break in 2007, she resumed teaching the Advanced Ballet level at the CCP Summer Dance Workshop.

In 2012, she joined the Dance Department of the De La Salle-College of Saint Benilde School of Design and Arts, teaching classes in ballet repertory, dance history, and dance ethics. She is also a volunteer for Educhild Foundation, a proponent of Parenting Education.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Enrico Labayen

(Screencap from YouTube)

Enrico Labayen performing his own piece, Unearthing, The LAB Project Group

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
LABAYEN, ENRICO b. Paco, Manila 23 Oct 1953. Dancer, choreographer. He first trained with Antonio Llacer at Dance Arts Studio, then with Alice Reyes, Eddie Elejar, Antonio Fabella, and visiting choreographer-teachers at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School and Ballet Philippines (BP). On several scholarships, he studied further at the American Ballet Theater School, American Ballet Center, American Dance Center, School of American Ballet, San Francisco Institute of Choreography, Joffrey American Ballet Center, and Harkness Ballet. He studied with Alvin Ailey, Norman Walker, Maggie Black, David Howard, Patricia Wilde, Leon Danielian, Andre Eglevsky, Joanna Haigood, and Alonzo King.

He performed with BP, American Ballet Theater II, Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, Larry Richardson Dance Company, Edward Villela and Friends, Eglevsky Ballet, Rod Rodgers Dance Company, New York Dancers, Garden State Ballet, and guested with Saeko Ichinohe Dance Company, San Luis Ballet, San Francisco Dance Spectrum, and Hartford Ballet. Between 1988 to 1990, he worked with Lines Dance Company where Alonzo King choreographed special roles for him, as in Granados Pas de Seul and Ligetti Variations.

As ballet master, Labayen has worked with Sacramento Ballet (USA), New York Dancers, Eglevsky Ballet, Bern Ballet (Switzerland), Mainz Stadt Theater (Germany), Singapore Dance Theater, Ballet Philippines, Philippine Ballet Theatre, Hofstra University (USA), LINES Ballet School (SF), Westlake School of Performing Arts (Daly City), San Francisco Dance Center (USA), and ODC in San Francisco. He was invited as guest ballet master for Norwegian National Company for Contemporary Dance and Icelandic ballet in Bergen, Norway, and Salzburg Experimental Academy of Dance in Austria. His students include Katherine Healy, Christopher Boatwright, Roseanne Germer, Anna Villadolid, and Melissa Cuachon.

In 1991, he founded Lab., Projekt which encompasses a broad range of theatrical forms—ballet, modern and ethnic dance, visual installation, and performance arts, multigravitational approach to explore and expand choreographic possibilities and, “hopefully, to find a style suited to the Filipino.” Since its debut at the CCP Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, the Lab., Projekt has performed in the First Manila Contemporary Dance Festival, Baguio Arts Festival, Iloilo Arts Festival, Sagada Arts Festival, Stars of Philippine Ballet tours, and the 1992 Singapore Arts Festival. As artistic director, he organized the Labayen Dance/SF in 1994.

Between 1990 and 1992, Labayen choreographed more than 30 works, notably Mindstorm, Maya, Etchings, Icarus Eternally Damned/The Dupe of Time, and Sa Isip, sa Salita, at sa Gawa? (In Thoughts, Words, and Deeds?). He has collaborated with musical artists Lucrecia Kasilag, Shant Verdun, Jeffrey Ching, and visual artists Ben Cabrera and Santiago Bose. Three of his works premiered in 1999: Unearthing: The Creation Myth, Song of the Water, and Common Tao at Theater Artaud, San Francisco. In May 2003, he performed Enrico Labayen: Unbound at the Dance Forum, Quezon City. It featured Excerpt Arias: WithKindness Deep, a contemporary piece performed to the music of Friedrich Handel; Quiet Please, There’s a Lady; Cloth, a work inspired by a passage from the Song of Songs of the Hebrew Bible; and the world premiere of Labayen’s Le Sacre du Printemps. In Jan 2010, Labayen’s Three World Premieres was staged at Dance Mission Theater, SF with three of his works: Quirk, to Sirakiz’s Concerto for Violin and Orchestra; Night Clouds to Charles Valentin Alkan; and Raga Suite to Rahman Assadolahi. In 2010, he was the dancer-choreographer in Carmina Burana: Revisited inspired by the Tadtarin ritual, at Dance Mission Theater, SF. Carmina marked the return of Labayen to Dance SF after a five-year hiatus when Labayen was in Southeast Asia on research fellowships. In Apr 2012, Revivals & Premieres at the ODC Theater, SF showcased Labayen’s Sacred Stones and the world premiere of his Kulang ang Dasal (Prayer Is Not Enough). Three revivals in the program were en-GULF-ed, Cloth, and Glass. en-GULF-ed was done in response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

His awards, fellowships, and citations include Dancer of the Year from the Beaux Arts Society of New York; Cultural Exchange Fellowship Award from the Dutch Ministry; Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music Residency Fellowship; Philippines Choreographer of the Year from the Manila Chronicle; Isadora Duncan Award for Outstanding Achievement in Choreography, 1996, for Cloth and Puirt a Beul; Filipinas Achievement Award, USA; Djerassi Artists Residency, USA; and Rimbun Dahan Artist residency, Malaysia. He was named one of the Filipino-American faces of the Century. In 2012, he received his second Isadora Duncan Dance Award for Outstanding Achievement in Visual Design, Costumes, and Visual Design, for en-Gulf-ed.Written by Rene de Guzman and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Lahing Batangan Dance Group

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/LahingBatanganDanceTroupe)

Lahing Batangan Dance Group

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/LahingBatanganDanceTroupe)

text:
LAHING BATANGAN DANCE TROUPE ( Batangan Race Dance Troupe )Founded in 1995 at the Lyceum of the Philippines University (LPU), Batangas City, Lahing Batangan Dance Troupe (LBDT) aims to promote the cultural traditions of the Philippines through music and dance. Its artistic and dance director is Rodel M. Fronda, a former member of the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company. The group is supervised by LPU Director for Culture and Arts, Eric Orolfo.

It has staged four major dance concerts in LPU-Batangas, showcasing full-length all-Filipino repertoire: Lahing Pilipino: Mga Sayaw Para sa Pagkakaisa (Philippine Race: Dances for Unity),2003; Pamana: Mga Sayaw Pilipino para sa Batangueño (Heritage: Philippine Dances for Batangueños),2005; Ala-Eh! Tara na sa Italya! (Ala-Eh! Let’s Go to Italy!), 2008; Alay-Tahanan sa Batangueño: Sining Pilipino (Home Offering to the Batangueño: Philippine Art), 2009.

LBDT is a regular participant in programs of the Cultural Center of the Philippines such as Sari-Saring Sayaw, Sama-Samang Galaw (Diverse Dances, Synchronized Movements); Pasinaya: CCP Open House Festival (Inauguration: CCP Open HouseFestival);Feb Arts Month Celebration, and Filipiniana Sunsets at the CCP. It is involved in the yearly projects of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) like Sayaw Pinoy (Pinoy Dance) and InternationalDance Xchange, and those for the National Historical Commission of the Philippines and the Department of Tourism. LBTD has toured the country, performing in Cebu, Iloilo, Dumaguete, Ozamis, Bacolod, Roxas, Aurora, Naga, Davao, Vigan, Bukidnon, Pagadian, Zamboanga, Misamis Oriental, Cagayan de Oro, and Olongapo. It has also represented the Philippines in international folklore festivals in Italy, Malaysia, and South Korea.

LBDT has garnered several recognitions, including Most Promising Cultural Dance Group: Year-Ender Excellence Award, 2003; Outstanding Cultural Dance Troupe, Asia-Pacific Excellence Award, 2004; Best Cultural Dance Group, Huwarang Pilipino Award, 2005; Most Outstanding Cultural and Artistic Group, Dangal ng Pilipinas Award, 2005 and 2006; Most Outstanding Cultural and Artistic Group – National Category, Dangal ng Pilipinas Award – Hall of Fame, 2009; National Champion, Sayaw Pinoy Creative Folk Dance Competition, National Association of Higher Education Institutions (NAHEI) and Commission on Higher Education (CHED), 2010; Best Cultural and Artistic Group – National Category, Dangal ng Pilipinas Award – Seal of Excellence, 2010, 2011, 2012; National Champion, Creative Folk Dance Competition, Union of Filipino Tourism Educators, 2011; National Champion, Philippine Festivals Dance Competition, League of Tourism Students of the Philippines, 2012; and 3rd Place at the 7th Sabah Folklore Festival and Competition, Malaysia, 2012.Written by Josefina B. Guillen

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Elena Laniog

(Photo from facebook.com/ma.elena.o.laniog)

text:
LANIOG, ELENA O. ( Maria Elena Ortizo Laniog-Alvarez ) b. Iloilo City 1979. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Laniog is the daughter of Antonio Laniog and Elena Ortizo. She is married to choreographer and teacher Herbert Alvarez. Laniog grew up in Iloilo City along with eight other siblings. Following the footsteps of her sister Marie Jill, she joined the Iloilo National High School’s Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company, where at age 13, she started training in dance under its artistic director, Edwin Duero. In 1995, she enrolled as a dance major at the University of the Philippines, College of Music Dance program, where she trained under Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Sonia Domingo, Christine Maranan, Judell de Guzman, Flordeliza Fernandez, and Corazon Iñigo.

With Dagyaw, she was able to perform in Cairo, Egypt, for the International Festival for Experimental Theater in 1995 and in Lisbon, Portugal, for the 1998 World Expo. As a student, Laniog became a member of the UP Dance Company, becoming its lead dancer in the company’s repertoire. She was the bride in Fernandez’s Ang Kasal (Stravinsky’s Les Noces ), 2001; Gisela in Villanueva and Comia’s Higanti (Vengeance), a 2003 deconstruction of Giselle; and Sisa in Fernandez’s Tatlong Mukha (Three Faces) in 2001. She also interpreted roles in restaged works of Basilio, as the sultana in Mosque Baroque,the bride in Cavatina,and as the main girl in Fernandez’s Femina.

In 2003, together with Herbert Alvarez, she choreographed Pedro Kusinero (Peter the Kitchen Boy), a deconstruction of the ballet Petrushka,for her graduation recital. The work became known as a very important piece in contemporary dance. It was featured in the 2009 WiFi Body Festival’s IndepenDance and at the UP College of Music Dance Program’s 30th Anniversary in 2012, with Stravinsky’s music first played live in the Philippines. In 2005, Pedro Kusinero won the UP Chancellor’s award for best student production.

Laniog has developed a distinct choreographic style in contemporary dance in the Philippines. Her choreographies Isa, Women Warrior, Sa se si, Hide and Seek, Dulce, Dotted Whispers, Class Menu, Silhouette, Mata sa Damgo (Eye of the Dream), On the Wings of 44 ,and Feet of Clay are products of explorations with her own body and with other dancers, which she developed as a technique in her contemporary classes. Several of these have been featured in festivals in the Philippines and abroad.

Her achievements in choreography have earned Laniog international recognition through the World Dance Alliance (WDA) and Japan Foundation. She was a featured solo artist at the WDA-Asia Pacific Arts Forum in 2009; artist-in-residence, at WDA-Asia Young Choreographer’s Project, in Chung Hwa School for the Arts in 2005, and in Tsoying High School in 2006. In 2004, Japan Foundation through Dance Box sent her to dance in a festival in Kobe, Japan, as solo artist, and again in 2009 and 2010 as artist-in-residence.Written by Angela Lawenko-Baguilat

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Mercedes Lauchengco-Drilon, center, with Ballet Federation Philippines colleagues

Steve Villaruz, left, Lydia Madarang, Eddie Elejar, and Rose Borromeo

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
LAUCHENGCO-DRILON, MERCEDES b. 1933. Dancer, teacher. She is the daughter of impresario Jose Lauchengco, mother of dancer Maricar Drilon and economist Marilou Drilon, wife of management expert and poet Jose Drilon, and grandmother of Derek, Maricar’s son who is the first prize winner at the Youth America Gran Prix in San Francisco and an apprentice at the Joffrey Ballet in Chicago. Inspired by the visit of Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin in 1948, she started formal ballet lessons at age 16 with RosaliaMerino-Santos at the Philippine Women’s University, and continued with Ricardo and RobertaCassell and RemediosdeOteyza. She was a leading dancer of the StudioDanceGroup. Until 1953, she had two years of physical education courses at the University of the Philippines, as well as courses in business administration. She also took lessons from visiting artists in Manila, like Frederic Franklin, Alexandra Danilova, Michael Maule, Mocelyn Larkin, TrudlDubsky-Zipper, and Jean Deroc. In New York, she studied with Melissa Hayden and jazz master Luigi or Eugene Louis Pacciuto.

In 1962 Lauchengco-Drilon established the Maria Makiling Dance School in Los Baños, Laguna, which existed for more than 20 years. For a while, there was a Maria Makiling Dance Group associated with the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) also in Los Baños. Her most noted students are actor-director TonyMabesa and her own daughter Maricar. Lauchengco-Drilon was also a founding member of the BalletFederationofthePhilippines in 1976, and was actively involved with the Friends of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. From 1978, she taught ballet at the PHSA. She has retired from teaching and directing dance. Written by Paul G. del Rosario and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Angela Lawenko-Baguilat

(Photo from facebook.com/angela.lawenkobaguilat)

text:
LAWENKO-BAGUILAT, ANGELA ( Angel Ravalo Lawenko-Baguilat ) b. 26 Oct 1975. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. She is the daughter of CPA Ramon C. Lawenko and music teacher Elinor Ravelo. She is married to Johan Baguilat. She completed her secondary education at the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) in 1992, and then enrolled in the Diploma for Creative and Performing Musical Arts, major in dance at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. She completed her bachelor in music, major in dance at the same college in 2005 and her master’s degree in human movement science at the UP College of Human Kinetics.

From 1992 to 2005, Baguilat performed with various dance groups and companies such as the PHSA’s Makiling Ballet, 1988-92; Ballet Philippines, 1992-94; UP Dance Company, 1994-2000; and the UP Filipiniana Alumni Dance Group, 2000-04. She was the soloist in Agos (Flow), 1996, UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium and Cracked Nut, Maria Clara’s Colonial Dream, 1997, UP Theater.

In 1992, Baguilat choreographed Introspection for their graduation Recital at the PHSA, CCP Little Theater. Her recital production Mariang Sinderela, ang Bagong Bayani (Maria Cinderella, the New Heroine)at theUP Theater, 1996, was the first UP deconstruction of a classical ballet (i.e., of Prokofiev’s Cinderella ) performed by the College of Music dancers. It inspired succeeding students to choreograph along the same framework. In 2006, her choreographic fusion, Bharatanatyam with Pangalay was performed at the President’s Palace in New Delhi, India.

For more than ten years, Baguilat has been visible in the world of dance as the head of a delegation to the Global Dance Summit, Taipei, Taiwan, 2012; curator and director of the International Dance Day show, Quezon City, 2010-12; curator and director of the Emerging Talents Showcase, WiFi Body Festival, CCP, 2007-10; festival director of the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival, 2012; and associate festival director of the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival, 2008-10. Since 2009, she has been at the helm of the Contemporary Dance Network Manila. Beginning as an associate artistic director of the UP Dance Company from 2001 to 2004, Baguilat eventually became its artistic director in 2007, and later as its faculty artistic consultant.

Since 2010, she has been in charge of the UP College of Music Dance Program. She is also currently a dance faculty of the Fides Cuyugan Institute of Music and Arts.

In 2005, Baguilat received a grant from the Indian Council for Culture and Research. During her one-year scholarship, she performed the Bharatanatyam at the Ayyapa Temple, Presidents Palace, and Karnataka Sanggam, all in New Delhi, India. Her exceptional performance of the classical Indian dance won for her and Bea Puno the 1st prize during the Tha Kha Dhimi Tha, Bharatanatyam Competition, Chennai, India in 2006. Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Luis Layag with Tita Layag-Radaic

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Luis Layag in Der Fliichtende/The Fugitive

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
LAYAG, LUIS ( Luis Pacia Layag )b. Manila 31 Oct 1946 d. Dusseldorf, Germany 23 Apr 1979. Dancer, choreographer, dance director. His parents were Felino Layag and Rafaela Pacia; his sisters were dancer-choreographers Felicitas“Tita”Layag-Radaic and Lucy Layag-de los Reyes. He studied Fine Arts at the University of the Philippines where he was one of the Ten Outstanding Students in 1967.

He trained in ballet with Layag-Radaic, AnitaKane, EddieElejar, TonyLlacer, ElGabriel, Poul Gnatt, Robin Haig, and Miro Zolan. He studied moderndance with AliceReyes and Norman Walker. Abroad, he studied at the Cologne Summer Dance Academy, American Ballet Theater School, School of American Ballet, Harkness Ballet School, and the schools of Finis Jhung, and of the companies of Robert Joffrey, Martha Graham, and Alvin Ailey.

In 1974 he trained with and observed ballet companies in Berlin, Hamburg, and Cologne. From 1974, he danced with the Heidelberg Ballet, and from 1976 with Pina Bausch’s Wuppertal Dance Theater until his death. He joined the Gulbenkian Choreographic Summer School in London in 1978.

In the Philippines, he danced with the Pamana Ballet, Dance Theater Philippines (DTP), Ballet Philippines (from its start in 1970) and his own group, Dancers of Mercury. He also taught and choreographed for the Royal Academy of Dancing (RAD)-Philippine Center, directed the Amihan at Habagat (Amihan and Habagat)dance series at the Rizal Park in 1972, and worked on everything, from choreography to costume, set, and lighting design. He was mainly interested in movement and its visual-aural effects.

For DTP, he choreographed Take Four to music by Felix Padilla Jr, La Mora to AntoninoBuenaventura, and They Came “Jorking” In to John Lennon, Paul McCartney, and Joshua Rifkin; for the RAD-Philippine Center, Back to Bach and LucretiaMcEvil to the Beatles; for BalletPhilippines and its school, Positive-Negative to Victorio Fellegara, TranSept to Robert Helps, Walls to Luciano Berio, The Warrior, later called The Fugitive,to Kazuo Fukushima, and Bagatelle to Berio. Some of his works were revived in Germany, sometimes to different music.

In Manila, he staged dances for Pajama Game, Once Upon a Mattress, West Side Story, Guys and Dolls, Jesus Christ Superstar, Godspell, The Survival of St. Joan (in collaboration with RolandoS.Tinio), Cabaret, and the Filipino operetta Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird). In Heidelberg, he did dances for The Mikado, Das Land des Lachelns, and Salome, which he codirected. He also choreographed for television in Cologne.

Layag was awarded first prize for choreography and costume design in the 1971 Songfest Choral Competition. He received study grants from the German International Theater Institute in 1974, the JDR III Fund in the United States in 1975, and the Gulbenkian Foundation in 1978. He represented Wuppertal, Germany, in the Young Choreographers Concert in 1978 and the Philippines in the International Theater Institute. In 1982, Basilio honored him with Domain of Peace to Alan Hovhaness from Dance Theater Philippines.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Tita Layag-Radaic in Pas de Quatre

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Tita Layag-Radaic

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
LAYAG-RADAIC, TITA ( Felicitas Pacia Layag-Radaic ) b. Manila 10 Jul 1936. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She is the daughter of Felino Layag and Rafaela Pacia, and was married to writer Ante Radaic. She is the sister of dancers Lucy and Luis Layag. She holds a bachelor of arts degree from the University of the Philippines (UP), 1955, and a master of arts in Spanish language from the University of Madrid. She also writes dance criticism and poetry. She is a founder of Philippine Ballet Theatre and member of its artistic council.

Layag-Radaic trained with Anita Kane and danced with Kane’s company as principal dancer. She trained further in Paris and Madrid with Valentina Kaschuba, Xenia Tripolitoff, and Karen Marie Taft. With a scholarship from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines, she trained in London from 1964 to qualify for membership in the Royal Academy of Dance (RAD) after passing all examinations to the advanced level, distinguishing her as the first Filipino member of the RAD. She also earned membership in the Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing that trains in the Cechetti Method. In 1973, she was awarded a German International Theater Institute grant to study in Germany and a British Council endorsement to observe the work of Royal Ballet and Scottish Ballet Theater in the United Kingdom. In 1968, she organized the RAD Philippine Center and soon founded her own school at St. Theresa’s College. Her school granted scholarships to both girls and boys, with the latter also provided with academic scholarships in schools of their choice.

With Julie Borromeo and Eddie Elejar, she cofounded Dance Theater Philippines (DTP) in 1968. She served the company for 21 years in various capacities as dancer, teacher, choreographer, and artistic and managing director. Through DTP and her school, she trained Irene and Hazel Sabas, Sophia Radaic, Mary Anne Santamaria, Eloisa Enerio, Anna Villadolid, Lisa Macuja, and Mylene Saldana. She choreographed ballets for DTP including the full-length Mir-i-nisa, 1969, with J. Borromeo, to libretto by Jose Garcia Villa and music by Eliseo Pajaro; May Day Eve, 1971, to the story by Nick Joaquin and music by Eliseo Pajaro; The Prey, 1973, to music by Rosalina Abejo RVM; Maho-no-Ken, 1974, to music by Alan Hovahnes; Japonsina, 1975, to music by Lucrecia Kasilag; Nan-Pangkat, 1975, to music by Angel Pena; Diwata (Goddess), 1976, to music by Nicanor Abelardo; La Innamorata (The Enamored), 1983, to music by Chopin; the comic ballets Oy Akin ’Yan! (Hey, That’s Mine!) and Tanan (Elopement), both in 1968 and to music by Juan Silos Jr; and Tubig!!! (Water!!!), 1979, to a commissioned score by Roberto Robledo. Radaic worked for two full seasons of DTP at the Meralco Theater, 1981-83; DTP’s residency at the UP College of Music, 1984-90; its foreign tours to the Aberdeen International Youth festival in the United Kingdom, 1975 and 1979, and to the Asian Arts Festival in Hong Kong, 1980. She is credited for staging DTP’s monthly performances at the Rizal Park for 13 years, bringing ballet to a vast audience.

After DTP, she focused on pedagogical endeavors, this time bringing ballet education to the private and public school system. In 1995, along with Noordin A. Jumalon and Vella C. Damian whom she invited, she conceptualized and initiated the Philippine Ballet Syllabus in order to create a professional method of ballet instruction that was accessible to schools in the Philippines. Funded and supported by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the first volume, renamed National Ballet Syllabus, was released in 2000 and the second in 2002. It has since been in use in the CCP Dance School and other ballet schools in Metro Manila, Visayas, and Mindanao. The first volume was updated in 2011 with Violeta Velasco as coauthor and Vibal Press as publisher. Its widespread use has been facilitated by workshops given by Radaic, Noordin Jumalon, and NBS Examiners trained by her.

For her extensive work in dance, Radaic was given numerous awards: the Mariang Maya Award by the UP Sigma Delta Phi sorority in 1985; the Patnubay ng Kalinangan at Sining by the City of Manila in 1988; the President’s Award by the Royal Academy of Dance in the UK in 1996; the CCP Centennial Honor for the Arts and a centennial citation from the University of Santo Tomas, both in 1999; and the Outstanding Alumna in the Arts by the UP and the Gawad CCP Award for Dance by the CCP, both in 2008.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Cathee Lee

text:
LEE, CATHEE ( Cathereen Vivien Lee-Roslovtsev )b. Manila 28 Oct 1973. Daughter of Apo Lee and Charlotte Batad, she is married to former dancer Andrei Roslovtsev, with whom she has four children. Lee has a BA in Communication Arts from Miriam College, 1995.

She started her dance training at Julie Borromeo’s Dance Arts Studio at the age of six, under Anamarie Aragon-Quirino, Josette Salang, Maricar Aragon, Edward Malagkit, Jeng Halili, and Julie Borromeo. She trained extensively with Dance Arts until the age of 14. In 1991, she attended the Summer Intensive Program of the National Ballet School of Canada in Toronto. Lee counts Anna Villadolid, Maniya Barredo, and Lisa Macuja-Elizalde as her artistic influences.

In 1989, she joined Philippine Ballet Theatre, until she retired as principal dancer in 2004. For over two decades of dancing, she moved up through several ballets, from corps de ballet to soloist to principal roles. She appeared in David Campos’s Carmina Burana, 1995, 1997, 2003, and 2004; George Balanchine’s Serenade, 1996, 2002, and 2003; Jean Paul Comelin’s Raymonda, 1998, performing the title role in 2002; and Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, where she played Juliet in 2000 and 2003. In this role, she was partnered by Francis Jaena and later by Ronilo Jaynario.

There were other roles where she matured in both characterization and expressiveness. These include one of the four cygnets in Swan Lake, 1993, 1994, and 2001; Amour in Don Quixote, 1993, 2000, and 2001; and in the dual role of Masha/Sugarplum Fairy in Michael Chernov and Gelsey Kirkland’s The Nutcracker, 1995, 2002, and 2003. Other highlights include the White Cat in Christine Walsh’s The Sleeping Beauty, 1996; peasant pas de deux in Giselle, 1997; and a signature role in Pazik’s Trio, 2002, and Scherzo, 2003, both of which she performed until she retired in 2004. For her, Tony Fabella created the role of shy girl in Fiesta, 2001. She also performed as a guest artist in some of Repertory Philippines’ children’s musicals, including the role of Iris in Fame!, 2004.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Leyte Dance Theater performing “Dances of the Lowlanders”

(Photo from facebook.com/leytedancetheater)

Leyte Dance Theater performing “Mindanao Sketches”

(Photo from facebook.com/leytedancetheater)

text:
LEYTE DANCE THEATER Founded in 1990 by Jess de Paz, the group started in 1965 as the Danzz Corps, a student organization based at the Divine Word University (DWU) of Tacloban. The company changed its name to Academy of the Arts Dance Repertory when Paz worked as the director of the Academy at the Leyte State College (LSC). It changed its name again to Dance Theater of Tacloban in partnership with the Arts Council of Tacloban City and was based at the DWU Hall. Eventually, Paz brought the company back to LSC and renamed it the LSC Dance Theater, and later the Leyte Normal University Dance Theater when the college became a university. In 1990, the company became private and officially renamed itself the Leyte Dance Theater (LDT). Paz has served as artistic director and choreographer of the LDT since its inception. Dancers who have performed with LDT are Douglas Nierras, Butch de Veyra, Manny Letrondo, and Danny Marshall.

Known for dances similar to those conceived and choreographed by National Artist for Dance Leonor Orosa-Goquinco, LDT’s repertoire includes ballet, contemporary, jazz, and the fusion of ballet-contemporary and folk movements. Among the notable works of the company are full-length productions of West Side Story,and The Nutcracker Suite,and original productions such as Pag-ibig: Philippine Style (Love: Philippine Style), Mariang Maya (Maria the Maya Bird), Purundok (Gathering), Tatlong Handog (Three Offerings),and Broadway Hits. The LDT has also staged short, nationalistic pieces, with the most recent, Bayan Ko (My Country), 2014, being performed extensively by the LDT as it toured the Philippines and the US. Other short pieces include An Iroy Nga Tuna (Motherland), Lupang Hinirang (Chosen Land), Pilipinas Kong Mahal (Philippines, My Beloved),as well as 20-30 minute short productions such as An Hadi (The King), Pintados (Painted Ones), Diwata (Nymph), Mindanao Sketches, Cordillera Images, Call of Mountains, Dance of the Lowlanders, Bahandi (Treasure),and Danhani (Once Upon a Time).

The LDT is active in performing for local and national audiences and joining dance festivals such as the International Dance Day celebrations sponsored by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCAA) and its Dance XChange. It has represented the Philippines in the Chingay Festival in Singapore in 2000, the International Council of Organizations for Folklore-sponsored International Folkloric Dance Festivals in Turkey in 2004, Indonesia in 2007, and Malaysia in 2009, where the LDT won the grand championship. The LDT, along with 20 other countries around the world, was also invited to perform in Bahrain during its Grand Prix event in 2013. The group toured the United States seven times as Ambassadors of Culture, in 1997, 1998, 1999, 2002, 2005, 2007, and 2014.

The LDT is a recipient of the Sangyaw Foundation Inc Award for Culture and Entertainment, 2012, and the Lifetime Achievement Award in the Performing Arts during the 26th Annual Aliw Awards in 2013.Written by Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Original members of the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company with founder Teresita Veloso-Pil on tour in the United States, 1965

(Photo courtesy of Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company)

text:
LEYTE KALIPAYAN DANCE COMPANY Formerly the Leyte Filipiniana Dance Troupe, it was founded in 1960 by TeresitaVeloso-Pil, its choreographer and artistic director. It started at the Holy Infant Academy in Tacloban City, drawing members from the students and the faculty, and with the support of Sr Mary Canisius, director of the academy.

The Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company (LKCD) made its professional debut on 21 Sep 1961, which led to numerous invitations all over the country. From 1961 to 1964, the company toured major cities in the Philippines. In 1965, the troupe was designated Cultural Ambassadors by President Diosdado Macapagal and embarked on a ten-month tour of the USA. The company made an appearance in the famed Ed Sullivan show watched by millions of Americans.

Since then, the troupe has gone on 12 international tours, performing to capacity crowds at Expo ’70 in Osaka, opening the UNESCO cultural season in Paris, dancing to standing-room audiences in Saudi Arabia, receiving standing ovations from over 7,000 spectators at the World’s Fair ’82 in Tennessee, participating as one of the “18 World’s Best Dance Troupes” at the opening rites of the Epcot Center in Disneyworld in Florida, and joining international festivals in Israel, Rome, France, Switzerland, Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, Spain, Portugal, England, Slovenia, Greece, Kuwait, Bahrain, Mexico, and Malaysia. In 1980, the LKDC received the silver medal at the Dijon International Folklore Festival, held in Dijon, France, a dance competition participated in by over 32 folk dance groups from all over the world. In 2014, the company was able to honor prior engagements despite suffering from the ravages of super-typhoon Yolanda, performing at the International Cultural Festival in Thailand from 17 to 22 Aug, and at the closing ceremony of the China-ASEAN Cultural Exchange Year from 12 to 17 Dec at Myanmar.Written by Teresita Veloso-Pil, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Tony Llacer, 2001

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
LLACER, TONY ( Antonio Llacer )b. Manila 14 Oct 1935 d. in Singapore. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. After high schoolin San Beda College, he took journalism courses at the University of Santo Tomas. He trained in dance in Manila with Ricardo Cassell and Anita Kane. He performed in their ballets, such as Fifth Symphony, Peruvian in Paris,and Les Sylphides.He also danced for Trudl Dubsky-Zipper in A Midsummer Night’s Dream and other ballets. On full scholarships, he studied further at Ballet Arts, 1958-60, and at the School of American Ballet, 1959-60, both in New York, and at Eugene Loring’s American School of Dance, 1963-68, in Los Angeles. Among his teachers were George Balanchine, Vladimir Dokoudovsky, Anatole Oboukhoff, Pierre Vladimirov, Valentina Preyeslavec, Jose Limon, and Eugene Loring. Aside from ballet, he also trained in jazz and modern dance.

Between 1959 and 1961, he danced in the original Broadway production of Flower Drum Song,and later with its national road company tour and in Las Vegas. He also danced in Pal Joey, Peter Pan,and TheSound ofMusic,and took bit parts in the movies Sand Pebbles, The Detective,and An Extraordinary Seaman.From 1964 to 1965, he taught for Western Ballet Company in Los Angeles, and from 1967 to 1968 in Loring’s American School of Dance and Ballet Petit. Returning to Manila, he was ballet master and dancer for DanceTheaterPhilippines between 1968 and 1971, at the same time that he taught ballet and jazz for Dance Arts Studio. Among the dancers he nurtured were Odon and TommySabarre, Mitto Castillo, NonoyFroilan, and EnricoLabayen. Between 1971 and 1972, he also taught for the school of National Artist in Dance LeonorOrosa-Goquingco; between 1973 and 1974, the Manila Symphony Society Corps de Ballet; and between 1971 to 1979, the Karilagan Cultural Arts International. For Dance Theater Philippines, he choreographed In the Beginning…, 1969, to music by Villalobos, and Les Patineurs (The Skaters), 1969, to Meyerbeer. For the Singapore National Dance Company, he did Quintet, Triad,and Three Songs. For Dance Arts Singapore and the Singapore Dance Festival, he also choreographed Hi-Jinks, Variaciones, Etudes, Cantata, and Movements Cinq.He carried on teaching in schools in Singapore until he died. In 1980, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts honored him with the award Pasasalamat ng Bayan sa Sayaw (Nation’s Gratitude in Dance).Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Agnes Locsin

(Photo by Jojo Mamangun, courtesy of the artist)

Agnes Locsin rehearsing with Sonny Locsin for SANGA: Ika-Apat Na Galaw

(Photo by Jojo Mamangun, courtesy of the artist)

text:
LOCSIN, AGNES ( Agnes Dakudao Locsin )b. Davao City 28 Sep 1957. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. Locsin is the daughter of Jose Severino Locsin and Carmen Dakudao, a pioneering ballet teacher in Davao. Her sister, Bing Locsin, was a tap dancer and jazz teacher in Los Angeles, who later moved to Davao. She received her degree in English from the Ateneo de Davao University, 1979, and her master of arts in dance from the Ohio State University, USA. She first trained with her mother in Davao at the Locsin Dance Workshop where she later taught and became artistic director of the Locsin Dance Ensemble. She was dance director of the Terpsichoreans in Ateneo de Davao and has taught in the faculty of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School, the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, and the Jazz Tap Center. She served as dance consultant to the Philippine Educational Theatre Association and Tanghalang Pilipino. In 1990, Locsin became Artistic Director of Ballet Philippines (BP) II. In 1994-96, she became artistic director of the main company, and continued to be chief choreographer until 1999. Today, it is in her mother Carmen’s studio in Davao that Locsin continues her own vocation to nurture and train choreographers from the regions through her Mulihok Dance Workshop.

In 1986, she gave a solo choreographer’s concert titled Female Moves with selected dancers from Manila and Davao. It premiered Only a Woman using video-film and was about a woman’s qualities and life cycle; La Lupa (The She-Wolf) all to sound effects and based on a story by Giovanni Verga; and Dabaw based on the Bagobo belief regarding the solar eclipse as a monster eating the sun, the symbol for the terrorism in Davao. It also premiered Igorot in the Philippines which was staged for the Petit Ballet Theatre in Amsterdam in 1987. Her Ismagol and Bagobo, both in 1990, launched BP II.

Her other works include Carmen, 1977; Teresa,about Santa Teresa of Avila, 1981; Ang Kapalit (The Substitute), 1981/1982, her master’s thesis about Gabriela Silang; Kulam (Witchcraft) for the Metropolitan Dance Theatre, 1991; Moslem for UP and BP and Moriones for the CCP Dance School, both in 1991; Roll Over, Beethoven for BP II and Paglalakbay (Journey), 1992, for the Pas de Deux Program, a joint concert of BP II and Le Jeune Ballet de France.

In 1992, she collaborated with composer/singer Joey Ayala and librettist Al Santos to produce the much-acclaimed full-length work, Encantada (Enchantress). With this apparent focus on indigenous Philippine tradition, its beliefs and rituals rendered in a modern dance idiom, Locsin’s works were described as “neo-ethnic.” She continued to create works in this style such as Babalyan which won second place in the 1993 Tokyo International Choreography Competition; the solos Taong Talangka (Man-Crab)and Salome,which won for Camille Ordinario the 2nd place in the 6th Concours International de la Danse, Paris, 1994; Dalagang Filipina (Filipina Maiden),1995; and Labaw Donggon,about the mythical hero in the Panayanon epic Hinilawod for the Philippine High School for the Arts, 1997.

Locsin’s Elias,1995, about Jose Rizal’s character Elias in the novel Noli Me Tangere,and La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution),1996, about Apolinario Mabini, placed her in the ranks of some of the major choreographers of her time. Aside from these, she also created her versions of Western classical works such as A Midsummer Night’s Dream,1994, Romeo and Juliet, 1997, Medea,1995, and Four Last Songs,1999, choreographed to Richard Strauss.

At the Locsin Dance Workshop in Davao, she created more intimate works for smaller ensembles, some of which are cochoreographies under her direction. Works produced in Davao include the 30-minute solo Balyan (Shaman), Sayaw sa Labi (Dance of the Other),2006, co-choreographed with Gaye Galiluyo and Georgette Sanchez; Sayaw Sabel (Dance of Sabel),2010, inspired by visual artist BenCab’s iconic “Sabel,” as a reinvention of Noli Me Tangere’ s“Sisa”; and the Alay sa Puno (Tribute to Trees)four-part series which consists of Ugat (Root),2010, Dahon (Leaf),2012, Puno (Tree),2012, in collaboration with Gaye Galiluyo and Georgette Sanchez, and Sanga (Branch),2013, featuring the choreography of Biag Gaongen in collaboration with Krisbelle Paclibar and Sonny Locsin. The last is her tribute to the vanishing trees of her native Davao.

For her efforts, Locsin has received the following awards and recognition: the Hiyas ng Lahi Award, from the Dance Alliance and National Choreography Endeavors, as well as the CAPA Award, Outstanding Alumnus from the Philippine Women’s College in Davao City, both in 1992; the Blue Knight Award, Outstanding Alumnus In the Field of Dance from the Ateneo de Davao University, the Prince Takamado Award as well as a silver medal in the Tokyo International Choreography Competition, both in 1993; the Araw ng Maynila Award Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan given by the city of Manila in 1994; a Special Philippine Centennial Citation from the City of Davao in 1998; the Datu Bago Award from the City of Davao in 2000; a Mindanawan Art and Culture Citation, awarded by the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble, Mindanao State University and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts as well as the Pilak Award Para sa Serbisyong Pangkultura, Sining, at Komunidad, given in celebration of the 25th Anniversary of the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program, both in 2004; the Gawad Buhay Award in the categories of Outstanding Original Choreography and Outstanding Production for La Revolucion from Philstage in 2008; the Kamindanawan Award given by the Mindanao Commission on Women, as well as the Gawad Buhay Award in the categories of Outstanding Original Choreography and Outstanding Production for Encantada fromPhilstage, all in 2011; the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 2013; and the Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi, given by the Ateneo de Manila University in 2014.

Her book Philippine Neo-Ethnic Choreography: A Creative Process published by the University of Santo Tomas in 2012 won the Alfonso T. Ongpin Prize for Best Book on Artduring the 32nd National Book Award sponsored by the National Book Development Board and the Manila Critics Circle.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Myra Victoria C. Beltran

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Sonny Locsin in Sayaw, Sabel, 2010, choreographed by Agnes Locsin

(Photo by Darell Sicam)

Sonny Locsin

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Sonny Locsin in Signing Off, choreographed by Paul Lightfoot and Sol Leon

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
LOCSIN, SONNY ( Cesar Jose Serena Locsin ) b. Davao City 26 May 1979. Sonny Locsin is the son of Veronica Isabel Sereno and Cesar “Boy” Dakudao Locsin. Among his four siblings, only he pursued dance, having been exposed to the world of his grandmother, Carmen Dakudao Locsin, who established the Locsin Dance Workshop in 1947, and his aunt, choreographer Agnes Locsin. Another aunt, Lourdes “Bing” Locsin is a tap and jazz dance teacher, and dancer Georgette Sanchez is his cousin.

Locsin began tap dancing at the age of 3 and started ballet at the age of 5. In Manila, he trained with Noordin Jumalon, William Morgan, Perry Sevidal, and Gina Katigbak at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School from 1994 to 1996, joining Ballet Philippines (BP) II in 1996. With BP, he performed the Nutcracker prince in The Nutcracker and other major roles in Denisa Reyes’s Te Deum; Lionel Hoche’s Le Petite Piece Exterieur (A Little Bit of the Outside), Agnes Locsin’s Babalyan (Shaman), and Moriones, Romeo in Romeo and Juliet, Basilio in Elias, and Mabini in La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution).

In 1996, he was awarded a full scholarship at the San Francisco Ballet School, where he performed George Balanchine’s Allegro Brillante and Stars and Stripes, as well as Helgi Tomasson’s Handel Celebration. He considers Ricardo Bustamante and Jorge Esquivel as major influences on his dancing.

He danced with the Jeune Ballet de France in Paris, 1998–1999, performing in Claude Brumachon’s Les Indomptes, and Ivan Favier’s Febrile; with Ballet Gulbenkian in Lisbon, Portugal, 1999-2000, in Rodrigo Pedeneiras’s Terra Nova,and Ohad Naharin’s Perpetuum; with Aterballetto in Reggio Emilia, Italy, 2000–01, in Kazimir’s Colours and A Midsummer Night’s Dream; with Badisches Staatstheater Karlsruhe in Germany, 2001–04, in Jerome Delbey’s Whim, and Hans van Manen’s Bits and Pieces. In 2004, he joined Ballett Am Rhein in Dusseldorf, where he became a demi-soloist in 2007 and soloist in 2009, performing Paul Lightfoot and Sol Leon’s Signing Off, Youri Vamos’s Romeo and Juliet, and Mats Ek’s Aluminum. He has performed the works of some of Europe’s most notable choreographers, including the aforementioned artists, and Martin Schläpfer and Ji?í Kylián.

He has performed in Paris, New York, Moscow, Australia, Spain, Russia, Kazakstan, Khirgistan, Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic, Colombia, Italy, Israel, Brazil, Austria, Switzerland, The Netherlands, Indonesia, Singapore, China, and Manila. He performed Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet pas de deux with Philippine Ballet Theatre in 2001. He joined the Visayas and Mindanao tour of Sayaw Sabel (Dance of Sabel), 2010, where a solo was tailor-made for him by Agnes Locsin. In 2013, he also created his role in Agnes Locsin’s Sanga: Ika-Apat na Galaw (Branch: Fourth Movement) in Davao.

Locsin was awarded the special prize Prix AROP (Association for the Radiation of the Opera de Paris) at the 9th Paris International Dance Competition in 2000.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Sony Lopez-Gonzalez

(Photo from facebook.com/sony.lopezgonzalez.9)

Sony Lopez-Gonzalez

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
LOPEZ-GONZALEZ, SONY ( Asuncion Fajardo Lopez-Gonzalez )b. Manila 3 Aug 1933. Dancer, pianist, teacher. She is the daughter of Francisco T. Lopez and Angelina Jacinto Fajardo, and the mother of dancer ToniLopezGonzalez and dance teachers Rosanna Gonzalez-Paredes and Gianna Lopez Gonzalez. She graduated as a music teacher from Santa Isabel College, Manila. She studied with RicardoCassell and RemediosdeOteyza, then at Ballet Arts Studio and School of American Ballet in New York, USA. She was briefly a member of the New York City Ballet. She trained with George Balanchine, Anatole Oboukhoff, Vera Nemtchinova, Vladimir Dokoudovsky, Edward Caton, Lisan Kay, and Nina Stroganova. Also in New York, she studied at the Juilliard School of Music, Marymount College, and Katharine Gibbs School.

Lopez-Gonzalez founded the Ballet Arts Studio in 1960, which presented the full-length Giselle,1961, and Swan Lake,1962, with MaribelAboitiz and EddieElejar. She also brought to thecountry Nora Kovach and Istvan Rabovsky todance with Filipino artists in 1962. For 20 years, she directed the Academie of the Performing Arts in Makati, after which she briefly supervised the Philippine Ballet Theatre School.

Lopez-Gonzalez was active in the Society for BalletPhilippines (which she cofounded), ManilaSymphonySociety, and was a member of the artistic council of the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), of which she is one of the founders. In 1992 she became chairperson of the National Committee on Dance of the Presidential (now National) Commission on Culture and Arts. She has been cited by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance Foundation, as well as numerous civic groups. She has retired from dance, but maintains some link with PBT and some ballet studios and schools.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Jojo Lucila

(Photo from facebook.com/jojo.lucila)

text:
LUCILA, JOJO ( Constantino Tactacan Lucila Jr )b. San Juan 1 May 1958. Dancer, choreographer, arts manager. He is the son of Constantino Lucila and Rosalina Tactacan, and brother to five siblings. He is married to dancer, teacher, and arts manager Ida Beltran, with whom he has three children. Lucila was a Marketing major at the University of the East (UE). He started dancing with the UE Dance Troupe in 1977, and later joined Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1983, training with Gener Caringal, Tony Fabella, Norman Walker, William Morgan, Luminita Dumitrescu, Mikhail Kukharev, Vakhtang Chabukiani, Armin Wild, Alfred Rodriguez, Rosemary Helliwell, Kenneth Gillespie, Gray Veredon, Effie Nañas, Cora Iñigo, Ester Rimpos, Noordin Jumalon, and Alice Reyes. Lucila started his own company, Chameleon Dance Company, in 1989, with wife Ida. His vision for the company was for its dancers to be proficient in different dance styles, particularly those that he uses in his choreographies.

He started to choreograph in 1983, and was featured in BP’s Five Young Choreographers, where he presented I, Judas,1987, and Huling Hibla (Last Strand),1988. I, Judas was also presented at the launch of BP II in 1990. For his own Chameleon Dance company, Lucila did modern experimentations that included transformations of Philippine folk dance movement. Of these works, the most choreographically realized were Pantomina, 1994; Flagellantes, and Maria Clara and the Leper, 1994, both from Lucila’s recreation of Leonor Orosa Goquingco’s Filipinescas and Noli Dance Suite; Tagabanbantay (Creatures of the Mountains) and Kuwentong Pinoy (FilipinoStory).

He was commissioned to create these modernized folk transformations for other companies, producing Martial Ways, 1991, for Ballet Philippines’ Neo-Filipino; Banbantay: Ritual at Tradisyon (Mountains: Ritual and Tradition), 1999, for Philippine Ballet Theatre; another version of Pantomina, 1995, as well as Sayaw nAPO Sila (They All Danced), to music by the APO Hiking Society, and Sari’t Bahag (Sarong and Loincloth)for Ballet Manila, 1996.

Lucila served as the dance director of the UE Dance Troupe, artistic director of Teatro Silencio Pilipinas, a theater company of hearing-impaired dancers, theater director of Teatro Aguinaldo, and an officer of the Dance Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). He also directed and choreographed the Philippine Independence Day celebrations from 1997 to 2005.

He migrated to Canada with his family and established the Chameleon Dance Edmonton. There he taught and choreographed for several dance companies and schools, such as the Edmonton Festival Ballet, Edmonton Contemporary Dance Company, Dance Unlimited, and the Ukrainian Shumka Dancers. He received the Cultural Diversity in the Arts award from the Edmonton City Government in 2011.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Alden Lugnasin

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

text:
LUGNASIN, ALDEN ( Aden Colinayo Lugnasin )b. Leyte, Philippines 25 Jun 1969. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. Alden Lugnasin is the son of Pedro Manzano Lugnasin and Eugenia Baclayo Colinayo, and the oldest brother of Aldrin Lugnasin, Jane Lugnasin Canonigo, and Argie Baliclic. He graduated from the Leyte State College with a degree in Hotel and Restaurant Management in 1989.

Lugnasin’s training began when he joined the Leyte State College Dance Troupe during his third year of college. With the group, he studied ballet, jazz, and contemporary dance with Jess de Paz who, along with Antonio Cinco Jr, later encouraged him to audition for the CCP Summer Dance Workshop. He joined the Summer Dance Workshop in 1991 and was later taken in as apprentice. As an apprentice and later a Ballet Philippines (BP) II member under Agnes Locsin, he toured with the junior company nationally and internationally in La Baule, France, in 1992. He competed in Japan with the group winning for Agnes Locsin the Silver Medal and the Prince Takamado Award at the Tokyo International Choreography Competition in 1993, where he performed originated roles in Locsin’s Moriones and Babalyan (Shaman). In 1994, he became company member of BP, performing lead roles as the Frayle in Encantada (Enchantress), 1993; the lead in Redha Bentifour’s Le Petits Mots D’Amour (Little Words of Love),1994, which was created on him; the title role in Elias, 1995;Espada in Don Quixote, 1995; the Prince in The Nutcracker, 1996; and Mabini in La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), 1996, which toured the Philippines and the United States.

His choreographic debut was in Impasse at the 1993 Neo-Filipino offering, which was also performed at the 1994 Jacksonville International Ballet Competition as a solo. After serving as a guest choreographer-in-residence for the International Dance Festival at Connecticut College, he became the resident choreographer of BP in 1998. With the latter, he molded the modern style and technique of the company, as they regularly staged and toured his modern pieces such as Swimming the Ilog Pasig, 1997, which was restaged by the Nashville Ballet Tennessee; Flippers, 2001; Aku (Me), 2004, a regular competition piece of the company which won the silver medal at the Concours International de Danse de France; Lahat ng Araw (Every Single Day), 2005; This is My Life, 2006; You Don’t Bring Me Flowers, 2006; and Words and Phrases, 2010. Notable for his ingenious and satirical style, some of his other memorable works include Life is a Rope, 1994; Swans … Fluttering Disturbances, 1997; Accidental Swans, 2001. A prolific choreographer, he created the full-length works Neverneverland, 2004, Pusong Wagas (Pure Heart), 2012, and Rite of Spring, 2016; the one-act Bungansakit (Fruit of Pain), 2010; and co-choreographed the full-length Rock Supremo, 2013, and Manhid (Numb), 2014.

A choreographer of international scope, he represented the country in the Asia Pacific Performance Exchange Artist Program in Indonesia under the University of California, Los Angeles-Center for the Intercultural Performance in 1998, was sponsored by the Asia-Europe Foundation in a collaborative project with visual artists like Anne Rochette in Paris, France, and Warsaw, Poland. He has been the Artistic Director of BP II since 2011 and continues to train scholars and apprentices in his distinctive and dynamic modern technique.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Max Luna, 1988

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Max Luna in Alvin Ailey‘s The River, 1980

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
LUNA, MAX ( Maximino Arenas Luna III ) aka Max Luna III. b. Batangas City 4 Jan 1947. He is the son of Maximino Luna Sr and Felicidad Arenas. He is a cousin of Leonor Luna Orosa-Goquingco and Gilda Luna Cordero-Fernando. At the young age of 13, he was already a scholar of Ballet Philippines (BP), became a company member when he turned 14, and performed with the company under Alice Reyes in the early 1970s.

At the age of 15, he continued his dance education as a scholar with the American Ballet Theater School, the School of American Ballet, and the Joffrey Ballet School when his family migrated to the United States. For further training, Luna joined the Ballet International de Caracas, Ballet Hispanico, the Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal, and the Joyce Trisler Dance Company where he learned the Horton syllabus, a codified modern dance technique by Lester Horton.

After performing extensively with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Luna was invited by Alvin Ailey to be the company’s resident choreographer in the early 1990s. In the late 1990s, he went to Italy and taught jazz and modern dance using the Horton syllabus. For 11 years, Luna was also connected with the Central Pennsylvania Youth Ballet where he served as artistic director, resident choreographer, and faculty.

In 2008, and after spending more than 30 years abroad, Luna returned to the Philippines and together with Alan Hineline, became BP’s artistic director from 2008 to 2009. For BP, he staged The Hurt We Embrace and Mga Awit (Songs), both in 2008, and Kati, Taog (Low Tide, High Tide) for the Neo-Filipino series in 2009.

After his stint with BP, Luna taught in the schools of Lydia Gaston and former BP member Dwight Rodrigazo. With the latter, Luna was featured in the dance concert titled Pinasadiyaw (a combination of the words “pananaw, mga sayaw, isang diwa” – views, dances, one thought) sponsored by the Ayala group in 2008. His work Pangadamlong Bulan or “ pangalay, damdamin, alon ng buwan” (pangalay, feelings, and waves of the moon), took off from the pangalay dance of the Sulu archipelago.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Jun Mabaquiao

text:
MABAQUIAO, JUN ( Ely Feria Mabaquiao Jr ) b. 16 Feb 1968. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. He is the son of accountant Ely Diocson Mabaquiao Sr and entrepreneur Norma Dumlao Feria. His other siblings are all dancers and/or dance teachers: Maria Elena “Mailen” Mabaquiao-Valera, Leoncito “Chito” Mabaquiao III, and Maria Eleanor “Yek” Mabaquiao-Barlongay. The Mabaquiao siblings’ early exposure to ballet, jazz, and tap dancing was at the Dance Arts Studio of Julie Borromeo where their mother was officer-in-charge. Jun Mabaquiao started dancing at age 10. In the mid-1980s, their mother set up the MJM School for Dance which also operated a small business that created dance wear, costumes, and footwear. Mabaquiao’s natural versatility enabled him to master those different dance styles. Later, he became one of the dance teachers at their family’s dance school and at Dance Arts Studio. His mentors were Bing Locsin, Agnes Locsin, and Rose Borromeo. He studied Economics at the University of the East.

In 1986, he received a scholarship from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School, which paved the way for his becoming a regular member of Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1987. Mabaquiao danced significant roles in BP’s Njinsky, Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), TheNutcracker, Peter Pan, Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), and Coppelia, 1986-87. As lead dancer of BP, he danced roles such as Siegfried in Swan Lake, 1989. He joined the Hong Kong Ballet (HB) in 1991 and became one of its principal dancers. HB performed in theaters all over Asia, Europe, and America. As senior soloist, he essayed roles in Unknown Territory, Allegro Brillante, Who Cares, and The Last Emperor. A knee injury in 1996 sidelined him for a while, but he later returned to dancing. He came home to the Philippines in 1997 to dance in Agnes Locsin’s Romeo and Juliet. Mabaquiao danced Romeo opposite Toni Lopez Gonzalez as Juliet.

After retirement from HB, Mabaquiao completed a certificate course in Pilates at the Physical Mind Institute in 2000 in San Francisco, California, and with Stott Pilates in 2002 in London. He also co-established the Steps Ahead Dance production in Hong Kong and taught at the House of Dancing Water in Macau. He choreographed for the musical thriller Sweeney Todd in 2009; Spring Awakening in 2011; and A Chorus Line with Giselle Liu for the HK Youth Arts Foundation in 2013.Written by Rosalie Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Lisa Macuja as Princess Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Lisa Macuja

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Manila)

Lisa Macuja with Osias Barroso

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Lisa Macuja with Nonoy Froilan in Giselle

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MACUJA, LISA ( Lisa Teresita Pacheco Macuja-Elizalde ) aka Lisa Macuja-Elizalde. b. Mandaluyong, Metro Manila 3 Oct 1964. Dancer, teacher, choreographer, and artistic director. She is the daughter of Cesar Macuja and Susan Pacheco. The second of four siblings, Macuja is the sister of the late theater actor Jerome Macuja and theater actor/teacher Guia Macuja. She is married to Fred J. Elizalde with whom she has two children. She obtained her secondary schooling at St. Theresa’s College in Quezon City. She received an associate of arts degree in general studies in 2004, and her bachelor of science degree in business management (with honors) in 2007, both from the University of Phoenix, USA.
