At the age of eight, she was enrolled at the St. Theresa’s College School of Dance under Felicitas Layag-Radaic. She apprenticed as a young soloist and became a member of Dance Theater Philippines (DTP). Under the guidance of Layag-Radaic, Macuja received her advanced certificate from the Royal Academy of Dance. In 1982, at the age of 18, she received a scholarship from the USSR Ministry of Culture to study at the former Vaganova Choreographic Institute (now the Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet) in St. Petersburg, formerly Leningrad. There she was mainly coached by Tatiana Alexandrovna Udalenkova and graduated in 1984 at the top of her class. While in school, she performed Masha/Sugarplum Fairy in the full-length The Nutcracker.

After her graduation in 1984, Macuja was invited to be a soloist for the Kirov Ballet, the first ever foreigner to be so invited. In 1986, she danced Kitri in Don Quixote with Farukh Ruzimatov and Giselle with Ravil Bagautdinov. Returning to Manila in 1986, she became the first artist-in-residence of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) while dancing with Ballet Philippines and in CCP outreach tours nationwide. In 1988 she became a dancer of the Philippine Ballet Theatre.

She has guested with many other international ballet companies: Royal New Zealand Ballet in 1980, Bolshoi Ballet in 1988, Yokohama Haruchi Ballet in 1989, and Ballet Nacional de Cuba in 1990. With the last, she made her debut in Swan Lake with Ernesto Quenedit. In 1988 she was invited to the 250th anniversary gala of the Vaganova Institute. She won fifth place in the First Diaghilev Ballet Competition in 1992.

In 1995, together with Eric V. Cruz and Osias Barroso, she established Ballet Manila (BM). As BM’s principal ballerina and artistic director, she took the company on tours of 16 cities in Russia and 15 cities in the USA, to the Aberdeen Youth Festival in Scotland, the Folk Arts Festival in South Korea, the Asia Arts Festival in China, the Angkor-Gyeongju World Culture Expo in Cambodia, the Philippine Fiesta in Japan, and a concert tour of England and Ireland.

In her repertory are La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), Sleeping Beauty, Coppelia, Paquita, La Sylphide, Les Sylphides, Ang Pilya ( La Fille Mal Gardee,Filipinizedby William Morgan), Serenade, Pineapple Poll, Madame Butterfly, and the works of Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Gener Caringal, Tony Fabella, and David Campos Cantero. Among her partners have been Barroso, Nonoy Froilan, Nicolas Pacaña, Rey Dizon, Andre Reyes, Brando Miranda, Vivencio Samblaceño, Rudy de Dios, Gerardo Francisco, Baknian Smagulov, Rinat Gizatulin, Paul de Masson, Pyatas Skirmantas, Aivars Leimanis, Sabir Yapanrov, Rudolf Kharatyan, Ravil Bagaudinov, Rafael Avnikyan, Gennady Garbanyov, Irek Mukhamedov, Ou Lu, Ju Horiuuch, David Makhateli, and Mikhail Martynuk.

In 2006, BM celebrated Macuja’s 20th year as ballerina and staged Halo-Halo: Lisa@20, where she danced scenes and excerpts from Don Quixote and Romeo and Juliet. In the same year, she coauthored with Angela Blardony Ureta and Susan de Guzman her autobiography titled Ballerina of the People. In 2011, she launched for her swan song a three-year series of final performances from ballet classics ending with her retirement in 2014. In the series, she danced leading roles in Swan Lake and Romeoand Juliet, 2011; Giselle, Don Quixote, and Carmen, all in 2012; and La Bayadere and The Nutcracker, 2013.

Macuja has received numerous awards. In 1987, she was the first Filipino to bring home a silver medal from the 1987 Asia-Pacific Ballet Competition in Tokyo. Other awards include Manila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan, 1988; Quezon City’s Outstanding Citizen Award, 1989; The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service, 1989; the Special Prize for Artistry by the House of Diaghilev (Moscow), 1992; The Outstanding Young Filipino, 1995; the Ten Outstanding Young Persons of the World (TOYP USA), 1997; and the Order of International Friendship from Russian President Vladimir Putin, 2001. In 2012, she received the Entertainer of the Year award from the Aliw Awards Foundation. Three other recognitions conferred on her the same year by Aliw were Best Classical Dancer, Best Concert Collaboration (for The Legends and the Classics with Cecile Licad and Lea Salonga), and Best Dance Company.

Macuja hosts Art2Art,a radio program on artists which was launched in 2007.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Lydia Madarang-Gaston

(Photo from facebook.com/lydiagaston.schoolofdance)

Lydia Madarang-Gaston

(Photo from facebook.com/lydiagaston.schoolofdance)

Lydia Madarang-Gaston

Photo from facebook.com/lydiagaston.schoolofdance)

text:
MADARANG-GASTON, LYDIA b. Manila 8 Aug 1936. d. Manila 13 Nov 2011. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. The daughter of Jose Madarang and Consuelo Llaguno, she is the wife of Victor Azcona Gaston and mother of dancers Lydlyd and Nicole Gaston. She started ballet training at 9 with Remedios de Oteyza until the Papal Nuncio and Catholic schools banned the study of ballet in the 1950s. After obtaining her BSE from Maryknoll (now Miriam) College, she went to the United States for graduate studies and further dance training. As scholar at the school of Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, she trained with Alexandra Danilova, Edward Caton, Frederic Franklin, and Leon Danielian; at Ballet Arts Studio with Vladimir Dodoukovsky; and in modern dance with Martha Graham and Drid Williams. Later, in Manila, she continued modern dance training with Alice Reyes. She danced with the De Oteyza Ballet and in productions of Paul Szilard. In Bacolod she set up the the Lydia M. Gaston Ballet, later renamed as the Lydia Gaston School of Dance. In 1968, Madarang-Gaston joined Dance Theater Philippines (DTP) but only periodically since her school kept her busy. In the 1980s, she taught at the Baltimore Ballet School, Mount Vernon Dance School, and Peabody Preparatory School of the Johns Hopkins University.

She choreographed such dances as Buntot Pagi (Stingray), Tree of Life, Halad (Offering), and Anak-Bulan (Moon Child) for Ballet Philippines (BP), 1978, and Etude, for the CCP National Dance Festival in lloilo, 1989. In Bacolod, she also choreographed for musical comedies in collaboration with Jess Aiko.

In 2011, she was one of the five outstanding Negrense recognized by the Negros Occidental Provincial Government.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Corazon Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Mercedes Mañago

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MAÑAGO, MERCEDES ( Merceditas Manza Mañago-Alexander ) b. Manila 24 Sep 1967. Dancer, choreographer, and teacher. Mercedes Mañago is the daughter of Nicolas Cortes Mañago and Carmen Nelly Manza. Her brother Enrico M. Mañago is a guitarist, and her sister Marichu Mañago Ramos is a writer. She is married to Aaron Alexander, a Jewish-American musician based in New York, with whom she has two children. She finished her BA in Dance Anthropology at the State University of New York (SUNY)/Empire State in 2005.

She started ballet at age 5 with the Effie Nañas School of Classical Ballet. At the age of 9, she danced with Ballet Philippines (BP), essaying the role of Clara in The Nutcracker Ballet. At age 12, she was invited by BP to be an apprentice and later promoted to principal roles in Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty, Carmen, Paquita, Giselle, Napoli, La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), Don Quixote, and many other neo-classical and contemporary works by local and guest artists. At the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), she studied ballet and modern dance under Alice Reyes, Basilio, Norman Walker, Alfred Rodriguez, Armin Wild, William Morgan, Ester Rimpos, Nonoy Froilan, Jose “Peping” Antonio, and Agnes Locsin. She also performed the lead role in Edna Vida’s Mutya ng Pasig (Muse of Pasig)in 1983, at the American Dance Festival in Durham, North Carolina. In 1989, she danced the title role in Corazon Generoso-Iñigo’s Gabriela opposite Nonoy Froilan as Diego.

In 1986, the University of the Philippines (UP) President’s Committee on Culture and the Arts gave her the recognition of “Outstanding Student Artist Award” for representing her country at the Third International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Mississippi. From there, she moved to New York and danced with Feld Ballets/NY, 1986-87; Dennis Wayne’s Dancers, 1988; Ballet Hispanico of NY, 1989-93; Elisa Monte Dance Company, 1993-94; Pepatian, 1995-96; and Doug Varone and Dancers, 1996-2001.

In New York, she presented solo choreographies at St Mark’s Church’s Danspace Projects, 2006; Dixon Place’s Crossing Boundaries, 1994 and 2006; and Freerange Arts and Gowanus/Brooklyn Arts Exchange, 1994. Her group choreographies include Tatlo, Apat (Three, Four) presented at Rutgers University in New Jersey in 2002, and another work at the Ailey Junior Division Recital at John Hay College in 2003 and 2004.

She performed for the Sara Rudner Project at the Baryshnikov Arts Center in 2007. In 2005 and 2007, she collaborated and danced with Malaysian choreographer Joyce Lim at St Mark’s Church’s Dance Space Projects, and at the Dixon Place / Crossing Boundaries in 2013.

She currently teaches dance at the Sarah Lawrence College and previously with the Alvin Ailey School in New York.

Among the awards and recognition she received are the Robert Porter Leach Fellowship at SUNY Empire State College, 2001, and an Education Grant with Career Transition for Dancers in 2001 and 2002.Written by Rina Angela P. Corpus

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ernest Mandap

(Photo from  facebook.com/ernest.mandap)

Ernest Mandap

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MANDAP, ERNEST ( Ernesto Sarino Mandap ) b. Manila 23 Jun 1973. Dancer and choreographer. Ernest is the only son of Raynaldo Mandap and Cecilla Sarino. He started his dance training at the Manila Metropolitan Theater under Bing Locsin and Teta Sugay of the Jazz Tap Center at age 9. At 14, he started taking classes in classical ballet with Noordin Jumalon and William Morgan. With the Cultural Center of the Philippine’s Dance School (CCP-DS), he also took modern dance classes with Agnes Locsin and Norman Walker.

Mandap belonged to the first batch of Ballet Philippines (BP) II. As part of the junior company, Mandap performed in landmark works such as Locsin’s Moriones, Jojo Lucila’s I, Judas; and Denisa Reyes’s SaUgoy ng Duyan (As the Cradle Rocks) and Muybridge Frames from 1988 to 1991.

Mandap went to Paris, France, to join the Jeune Ballet de France in 1991. There he was able to work with choreographers Régine Chopinot, Bertrand d’At, Redha, Ivonice Satie, and Claude Brumachon whom Mandap followed to the Centre Chorégraphique National de Nantes (CCNN) in 1992.

Mandap stayed with CCNN under Claude Brumachon and Benjamin Lamarche for 21 years. He was featured in the choreographies Nina, Emigrants (Immigrants), Les Avanlanches (Avalanches), Una Vita (One Life), Aventure Extraordinaire (Extraordinary Adventure), Humain Dite-Vous (The Human Called You), and Hotel Central.Mandap rose up the ranks from company member to eventually become rehearsal master, restager, and assistant director. His position in the prestigious company brought pride to the Philippines.

Brumachon and Lamarche allowed him to collaborate with other artists. In 1999, he cofounded the Company Esther Aumatell and was its Assistant Director until 2013. The gentle and thorough style of Aumatell was a welcome change and good compliment to Mandap’s syncopatic, angular Brumachon technique. He took part in all the productions of Aumatell, and gave workshops and master classes for children, amateur dancers, and professionals. He also choreographed and performed in Germany from 2010 to 2011 with artists such as Anna-Maria Besnier Bayon, Bianca Sere Pulungan, and Fang-Yu Shen.

In 2012, Mandap appeared in the highly acclaimed Belgian production of Peter Pan, The Never Ending Story as one of the lost boys. The musical spectacle introduced new technologies for visual projections and sound manipulation. He collaborated with Philippe Jamet for the project Une Heure au Palais (One Hour in the Palace), which premiered in France, 2014, and participated in Bodies in Urban Spaces with Willi Dorner, which was performed at Le Mouvement, the 12th Swiss Sculpture Exhibition in Biel/Bienne, Switzerland, also in 2014.

When Mandap visits the Philippines, he connects with dance companies and dance schools. His choreographies have been included in the programs of Ballet Philippines (BP), Ballet Manila (BM), Airdance, and various dance schools in Metro Manila, most notably Reve (Dream)for BM, 2010; Breathing Space for Airdance,2012; and Zebra for BP, 2013.

He was given a Parangal ng Bayan award by Senator Vicente Sotto in 1994. He also won the Florence Gould Foundation award, a special jury prize, for a solo that premiered at the Paris International Dance Competition held at the Theatre Champs-Elysées in 1998.Written by Clarissa Cecilia Mijares-Ramos

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Tiffany Mangulabnan in performance with konverjdans at Mark Morris Dance Center, Brooklyn, New York, May 2017

(Photo by Sergio Carrasco, courtesy of the artist)

Tiffany Mangulabnan in rehearsal for Emery LeCrone DANCE at The Joyce Theater, New York, New York, July 2017

(Photo by Ani Collier, courtesy of the artist)

Tiffany Mangulabnan in BalletNext, New York, New York, 2014

(Photo by Nisian Hughes, courtesy of the artist)

text:
MANGULABNAN, TIFFANY ( Mary Chris Tiffany Evidente Mangulabnan ) b. Manila 19 Dec 1989. Dancer. She is the daughter of Cris Mangulabnan and Lizabeth Evidente. She first studied classical ballet in 1997 at the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) Conservatoire. She also trained with Raul Sauz and Sofia Zobel-Elizalde at Steps Dance Studio. She also secured scholarships to Ballet Philippines’ (BP) Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School, and Alonzo King’s LINES Ballet School in San Francisco, in 2006 and 2007.

In 2001, PBT invited her to be an apprentice. In 2005, she became a faculty member of the conservatoire and a member of the PBT. Before she was 15, she danced, among others, Don Quixote and Swan Lake, 2001; La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 2002 and 2004; George Balanchine’s Serenade, 2002 and 2003; The Hunchback of Notre Dame, 2003; Madame Butterfly, 2003; Carmina Burana, 2003 and 2004; and Cinderella, 2005, among others.

Mangulabnan also worked with San Francisco-based Filipino choreographer Enrico Labayen who further exposed her to contemporary and modern ballet. With Labayen and dance mentor Katherine Trofeo, she cultivated a dance identity of her own, which is seen in Labayen’s Vivaldi Sketches, 2004, and Dalagang Bukid (Maiden of the Field), 2004.

In 2010, Mangulabnan placed second in the Senior Ballet Category of the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA). Returning to PBT, she became a principal dancer, and danced Odette/Odile in Swan Lake, 2010; the lead in Paquita, 2010; solo parts in Jean Paul Comelin’s Raymonda,and the neoclassical works of PBT artistic director Ronilo Jaynario.

In 2011, Maniya Barredo invited Mangulabnan to be a guest artist at the Metropolitan Ballet Theatre in Atlanta, Georgia. From there she went to New York and was accepted in Ballet Next in 2012. As soloist, she has been featured in ballets by Mauro Bigonzetti, Brian Reeder, Katarzyna Kozielska, Tobin Eason, and Ballet Next’s artistic director Michele Wiles. In 2012, she was highlighted in Alison Cook Beatty’s Tintinnabuli.Written by Clarissa Cecilia Mijares-Ramos

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
MANILA METROPOLIS BALLET ( MMB ) Founded in 1978 by Eddie Elejar and Tony Fabella, its first public performance was at the First ChoreographicConcert ofthe Ballet Federation of the Philippines on 7 Nov 1978. This started the company’s series of original dances. When the project “Save the Met” (MetropolitanTheater) was launched, MMB was the first dance company to perform there. It showcased Fabella’s MiBandera (My Flag) and other works like SaUgoyngDuyan (As the Cradle Rocks) and Elejar’s Hayop ang Galing (Fantabulous). In 1983, it staged Giselle at the Met with AnnaVilladolid, LutherPerez, and Becky Rodriguez as principal dancers.

The MMB mounted most of its productions of original choreography at Puerta Real, Intramuros, Manila and the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Rizal Theater was the seat of their performances in 1986, featuring artists like Nina Anonas and Villadolid. Among its important tours were those in Metro Manila in 1980, Guam, and Saipan. The company was also active in the Festival Four series at the CCP from 1984 to 1988 and in the Balletfest in 1990.

MMB is noted for having contributed artists such as Villadolid, Anonas, Perez, Rodriguez, Cecile Quirino, Noreen Ostrea, DouglasNierras, and Sol Fernandez. In 1988 the company merged with other dance groups to form the Philippine Ballet Theatre.Written by M. G. Castro

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Carlyn Manning-Drumm, left, with Bobbi Cassell at the Manila Polo Club, 1955

(Photo courtesy of Isidra Reyes)

text:
MANNING-DRUMM, CARLYN ( Carlyn Leever Truax Manning-Drumm )b. Chicago, Illinois, USA 26 Sep 1925. d. 20 Jul 2016. Dancer, choreographer. Daughter of well-to-do Americans Carl Truax and Fern Leever, an opera singer, Manning-Drumm was educated at Bryn Mawr Grammar School, Hyde Park High School, and the University of Chicago, where she got her bachelor of arts degree in English and philosophy. She started ballet at 9, and studied all forms of dance with Muriel Abbott. Joining the Abbott Dancers at 16, she toured South America with the group. After some time as a commercial model, she landed in the movies, dancing leading roles at Paramount Pictures with Jack Benny and Mary Martin, 1945, and at MGM with Danny Kaye, 1946.

In 1948 she came to the Philippines to join her husband John Manning. In 1951 she danced the lead role in Die Fledermaus under TrudlDubsky-Zipper. She also learned flamenco both in Manila and Madrid, and later performed with the Philippines’ foremost Spanish dancer Ruben Nieto in 1957.

She was active with the ManilaSymphonySociety from 1951 and launched Concert at the Park in Luneta with Oscar C. Yatco as conductor in 1967.

She choreographed for MetropolitanTheater, most notably in Best ofBroadway,and performed in its production of My Fair Lady as well as in many charity productions under Conchita Sunico. In 1961 she opened the Carlyn Manning School of Dance, which operated until 1974. In 1967 she studied briefly under Robert Joffrey in New York and became a member of Dance Masters of America.

Manning-Drum was president of the Manila Symphony Society. She was president twice of the St Luke’s Hospital Women’s Board and of the American Association of College Women, and chair of the American Girl Scouts in the Philippines. She was also associated with the Manila TheatreGuild and ran a travel agency in Makati.Written by Malou L. Maniquis, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Maiqui Mañosa with Jun Samblaceno in Philippine Ballet Theatre’s Camille

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Maiqui Mañosa

(Photo from facebook.com/maiqui.manosa)

text:
MAÑOSA, MAIQUI ( Ma. Cristina Gaston Mañosa-Steele ) b. Manila 25 May 1960. Dancer. Her parents are architect Manuel T. Mañosa Jr and dancer Maria Luisa (Inday) Gaston-Mañosa. Her sisters Mia Monica and Mimel are also dancers, as well as her cousins Lydlyd and Nicole Gaston. She is married to Milton Steele. She studied for a bachelor of arts at Assumption Convent and then went to the Atlanta School of Arts in Georgia, USA. Her teachers in the Philippines included her mother, Remedios de Oteyza, Sulamith Messerer, Jean Deroc, and William Morgan. In Atlanta she trained with Mannie Rowe, John Derve, and Robert Barnett.

While in the Philippines in the 1970s, she danced for the Hariraya Ballet Company, and for the productions of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines: Giselle, Coppelia, Cinderella, and La Fille Mal Gardee. Joining the Atlanta Ballet in 1980, she became principal dancer. There, she danced the Sugarplum Fairy in The Nutcracker, the Lilac Fairy in The Sleeping Beauty, Effie in La Sylphide, Juliet in Thomas Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, Titania in Dennis Nahat’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream and Swanhilda in his Coppelia; and Lizette in La Fille Mal Gardee. She has danced in Balanchine works such as the Dark Angel in Serenade, the Siren in Prodigal Son, Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux, Four Temperaments, Allegro Brillante, Concerto Barocco, Themes and Variations, and Square Dances. She also danced leading roles in Eugene Loring’s Billy the Kid as the Sweetheart, Fernand Nault’s Carmina Burana, Lynne Taylor Corbett’s Escape, and Pazik’s By George.

At 35, she retired from Atlanta ballet and joined Singapore Dance Theater as its ballet mistress. Back in the US, she was the principal teacher with Rock School of Pennsylvania Ballet for four years. She stages ballets for Val Caniparoli and Graham Lustig in North America and other parts of the world. She has staged works with American Repertory Ballet, Boston Ballet, Cincinnati Ballet, Nevada Ballet Theater, Orlando Ballet, Tulsa Ballet, Sacramento Ballet, and Pennslyvania Ballet. For Atlanta Ballet, she restaged John McFall’s Nutcracker and Fernand Nault’s Carmina Burana. She does guest teaching in summer workshops around the United States such as the Inland Pacific Ballet in Montclair, California. Often a guest artist for Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), she did the title role in Eric Cruz’s Camille and Leonora in La Gitana which she also performed in Beijing, China, in 1990. In 1991, she created the title role in Pazik’s Madame Butterfly for PBT.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Manunubli ng Sinala performing at the Sublian Festival, 2016

Manunubli ng Sinala

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Manunubli ng Sinala during a  street dance and performance, 2016

text:
MANUNUBLI NG SINALA100">Subli performers from Sinala, Bauan, Batangas. Composed of eight male and female dancers, the Manunubli are acknowledged master artists and inheritors of the subli, a Maytime tradition that mixes dance, poetry, theater, prayer-devotion, celebration, and music. The Manunubli is headed by the femalematremayoand their male partners. They usually perform on 2 May on the occasion of thesalubong,or welcoming, of the Mahal na Poong Santa Cruz, patron of many towns in Batangas. They also perform during weddings, baptisms,floresdeMayo, thanksgiving, and other religious festivals. Performers come from Pook Agoncillo as well as from the different barrios of Bauan—San Vicente, Manalupang, Sinturisan, San Diego, Nangkaan, Luklok, and San Agustin. Training is rigid as the performers are required to achieve precision, discipline, and the refinement of form that a subli performance entails.

In 1988 and 1989, the Batangas City government sponsored a subli competition where both the young and the old of Bauan participated. As most of the Manunubli are already well past adulthood, the competition signalled the growing interest of the younger generation of Bauan to keep the subli tradition alive. The older members of Manunubli continue to oversee the dancing of the subli among the young in Batangas. At the opening of the annual subli competition in Batangas, they dance to show early performances of the subli. They continue to influence the young teachers and dancers.

The ManunublingSinala received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 1991.Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Melvin Martinez

(Photo from facebook.com/martinez2k16)

text:
MARTINEZ, MELVIN ( Melvin Javier Martinez ) b. Manila 11 Aug 1973. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. Melvin Martinez is the son of Arturo Martinez and Leonila Javier. He is married to Michelle Martinez, with whom he has three children. He has a degree in BS Computer Engineering from the Asian College of Science and Technology in Antipolo, 2004.

He started dancing at the age of 10 with Nonoy Froilan; a year later, Froilan encouraged Martinez to enroll in the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Summer Dance Workshop. He trained that summer with Noordin Jumalon, Emillie Rigonan, Jinn Ibarriola, and Cecile Sicangco. He was given a scholarship by Ballet Philippines (BP), training with William Morgan, and promoted to BP company member in 1988. In 1990, he portrayed the lead in I, Judas. He was also cast in the pas de trois of Morgan’s Swan Lake; a Peasant Dance solo in Giselle, 1991. In 1992, Agnes Locsin created the role of the Frayle in Encantada (Enchantress)on Martinez. Between 1990 to 1993 he had also performed Gener Caringal’s Ang Sultan (The Sultan), Denisa Reyes’s Muybridge Frames, and Edna Vida’s Pagsamba (Worship) and Vision of Fire.

He was part of the pioneering and touring batch for both BP II under Agnes Locsin, and UP Dance Company (UPDC) under Basilio, as dance major at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman from 1988 to 1991. With UPDC, he created the lead in Locsin’s Moslem, which also entered BP’s repertoire in 1990; performed important roles in Basilio’s Paean to Pavlova, 1992; George Balanchine’s Valse Fantasie, 1992; and Basilio’s Mga Awit ni Basil I (Songs of Basil I),1993.

He joined Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 1994, where he was cast as the faun in the Dance of the Reed Flutes in Gelsey Kirkland and Mikhail Chernov’s The Nutcracker, 1994; the Jester in Jean Paul Comelin’s Cinderella, 1995; Jean de Brienne in Comelin’s Raymonda, 1996; and peasant pas de deuxin Giselle, 1997. He was also well-remembered for his portrayal of the hero in Gener Caringal’s Andres KKK in 1996.

At Comelin’s invitation, he joined the Playhouse Dance Company (PDC) in South Africa in 1998, and was the first Asian principal dancer of the company. During a one month hiatus of PDC, he guested with Cape Town Ballet to perform several pas de deux. After the eight-month season in South Africa, he returned to PBT, where he danced and served as company manager.

In 2001, he choreographed Free on Rebecca Rodriguez and Joel Matias, which Artist Leonor Orosa-Goquingco spotted as one of the best new works of the company. In 2005, he danced the antagonist role in Enrico Labayen’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden)with PBT. He retired soon after to set up a studio in Aklan for three years and then in Cambodia for a year with Robert Wildermann. There he taught both ballet and modern dance. In 2011, he started teaching contemporary dance at Maritoni Tordesillas’s Dancespace. He also taught at Araceli Root’s Pink Toes and Bella Benco’s Alessi Ballet.

His choreographies for the Tordesillas’s Dancespace won 2nd place in the Philippine Dance Cup in 2011 and the ABAP Competition in 2012.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
MEDINA, MARICAR ( Maricar Mendoza Medina-Franco ) aka Cherry Medina. b. Cabanatuan City 13 Oct 1973. Dancer, restager. Daughter of Delfin Peñaflor Medina and Carded Mendoza, she is the wife of Victor John Franco. She has a BS in Tourism from the University of Santo Tomas, 1990.

Medina began her dance training at St. Anne’s Ballet School in Cabanatuan City where Liza Ocampo-Mata, Jane Dungca, Ida Beltran, Jojo Lucila, and Mario Esperanza taught, gave master classes and choreographed between 1980 to 1990. She joined Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 1992, training under Lisa Macuja, Osias Barroso, Beltran, Jean Paul Comelin, and Anatoly Panassiukov. She also trained with guest ballet masters and restagers that PBT engaged through the years, including Robert Barnett, Nicolas Pacaña, Maiqui Mañosa, Thomas Mayr, Anna Valladolid, and Nonoy Froilan. She counts performing George Balanchine’s Concerto Barocco, as restaged by Barnett, 1992, as a turning point in her career.

Noteworthy roles that Medina had with PBT include Adela in Comelin’s Daughters of Mourning (based on The House of Bernarda Alba ), 1995; the Autumn Fairy in Comelin’s Cinderella, 1995; Marie/Sugar Plum Fairy in Michael Chernov and Gelsey Kirkland’s The Nutcracker, 1995; Ballerina in Paquita, 1997; the title role of Giselle, 1997; Russian girl in Balanchine’s Serenade, 1998; the title role in Comelin’s Raymonda, 1998; Nikiya in The Kingdom of the Shades from La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 1999; Cio Cio San in Thomas Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, 1999; Juliet in Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, 2000; and Kitri in Don Quixote, 2001. Medina performed the Le Corsaire (The Pirate) pas de deux with American Ballet Theatre’s principal dancer, Marcelo Gomes, in 2001.

Her quick learning and photographic memory made her valuable to PBT as rehearsal mistress. Medina took over the young members of the company and rehearsed them into a corps de ballet. While with PBT, she restaged ballets for off-season outreach performances, such as David Campos’s Carmina Burana, Tony Fabella’s Kundiman: Noon at Ngayon (Love Song: Then and Now), Edna Vida’s Thatness, Thereness, and Gener Caringal’s Vinta, Prism,and Andres KKK.

She left the company in 2001 and became a freelance contemporary dance artist for the next two years, performing with Jojo Lucila’s Chameleon Dance Theatre, Myra Beltran Dance Forum, and the initial configuration of E-Dance Theatre with Gerald Mercado and Katrina Santos-Mercado. She joined Chameleon in a performance tour to Berlin, Germany, in 2002. From 2002 to 2004, she performed with the Peninsula Ballet Theatre in San Francisco, California.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Cesar Mendoza

(Photo from facebook.com/profile.php?id=100009303841532)

Cesar Mendoza

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MENDOZA, CESAR ( Cesar Gabriel Santiago Mendoza )b.Malabon, Rizal 16 Feb 1935. Dancer, teacher, choreographer, and artistic director. He is the son of Benigno Mendoza and Evangelina Gabriel Santiago. He started ballet with Ricardo Cassell with whom his sister took ballet lessons. After six months, he performed with Cassell’s Studio Dance Group and its annual seasons, an early attempt to professionalize ballet in the Philippines. In 1962 he went to New York for advanced training in ballet, modern dance, and jazz. Returning in 1963, he joined Remedios “Totoy” de Oteyza’s Manila Ballet Company as a soloist. Simultaneously, he taught dance at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), Far Eastern University (FEU) and its Experimental Dance Troupe under Rosalia Merino-Santos, School of the Arts at University of the East (UE), and Dance Arts Studio of Julie Borromeo. His close teaching associates were Joji Felix Velarde and Eddie Elejar.

He also performed for the annual productions of Manila Symphony Society, dancing in the choreography of Trudl Dubsky Zipper and partnering her in Pictures in an Exhibition to music by Mussorgsky. He also danced for Leonor Orosa-Goquingco in her Noli Dance Suite and The Clowns.Among his own notable works are the full-evening dance-drama The Book of Job in 1966 for Manila Central University, and Ecole de Ballet, Divertissement,and Difficult Years (a first in the Philippines on the drug problem), all in 1968 for Hariraya Ballet Company. Difficult Years was again performed in 1969 for the company’s Philippine tour, together with a contingent of the Bolshoi Ballet led by its principal dancers Raissa Struchkova and Alexander Lapauri.

In 1969, he went to Europe for further training at Centre de Danse Classique in Cannes, Netherlands Dance Theater in The Hague, Dance Center in London, and Maurice Bejart’s Mudra School in Brussels. For two years he worked as a disc jockey in Germany and Switzerland. In 1973, he moved back to New York and taught full-time at the International Dance School, and the Farnworth and Hauer School of Dance. Moving to Illinois in 1977, he taught for the American Dance Center and Company. He also founded the short-lived Ballet Albuquerque. He continues to teach ballet for adults at a community center in a suburb of Chicago.Written by Franklin Bobadilla and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
First significant batch of Filipino dancers, including Rosalia Merino-Santos, third from left, taught by Luva Adameit during the American period

(Rosalia Merino-Santos Collection)

Rosalia Merino-Santos

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Rosalia Merino-Santos

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MERINO-SANTOS, ROSALIA ( Rosalia Ramos Merino-Santos ) b. Manila 7 Nov 1923. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Her parents were Gonzalo Merino and Enriquita Ramos and her husband is Ruben Santos. She earned her bachelor of science in education, major in physical education from the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) in 1949. She was a Fullbright scholar in 1950 at the University of Wisconsin where she earned her master’s degree in physical education major in dance in 1952.

Her studies and career encompass the range of Philippine dance. She studied ballet with Luva Adameit, Ricardo Cassell, and Joseph Stemberski; modern dance with Trudl Dubsky-Zipper; Spanish dance with Conchita Sotelo; folk dance with Francisca Reyes-Aquino, of whose Filipiniana Song and Dance Troupe she was a member. Later, she specialized in modern dance at the University of Wisconsin, USA, under Margaret H. Doubler, Louise Klopeer, and Louis Horst, pedagogical giants in dance. She was also exposed to many schools and styles of modern dance: the Limon, the Holm, the Graham, the Weidman schools, all in America, and the Wigman-Kreutzberg school in Switzerland.

She taught ballet, modern dance, and folk dance at PWU, St. Paul College, University of the East (UE), Far Eastern University (FEU), Centro Escolar University, National Teachers College of Physical Education, Young Men’s Christian Association in Madison, Wisconsin, and privately. In 1958, she founded the Far Eastern Experimental Modern Dance Group in FEU which performed modern dance pieces utilizing athletic activities such as basketball.

Among her notable works are What is Dance?, 1958, a lecture-demonstration on modern dance; Fan-fare, 1958, on pure movement dynamics; Feminine Gender, 1958; Portrait of the Filipino as Seen through Philippine Folk Songs, Dance, and Music, 1959, a presentation of the FEU Folk Dance Group in Europe; Opus 17 to Brahms, 1959; Ugaling Filipino (Filipino Customs), 1963, depicting the historical evolution of Filipino customs and traditions in dance; “Hunt” and “Storm” in Sarimanok, 1968, dance drama; one of the four dances in Dularawan: Gintong Salakot (Image-Play: The Golden Salacot), 1969; and Halina’t Maglaro (Come and Play), 1971, for Ballet Philippines. She is most noted for Of Cocksand Kings, 1958, based on a story by Alejandro Roces, and cited by critic Morli Dharam as a “contribution from us to the world’s treasury of dance dramas.” She also incorporated jazz in cheer dancing and choreographed aquaballets.

In 1978, during the Third National Ballet Festival of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines, she was awarded by Malacañan for her contributions as teacher and choreographer of modern dance, and as director of the FEU Modern Experimental Dance Troupe. She received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award from the City of Manila in 1981. In 1994, she received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Dance) “for enriching dance through her pioneering efforts in experimental and modern dance techniques incorporating Filipino customs and traditions, and for her dedication in promoting appreciation of dance in the country.Written by R.F. Santos and Basilio, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
METROPOLITAN DANCE THEATER COMPANY ( MDTC )Established in 1982, it was the resident dance company of the Manila MetropolitanTheater (MMT). Under the direction of VedaBañez-Alonso, the company had on its first staff choreographers and dance masters like Rene Hofileña, DouglasNierras, Hans Christian Wagner, and Rene Hinojales, for jazz; IndayGaston-Mañosa, Jun Dalit, Victor Madrona, and Nida Onglengco, for ballet; GenerCaringal for moderndance; and Eno Mescallado and Danny Vinculado, for folkdance.

Informally, the incipient company was involved in Conchita Sunico’s productions from 1979 to 1982, such as AngKiri (The Flirt), MaalaalaMoKaya (Will You Remember), Alamat ngBundok Bangkay (Legend of Mount Bangkay), Hindi Kita Malimot (ICannot Forget You), Kismet, Mephistofele, Pearl Fishers, TheMikado, The Sound ofMusic,and MyFair Lady.

MDTC presented its first concert on 5 Dec 1982. This was followed by Tintinnabulation in 1983. Since then, the group presented TheGreat WhiteWay I and The Mikado,1983; Cats,1984; Aristocrats, 1985; and The Great White Way II and Flower Drum Song, both in 1987.

MDTC was also involved in Filipino musicals and productions like Sarung Banggi (One Night), DahilsaIyo (Because of You), Gomburza, Handog (Offering), Ewagan, Ginintuang Alaala (Golden Memory), EDSA, Kayumangging Malaya (Brown and Free), and Pagdiriwang: BayanKo (A Celebration: My Country). The company’s versatility lent itself to some commercial dancing, supporting such singing stars as GaryValenciano and Zsa Zsa Padilla, and foreign performers. It appeared in popular concerts, hotel shows, video commercials, and campus tours.

MDTC joined the annual CCP Balletfest from 1987 to 1990, the Yugyugan Festival in 1989, and the First Manila Contemporary Dance Festival in 1991. When the MMT closed due to financial difficulties, MDTC was dissolved.Written by M. G. Castro, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Brando Mirando as Albrecht in Giselle, 1986, with Cecile Sicangco 

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Brando Miranda

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

text:
MIRANDA, BRANDO ( Brando Mañate Miranda ) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 12 May 1956. Dancer, choreographer. Born to Domingo Miranda, an actor, and Perpetua Mañate, he graduated from the Manuel L. Quezon High School, and studied for a degree in bachelor of science in business administration at the University of the East (UE). In college, he trained and danced with the UEDanceCompany under the direction of GenerCaringal. He won a scholarship to the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP) Summer Dance Workshop and from thereon trained with AliceReyes, DenisaReyes, TonyFabella, Jan Stripling, Kenneth Gillespie, Armin Wild, Rita Lusi, Luminita Dumitrescu, Alfred Rodrigues, Mikhail Kukharev, Rosemary Helliwell, and WilliamMorgan.

He became a member of BalletPhilippines (BP) in 1979 and rose to principal rank in 1983. He was given a six-month grant to observe major ballet and modern dance companies in the United States in 1984. As BP principal dancer, he played lead roles in major productions like Prince Charming in Cinderella, 1981; the Prince in TheNutcracker,1982; Romeo and Benvolio in RomeoandJuliet,1984; the First Man in TalesoftheManuvu,1985; Basilio in Don Quixote, 1986; Albrecht, Hilarion, and the peasant pas de deux in Giselle,1986; and the title role in the full-length Nijinksy,as well as in the ballets Rama,Hari (Rama, King), AngSultan (The Sultan), and Season of Flight.

Choreographing for the company, Miranda was cited for The Awakening,1981 and 1984; Lawang Paoay (Lake Paoay), 1983; Vivaldi Concerto,1983; Ang Misa (The Mass), 1985; Tomorrow’s Monday and SummerHeat, 1986; and 1970-1980,1987. Miranda left in 1988 to guest with the Royal New Zealand Ballet where he later became a full member and principal dancer. Courtesy of the company, he danced with BP in Giselle and premiered HazelSabas’s ballet Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), both in 1991. His Duet was featured in BP’s mixed-billed production The Art of Dance,2014.

In 2003, Miranda earned his Pilates certification from the Romana’s Pilates at The Pilates Method Studio, Australia’s certifying center for Romana’s Pilates. He trained under Master Instructor Trainer Juanita Lopez and later under Instructor Trainer Cynthia Lochard. He is a certified Level 5+ Instructor and has been teaching Pilates at the Integrated Body Arts (IBA) since 2003. He also handles private Pilates sessions at the Steps Dance Center founded and managed by dancer Sofia Zobel-Elizalde.Written by M. G. Castro, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Christopher Mohnani with Elline Damian in Ballet Manila’s Giselle

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MOHNANI, CHRISTOPHER ( Christopher Bunao Mohnani ) b. 24 Oct 1974. Dancer, teacher, arts manager. Christopher Mohnani is the son of Anthony Mohnani and Manuela Bunao. He started dancing at the age of eight as a member of the group called the WEA Twins. An alumnus of the University of Santo Tomas (UST), he became a member of the UST Salinggawi Dance Troupe and studied Philippine folk dance, jazz, and modern dance with Rene Hofileña. He was later trained in classical ballet when he became part of the Philippine Ballet Theatre ’s (PBT) scholarship program for boys in 1992 under Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, Osias Barroso, and Gener Caringal. As a scholar of PBT, one of his significant roles was Tybalt in Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet,1994.

In 1995 Mohnani became one of the twelve founding members of Ballet Manila (BM), where he became a soloist for five years. He was given romantic and dramatic roles such as Siegfried in Swan Lake,1995, 1996, 1997, and 1998; Albrecht in Giselle, 1995, 1997, and 1999; Don Jose in Eric V. Cruz’s Carmen,1996, 1997, and 2000; Conrad in the Asian premiere of Le Corsaire (The Pirate), 1998. In 2000, he took on the lead role as Dracula in the Asian Premier of Paul Vasterling’s Dracula. Later, Vasterling invited him to become a principal dancer at Nashville Ballet in Tennessee, USA, where he danced for ten seasons, from 2001 to 2009. With Nashville Ballet’s premiers, he danced a wide range of roles, some of which were Faun in Afternoon of a Faun,2002; Young Warrior in The Rites of Spring,2003; Romeo in Romeo and Juliet, 2004; and Prince Desire in The Sleeping Beauty, 2005.

In 2004 Mohani created the Asian American Performing Arts Society (AAPAS), a non-profit organization that promoted the beauty and diversity of Asian American Performing arts and artists. In 2007, he was one of the recipients of the Individual Artist Fellowship Award for Dance given by the State of Tennessee and the Tennessee Arts Commission. In 2009, he was awarded by Career Transition for Dancers with the Sono Osato Fellowship Award, the highest award given to a professional dancer in the USA.

Upon his retirement in 2009, he turned AAPAS into Dance Theatre of Tennessee (DTT). As artistic director and CEO, he led DTT in just three years to become one of the Top 10 Performing Arts Organization in Middle Tennessee. He steered DTT to its first national and international appearance, at the opening of the 2013 Spring Dance Festival held in St Louis, Missouri, and an international gala held in the Philippines. The Nashville Chamber of Commerce (NCC) named him one of the “Five Emerging Leaders” in Arts and Entertainment for 2012 and 2013. In 2013, he was recognized one of the “Forty Under Forty” by the Nashville Business Journal and received the Nashville Emerging Leaders Award for Arts, Entertainment and Music Business from the NCC. Also in 2013, he was presented by Mayor Karl Dean with a Certificate of Achievement recognizing his efforts in promoting dance and arts in the city of Nashville.

After leading DTT for five years, Mohnani returned to the Philippines to become the managing director of BM in 2014, and as such introduced some reforms in its operation. After two or so years, he returned to the United States.Written by Sarah Maria Samaniego

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Manuel Molina

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Manuel Molina with Maiqui Mañosa for Philippine Ballet Theatre

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Manuel Molina

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MOLINA, MANUEL b. Sampaloc, Manila 6 Aug 1951. Dancer, choreographer. He started dance training at 16 with CorazonGeneroso-Iñigo at the UniversityoftheEastDanceTroupe, and in ballet with EddieElejar and TonyLlacer with DanceTheaterPhilippines. Soon after, in 1970, he joined the AliceReyes and Modern Dance Company (now BalletPhilippines), where he became a principal dancer. He assumed the lead roles in Elejar’s JulietandHerRomeo;FelicitasLayag-Radaic’s MayDayEve;Basilio’s The Rebels; AliceReyes’s Amada, ItimAsu (Onyx Wolf), and her rock opera ballets— Tommy and Rama,Hari (Rama, King); RemediosdeOteyza’s Spectrum;and Norman Walker’s Season ofFlight.In 1973, through Walker, he received a scholarship to the Harkness School of Ballet in New York, while also receiving assistance from the John D. Rockefeller III fund.

Joining the Harkness Ballet in 1974, he toured Europe and the United States, and guested with Ballet Concerto, where he choreographed South American Suite,and Miami Ballet, both in Florida. Between 1975 and 1982, he danced with Vicente Nebrada’s Ballet Internacional de Caracas, later turned into Zhandra Rodriguez and Dale Talley’s Ballet Nuevo Mundo de Caracas. With these troupes, he toured North and South America, Canada, Europe, and Asia, including the Philippines, 1982. He was a principal dancer with both companies, dancing in the works of Nebrada, John Butler, Choo San Goh, Margo Sappington, and Hans Van Manen. An injury forced him to rest. He guested with Eglevsky Ballet in 1984 in TheNutcracker. Between 1985 and 1987, he danced with Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal which brought him all over Canada, South America and, again, Asia. Since he returned to Manila in 1988, he performed with Ballet Philippines; Philippine Ballet Theatre, which created Vinta for him in 1989; Gener Caringal Dance Repertory Company, which created The Tribe for him in 1988; ManilaMetropolisBallet, which created Narciso for him in 1988; Hotlegs Ballet Manila and the Stars of Philippine Ballet Tour and the Yugyugan Festival, all in 1989. He also choreographed for Hotlegs, Ballet Manila, and Yeh Shian Folk Ballet Company.Written by Mary Jane L. Globio, Mena Ojeda, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Greta Monserrat

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MONSERRAT, GRETA b. Shanghai, China. Active 1950s and 1960s. She trained under Nicolai Sokolsky. At 12 she was dancing in productions of ballet classics, and at 15 did the lead roles in Cinderella and Snow Queen.When she moved to Manila, she studied with AnitaKane and RicardoCassell. She also trained with Alexandra Danilova and Michael Maule.

She danced in many major productions, including in the first full-evening production of Swan Lake in Manila in 1962. In the mid-1960s, she was prima ballerina of the Pamana Ballet, partnered by EddieElejar. She danced Myrtha in Giselle,the Sugar Plum Fairy in TheNutcracker,the Lilac Fairy in The Sleeping Beauty (Vision Scene), the grand pas de deux from DonQuixote,and Mei Li in the “Dream Ballet” from MaureenTiongco’s production of Flower Drum Song.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Paul Morales

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

text:
MORALES, PAUL ( Paul Alexander Yap Morales ) b. Quezon City 14 Oct 1969. Dancer, choreographer, librettist, theater director, filmmaker, actor, producer, and administrator. He is the son of Maria Virginia Yap and Horacio Morales. His interest in the arts began when he was a student at the Davao City High School where he was part of the school’s drama club and dance troupe. He majored in theater directing for his tertiary education at the University of the Philippines where he was mentored by director Tony Mabesa. Apart from directing and acting in college, he started training in classical ballet with Dance Theater Philippines’ Felicitas Layag-Radaic, Basilio Villaruz, and Sonia Domingo. He later on became a founding member of Agnes Locsin’s Ballet Philippines (BP) II in 1988. He earned his bachelor’s degree in theatre arts in 1992.

With the endorsement of then BP’s Artistic Director Denisa Reyes and the support of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the British Council, Morales was able to pursue a scholarship to Dance Theater Performance at the Laban Center for Movement and Dance with the Transitions Dance Company in London. He learned the choreographies by Ellen Bromberg, Claude Brumachon, Rui Horta, and Herve Jordet, and toured with the company to the United States, United Kingdom, and Asia, prior to returning to the Philippines in 1994.

Morales, along with Herbert Go, Tess Jamias, and Julien Mendoza, established Dulaang Talyer upon his return. Taking off from their student organization the UP Workshop, the group pursued a dynamic, experimental, and professional theater. Morales served as its artistic director from 1994 to 2002. In 2003, Morales became the artistic director of the independent contemporary dance company Airdance which was founded and first directed by Dwight Rodrigazo. It started as a commercial jazz company that focused on performances for corporate companies. He encouraged the company to have seasonal shows featuring the choreographies of its members with productions such as R-18: Bold Contemporary Dance and Indios Bravos (Brave Natives), both in 2004, and the series Body Politics: A Season of New Dance,2006. Airdance contributed much to the promotion of contemporary dance practice in the country. Airdance was awarded Best Modern/Contemporary Dance Company in 2007 and 2008 by the Aliw Awards. Morales became one of the founders of the Contemporary Dance Network Philippines and directed the fifth WiFi Body Contemporary Dance Festival in 2009.

In 2009, Morales was invited to become artistic director of BP. His works for the company include the full-length ballet Crisostomo Ibarra, 2010; the multimedia sensation Rock Supremo, 2013; and the updated Manhid,The Pinoy Superhero Musical (Numb, The Pinoy Superhero Musical),2015. He revived many BP classics which include Alice Reyes’s Rama, Hari (Rama, the King) and Cinderella and Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress) and La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), as well as embarked on new projects for young choreographers of the company.

Morales also directed the motion picture Concerto,2008, set during World War II. Based on his family’s story, the movie was commended for its cinematography. It won Best Adapted Screenplay from the 6th Golden Screen Awardsand the Bamboo Camera Award from filmmaker Kidlat Tahimik.Written by Clarissa Cecilia Mijares-Ramos

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
William Morgan in Coppelia

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

William Morgan

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

William Morgan

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
MORGAN, WILLIAM b. Edinburgh, Scotland 27 Jul 1936. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Morgan first trained with Marjorie Middleton at age 16 and performed with her ballet club. He continued at the Royal Ballet School, mainly with Harris Plucis and Harold Turner, and occasionally with Ninette de Valois and Barbara Fewster. He apprenticed by dancing for the operas and ballets at Covent Garden, London. After a five-year break, he went back to dancing in Malmo, Sweden, Wuppertal, Germany, and Capetown, South Africa where he became principal dancer, choreographer, and later, ballet master of the Capab Ballet.

Deciding to end his dancing and to broaden his career at age 40, he left Capetown and received invitations to restage and choreograph abroad, most importantly, in Hong Kong. With the Hong Kong Ballet Group, he choreographed Cinderella,1976; Amah Rock and TwoPigeons,and restaged La Sylphide (Act II), all in 1977. In 1978 he came to Manila and worked on restaging Coppelia, Pas de Six from Napoli,and his own Cinderella,and later created Czerniana,1979, all for the BalletFederationofthePhilippines which kept him as ballet master until 1980. He became choreographer and ballet master of BalletPhilippines (BP) where he restaged the classics: Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty, DonQuixote, Giselle, La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), Coppelia,extant parts from Paquita, Raymonda,a number of pas de deux and the complete Les Sylphides, Pas de Quatre,and Spectrede la Rose,all between 1983 and 1987. He also staged his own works: Classical Symphony,1983; Encounters,1984; Nuances, 1987; AngPilya (Naughty Girl), 1988, a Philippine adaptation of La Fille Mal Gardee;and Options ofLove.During his nine-year stay, he upgraded the standards of classical dancing in the Philippines. After he moved to Bangkok, Thailand where he teaches, he periodically returned to restage the classical works for BP.Written by Mary Jane L. Globio, Mena Ojeda, and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Melanie Motus

text:
MOTUS, MELANIE ( Melanie Reyes Motus ) b. San Pablo, Laguna 15 Nov 1968. Dancer and teacher. Melanie Motus is the daughter of Renato Trinidad Motus and piano and music teacher Cynthia Pavon Reyes. She has a son, Kevin Ulric, with dancer Raoul Banzon. She has a BA in Communication, major in Broadcasting, from the University of the Philippines, 1992.

Motus trained with Nida Onglengco School of Ballet in St Joseph’s College from 1978 to 1980, Pinky Puno in New Manila Ballet Center from 1980 to 1983, and Inday Gaston-Mañosa in her Classic Ballet Academy from 1983 to 1986. She danced for Hariraya Ballet Company, and was a pioneer member of Philippine Ballet Theatre, a conglomeration of independent dance groups formed in 1986. She trained with Sonia Domingo to complete the Royal Academy of Dance Elementary to Advanced syllabus from 1988 to 1989, and was a full scholar with the Australia Ballet School in 1990, under Onstage Artists, Inc.

As a dancer, Motus was known for her stately elegance and crisp technique. She is also a fulsome dancer, maintaining that aura even when cast in earthy, passionate roles. An example is her tempestuous portrayal of the title role in Eric V. Cruz’s Carmen, with both PBT in 1989 and 1991, and Ballet Manila in 2000 and 2003. She similarly shone as Kitri in PBT’s Don Quixote,1992, partnered by American Ballet Theatre’s Parrish Maynard. With PBT, she performed in Swan Lake, 1988; lead wili in Giselle, 1988; Swanilda in Coppelia, 1989 and 1992; Russian Girl in George Balanchine’s Serenade, 1989 and 1996; Josephine Bracken in Basilio’s La Lampara (The Lamp), 1991, and Woman in his Testament, 1992; and 2nd violin in Balanchine’s Concerto Barocco, 1992. She created the roles of Valentina in Gener Caringal’s Filipino Komiks (Filipino Comics), 1993; the title role in Jean Paul Comelin’s Raymonda, 1996; and Oryang in Gener Caringal’s Andres KKK, 1996.

With Ballet Manila, Motus performed as Odette in Swan Lake, 1998, in a joint production with the Krasnoyarsk Ballet in Cebu. She portrayed Myrtha in Giselle, 1999, and Giselle in 2002. She also danced in David Campos’s Petrushka, 1997, and Velvet Wings, 1998; Ric Culalic’s Ouch, 1999; as the Lotus Goddess in Jean Paul Comelin’s Firebird, 2000; Mina Murray in Paul Vasterling’s Dracula, 2000; and the lead in Agnes Locsin’s Sayao sa Pamlang, 2001. Motus was a semifinalist at the first Diaghilev Ballet Competition in Moscow, Russia.

Motus joined Powerdance from 2003 and 2008, and was featured in Douglas Nierras’s Waltz and Ne Me Quitte Pas (Do Not Leave Me). In 2010, she performed the title role in Myra Beltran’s Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), her portrayal decidedly larger-than-life.

She judged for the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA) ballet competition until 2012. In 1998, she opened IDMM Ballet School at the Learning Tree in Sikatuna Village with Ianne Damian.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Effie Nañas

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Effie Nañas

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
NAÑAS, EFFIE ( Epifania Nañas )b. Shanghai, China 15 Feb 1949. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Her parents were Filipino musician Jose Nañas and Chinese singer Nora. As a child, she trained at the Classical Ballet Academy of Nicole Triem of Saigon, Vietnam, and later at the International Dance Theatre of Richard Maitland in New Delhi, India. In Indian classical dance, she trained with Uma Shama in India and Raffi Anwar in Pakistan. In the Philippines, she trained with AnitaKane, Heather Llodra, RemediosdeOteyza, Raisa Struchkova, Sulamith Messerer, AliceReyes, EddieElejar, TonyLlacer, Edgar Valdez; and visiting choreographer-teachers Miro Zolan, Norman Walker, Rochelle Zide Booth, Garth Welch, Jan Stripling, Alfred Rodrigues, and Armin Wild.

Upon settling in the Philippines, she joined Kane’s Pamana Ballet, de Oteyza’s Hariraya Ballet, and finally, Ballet Philippines (BP). With Maitland in India, she danced the lead roles in TheSleeping Beauty, The Nutcracker, Les Sylphides,among others. With Hariraya, she again danced the leads in these ballets, plus Paquita, La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), Pas de Quatre, Legend of the Sarimanok, Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), Designs and Variations, The Four Elements,and Capriccio Espagnol.With Ballet Philippines, she became a lead dancer for de Oteyza’s Spectrum, 1972; Joji Felix-Velarde’s Kulas na Batugan (Kulas, the Lazy), 1973; Rodrigues’s Variaciones Concertantes and Balanchine’s Valse Fantaisie, both in 1974; Welch’s Hail and Farewell,1975; Elejar’s Juliet and Her Romeo,1970, Trio con Brio, 1972, and Rigodon Sketches, 1976; Edna Vida’s Pagsamba (Worship), 1976; Chabukiani’s La Bayadere,1982;Alice Reyes’s Chichester Psalms, 1973, Carmina Burana,1975, Midsummer Night’s Dream,1976,and Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 1980;Walker’s Songs, Drones and Refrains of Death,1980.Her own choreographies include Bach’s Air,1974; Variations d’Amour and Images,1975; Maria Makiling,1981; Parvati and Chopin Piano Concerto,1985; Andaluza,1986; SnowWhite,1988; and Ying Yang,1992.

Nañas has received grants from the International Theater Institute to observe dance in Germany, and the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs to observe the Paris Opera School and Ballet. On her own she has visited the dance scene in the United States, Canada, Holland, and Denmark. She coached Mercedes Mañago in the 1986 International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Mississippi, USA. She has taught at BP and HwaYiEthnicDanceCenter and runs the Effie Nañas School of Dance at the Shangri-La Mall, Madaluyong. Over the years, her students have performed internationally. They have also trained with the Beijing Dance Academy, considered the largest dance institution in the world.Written by Emilie B. Capulong and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Douglas Nierras

(Photo from facebook.com/douglas.nierras)

Douglas Nierras

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/dnpd88)

text:
NIERRAS, DOUGLAS ( Douglas Price Nierras ) b. Tacloban, Leyte 28 May 1954. Dancer, choreographer, actor, director. He is the son of Rodolfo Nierras and Simeona Price. He started dancing with Jess de Paz in Tacloban, then won a scholarship in 1974 to the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School where he trained with Alice Reyes, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, Betsy Escandor, Garth Welch, Jan Stripling, Takako Asakawa, David Hatch Walker, Eddie Elejar, Antonio Fabella, William Morgan, and Effie Nañas. He was Ballet Philippines’s (BP) sound and stage manager. In 1976, he entered the University of the Philippines (UP), where he studied Speech and Drama, joined the Filipiniana Dance Group as lead dancer, and acted in UP Repertory productions. He toured Asia, Europe, and the United States with the UP Filipiniana. In 1978, he joined the Manila Metropolis Ballet, and started teaching jazz in several studios. In 1981 he cofounded Hotlegs with Johnny Manahan. Abroad, Nierras trained in New York with Phil Black and in Hollywood, with Joe Tremaine, Doug Caldwell, Chuck Moore, and Jackie Sleight. In 1988, he left Hotlegs and established Powerdance. He was featured in the Choreographer’s Showcase of CCP the following year.

Nierras has choreographed and directed numerous concerts of popular entertainers and stage, TV, and movie productions. His works include Adios (Farewell), a tribute to OFWs; Buhay Hapis at Pag-ibig Ngayon at Kailan Man (Life of Sorrow and Love Now and Forever); Arurong ng Tricycle, Harurot ngJeepney, Talbog ng Mini-Bus, Tunog ng Van (Roar of the Tricycle, Brooming of the Jeepney, Bouncing of the Mini-Bus, Sound of the Van), a tribute to the jukebox hits of Imelda Papin; Ampalaya at Asukal (Bitter Melon and Sugar); Sayaw ng Puso at Kaluluwa (Song of the Heart and Soul),and A Lightbulb Moment concert, all in 2012. He choreographed Luther Vandross’s song Dance with My Father in 2010.

In 1999, he won the grand prix at the 10th Saitama International Creative Dance in Yomo City, Japan. The following year, he received the Gawad Alab ng Haraya Award given by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts . Through Nierras’s extensive work in various media featuring dance, he has extended significantly the range of contemporary jazz dancing and choreography, and influenced many dancers in this idiom.Written by Mary Jane L. Globio, Mena Ojeda, and Malou L. Maniquis, with notes from Rosa Corazon Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ruben Nieto, kneeling, and his group performing Remedios de Oteyza's Capriccio Español

(Photo courtesy of Isidra Reyes)

Ruben Nieto with Rose Borromeo

(Photo courtesy of Paquito Dela Cruz)

Ruben Nieto

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
NIETO, RUBEN Active 1950s to 1980s. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Son of the Philippine ambassador to Spain, Nieto started training with flamenco dancer Finina Sabater in Manila. During World War II, he went into Philippine folk dancing. Going to Spain in 1950, he studied with Estampio, La Quica, Maria de Roman, and Rosario and Paco de Reyes. Flamenco dancer Mariemma took him to perform at La Scala in Milan, Italy.

In 1956 he opened a dance studio in Manila, where he taught, danced, and choreographed. He was guest artist in the schools and companies of Julie Borromeo, Anita Kane, Remedios de Oteyza, and Ballet Philippines. He also appeared on television and in the movies, and choreographed for Sampaguita Pictures. With Rally Calvo, he won an award for choreography for The BigBroadcast in the Ninth Asian Film Festival held in Korea. He nurtured and partnered a number of notable dancers like Rose Borromeo and Marilen Martinez. In 1985 he choreographed a one-act version of Bizet’s Carmen,with Borromeo in the title role.

In 1970, he moved to Madrid where he ran a dance studio, periodically visiting and performing in Manila. Nieto is considered the foremost flamenco dancer the Philippines has produced. He died in Madrid.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ramon A. Obusan

(Photo courtesy of National Commission for Culture and the Arts)

Ramon A. Obusan

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
OBUSAN, RAMON A. ( Ramon Arevalo Obusan ) b. Legazpi, Albay 16 Jun 1938, d. 21 Dec 2006. Choreographer, dancer, scholar. National Artist for Dance. The son of Praxedes Obusan, a physician, and Josefina Arevalo, a music teacher, Obusan held degrees in marine biology and cultural anthropology from the University of the Philippines. He taught briefly at the Aklan National School of Fisheries before joining the BayanihanPhilippineDanceCompany in 1964. He was one of the dancers of Bayanihan, but his main responsibility for the group was to record and document the dances of the various indigenous groups in the Philippines. After a few years and finding the company’s choreography too stylized and unable to contain his strong desire to promote the country’s indigenous dances in their natural form, he decided to establish his own dance group. On 21 Sep 1972, the RamonObusanFolkloricGroup (ROFG) was born.

Through ROFG, Obusan was able to mount folk dance productions based on his painstaking research in traditional folkways from Aparri to Jolo, Sulu. Actual movement patterns, costumes, and music were used, even as the dances were performed on stage. His productions include full-length presentations, notably Kayaw ’68 and Kayaw ’74, RITWAL: Rare and Unpublished, Maynila (Manila), 1989; Noon Po sa Amin (The Way It Was), 1991; Under ASEAN Skies, 1992; Mystique Asia, 1994; TheRare and Unpublished Dances series, I and II, 1991, and III, 1995; Obra Maestra, a collection of his major works, 2001; and Vamos a Belen (Let Us Go to Bethlehem), 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, and 2006. He collaborated in various film projects, among them Banawe,1975, Waywaya, 1982, Hubad na Gubat (Naked Forest), mid-1980s, American Ninja,1985, and The King and the Emperor,1987.

He was able to bring ROFG to international festivals and expositions in over 20 countries in Asia, America, and Europe. His dance group also toured the Philippines extensively and was finally made a resident company for folk dance by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1987. Outside of his own dance group, Obusan was also able to choreograph and direct for some 45 dance groups, notably the Nayong Pilipino Dance Troupe, Larawan Dance Company, St. Anne Dance Company, and Xavier Dance Society of Cagayan de Oro; and over 100 productions nationwide—dance concerts, pageants, festivals, special events, competitions, exhibits, television, movies, and video-films.

Aside from staging productions, Obusan continued studying and documenting the culture of various less well-known Philippine indigenous groups. He also researched on the Polynesian culture of Fiji, Samoa, Tahiti, and New Zealand, and gave lectures, demonstrations, and workshops worldwide.

Two documentaries he directed for the Tuklas Sining series won awards in France: the grand prize, Prix de Reportage for Sayaw: A Video Documentary on Philippine Dance, 1990, and Special Mention, Grand Prix International Video-Dance for Sayaw: A Video Documentary on Philippine Ethnic Dance, 1992. He also directed Sayaw: A Video Documentary on the Spanish Influence in Philippine Dance and Dulaan: A Video Documentary on Philippine Ethnic Theater.

Obusan was an officer of the PhilippineFolkDanceSociety and became a consultant for UNESCO where he was cited for his achievements in research. For his great contributions in the preservation and promotion of folk dances in its pure form, he received various awards such as the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila in 1992, the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 1993, the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts given to 100 artists in 1999, and the Mayor’s Award for Excellence in the Arts from the City of Pasay in 2005. The most prestigious award, the National Artist for Dance, was bestowed on him in Jun 2006 by the Philippine government, a few months before he passed away.Written by Paul G. del Rosario and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes fromSarah Lumba

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Leonor Orosa-Goquingco in Luva Adameit’s A Chinese Temple Garden

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Leonor Orosa, after she graduated from St Scholastica’s College with a degree in Education,

major in English and Literature, summa cum laude

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Leonor Orosa-Goquingco

Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, National Artist for Dance, 1976

(Photo courtesy of CCP Library)

text:
OROSA-GOQUINGCO, LEONOR ( Leonor Luna Orosa-Goquingco )aka Cristina Luna. b. Jolo, Sulu 24 Jul 1917 d. 15 Jul 2005. Poet, playwright, composer, visual artist, scenic and costume designer, pianist, cultural historian. National Artist for Dance. She is the second child of pioneer physicians Sixto Orosa and Severina Luna, and the elder sister of critic Rosalinda Orosa. She was married to Benjamin Goquingco. They had three children, two of whom—Rachelle and Regina—are dancers. Orosa-Goquingco graduated valedictorian of her high school class, and finished bachelor of science in education, summa cum laude, at St. Scholastica’s College. She took graduate courses in theater craft, drama, and music at Columbia University and Teachers College in New York City, USA.

Her early ballet training was under Lilia Lopez, Epifania Rodriguez, and LuvaAdameit. She took professional and teacher’s courses at the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, coming under the tutelage of Hilda Butsova, Thalia Mara, Anatole Vilzak, and Madame Ludmilla. National Artist in Dance FranciscaReyes-Aquino was also her mentor.

In 1934, at the age of 17, she started her major dance experiments and, in 1939, was the only dancer on the First Cultural Mission to Japan. That same year, she produced Circling the Globe, and a year later, Dance Panorama. In 1940 she created The Elements, a ballet choreographed with commissioned music, and Sports, featuring cheerleaders, a tennis match, and a basketball game. A year later, she choreographed the first Philippine folkloric ballet, Trend: Return to the Native.

After World War II, she organized the Philippine Ballet where she brought to life Maria Clara, the leper, Sisa, Elias, and Salome—all characters in Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not). Her Noli Dance Suite, 1956, including the pieces “Maria Clara and the Leper” and “Asalto for Maria Clara” were among the first few choreographies revolving around the novel. In 1958 she founded the Filipinescas Dance Company.

Orosa-Goquingco was inclined not only to classical ballet but also to Indian and Spanish, as well as modern, dance. She is noted for her courage in breaking traditions in dance despite public indifference. Her other important works include Vinta!Morolandia (choreographed in 1938), Festival in Maguindanao (depicting a Muslim royal wedding), Eons Ago: The Creation (depicting Philippine legends of the creation of the world and of the first man and woman), all forming part of her Filipinescas:Philippine Life,Legend,andLoreinDance, and Miner’s Song. Inevitably her innovations revolutionized the folkdances. The Bird and the Planters is the first weaving together of the various rice-planting sequences, climaxed by a new version of the tinikling where the dancer personifies thetiklingbird. It was the first to utilize bamboo poles to actually catch the bird, the first to use a double-time finale and breathtakingly rapid turns while the dancer hops in and out of the bamboo poles. Orosa-Goquingco’s Tribal, about the death of a warrior, is the first dance composition in the Mountain Province-dance style. Other works along the same line are “Ang Antipos” (The Flagellant), “Salubong” (Meeting), and “Pabasa” (Reading of thePasyon)—all dance sequences celebrating Philippine lenten practices. Philippine games such aspalo sebo,sipa, andjuego de anillowere depicted in Easter Sunday Fiesta. Orosa-Goquingco is also remembered for her transmutation into dance theater of the cockfight, theasalto, and the fiestas.

Additionally, under her own name and pen name (Cristina Luna), she has been published by the Philippine Cultural Foundation and Philippine periodicals, by Arts of Asia (Hong Kong), Enciclopedia dello Spettacolo (Rome, Italy), and Grove’s Dictionary of Music and Musicians. She is the author of a history of Philippine dance, DancesoftheEmeraldIsles, 1980, and of the popular one-act play, Her Son, Jose Rizal.Her critical essays are compiled in a collection titled Curtain Call: Selected Reviews1957-2000, published in 2001.

Orosa-Goquingco is also known as “Mother of Philippine Theater Dance” and “Dean of Filipino Performing Arts Critics.” She became the honorary chair of the Association of Ballet Academies of the Philippines (ABAP) and a founding member of the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), 1987. She has received numerous awards, among them the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award, 1961; the Rizal Centennial Award, 1962; Republic Cultural Heritage Award, 1964; Presidential Award of Merit, 1970; Tandang Sora Award, 1975; and the Columbia University Alumni Association Award, 1975. She was proclaimed National Artist in Dance on 27 Mar 1976.Written by Marge C. Enriquez, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
OSTREA, NOREEN ( Noreen Rita Ramirez Ostrea-Nepomuceno ) b. Benguet, Mt Province 12 Jun 1968. Dancer. She is the daughter of Dr Antonio Mapua Ostrea and Maria Imelda Ramirez; her brother is married to actor and scriptwriter Raquel Villavicencio. She is married to David Nepomuceno, with whom she has four children. She has a BA in Communications from the Assumption College, 1989. In 2012, she earned her Stott Pilates Mat Certification.

She trained with Felicitas Layag-Radaic, Karen Rowe, and Sonia Domingo at the Academy of the Performing Arts from 1974 to 1981. After that, she joined the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance Company until 1984, training with Ester Rimpos, William Morgan, Jose “Peping” Antonio, Noordin Jumalon, and various guest artists, including Armin Wilde, Luminita Dumitrescu, Laura Alonso, Mikhail Kukharev, and Natalia Makarova.

In 1984, she joined the Manila Metropolis Ballet (MMB) directed by Tony Fabella and Eddie Elejar. When MMB became part of the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 1987, she joined the activities of the new company. In PBT, she was mentored by Gener Caringal, Inday Mañosa, Vella Damian, and has worked with Sophia Radaic, Lisa Macuja, and Osias Barroso; guest ballet masters Alexander Bykov, Rinat Gizatulin, Paul de Masson; and guest artists Maniya Barredo, Nicolas Pacaña, Maiqui Mañosa, Robert Barnett, and Tomas Mayr.

Ostrea took lyrical roles asEffie in La Sylphide, 1991, and Dawn in Coppelia, 1992. In 1991, she was cast as the lead ballerina in Fabella’s Three Tchaikovsky Waltzes.Fabella created more roles for her such as the solo in “Sala”(Living Room) section of Mantones de Manila (Shawls from Manila), and the firstsoloist in Beautiful Girls, 1990.She was also a lead in Julie Borromeo’s jazzy-ballet On to Side A, 1992, and in Gener Caringal’s Filipino Komiks (Filipino Comics), 1993, as the deep sea monster, Bangenge.In 1994, she essayed Juliet in Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet and Black Swan Odile in Swan Lake, partnered by American Ballet Theatre principal Charles Askegard.

She migrated to the US in 1995 and joined Ballet Memphis until 1997. She was featured as the lead in George Balanchine’s Allegro Brilliante.When PBT visited the US, Ostrea performed with them, doing the role of the Spanish dancer in Edna Vida’s Thatness, Thereness.

In 1997, she joined the Broadway production of The King and I, where she was cast as Uncle Thomas. That year, she also performed for Staten Island Ballet and Connecticut Ballet. She also joined productions of New York Ballet in 1999, and City Ballet of San Diego in 2002.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto
