Nicolas Pacaña

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Nicolas Pacaña and Katherine Sanchez-Trofeo in Romeo and Juliet, 2012

(Photo by Edward Hayco, courtesy of Ballet Center Cebu)

Nicolas Pacaña

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Nicolas Pacaña

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Nicolas Pacaña as Colas in La Fille Mal Gardee 

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
PACAÑA, NICOLAS ( Nicolas de Villa Pacaña )b. Cebu City 10 Sep 1953. Dancer, teacher, choreographer, director. He is the son of Herminigildo Pacaña and Eva de Villa, an actor in Visayan movies. He trained with Fe Sala-Villarica and Mario Recto, and danced with the Queen City Junior Ballet. He has been in the United States since 1973, training first in San Francisco and Los Angeles, then joining the Honolulu City Ballet in 1974. In 1976, he joined Boston Ballet as a soloist, then rose to become a principal dancer, in roles like Colas in La Fille Mal Gardee, Albrecht in Giselle, and the Gypsy Boy and Espada in Rudolf Nureyev’s Don Quixote production. He toured China, the Middle East, and Europe with the company.

In 1982, Pacaña joined Atlanta Ballet as principal dancer, with major roles in Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty, Thor Sutowski’s Midsommernatten, Fernand Nault’s Carmina Burana, Thomas Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, and Madame Butterfly which he had also danced in Manila with Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT). He has danced in several Balanchine ballets, in Boston and Atlanta, and taken principal parts in the ballets of Bruce Wells, Jerome Robbins, Choo San Goh, Lynne Taylor-Corbett, Robert Barnett, Peter Anastos, Dennis Nahat, John McFall, and Lisa de Ribere, as well as the title roles in Mikhail Lavrosky’s Casanova, Matthew Wright’s Gustav, Farewell, Joseph Rusillo’s Shakespeare Suite, Eric Cruz’s Carmen, and Gener Caringal’s Vinta.

Pacaña was a principal teacher with the Atlanta School of Ballet, and has taught in Boston, San Francisco, and Hawaii, and ballet master for PBT in 1993. As choreographer, he staged El Amor Brujo (Wild Love) for Honolulu City Ballet, 1975; El Amor (Love) pas de deux for Hariraya Ballet in Manila, 1983; Ballet Imperial (Imperial Ballet) for Atlanta Ballet apprentices and the Atlanta Symphony, 1985; Ballet Classique for Atlanta Ballet II, 1986; and classical excerpts for Clayton Festival Ballet where he was artistic adviser beginning in 1991.

In 1993, he taught and choreographed ballet in the Philippines. The next year, he was back in the USA and appointed as the coartistic director of Atlanta Festival Ballet Company and Atlanta Festival Ballet School, in Stockbridge, Georgia. His Paganini closed the GALA at the Southeastern Regional Ballet Association Conference in 1994. His works such as Peter Pan, Beauty and theBeast, The Little Mermaid, and Tchaikovsky have been commissioned internationally. In 2001, he was invited by his former teacher, Fe Sala Villarica as a guest dancer and choreographer in Cebu’s BalletCenter. Every year, he returns to the Philippines to stage productions for Repertory such as The Little Mermaid, Alice inWonderland, and The Nutcracker for BalletCenter. In 2006, he was appointed artistic director with Gregory Aaron of BalletCenter in Cebu, artistic associate of the Royeca Schools of Ballet, Davao City, Tagum City, and General Santos City. He also introduced the International Summer Series in Cebu. In 2007, he choreographed, staged, and performed Beauty and the Beast for BalletCenter in Cebu, Davao City, and General Santos City.

In 2011, he returned to Atlanta Festival Ballet to dance Romeo and Juliet. His last performance as Romeo, his favorite role in Sergei Prokofiev’s Romeo and Juliet, was in Cebu City in 2012 and Davao in 2013. He is listed in Who’s Who in America. He continues to direct the Atlanta Festival Ballet and Ballet Center in Cebu.

In 2007, he received the “Garbo sa Sugbo” (Pride of Cebu) Award from the Cebu City Government.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Carlo Pacis

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Carlo Pacis

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
PACIS, CARLO ( Carlo Alexis Chanco Pacis )b. Manila 5 May 1976. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Son of Oscar Agcaoili Pacis and Juanita Chanco. Carlo Pacis holds a BFA in Dance (First-class Honours), 1998, and an MFA in Dance from the Hong Kong Academy of Performing Arts (HKAPA), 2009. He graduated from the Philippine High School for the Arts as a ballet major in 1993 and entered the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music as a dance major, leaving in 1995 for a scholarship at the HKAPA. While at UP, he performed the title role in Tchaikovsky Fantasie, and the second duet in Paean to Pavlova, both by Basilio.

He joined the Hong Kong Ballet (HKB) in 1998, and became senior soloist in 2002. Until his retirement in 2010, he performed Alain in Fredrick Ashton’s La Fille Mal Gardee (The Wayward Daughter); the second movement in Stephen Baynes’s The Way Alone; Texan Kangaroo Rat in David Bintley’s Still Life at the Penguin Café; the Satyr in Irek Mukhamedov’s Spartacus; Men’s Duet in Natalie Weir’s Rite of Spring; Bronze Idol and Magdaveya in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer); and the lead Nathaniel, who replaced the usual Franz character, in Bengt Jörgen’s Coppelia. He danced in two versions of Romeo and Juliet,as Benvolio in Rudi van Dantzig’s, as Romeo and Mercutio in Ballet Jörgen’s, and as Mercutio in Canada in 2006.

Pacis was described as an elegant and musical dancer in Stanton Welch’s Clear, 2007, Balanchine’s Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux, 2006, and Rubies, 2008. His depth of characterization was seen in his portrayal of the Mechanical Bird in Domy Reiter-Soffer’s The Emperor and the Nightingale, 2005; and Dr Coppelius in Ronald Hynd’s Coppelia, 2008. He won the Hong Kong Dance Alliance Award in 2002 for technical artistry and depth of portrayal and Best Performance in a Solo, Pas de Deux, or Pas de Trois in 2005 for his rendering of Neapolitan in Swan Lake.

He choreographed several works for the HKAPA, including There’s a Fly in This Soup, 2005, seen at the 1st Asia-Pacific Ballet Festival in Seoul, Korea, 2006; Beatles on a String, 2004; sections of Swan Lake for the HKB, 2007; and Happenstance, 2005, for HKB’s Education and Outreach Programme. He was commissioned to create works for Ballet Philippines, producing Shifting Wait, 2010, which won the Gawad Buhay Outstanding Choreography Award in the same year; Mithi (Desire), 2011; and the full-length A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 2013, which won two Gawad Buhay Awards for outstanding choreography and production.

He has been teaching ballet technique full-time and for the Gifted Young Dancer program of the HKAPA since 2010, and was adviser to the MFA program in 2014. Since 2011, he has been the workshop tutor of the Asian Grand Prix International Ballet Competition and the Associate Artistic Director of Youth Ballet of Asia.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Anatoly Panassiukov

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Ballet Theatre)

Anatoly Panassiukov

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Ballet Theatre)

text:
PANASSIUKOV, ANATOLY b. Moscow, Russia 10 May 1953. Teacher, choreographer, dancer. Anatoly Panassiukov has been the ballet master of Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) since 1995. He is the son of Peter Panassiukov and Maria Evceeva. Divorced from his wife, he has one daughter and two grandchildren.

He enrolled in folk dance classes at the local Arts Center in Moscow, under former professional ballet dancers. At 9 years old, Panassiukov was encouraged to audition at the Bolshoi ballet school, where he received professional training for eight years. The Bolshoi Ballet regularly invited Panassiukov and some of his classmates to perform in the season productions; his first as a little tavern boy in Don Quixote. Upon graduating with a cum laude, he performed a few years with the Bolshoi, but left to join the Theater Stanislavsky, where he became a featured soloist and eventually principal dancer. After seven years, he followed his mentor, Naoum Azarin, who was a cousin of prima ballerina Maya Plisetskaya, when Azarin transferred to Moscow Classical Ballet. Panassiukov danced as a principal for 15 years, alongside Irek Mukhamedov, Galina Schlyapina, and Vladimir Malakhov.

While on tour in the United States, Panassiukov’s friend Valentina Kozlova invited him to dance with her at the Hartford Ballet in Connecticut. It was here that PBT artistic director Gener Caringal asked Kozlova for recommendations for a ballet master, and Kozlova thought it a good opportunity for Panassiukov. He, however, turned down the first invitations, only accepting after several tries over the span of a month. His first year in the Philippines was a trial period, but despite the difficulty of the language barrier, he decided to stay.

Dancers who were in PBT from 1995 to the present have undergone intensive training with Panassiukov. His unorthodox approach to class has strengthened many dancers’ stamina, ballon, and aplomb. Among the dancers who owe their development to Panassiukov are Faye Abigail Tan, Jared Tan, Tara Ferrer, Joan Ayap, Alvin Aficionado, Nino Guevarra, Mark Joseph Pineda, and Lobreza Pimentel. He also arranged for Russian dancers Iouri Vyskubenko and Andrei Roslotsev to join PBT in 1997. Several dance schools in Metro Manila have invited Panassiukov as guest teacher.

As ballet master of PBT, Panassiukov manages daily rehearsals of the company and has worked with artistic directors Caringal, Julie Borromeo, and Ronilo Jaynario during their tenures. He restaged several evening-length ballets, including Swan Lake, 2001, 2005, and 2010; Don Quixote, 2000 and 2001; Hunchback of Notre Dame, 2003; La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 2004; Giselle, 1997 and 2006; and the divertissement from Paquita, 1997 and 2010. In 2005, he choreographed Classical Symphony to Sergei Prokofiev’s opus, which has become a staple in PBT’s repertoire.

He has also appeared as a character soloist in PBT productions, namely as the father of Kitri in Don Quixote, alternately the stepmother and stepsister of Cinderella, the King in Raymonda, the Duke in Swan Lake, the mother of Swanilda in Coppelia, the nurse and Lord Capulet in Romeo and Juliet, and the Spanish general in Gener Caringal’s Andres KKK. Ballet Philippines invited Panassiukov to perform as Madam Simeona in their restaging of William Morgan’s Ang Pilya (Naughty Girl, based on La Fille Mal Gardee ) in 2004. Panassiukov also originated the role of the Angel of Death in Gener Caringal’s Darangen ni Bantugen (The Epic of Bantugen), 2008, which was proclaimed as having “magnificently aroused fear and dread” by critic Rosalinda Orosa.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Luther Perez

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Luther Perez

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
PEREZ, LUTHER ( Luther Oliva Perez )b. Manila 27 Jan 1955. Dancer. The son of Federico Perez and Maria Oliva, he studied at the University of the East and the University of the Philippines. He trained in ballet mainly with Vella Damian, Eric V. Cruz, Eddie Elejar, Tony Fabella, Gener Caringal, and William Morgan. He also trained in modern dance with Fabella, Alice Reyes, and Takako Asakawa; in mime with Tony Mabesa; and in folk dance with Corazon Generoso-Iñigo.

Perez was a member of Ballet Philippines, then Manila Metropolis Ballet (MMB), where he was a principal dancer and ballet master. He was also ballet master for the Fabella-Elejar Dance Studios. He was Albrecht in the MMB productions of Giselle,Siegfried in Swan Lake,and a soloist in Bournonville Variations.He danced Franz in 1978 for the Ballet Federation of the Philippines, staged by William Morgan; the poet in Les Sylphides;and the male lead in Balanchine’s Valse Fantaisie.

Among his other major roles have been those in Caringal’s Ang Sultan (The Sultan), Ester Rimpos’s Duo,and Elejar’s Hayop ang Galing (Fantabulous), Song Cycle, Iago, and Juliet and Her Romeo. Many of his main roles were created for him by Fabella: Araw atBuwan (Sun and Moon), to music by Ramon P. Santos, 1976; SnowQueen,to Khatchaturian, 1978; Sa Ugoy ng Duyan (As the Cradle Rocks), to Lucio D. San Pedro and Levi Celerio, 1978; Mi Bandera (My Flag), 1979; Munahamat Isara (Munaham and Isara), to Labrador and Faustmann, 1981; Love,Like the Moon… The Inconstant Moon,to Massenet, 1982; Reyna Elena (Queen Helena), to Chino Toledo, 1982; Ang Kasal (The Wedding), to Stravinsky, 1982; Three Tchaikovsky Waltzes and A Gift of Dance,to Chopin, and Lingon sa Nakalipas (Retrospective), to Lucrecia R. Kasilag, all in 1983; SixFilipino Pop Songs,1986; Music Poetica,to Orff, 1986; and Four Songs and Back to Bach,1988. He now teaches, choreographs, and directs for the Quezon City Performing Arts Development Program (QCPADP) founded by his teachers Elejar and Fabella. Through QCPADP, Perez has staged his own choreographies and has produced distinguished dancers.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

(Photo courtesy of Philippine Ballet Theatre)

text:
PHILIPPINE BALLET THEATRE ( PBT )Founded in 1986 and operated in 1987, it was formed in response to an appeal to support ballet artists outside of Ballet Philippines (BP) after the 1986 EDSA Revolution. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) provided funding and a seasonal home at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo. Active companies that merged to form it—like Dance Concert Company, Dance Theater Philippines, Hariraya Ballet, and Manila Metropolis Ballet—lent costumes and their repertoires. Its first studio was based in the Classic Ballet Academy of Inday Gaston-Mañosa in Makati, until it moved to the Meralco Theater in 1989.

Behind its board of directors is an artistic council composed of directors of affiliated schools and companies that chose dancers and merged to form PBT. Among its founding members is National Artist LeonorOrosa-Goquingco. Its first director was Gaston-Mañosa, followed by JulieBorromeo, EddieElejar, Gener Caringal and Ronito Jaynario. Among its ballet and rehearsal masters were VellaDamian, SoniaDomingo, Nida Onglengco, Wu Zhen Rong, and Rinat Gizatulin.

In its record of ballet productions from 1987 to 1991 are Basilio’s Exultations to music by NicanorS.Abelardo, Mga Awit ni Basil (Songs of Basil), RitualBonds to AlfredoS.Buenaventura, LaLampara (The Lamp) to JerryDadap, and Testament to Bartok; Julie Borromeo’s Merry Widow to Lehar and GraduationBall, after Ricardo Cassell, to Strauss; GenerCaringal’s Haram to LucreciaR.Kasilag, The Tribe to Power of Classical Rock, Vinta and The Offering,both to Vangelis, Prism to Mozart; EricV.Cruz’s Camille and La Gitana,both to JeffreyChing, Panaginip (Dream) to AntonioJ.Molina, and Carmen to Bizet; Eddie Elejar’s Rigodon to Castillo and Masks to RamonP.Santos and VirginiaMoreno; TonyFabella’s Brahms Overture, LimangDipa (Five Armstretches) to RyanCayabyab, Santiago Suarez, Dominador Santiago, and TitoArevalo, Pas Classique to Glazounov, Pinoy Talaga (Genuine Filipino), BeautifulGirls to JoseMariChan, Three Tchaikovsky Waltzes,and The Company to Czerny; FelicitasLayag-Radaic’s Tanan (Elopement) to JuanSilos. Other significant PBT productions were Andres KKK, Filipino Komiks (Filipino Comics) and Darangen ni Bantugen (The Epic of Bantugen).

From 1989, LisaMacuja joined the PBT as prima ballerina, forming a partnership with soloist OsiasBarroso. Among its leading dancers have been Melanie Motus, Noreen Ostrea, Maritoni Rufino, Mylene Saldaña, Raoul Banzon, Mike Uy, Edward Malagkit, and Robert Policarpio. It also had guest artists and directors in Nicolas Pacaña, Paul de Masson, Harold King, Thomas Shoemaker, and Robert Barnett, and Atlanta Ballet ballerinas ManiyaBarredo, MaiquiMañosa, and Mia Monica. It hosted AnnaVilladolid from Munich, ToniLopezGonzalez from Washington DC, Rebecca Rodriguez from Cincinnati, YvonneCutaran from Montreal, and China Central Ballet’s Zhang Roufei, Wei Dong Sheng, and Zhang Dandan.

Among its guest choreographers have been Barnett ( Reflections, Arensky Dances ), Thomas Pazik ( Scherzo, RomeoandJuliet, Madame Butterfly ), Jiang Zuhui ( New Year’s Sacrifice Act III, Farewell Maria Clara ), and Paul de Masson ( Impromptus ). It has also acquired classical and contemporary works like Paquita, La Bayadere Divertissement, Aurora’s Wedding, Giselle, Swan Lake ( Act II ), Coppelia, and Fokine’s Les Sylphides, Balanchine’s Valse Fantaisie, Serenade, Concerto Barocco, Prodigal Son, and Cranko’s Pineapple Poll.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Postcard featuring Philippine Barangay Folk Dance Troupe
Postcard featuring Philippine Barangay Folk Dance Troupe
Philippine Barangay Folk Dance Troupe with founder Paz Angeles-Belmonte
Postcard featuring Philippine Barangay Folk Dance Troupe
Postcard featuring Philippine Barangay Folk Dance Troupe

text:
PHILIPPINE BARANGGAY FOLKDANCE TROUPE ( PBFDT ) The troupe started informally in 1946 at the Philippine Normal School (later College, now University), as a cocurricular activity of the Physical Education Department, called the “mixed folk-dancing group.” In 1947 it began giving public performances, and soon a school-based dance troupe was founded by PazCieloAngeles-Belmonte. In 1958 the troupe was formally named and organized.

The PBFDT's repertory portrays a panorama of Philippine life and culture through wedding and courtship dances, martial dances, occupational dances, festival dances, and some comic dances from tribal and various ethnic groups, as well as Western-influenced dances of the Spanish period. A distinct characteristic of the group is that it continues the work of Francisca Reyes-Aquino by presenting her published folkdances as well as newly researched ones in a simple, precise, and instructional way. This mode stems from Angeles-Belmonte’s affiliation with Reyes-Aquino in the University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Group.

In 1959 the PBFDT represented the Philippines in the First Floating Exposition which toured 10 countries in the Asia-Pacific. In 1963 it participated in the First Southeast Asian Cultural Festival in Singapore and Malaysia. In 1965 the troupe represented Manila in the Royal Orchid Revue in Bangkok, Thailand, and fulfilled a command performance before Cambodia’s Prince Norodom Sihanouk and his queen mother. In the same year, it was adjudged the best in the Pageant of Asia Spectacular in Sydney, Australia. This was followed by concerts in Malaysia and Singapore in 1966. In 1968 it went on an eight-month world tour as official ambassador of goodwill. For 65 years, the group has performed in Asia, Europe, and North America.

Upon Angeles-Belmonte’s retirement from Philippine Normal College, the troupe became a foundation and is now no longer attached to the university. PBFDT is now administered by its director Eugene Ticzon.

Two PBFDT’s most prestigious national awards are the Presidential Cultural Award, 1959, the Philippine Presidential Medal of Merit Award for the advancement of Philippine culture, and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan (Sayaw) Award, both in 1971. Among the many awards received by the troupe are, the silver trophy from Hari Wanita, Federation of Men’s Club of Malaysia; the Hiyas ng Pilipinas Award, 1964, from the Board of Travel and Tourist Industry; recognitions and medals from the Cambodian Government and the City Council of the City of Los Angeles as Cultural Ambassadors of Goodwill and Friendship, 1965, and Cultural Ambassadors of the Philippines, 1968, respectively; and the Most Outstanding Folk Dance Group from the Bank of Commerce, 1983.

The PBFDT continues to be one of strongest companies in the country and has contributed to the strengthening of folk dance education and tradition. Written by Larry A. Gabao, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

article_title: Philippine Dance Company of New York
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Philippine Dance Company of New York

(Photo from facebook.com/The-Philippine-Dance-Company-of-New-York)

Members of Philippine Dance Company of New York in the late 1970s, front, from left: Ramon de Luna, Laura Gaspay, and Eddie Sese;

back, from left: Cynthia Evangelista, Rosemarie Valdes, Vida Dacanay, Maniya Barredo, Ching Valdes-Aran, and Cesar Villanueva

Philippine Dance Company of New York

(Photo from facebook.com/The-Philippine-Dance-Company-of-New-York)

Philippine Dance Company of New York

(Photo from facebook.com/The-Philippine-Dance-Company-of-New-York)

Members of Philippine Dance Company of New York in the late 1970s,

from left: Ramon de Luna, Tony Parel, Elizabeth Roxas, Bennie Felix, and Nestor Laxina.

Philippine Dance Company of New York

(Photo from facebook.com/The-Philippine-Dance-Company-of-New-York)

text:
PHILIPPINE DANCE COMPANY OF NEW YORK Founded in 1943 by Bruna Seril, a Filipino nurse who migrated to New York in 1931, it is the longest continuing performing Philippine arts group in the United States. Known as the Filipino Folk Dance Group before 1969, the group’s repertoire was developed by Maria Batoon, Salud Datoc, and Francisca Reyes-Aquino.

In 1969, ReynaldoAlejandro changed the name to Philippine Dance Company of New York, and for 12 years the artistic orientation was stylized and synthesized, incorporating other dance idioms. During this time, Maniya Barredo, Jamin Alcoriza, Lulu Puertollano, Gloria della Casa (Tobilla), Maxie Luna, Joy Coronel, Elizabeth Roxas, Kristin Jackson, Ray Tadio, Ching Valdes, and others performed with the company. Among the many dance teachers of the company were Rebecca Estepa, Leo Ona, Joe de Guzman, Deo Aclo, and Chito Grajo III.

Subsequently, Rebecca Estepa, a student of Reyes-Aquino, became the group’s artistic leader and works of Reyes-Aquino were reintroduced to the company. Later, Orlin Eijansantos who became the company’s resident director and choreographer, was assisted by Rolly Postadan and Princess Reymundo, dance master and dance mistress, respectively. Ramon de Luna served as president and managed the company.

Although committed to performing dances and songs embodying the Philippine’s rich indigenous, Hispanic, and Muslim cultures, the company has included modern dance, jazz, dance-dramas, and various dance styles in its repertoire.

Since its founding, the company has performed throughout the United States, with some of its members joining the international All Nations Dance Company on occasional tours of Europe and the Middle East. It performed at the New York World’s Fair in 1964 and 1965, and over the years, at the Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, Town Hall, Asia House, Broadway theaters, the Florence Gould Auditorium, the United Nations, the New York Dance Festival, the Felt Forum of the Madison Square Garden, the New York City Parks, and the Garden State Arts. The company also performed at the Havana University, Cuba. Grants from private and public endowments, such as the Performing Arts Foundation and the International Media Studies Foundation, have given extensive support to the company.Written by Reynaldo G. Alejandro, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Philippine Folk Dance Society

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/PFDSayaw)

Philippine Folk Dance Society

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/PFDSayaw)

text:
PHILIPPINE FOLK DANCE SOCIETY ( PFDS ) Founded in 1949 by Francisca Reyes-Aquino, with former members of the University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club and the Bureau of Education Folk Dance Club, the Society sought to preserve the traditional characteristics of Philippine folk dances; to enrich the knowledge of these dances and develop appreciation for them; to promote nationalism through them; and to propagate authentic folk dances.

In 1950, Reyes-Aquino initiated the annual dance festival in cooperation with the Department of Education. Ethnic groups were invited to perform at the Rizal Memorial Complex. She also began dance clinics where teachers from various Luzon provinces met every Sunday to learn the latest dances discovered through her researches. The clinic also served as a clearing house on issues of interpretation, costumes, music, and dance steps. In 1953, then PFDS president Carmen Adevoso, established regional chapters; today, PFDS has chapters across the country. Another significant activity of the Society was the Hiyas ng Lahi (Treasures of the Race) in 1959-60 where school-based dance troupes presented their repertoire of Philippine folk dances. It also had special demonstrations and clinics for visiting foreigners such as members of the International Recreation Association, the Folk Dance Society of America, and the Peace Corps.

For a time, the Society became inactive but was revived in 1975 through the initiative of Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, then artistic director for dance of the Folk Arts Theater. She invited some of the old members to help establish the new Society. As its main activity, it conducted folk dance workshops, the first being held at Philippine Normal College. Later, they were held at the Folk Arts Theater, in collaboration with the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports (DECS). Participants reached nearly 700 in 1990.

In 2013, PFDS held its 33rd National Folk Dance Workshop where 11 dances were introduced such as Negros Oriental’s inagta; Bulacan’s wedding ritual desposorio; Ilocos Norte’s innalisan; Marinduque’s aetana; and Moncada, Tarlac’s la jota Moncada.

The presidents of PFDS since the 1950s include Maria Javier, Carmen F. Adevoso, Salud C. Datoc, Lourdes Morales, Remedios Tanzuaco, Gregoria Luna, Paz Cielo Belmonte, Merla Oteyza, Prosperidad M. Arandez, Emerita E. basilio, Carmen Lara Cruz, Noemi M. Bellosillo, Larry F. Gabao, and Josefina B. Guillen. It published the comprehensive Sayaw: Dances of the Philippine Islands, in eight volumes from 1998 to 2014.

It received the City of Manila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan, 1966; an acknowledgment from the Folk Arts Theater Foundation, 1983, as well as from the Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation, 1999. In 2008, it received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Tanging Parangal).Written by Prosperidad M. Arandez, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Teresita Veloso Pil

(Photo courtesy of Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company)

Teresita Veloso Pil

(Photo courtesy of Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company)

Teresita Veloso Pil

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
PIL, TERESITA ( Teresita Veloso Pil )b. Minundayan, Southern Leyte 10 Oct 1928. Choreographer, teacher. The daughter of Judge Cirineo Pil and Marina Veloso, and niece of famous Cebuanobodabilpianist Luis Veloso Borromeo or Lou Borromeo, Pil holds a master of arts degree in Folklore Studies from Xavier University, Ateneo de Cagayan de Oro.

Pil first began to study dance at the Holy Infant Academy in Tacloban City, serving as a lead dancer in the academy’s dance troupe, organized by Benedictine nuns. As a high school senior, Pil choreographed a dance-drama, Ang Nabasag na Banga (The Broken Jar), which won first prize at the Literary-Musical Competition held by the high schools of Tacloban.

She then studied ballet in Cebu City under Luz Mancao-Sandiego and Fe Sala-Villarica. While pursuing a college degree, she also took special dance lessons at the Anita Kane School of Classic Ballet and dramatics under Father E. Moerdemann, SVD at the San Carlos University, Cebu, and with famed thespian Narciso Pimentel at the University of Santo Tomas, Manila. She returned to Leyte in 1953 to start her own dance studio. In 1960 she founded the LeyteKalipayanDanceCompany, formerly the Leyte Filipiniana Folk Dance Troupe, in Tacloban, serving as artistic director.

Pil’s research includes extensive inquiries into the dances of the Ifugao of Northern Luzon and the dances of the mountain tribes in Mindanao. As artistic director of the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, she has created choreographies out of researched folk materials, such as the bamboo-stilts dance karang, created from a boy’s game remembered from childhood; a dramatic six-bamboo version of the singkil, presented only by the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company; and their versions of the itik-itik and tinikling.

In 1970, Pil collaborated with Xavier University Folklore Department Head FranciscoDemetrio, SJ in writing the Dictionary ofPhilippine Folk Beliefsand Customs. She also published children’s books such as the Philippine Folk Fiction and Tales, 1977.

In 1993, Pil received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for Regional Dance from the Cultural Center of the Philippines.Written by Emilie B. Capulong, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Powerdance in Milan, Italy

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/dnpd88)

Powerdance

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/dnpd88)

Powerdance

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/dnpd88)

text:
POWERDANCE Founded by DouglasNierras in 1988, this contemporary dance group was the first to launch full jazz concerts. The dancers received regular training in various techniques as well as in acting and production work, resulting in a characteristic theatrical dance performance style. The group’s first public appearance was in Randy Santiago’s concert Shades, followed by another performance in LouieReyes’s first major concert Passions,both in 1988. In 1989 the group launched a full jazz dance concert, The BodySings,and in 1990, had another solo concert— Tacos,Tamales,Burritos, at Iba Pa (Tacos, Tamales, Burritos, and Many Others)—in a Manila preview of their showpieces for the International Jazz Festival in Mexico a short time later. From Mexico, the group proceeded to New York and took classes with Phil Black, Alvin Ailey, and Steps. Back in Manila, they gave The BodySings Too Part II at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines in Apr 1991. In Dec of that year, they had another major solo concert, Fundanggo sa Museo (“Fundanggo” at the Museum), at the Music Museum, with a repeat performance in Feb 1992.

The company continues to offer classes in jazz, hip-hop, zumba,and projazz.The company also represented the Philippines at the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN)Festival of Songs in Singapore, from 1989 to 1994, the ASEAN Tourist Forum in Singapore, 1994, and the East Meets West Economic Summit in Europe, 1995. They performed the finale for the Asia Dance Festival in Tokyo in 1996. At the 10th Saitama International Creative Dance Concourse in Yono City, Japan, in 1999, it competed with 73 dance companies from all over the world andperformed in concerts with other artists onstage as well as on TV.Written by Malou L. Maniquis, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Rhosam Villareal Prudenciado Jr

(Photo by Ernest Mandap, courtesy of the artist)

Rhosam Villareal Prudenciado Jr

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Rhosam Villareal Prudenciado Jr

(Photo by Dookie Ducay, courtesy of the artist)

text:
PRUDENCIADO, RHOSAM VILLAREAL JR b. Oton, Iloilo 18 Jul 1984. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. He is the son of Rhosam Prudenciado and Cecilia Debayde. He studied computer engineering at the University of San Agustin-Iloilo (USA), 2003, and later shifted to mass communication, 2004-06.

He trained with Kawilihan-USA Dance Troupe, with Annie Divinagracia-Sartorio from 2003 to 2006. In Manila, from 2006, became a member of Airdance. His teachers included Paul Morales, Jethro Pioquinto, Nina Habulan, Sharon Brendia-Lastisimo, Ava Villanueva-Ong, Avel Bautista, Ma. Elena Laniog-Alvarez, Herbert Alvarez, Christine Maranan, and Myra Beltran. He started choreographing for the company within the next two years, and was later appointed its associate artistic director under Villanueva-Ong in 2010.

Prudenciado has choreographed and performed for Airdance, the WiFi Body Dance Festival, and Contemporary Dance Map. He also performed in international dance festivals, joining the UP Dance Company in Malaysia in 2007 for Tari Dance Festival at the Academy for Culture and Arts. He has also performed at the Daegu International Dance Festival in Korea, 2009, and was guest performer and choreographer for the House of Dance in Hawaii, 2012.

Among his most important choreographies was Which Way?, a solo that won him second place in the WiFi Body Festival New Choreographer’s Competition 2008 and later on, first place in the Yokohama Dance Collection 2009. His prize package included a dance residency for three and a half months under Centre Nacionale de la Danse, France, 2009.

He has done several collaborations, including Automated Love with Ava Maureen Villanueva-Ong and composer Kabaitan Bautista, 2009; Twinning Machine ( Is It Time To… Or Do I Have To? ), a solo experimenting on video delay with media artist Tad Ermitaño, 2009; House Warming, with choreographer Mia Cabalfin and composers Marihiko Hara and Polar M, as a result of a two and a half month long dance residency inJapan, 2012. He worked with Cabalfin again in the multimedia site specific work Agaw Eksena (Scene Stealer), which had him and two dancers performing with functioning television sets on table tops. In 2013, he joined Mau: ASEAN-Japan Dance Project that toured Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines.

In 2010 he received the Ani ng Dangal award from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.Written by Nicole Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Lulu Puertollano as Taglioni in Pas de Quatre, 1960

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Lulu Puertollano

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
PUERTOLLANO, LULU ( Lourdes Puertollano Mitchell )b. Gasan, Marinduque 2 Apr 1942. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. LuluPuertollano is the sister of violinist and choral conductor Rosa Puertollano, and actor, visual artist, and set designer Joselito Puertollano. She received a bachelor’s degree in business administration from the University of the East in 1960.

She trained in ballet with RicardoCassell, for whose StudioDanceGroup she was a young member. She continued with Puck Hoog Meyer and RemediosdeOteyza, for whose Manila Ballet Company she danced and made her farewell performance in 1960. As the first dance scholar of the MusicPromotionFoundationofthePhilippines, 1960 to 1965, and as endorsed by Alexandra Danilova for a scholarship at the School of American Ballet, she further trained there in 1960 to 1961. From 1961 to 1964, she also studied with Danilova at the International Dance School in Carnegie Hall. She also trained in jazz with Frank Wagner and Matt Mattox, and in character dance with Fedor Lensky and Yurek Lazouwsky.

In 1964 Puertollano obtained a scholarship at the Juilliard School of Music and trained in the Humphrey-Limon and Graham moderndance techniques, and in choreography and Labanotation. She also trained with Anthony Tudor, Jose Limon, Anna Sokolow, Margaret Craske, and Alfredo Corvino. She was a member of the Juilliard Dance Ensemble and danced in Limon’s There’s a Time, Humphrey’s Ritomo Jondo, and other modern works. She was also principal dancer with the Radio City Music Hall, and danced Mei Li in the dream sequence from The Flower Drum Song for a tour of the United States and Canada. She also performed in Mara’s dance dramas based on Asian legends and folklore.

Coming home to the Philippines, she choreographed dances for AlfredoS. Buenaventura’s opera Diego Silang, 1968, and shorter pieces. The Danish choreographer Poul Gnatt chose her for the Philippine premiere of his The Miraculous Mandarin in the 1968 debut of DanceTheaterPhilippines. Then she rejoined de Oteyza in her HarirayaDanceCompany as dancer and ballet mistress. She also taught dance at St Joseph’s College. After this, she migrated to the US.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
QUEEN CITY JUNIOR BALLET ( QCJB )Founded in 1963 in Cebu City, the Queen City Junior Ballet was organized by FeSala-Villarica to provide an outlet for talented dancers of CebuBalletCenter and to cultivate an audience for ballet in Cebu and other provinces. She was artistic director and choreographer, with Mario Recto as associate choreographer.

The company launched a series of quarterly informal concerts called Ballet Happenings, simple but fully rehearsed and costumed presentations featuring original works by Sala-Villarica and Recto and excerpts from ballet classics.

For 20 years, the company performed all over the Visayas and Mindanao in concerts sponsored by schools and civic and cultural organizations for fund-raising purposes. By performing on all kinds of stages—school auditoriums, gyms, and outdoor platforms—QCJB became one of the pioneers in bringing dance to the countryside. Among its dancers were Hebe Hife, Mary Faelnar, Lulu Araneta, Douglas Alo, Pinky Benedicto, Mary Boyarski, Mari Yasmin Villarica, NicolasPacaña, NoordinJumalon, Mary Poblete, Julie Dingal, Charibi Abad, Tessa Solis, Christine Javier, Frederick Abellana, Carmen Cabaero, and Ann Grace Merin.

QCJB became moribund but performed irregularly under various names. It finally ended with the transfer of Sala-Villarica’s Cebu Ballet Center to Nicolas Pacaña and Gregory Aaron in 2006, who renamed the school Ballet Center Cebu.Written by S. Villarica, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Al Quinn

(Photo from facebook.com/al.quinn.908)

Al Quinn as Mountaineer and Inday Gaston-Mañosa as Village Girl

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
QUINN, AL ( Alcuin Gargaritano Pastrano ) b. Guimbal, Iloilo 11 Nov 1933. Dancer, choreographer, TV and film director. The son of Anselmo G. Pastrano and Natividad Gargaritano, he was married to movie actor Lani Oteyza (Elizabeth Barnes) with whom he had five children. He remarried in 1985 to Elizabeth Bolanos, and they have three children. One of his sons, Dino Pastrano, is an actor. Like his brother who was a tap dancer, Quinn learned to tap dance during his teen days by imitating Gene Kelly and Fred Astaire. He also had talent in the visual arts like his grandfather who was a painter. He holds a Fine Arts degree from the University of Santo Tomas. He studied dance with Pancho Uytiepo while a student at the University of San Agustin in Iloilo, and later with Anita Kane, Ricardo Cassell, and Remedios de Oteyza in Manila.

Quinn started as a dancer and choreographer at the Manila Grand Opera House in the late 1950s. He worked there with the first jazz dance group—the Shirley & the Moderners— which he formed with Jamin Alcoriza, Jack Jacinto, Arturo Zamora, Rally Calvo, Chito Feliciano, Shirley Santos, and Marie Cui. In 1961, Quinn joined Steve Parker’s Philippine Festival in Las Vegas, USA. He choreographed for some 50 musicals, such as Bella Filipina (Filipina Beauty), 1959, and West Side Story, 1968, for Santa Isabel College.

Quinn brought his jazz dance group to the Friday Variety Show on Channel 7. He had television performances in the 1990s dance show Eezy Dancing and comic sitcom Ispup, 1999 to 2004, which featured parodies of several Philippine TV shows and advertisements.

He also appeared as an actor, his first film being Maria Went to Town, 1958, starring Tita Duran and Pancho Magalona. It was the latter who gave him the showbiz name “Al Quinn.” He was also in Pagsikat ng Araw (At Daybreak), 1957, and Gitarang Ginto (Golden Guitar), 1959, both directed by Efren Reyes. He then went on to film and TV directing, beginning with Vilma Santos vehicles, 1978 to 1979. He directed three films starring Dolphy: Jack and Jill and John (codirected by Ben Feleo), Good Father, and Manuela.

On television, Quinn first directed in 1967 for Carmen on Camera in black and white and Carmen in Color when color TV arrived in the country. He then directed Oh, Rosemarie!, Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing for You), Tanghalan ng Kampeon (Stage of the Champions), Awitawanan (Singing and Laughter), and from 1967 to 1982, Nora Aunor’s Superstar on Channel 9 during martial law. Some of the TV series he directed are: Bahay Mo Ba ’To? (Is This Your House?), 2004; Quizon Avenue, 2005; Ganda ng Lola Ko (My Grandmother is Beautiful), 2005; Dalawang Tisoy (Two Mestizos) and Who’s Your Daddy Now?, both in 2007. Among his specials were the tributes to Pugo, Ading Fernando, Bayani Casimiro, and Dolphy in Dolphy Alay Tawa: A Musical Tribute to the King of Philippine Comedy aired simultaneously by the country’s three major networks ABS-CBN, GMA 7, and TV5. Onstage, he directed the Star, Urian, Metropop Awards nights, Cecil Awards, and the Binibining Pilipinas beauty pageants.

Also a painter, he held his first solo exhibition, Take One,in1999.This wasfollowed by Shadows of Black and White, 2000; Quinntessential Flow, 2002; and Shell andSundance on a Blessed Shore, 2013.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Karryl Faye Katigbak

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group

(Photo by Laurence Castillo)

Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group

(Photo by Laurence Castillo)

Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group

(Photo by Laurence Castillo)

Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group

(Photo by Laurence Castillo)

text:
RAMON OBUSAN FOLKLORIC GROUP ( ROFG )Founded on 21 Sep 1972 by RamonObusan, the group aims to preserve and develop traditional Philippinemusic and dance. Its identity lies in its careful rendering of folk art and culture onstage. Its repertoire is based on the extensive research of Obusan, a former member of the BayanihanPhilippineDanceCompany and a cultural anthropologist.

For more than 40 years, ROFG has documented and performed the rituals of more than 50 ethnolinguistic groups in the country. Its flagship dance production, Unpublished Dances of the Philippines, is a series of dance productions that present little-known dances and rituals excluded from the standard dance repertoire of other major folk dance troupes. It has more than 20 outstanding full-length Filipino dance suites, including those of the Cordillera, Bagobo, Tboli, Tausug, Maranao, the Aeta, and the Talaandig. Among the group’s notable presentations are Cuaresma, 1984; Kayaw ’68 and Kayaw ’74; RITWAL: Rare and Unpublished, 1989; Pamalugo (a Bagobo cleansing ritual), 1989; TheRare and Unpublished Dances series, I and II, 1991, and III, 1995; Noon Po SaAmin (The Way It Was in Our Place), 1991; Under ASEAN Skies, 1992; and Mystique Asia, 2004. Ramon Obusan’s often-repeated presentation through the years was his annual Pastores de Belen at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). These are comprehensive and faithful presentations of Philippine traditions in rites, music, dances, and mythic and historical panoramas. Often, indigenous groups perform with the group in festivals and expositions abroad.

ROFG has toured extensively, having covered various countries in Asia, the Americas, and Europe since 1974. It has served as the country’s cultural ambassadors in various dance festivals and conferences. In 1991, it became the country’s official representative to the first joint ASEAN Performing Troupe. In 1994, it was the only Filipino company tasked to perform for six months at the ASEAN Village in Sentosa, Singapore, performing not only Philippine dances but dances of other Asian countries as well. It has so far gone on three successful European tours which included Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, France, Amsterdam, Luxembourg, Czech Republic, Yugoslavia, Greece, Italy, Spain, and Australia in 1987, 1990, and 1993.

ROFG became one of the resident dance companies of the CCP in 1987. Aside from performing, it assists some 50 groups and institutions in choreography, direction, and production design. It also participates in the outreach programs of the Philippine Folk Dance Society and the CCP by giving lectures and demonstrations on Philippine folk dances and traditions to teachers and students. After the demise of Obusan in 2006, his sister Dulce Obusan assumed directorship of the ROFG.

In 2001, the ROFG was awarded the Sining Kalinangan Award for being an outstanding folk dance company by the City of Manila.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Sarah Lumba

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Alice Reyes

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Alice Reyes with Ester Rimpos behind her in Amada, 1974

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Alice Reyes

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

text:
REYES, ALICE ( Alice Garcia Reyes-Van Doorn ) b. Manila 14 Oct 1942. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. National Artist for Dance. Her father, Ricardo Reyes, was “Mr. Folk Dancer” and a pianist; her mother, Adoracion Garcia, a noted voice teacher, headed the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) music department. Alice Reyes is sister to dancer-choreographers Denisa Reyes and Edna Vida, and musicians Betty and Cecile. She was married to Richard Upton, and later to Ted Van Doorn. She has two children. She graduated from Maryknoll College with a bachelor’s degree in history and foreign affairs in 1964, and then took graduate courses at the Ateneo de Manila University while teaching history in Maryknoll. For further studies in the United States, she won a scholarship from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines in 1966. In New York, she also received the Hanya Holm scholarship, the Sarah Lawrence scholarship, and a grant from the John D. Rockefeller III Fund, between 1966 and 1969. She completed her master’s degree in fine arts, major in dance, at Sarah Lawrence College, and taught as assistant in the introductory dance program at Barnard College, and high schools in the Bronx and Mt Vernon.

Early exposure to the arts brought Reyes to the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company. Barely 14, she danced with Ricardo Reyes in a renowned father-and-daughter partnership. In the early 1960s, she danced with Steve Parker’s Philippine Festival in Las Vegas, USA. She also became a dancer, choreographer, and director for TV and other musical productions. Among these was a dance drama for the International Eucharistic Congress in Bombay, India, in 1964, 400 Years in 40 Minutes, an enactment of Philippine history from pre-Spanish times to the present. For this production she founded and directed the Centenary Dancers with James Reuter, SJ. More commissions came in, resulting in such works as the Santo Niño dance drama for the Fourth Centennial of the Christianization of the Philippines in Cebu, the Te Deum dance drama for the 50th anniversary of St. Theresa’s College, and The Island for St. Scholastica’s College, all in 1965.

Her major compositions in the United States are Getting There, to Carvell’s Pianissimo Ostinato; Untitled, to Delio Joio, 1968; and Amada, 1969, her dance thesis. After graduation and despite offers for her to teach and perform abroad, Reyes chose to return home and share her knowledge in modern dance.

In 1969, she founded the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company and presented a full concert at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on 19 and 21 Feb 1970. Its success led her to organize the first CCP Summer Dance Workshop with Eddie Elejar in 1970. This became the nucleus of the CCP Dance Company, later Ballet Philippines (BP), now a major dance company in the Philippines and Asia. She served as president of the CCP Dance Foundation and Ballet Philippines’ artistic director from 1970 to 1991, dance consultant for the CCP, a trustee for the Philippine High School for the Arts at the National Arts Center, teacher at the CCP Dance Workshop, and professorial lecturer at the University of New Hampshire, USA. She was a member of the Commission on Arts and Culture of Manila, secretary of the Council of Living Traditions, and chair of the Fourth ASEAN Festival of Performing Arts.

Reyes’s major works from 1969 to 1991 include At a Maranaw Gathering to music by Colgrass; Company to Bach; Bungkos Suite (Bundle Suite) to traditional music; The Emperor’s New Clothes to Milhaud; Chichester Psalms to Bernstein; Compared to What to MacDaniels; Symphonic Abstractions to Eliseo Pajaro; Dugso to Ramon Santos; Bayanihan Remembered to Lucrecia Kasilag; Mga Babae (Women) to Inang Laya; Negro Spirituals (with two by Helen Tamiris); Getting There to Foss; Seven-and-a-Half to Hendrix and Zeppelin; Punch to Nyro; Tapestry to Kasilag; Carmina Burana to Orff; Lonely Hearts Club Band to John Lennon and Paul McCartney; A Midsummer Night’s Dream to Mendelssohn; Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf) to Alfredo Buenaventura; Anting-Anting (Amulet) to Bayani Mendoza de Leon; and Carmen to Bizet. Her full-evening ballets include The Nutcracker, Romeo and Juliet to Prokofiev; Cinderella to Tchaikovsky; Giselle (a restaging); Jesus Christ Superstar to Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice; Tommy to Townsend; Rajah Sulayman to Alfredo Buenaventura; Tales of the Manuvu to Nonong Pedero; and, Rama, Hari (Rama, King) to Ryan Cayabyab and Pedero. With her Rama, Hari, collaboration with musicians, visual artists, librettists, and theater designers expanded the efforts of Filipino artists to produce innovative and excellent creations for the Philippine stage. Rama, Hari was restaged in 2012 at the CCP with Reyes as the choreographer and director.

She had also led Ballet Philippines (BP) in many international tours and helped win recognition for the company with its blend of classical and modern dance techniques and the use of Filipino and Asian themes and music.

As a young artist, Reyes won the best choreographer award in the female division of the National Songfest of the Philippines for three consecutive years, and the overall grand prize in 1964 in Maryknoll College. In collaboration with her mother, she won the same award for two consecutive years with the Ateneo High School. She received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the City of Manila and the PWU Alumni Award-PWU Golden Jubilee Award in 1972, and the Karangalang Hiyas ng Bulacan in 1976. The French government awarded her the rank of Chevalier in the Ordre des Arts et Lettres in 1980, and The Republic of Taiwan, the Gold Medal of Culture. In 1981, she received The Outstanding Women of the Nation’s Service Award, and grants from the Philippine Entertainment Managers’ Association, Asia Foundation, and the British Council.

After retiring from BP in 1989, she taught design in an export and design company and established her own creative manufacturing company, Chrysara. On her retirement year, Reyes received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining. During its 40th anniversary in 2009, BP paid tribute to her by restaging a reworked version of her Tales of the Manuvu. In 2012, she was awarded the Gawad Buhay Outstanding Choreography for Dance for Rama, Hari. In 2014, she was awarded the National Artist Award for Dance.Written by Edna Vida, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Benjamin Reyes and Pacita Madrigal in Giselle, first staged in the Philippines by Ricardo Cassell in 1950

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Benjamin Reyes with Josefa Arnaldo in a pas de deux from Don Quixote  

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
REYES, BENJAMIN ( Bayani Cerdon Reyes )aka Benny Villanueva. b. Manila 7 Mar 1930. d. Santa Clara, California. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. He is the son of Rufino Reyes and Isabel Cerdon, and half-brother of Lydia Villanueva Arguilla, founder of Philippine Art Gallery, and Remedios Villanueva Piñon, dancer, choreographer, and teacher. He and his wife, ballerina Josefa Arnaldo, are the parents of Andre Reyes, former principal dancer of the San Francisco Ballet.

At age 13, he started lessons with his sister Remedios Piñon, a dancer of TrudlDubsky-Zipper. He studied with AnitaKane, but his main teacher was RicardoCassell. Catching the attention of enthusiasts, he was sent to New York as a scholar of the AsociacionMusicaldeFilipinas, the Music Lovers Society, and Cassell. In 1953 he was granted a full scholarship at the School of American Ballet where he studied with Muriel Stuart, Anatole Oboukhoff, Pierre Vladimiroff, Yurek Lazowski, and Felia Doubrovska. He also took lessons at the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo with Maria Svoboda, Anatole Vilzak, Leon Danielian, and Frederic Franklin.

Reyes returned to Manila in 1955 and danced in the Philippine Ballet Festival with Alexandra Danilova, Michael Maule, Mocelyn Larkin, and Roman Jasinsky. He also danced and choreographed for Cassell’s StudioDanceGroup and the Manila Ballet Company. After Reyes and Arnaldo married, they opened their own ballet school and formed a group which performed onstage and on TV and toured the Philippines.

In 1961, after performing in the Philippine Festival in Las Vegas, USA, Reyes settled down with his family in San Francisco on the US West Coast. He taught at the San Francisco Conservatory of Ballet and Theater Arts, 1962 to 1970, becoming the ballet master and dancer of Ballets Celeste, the school’s performing company. In 1966 he joined the San Francisco Opera Ballet; after one season, he joined the San Francisco Ballet where he danced principal parts until 1970. He danced in the ballets of Lew Christensen and Carlos Carvajal, a Filipino-American from the Philippinesarsuwelafamily, and choreographed Mindanao for San Francisco Ballet’s Summer ’67 program. All this time, he worked on and finished his bachelor’s degree, 1969, and master’s degree, 1971, at San Francisco State University where he began teaching in 1970. He also taught at San Jose State University, 1987 to 1988, and at the San Francisco Ballet Conservatory’s summer workshops.

In 1972 Reyes moved to Santa Clara, California, USA, opened a school, and formed the Santa Clara Ballet Company of which he was the artistic director, principal dancer, and choreographer. For his work, he was awarded a bicentennial citation in Santa Clara in 1976.

Among Reyes’s choreographies are Muslim Suite, Peter and the Wolf, Les Patineurs, and Jazz Americana all between 1962 and 1965; Zoidiakos, to Strauss, 1974; Divertimento, to Shostakovitch, 1974; Scuola di Balletto,to Czerny, 1975; Alamat (Legend), 1976; the full-evening production of TheNutcracker, 1978; Homage to Pavlova, 1981; and Carnival of the Animals, 1990. He has also restaged the classical grand pas de deux of Giselle (he was Albrecht in the first Philippine production in 1950 opposite lead Maribel Aboitiz), The Sleeping Beauty, Pas de Quatre (after Anton Dolin), and Les Sylphides.Written by Remedios V. Piñon, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Denisa Reyes

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Denisa Reyes

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

text:
REYES, DENISA ( Denisa Garcia Reyes )b. Manila 11 Mar 1952. Dancer, choreographer, teacher, director. She is the daughter of Ricardo Reyes and Adoracion Garcia, and the sister of dancer-choreographers Alice Reyes and Edna Vida, and musicians Betty and Cecile. She completed her general education at Maryknoll College and the Philippine Women’s University, and has a master’s degree in fine arts, major in dance, from the State University of New York, 1978. She received her early training from Greta Monserrat and Joji Felix-Velarde, and later from Alice Reyes, Norman Walker, Pauline Koner, Antonio Fabella, Eddie Elejar, Miro Zolan, and Alfred Rodrigues. She joined Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1970. Creating dances during the early Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) summer dance workshops, she presented The Last Flower in 1974, followed by Arem in 1975. She was the artistic director of BP in 1991-94 and in 2000-2004.

Reyes received a scholarship to the Jacob’s Pillow Festival and workshop in Massachusetts, USA, in 1975, and after that, a full scholarship to finish her bachelor’s and master’s degrees in 1978. That year, she was one of eight choreographers chosen to participate, with her work, Ifugaos, in the 20th anniversary of the Clark Center Dance Festival in New York City. To subsidize her choreography, Reyes joined the Asakawalker Dance Company, and later 5 Plus 2 company in New York City. Then, she also danced with the Jose Limon company, Saeko Ichinoe, and Philip Drosser. In 1981, she organized a concert, 3-D Vision, in New York, featuring her works and those of two other choreographers. In 1982, her works were featured again at the Glenn Palmer dance concert in New York. That year found Reyes dancing and touring with The King and I with Yul Brynner; she also went solo for her second major concert.

In 1983, Reyes taught and choreographed for the CCP summer dance workshops, premiering her Muybridge Frames (then titled Photography, a Gentleman’s Honor ). Returning to New York, she produced her own concert, Neo-Filipino, at the Larry Richardson Dance Gallery in 1984. It featured One Ton Pinay, and premiered Made in the Philippines and For the Gods.

After dancing briefly with the Hannah Kalui Dance Company, she choreographed the full-length Firebird for BP in 1985 using Isao Tomita’s electronic version of Stravinsky. Her succeeding works for BP include Te Deum, 1985, to Bizet; Love Lies Bleeding, 1986, to Philip Glass and Brian Eno; Hula (Prophecy), 1987, to Lucrecia Kasilag; See It Finish! Cock vs. Cock, and Balimbingan (Opportunism) 1987, to Lucrecia Kasilag; Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1988, to Fabian Obispo; Sa Ugoy ng Duyan (As the Cradle Rocks), 1991, to Lucio San Pedro; and Rite of Spring, 1993, to Stravinsky. For the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), she helped conceptualize, direct, and choreograph the full-evening dance drama Diablos (Demons), based on a Bagobo legend, in 1989.

Her other choreographic works include Realizing Rama, a dance-drama for the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information (COCI), 1998; Fire Water Woman,2002, based on Nick Joaquin’s short story, “Summer Solstice;” Lagi KitangNaaalala (I Remember You Always), 2002,a musical tribute directed by Chris Millado; Lagi Kitang Mamahalin (I Will Always Love You),2003,CCP’s musical tribute to National Artists; Darna, BP’s season opener in 2003-04, with Chris Millado and Alden Lugnasin; Once on This Island, 2005, a musical directed by Bart Guingona; Everywoman, 2011, as part of BP’s Inamorata; Mario O’Hara’s musical, Stageshow, 2012, for Tanghalang Pilipino; and Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior), 2015, for Tanghalang Pilipino.

Reyes also produced the full-length feature films Sandalang Bahay (A House You Can Lean on), 2005, and the documentary The Power of Dancing, 2007. For Cinema One, she codirected with Mark Gary, Hubad (Naked), 2008. In 2005, they formed the group Samasama with film, video, and performance artists.

She teaches at the College of St. Benilde’s School of Design and Arts, is involved in arts education in her capacity as member of the advisory panel for Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA), and is a consultant for Department of Education’s K-12 dance curriculum.

Reyes received grants from the Artist Network Asia, Shanghai, 1995; the Asian Cultural Council, 1995-96 and 1998; and the ASEAN Artists Creative Interaction, Indonesia, 1997. She is the recipient of the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan of Manila, 1996; Bayani at Bituin ng Malolos Award for Dance, 2012; Natatanging Gawad Buhay Lifetime Achievement Award, 2012, by the Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group, Inc; Dangal ng Lipi ng Bulacan for Arts and Culture, 2013; Gawad CCP for dance, 2015; and Philstage Gawad Buhay Award for choreography in a musical for Mabining Mandirigma in 2016.Written by Edna Vida, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Josefa Reyes with Benjamin Reyes

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
REYES, JOSEFA ( Josefa Avaricio Arnaldo-Reyes ) b. Iloilo City 19 Apr 1932. Dancer, teacher. Reyes is the daughter of Ramon Arnaldo, a congressman, and Josefa Avaricio. She is married to Benjamin Reyes (aka Benny Villanueva) and has a son, Andre Reyes, who was a principal dancer of the San Francisco Ballet. At age five, she trained in piano with Tuding del Rosario, mother of pianist Nena del Rosario-Villanueva. In 1955, Reyes received a degree in music, majoring in piano from St. Scholastica’s College. In her college days, Reyes also received training in dance from Roberta and Ricardo Cassell. After her music degree, she moved to Davao where she taught piano at the Immaculate Conception College, and ballet at the Philippine Women’s University. Back in Manila in 1956, she married Benjamin and together they opened a school and formed a performing group which went on provincial tours and appeared regularly on the television show Caltex Star Caravan.

In 1961, Reyes and her husband moved to San Francisco, California where they taught at the San Francisco Conservatory of Ballet and Theater Arts. She spent four years dancing principal parts for the San Francisco Ballet Celeste, the school’s performing arm. She then became a member of both the San Francisco Opera Ballet and the San Francisco Ballet. She also danced in the works of Lew Christensen and Carlos Carvajal. Among her major roles are the principal parts in The Sleeping Beauty, The Nutcracker, Giselle, Coppelia, and Pas de Quatre. Also in her repertoire are the grand pas de deux from Don Quixote and Swan Lake.

In between her performances, Reyes studied in New York at the American Ballet Theater School, Robert Joffrey’s American Ballet Center, David Howard’s Dance Center, the Darvash Ballet School, and the International School in Jackson, Mississippi. She took classes with Valentina Pereyslavic, Leon Danelien, Frederic Franklin, David Howard, and Jurgen Schneider, and master classes with Konstantin Sergeyev, Natalia Dudinskay, Sophia Golovkina, Kirsten Ralov, and Dina Bjorn. She received a postgraduate degree in early childhood education and dance education from the San Francisco State University and San Jose State University, respectively. She holds a lifetime credential to teach dance in community colleges.

In 1973, Reyes and her husband cofounded the Santa Clara Ballet School in California. For the school, she choreographed Amadeus and co-choreographed the Nutcracker, The Sleeping Beauty,and Giselle.

In 2011, the Isadora Duncan Dance Awards in San Francisco gave Reyes the Sustained Achievement Award for “offering instruction and training in classical ballet” and for providing “… performance opportunities for children and Bay Area professional dancers.”Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

text:
REYES, RICARDO ( Ricardo Aduna Reyes ) akaMang Carding. b. Calumpit, Bulacan 13 Jul 1914. d. Manila 27 Dec 1989. Dancer, pianist. He was the son of Vicente Tantoco Reyes and Consuelo Aduna. He married singer and voice teacher Adoracion Garcia in 1941, with whom he had six children, three of whom—Alice, Denisa, and Edna—are dancers, choreographers, and dance directors; and two—Betty and Cecile—are musicians. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP), major in piano.

He danced for FranciscaReyes-Aquino’s UPFolkSongandDanceClub. He also danced in the moderndance productions of TrudlDubsky-Zipper and Manila Ballet Moderne, and in the folkdance adaptations of PaulSzilard after World War II. He joined the BayanihanPhilippineDanceCompany in 1958.

Dubbed “Mr. Folk Dancer,” he partnered his eldest daughter Alice in several Bayanihan tours around the world. He also headed the cultural missions to Vietnam and Cambodia sponsored by Operation Brotherhood.

Reyes received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for dance from Manila in 1980 and the Gintong Ama Award for Arts and Culture as Outstanding Father of the Year in 1989.Written by Edna Vida

Francisca Reyes-Aquino

(Photo from CCP Library)
