(Photo from Lola Kikay: Life and Works of Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation, 2007)

text:
REYES-AQUINO, FRANCISCA aka Francisca Reyes-Tolentino or Kikay. b. Bocaue, Bulacan 7 Mar 1899. d. Manila 12 Dec 1983. Dancer, choreographer, teacher, researcher. National Artist for Dance. Her parents are Felipe Reyes and Juliana Santos of Tondo, Manila. She married her fellow researcher Ramon Tolentino in 1934, with whom she had a daughter, Celia. She was widowed in 1939. Her second marriage in 1947 was to Serafin Aquino, a PE superintendent in the Bureau of Education. She graduated from the Meisic Primary School, Tondo Intermediate School, 1916 (now Isabelo de los Reyes Elementary School) and at the Manila High School in Tondo, Manila, 1920. From the University of the Philippines (UP), she got her high school teacher’s certificate in 1923, and bachelor of science in education in 1924. As a student assistant in Physical Education in UP, she was asked to prepare a presentation of Philippine folk dances for the 1921 Manila Fiesta Carnival where she presented for the first time four dances, cariñosa, abaruray, salabat, and areuana, based on her field notes from ordinary people who knew the dances. In 1926, she earned a master of arts degree from UP with the thesis “Philippine Folk Dances and Games,” a collection arranged specifically for the use of teachers and playground instructors. This study was the beginning of research work spanning the next 45 years of her life. With the support of UP President Jorge Bocobo, she braved mountain trails and treacherous waters all over the Philippines to reach peoples and their dances.

In 1929-31 under a UP Fellowship, she worked for a certificate at the Sargent College of Physical Education of Boston University, USA. Returning to the Philippines, she became Physical Education (PE) director for women at UP, 1937-39, and organized the UP Folk Song and Dance Club. Reyes-Aquino became PE supervisor of the Bureau of Education in 1939, and organized its folk dance society in 1940. In 1945, she organized the Filipiniana Folk Dance Troupe to perform for American troops in the Philippines. She was appointed PE superintendent of the Department of Education in 1947. In 1949, she founded the Philippine Folk Dance Society. She led the Hiyas ng Lahi (Treasures of the Race) program from 1953 to 1959 where college and university troupes held a yearly exhibit of Philippine folk dances to preserve their authenticity as well as to propagate them.

From 1960 until her retirement, she was the chairman of the Bureau of Public School Cultural Team. She also taught at Centro Escolar University, Jose Rizal College, Philippine Women’s University, and National University. Her research works are preserved in books that are used extensively in the Philippines and abroad: Philippine Folk Dances and Games, 1927; Philippine National Dances, 1946; Gymnastics for Girls, 1947; Fundamental Dance Steps and Music, 1948; Foreign Folk Dances, 1949; Dances for All Occasions, 1950; Playground Demonstration, 1951; Philippine Folk Dances in six volumes, 1951-79; Rhythmic Activities, 1952; and Philippine Folk Dances and Songs, as coauthor, 1966.

Reyes-Aquino’s work earned her many awards. The first to honor her achievement was Boston University, which conferred on her an honorary doctorate in PE for her pioneering research. Then came the Republic of the Philippines Award of Merit in 1954; an honorary doctorate in humanities from Far Eastern University in 1959; Certificate of Award, UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines in 1959; the Rizal Pro-Patria Award in 1961; the Ramon Magsaysay Award in 1962; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award in 1969; a certificate of recognition from the American Young Men’s Christian Association or YMCA, in 1980, and the Smithsonian Institute and the Asia Society in 1981. She was proclaimed National Artist in 1973. She received the Ulirang Pilipina Award, Dance Education Association of the Philippines in 1998. In 2007, Lola Kikay: Life and Works of Francisa Reyes-Aquino was published in her honor by the Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation.

Reyes-Aquino once expressed concern that while Philippine folk dance does not face extinction anymore, it is being threatened with distortion. She had no objection to innovations in the presentations but felt that folk dances should be “left as they are – of the folk.”Written by Prosperidad M. Arandez, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrid

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, National Artist for Dance, 1988

(Photo courtesy of CCP Library)

Young Lucrecia Reyes

(Photo courtesy of CCP Library)

Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, recipient of the Tandang Sora Award for the Arts, 1982

(Photo courtesy of CCP Library)

Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula

(Photo courtesy of CCP Library)

text:
REYES-URTULA, LUCRECIA ( Lucrecia Faustino Reyes-Urtula )aka Mommy Urtula, Mommy Urts. b. Iloilo 29 Jun 1929. d. 4 Aug 1999. National Artist for Dance. Born to a music-loving couple, Col Leon S. Reyes, who encouraged her interest in folkdance and traditions, and Antonia Faustino, daughter of pianist Aniceto Faustino, Reyes-Urtula was exposed at an early age to the various indigenous groups in the Philippines because of the constant change in her father’s tours of duty. She was married to Dalmacio Urtula Jr with whom she had three children.

In Baguio she took ballet lessons with a Russian emigre. Later she apprenticed with FranciscaReyes-Aquino. She graduated with a bachelor’s degree in physical education from the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), 1950, where she immediately started to teach. She pursued further studies at the Martha Graham School in New York, USA; the Hanayagi School in Japan, 1955; San Francisco State College, 1953; and the Polytechnic University of the Philippines where she got a doctorate in theater management, 1985.

As a student and teacher at PWU, she was involved in the Filipiniana Folk Arts Group. In 1955 the group attended the International Festival of Dance and Music in Dacca, Pakistan. That trip spurred the group to enrich its research and performances, and following the example of Reyes-Aquino, made contact with remote indigenous groups. In 1957 the group became the Bayanihan Folk Arts Center and its performing arm, the BayanihanPhilippineDanceCompany, with Reyes-Urtula as choreographer and dance director. After winning the top award at the Brussels World Exposition in 1958, the group began a series of world tours of the rest of Europe, the United States, the Middle East, and Asia-Pacific. In these tours, Reyes-Urtula was involved not only with stage but with film and TV. She choreographed for the Icecapades at the Madison Square Garden in New York City and received praise from the critics. Her work and the Bayanihan inspired Amelia Hernandez to form the Ballet Folklorico de Mexico and Alvin Ailey, his American Dance Theater.

Reyes-Urtula represented the Philippines in numerous international festivals and conferences, delivering papers and conducting workshops. She was artistic director for dance of the Folk Arts Theater (FAT) for many years; she conceptualized and managed, with the PhilippineFolkDanceSociety, the FAT Philippine Folk Festival and National Folk Dance Workshops. A former consultant on cultural affairs in Malacañan, she was special projects officer for folk dance at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) performing arts department. She helped found and conduct the IndakPambata training program of Bayanihan and the Kasaysayan ng Lahi (History of Our Race) summer workshop at Nayong Pilipino.

She authored The First Philippine Folk Festival: A Retrospective published by FAT, 1981. Among her most notable choreographies, backed by research, are Singkil and Indarapatra from the Maranao, Pagdiwata from the Tagbanua, Tagabili from the Tboli, and Sound of Wings from the numerous bird dances of the Philippines. Her other known works are Tadok, Diw-diwan, Ug-gayam, Banga/Salidsid, Idaw, Jota Intramurena, Quadrille de Oro, Vinta, Paunjalay, Dugso, Itik-Itik and versions of Pandanggo saIlaw/Oasiwas, “Rice Sequence,” and Tinikling. She has woven into her works contemporary themes like the Spanish tradition in Un Carnet du Bal, 1987, European classical music in Arpeggio,the Asian traditions in the collaborative ASound of Tambours—AnASEAN Tapestry,1990, and the paintings of CarlosV.Francisco, 1991.

Awards recognizing her work include those from PWU and Davao, for Outstanding Choreography, 1960; Republic Cultural Heritage Award and International Women’s Year Award, 1963; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila, 1973; the title ofBai Kiokmayfrom the Mandaya and Manobo tribes, 1976; and Tandang Sora Award for the arts, 1982. She was proclaimed National Artist in 1988.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Adina Rigor-Ferrer, 1999

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
RIGOR-FERRER, ADINA ( Adina Babauro Rigor-Ferrer )b. Dolores, Abra 14 Jun 1919. Dancer, teacher. Her parents are Agapito Rigor and Perpetua Babauro. She is married to Simeon Ferrer. She trained in modernballet with TrudlDubsky-Zipper and earned her bachelor’s degree in physical education (PE) from the University of the Philippines (UP). She further trained in moderndance under Jean Marsh at Wellesley College in Massachusetts, USA, where she took a master’s degree in health and PE. In 1956 she earned her doctorate in PE at the University of Iowa. She took both postgraduate degrees on scholarships from the United States government.

While studying at the UP, she was a regular member of Francisca Reyes-Aquino’s Folk Song and Dance Group and Dubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne. After graduation, she taught at the Torres High School in Manila and later at the UP College of Education. Then she became PE supervisor at the Department of Education. While studying in the University of Iowa, she worked as a graduate assistant. Later, she became an instructor at Beaver College. Upon returning to Manila, she resumed her duties as supervisor. In 1956 she became the unit head of PE at the Far Eastern University (FEU). She also handled graduate courses at the UP, FEU, University of the East, and the National College of Physical Education. She chaired many curricular programs on physical education, from the elementary to the tertiary levels, for the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports. In addition, she was a much sought after resource person on physical education, gymnastics, dance, and recreation.

Rigor-Ferrer authored Physical Education Activities for Secondary Schools and Rhythmic Gymnastics with Carmen Adevoso, and prepared a Glossary on Modern Dance Skills.

The recipient of awards and citations, she has been many times president of the Philippine Association of Physical Education and Sports for Girls and Women. She was the first president of the FranciscaReyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation and has served as its adviser.Written by Prosperidad M. Arandez, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ester Rimpos

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Ester Rimpos as Princess Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
RIMPOS, ESTER ( Ester Viñerta Rimpos )b. Manila 13 Aug 1947. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She is the daughter of Adelaide Montelibano Viñerta and Benito Rimpos, both of Negros Occidental. Rimpos started dance at age five and trained with RicardoCassell, Puck Hoog Meyer, GretaMonserrat, and AnitaKane. She became principal dancer of the latter’s ballet company, later called Pamana Ballet. In 1970 she joined the CCP Dance Company (now BalletPhilippines or BP) where she was a principal dancer from 1970 to 1985. She holds a degree in Broadcast Communications, 1975, from the University of the Philippines (UP).

Rimpos danced the lead roles in most of the ballet classics for BP, such as Aurora’s Wedding, The Sleeping Beauty, Swan Lake, Giselle, Don Quixote, TheNutcracker, and Le Corsaire (The Pirate), as well as in many modern ballets like Amada, Kapinangan, Valse Fantaisie, Concertino, Season of Flight, Songs of the Wayfarer, Phaedra, Images, Rajah Sulayman, Rama,Hari (Rama, the King), Orpheus Descending, and Yerma, where she danced and sang. She also choreographed for some productions, notably Duo, to music by Fabian Obispo, for the 1977 Philippine Music Festival. She taught ballet at the Philippine High School for the Arts, 1977 to 1979, the UP College of Music, 1983, and the CCP Dance School, 1980 to 1984 where she served as director. In 1985, she became the director of the extension program in dance of the Musical Arts and Management Foundation, Inc. After she retired from dancing, she migrated to the United States.

Rimpos was cited as Dancer of the Year in 1976. She received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award from the City of Manila in 1985.Written by Paul G. del Rosario, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Malu Rivera

(Photo by Lemuel Abdon, courtesy of the artist)

Malu Rivera as Helen of Troy in Norman Walker’s Odysseus, 1979

(Photo by Rudy Vidad, courtesy of the artist)

text:
RIVERA, MALU ( Ma. Lourdes Gabriel Rivera-Peoples ) b. Quezon City 10 Apr 1959. Dancer, teacher. Rivera is the daughter of newsman Duds Rivera and Florina Gabriel, and wife to Paul Edwards Peoples. She has two children; her son, Patrick Rivera Cruz, is a hip-hop choreographer and teacher. She attended the Assumption College from 1975 to 1976 and De La Salle University until 1979.

Under full scholarships, Rivera studied with Felicitas Layag-Radaic from 1971 to 1975, and later with Eddie Elejar, Alice Reyes, Luis Layag, Tony Fabella, Gener Caringal, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Norman Walker, Armin Wild, Luminita Dumitrescu, and Gray Veredon at the CCP Dance School from 1976. From 1975 to 1978, she was principal dancer with Dance Theater Philippines, performing the roles of Fanny Cerrito in Robin Haig’s Pas de Quatre, Maria in Radaic’s Tanan (Elopement), the title role in Robin Haig’s Leonore,and the lead in Radaic’s Penumbra and Oy, Akin Yan! (Hey, That's Mine!), and Fabella’s Recuerdos (Memories) and An Afternoon in the Park.

In 1978, she joined the CCP Dance Company, now Ballet Philippines (BP). She performed significant roles in the full-length ballets Swan Lake, Giselle, Chopiniana ( Les Sylphides ), Don Quixote, The Nutcracker,and character roles in Alice Reyes’s Romeo and Juliet as Lady Capulet, and Cinderella as a Stepsister. She was also cast by Reyes as Kooni in Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 1980, and as the Tadtarin in Amada. Edna Vida cast her as the lead in her Gardenia, 1979, and in restagings of Vida’s Pagsamba (Worship). Guest choreographer Norman Walker created the dance of La Gitana for her in his Songs, Drones, and Refrains of Death, 1980, and cast her as Helen of Troy in his The Voyages of Odysseus, 1981. She was a soloist in Diana Haight’s Sweet Passion, 1980, and the unicorn in Vida’s The Little Tailor, 1982.

Migrating to the United States in 1991, Rivera established the Westlake School for the Performing Arts (WSPA), which received the Outstanding School award from the Youth America Grand Prix in 2004, 2010, 2011, and 2012. She was also named Outstanding Choreographer at the San Francisco regional competition in 2004 and 2006. In 2003, she was given the Pamana Award for Fostering the Arts by the Filipino-America Arts Exposition. In 2009, the Filipino Women’s Network named her as one of the Top 100 Most Influential Filipino Women, and in 2013, received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Asian-Pacific American, San Francisco.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Dwight Rodrigazo

(Photo by Terence Ronald Mitchao, courtesy of Dance Pull Project)

text:
RODRIGAZO, DWIGHT ( Dwight Gico Rodrigazo ) b. Murcia, Negros Occidental 13 Nov 1970. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. The son of former four-time mayor of Murcia, Negros Occidental, Elizalde Paculan Rodrigazo, and retired teacher, Erlinda de la Noche Gico, Rodrigazo was a soloist of Ballet Philippines where he was known as “Wild Man Dwight” (Torres) and a “livewire character” (Saspa). After his third year in college as a Political Science student at the San Sebastian College Manila, he decided to pursue dance.

In Bacolod, he received ballet training with Anabele Martinez Cudilla from 1983 to 1986 and Lydia M. Gaston from 1985 to 1986. With the CCP Dance School from 1986 to 1987, he became a Ballet Philippines (BP) II member from 1989 to 1990, and a soloist of BP I from 1991 to 1998. Rodrigazo was featured in Agnes Locsin’s award-winning works, Moriones and Babalyan. In 1996, he was awarded a residency grant with the Brumachon Centre Choreographique Natinonale de Nantes in France.

Influenced by Edna Vida, Agnes Locsin, and Denisa Reyes, Rodrigazo produced several works for BP. He collaborated with award-winning theater director Anton Juan on Bread of Angels, 1993, and with his peers in 1995’s Noche Buena. He also created Bistro Amoranto, a dance series for a 24-hour live band concert, Woman Unbound, 1994, PRESH-AR, 1998, Whimsical, 2010, Moving Two, 2012, and Hardin ng Balo (Garden of the Widow), 2012.

After 1998, Rodrigazo was a guest artist in Myra Beltran’s Dance Forum and a member of Power Dance from 2000 to 2001, before cofounding E-Dance Theater in 2002. He also founded Airdance shortly after, where he was associate artistic director and chief choreographer until 2006. Since 1995, he has also conducted dance workshops for the NCCA and CCP.

Rodrigazo’s major works include Clones, 2002, for E-Dance Theater, and Streams and Indios Bravos (Brave Natives) for Airdance, both in 2004. In the same year, an excerpt of the latter won for Airdance the “Best Young Contemporary Dance Theater Group of the Philippines” award during the 3rd Mindanao National Modern Dance Competition. He also choreographed Tsukat Yashua (Passion of Christ), a full-length contemporary work choreographed for Tapestry and Dance Inc.

Rodrigazo moved to Bacolod in 2006 with his wife Sigrid Claus and established Dance=Pull School of Performing Arts, which served as the center for the Australian Conservatoire of Ballet examination program in the Visayas from 2011. Through the programs Contemporary Audience Development Program and Composition and Movement Analysis Program (C-MAP), Dance=Pull explores the possibilities of dance by working with groups of different cultural backgrounds in Negros and the rest of the Philippines to raise the level of consciousness of dancers and audience.

Featured at the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival are his critically acclaimed Karga Tapas (Cut and Load) in 2008 and the lighter Birds of the Mind in 2009. The former, on thesakada(sugar cane workers) in Negros, embodies Rodrigazo’s aesthetics drawn from both his modern and contemporary training, and his Bacolod tableaux. These were followed by Port Links, 2010, Beatles Suite, 2012, and Defi,2013. He describes his choreographic style as “directional motivation,” which not only articulates how the moderns rebelled against the classical form but also his search for the various possibilities of movements. Such style is what he calls “Asian contemporary,” a cultural synergy of movements and cultures.

For his commitment to dance education, Rodrigazo was conferred the “Artista sang Banwa” (Artist of the Town) award in the field of dance by the Province of Negros Occidental, Municipality of Murcia-Murcia Tourism Council, on 24 May 1997. In 2015, he began the C-MAP Choreographers Festival International in Bacolod.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

Manuel Rosado performing Debussys’s Clair de Lune

text:
ROSADO, MANUEL aka Manolo Rosado. b. San Miguel, Manila 1908. d. Manila 6 Sep 1969. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Rosado studied at the Ateneo de Manila. His first dance teacher was the Viennese Kaethe Hauser. After World War II, he resumed his studies and was one of the first dancers to tour the Philippines extensively. In 1952 he went to Jacob’s Pillow in Massachusetts, USA, and worked with Ted Shawn and Ruth St. Denis.

He performed all over Europe as soloist and choreographer in the Viennese company of Kapps and Johannes. From 1953 to 1955, he danced with the Spanish Ballet of Magda Briones of Mexico. In 1958 he returned to Manila and staged his well-known works, among them Clair de Lune to music by Debussy, Minuet to Paderewski, The Blind Beggar to Chopin, Judas to M. Salvador, Arms Etude to M. Galea, El Greco to Turina, Don Quixote to W. Newmann, and Death and thePeacock to Ignoto. In the early 1960s, he also choreographed dances inspired by folk traditions and the common man in Quiapo?, The Debutante, The Fisherman and the Mermaid,and Ultimo Adios (Last Farewell). He staged Serenata d’Amore to Mantovani, for BalletPhilippines in 1964.

Shawn praised Rosado’s “sentiment, intepretation, and emotional force [that] place him among the most talented artists of our generation.” La Meri called him “poet of dance.”

Tragically, Rosado was later paralyzed and deprived of speech. In 1977 the Ballet Federation of the Philippines honored Rosado posthumously for his contributions to Philippine dance.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Elizabeth Roxas

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Elizabeth Roxas

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Elizabeth Roxas

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
ROXAS, ELIZABETH b. Manila 7 Aug. 1958. Dancer. Her parents are Virginia Diaz Roxas of Spring Valley, New York, and the late Valeriano M. Roxas, who was a district attorney in Manila. In 2000, she married Robert Z. Dobrish, a matrimonial lawyer in Manhattan. She began ballet at age four with Anita Kane, then with Julie Borromeo, Tony Llacer, and Felicitas Layag-Radaic. In 1970, she attended the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) summer dance workshop and two years later, at 14, she was taken in by Ballet Philippines (BP), becoming one of its leading dancers. In 1973, Eddie Elejar gave her the title role in his Swan of Tuonela. Subsequently, she danced in Edna Vida’s Pagsamba (Worship), Effie Nañas’s Variations d’Amour (Love Variations), Pauline Kaner’s Concertino, George Balanchine’s Valse Fantaisie, Alice Reyes’s Amada, and Gener Caringal’s Ang Sultan (The Sultan) and The Rite of Spring. In 1975, she started choreographing with Inventions. In 1978, she staged Three Figures for the CCP summer dance workshop.

In 1979, she received scholarships to Joffrey, Graham, and the Ailey schools. She danced with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet for a season, Ohad Naharin, and Joyce Trisler Dance Company for three years before joining the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater where she was a principal dancer from 1984 to 1998. In 1988, she guested in BP’s gala and won Manila audiences over in an excerpt from Ailey’s Witness and in Denisa Reyes’s One Ton Pinay. In 1989, she was featured in Elisa Monte’s Treading and Ulysses Dove’s Bad Blood. She worked with many of the most significant choreographers, including Alvin Ailey, Katherine Dunham, Jerome Robbins, Talley Beatty, Lar Lubovitch, John Butler, Ullysses Dove, and Judith Jamison.

After leaving Ailey, she performed as Eliza in Broadway’s TheKing and I. In 2001, sheperformed in BP’s Carmen with Spanish danseur Raul Padrana as part of her series of performances before retirement. She then turned full-time to teaching and worked with Anna Deveare Smith at New York University. She was movement coach for Smith’s show Let Me Down Easy. She taught at the Hartt School of the University of Hartford, Tisch School of the Arts, and at Harvard University. She now teaches the Horton Technique at the Ailey School as well as the Actors Studio Class.

She has choreographed for Jacob’s Pillow, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Ailey II, regional theaters, and off Broadway. In 2008, she attended BP’s gala, New Beginnings, and restaged Ailey’s Night Creature.In 2013, she restaged Ailey’s The Lark Ascending for Dance Theatre of Harlem at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center. She performed in the Emmy award-winning PBS specials Two by Dove and Judith Jamison’s A Hymn for Alvin Ailey. She was featured in a 1997 Dance Magazine cover article and named by Avenue Magazine as one of the most influential Asian-Americans.

At 55 and with an artificial hip, she was one of Ailey alumni invited to dance in Revelations, the company’s best known and most performed work at the New York City Center on New Year’s Eve, 2013.Written by Paul G. del Rosario and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Maritoni Rufino in Gener Caringal’s Darna

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Maritoni Rufino

(Photo from facebook.com/maritoni)

Maritoni Rufino with Osias Barroso

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
RUFINO, MARITONI ( Ma. Antoinette Bantug Rufino-Tordesillas )b. California, United States of America 13 Jul 1969. Dancer and teacher. Rufino is the daughter of Antonio Abad Rufino and Armita Bantug, who was vice president of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, president of the National Museum Foundation, and president of the Filipino Heritage Festival. She is the eldest of four siblings, and the niece of visual artist Marivic Rufino. She is married to Roque Tordesillas, and they have two children who are encouraged as artists. Rufino attended the Assumption College for high school, and later the Marymount School of New York.

Rufino trained with Sony Lopez-Gonzalez at the Academie of the Performing Arts in Makati in 1977, then at Fabella-Elejar Dance Studio from 1983 to 1985. In 1986, Maritoni trained at the Neubert Ballet Institute at Carnegie Hall in New York under Stefan Hoff, formerly of American Ballet Theater, who later was guest ballet master for Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 1998. At Neubert, she also trained with “placement guru” Maggie Black, Elena Kunikova, Jenny Chiang, and Nina Popova. She danced with the Eglevsky Ballet in New York in 1989, and with Basel Ballet from 1994 to 1995, under Youri Vamos, and danced in The Nutcracker and in Pulcinella by Nils Christie. She also took the Royal Academy of Dance examinations in 1993, mentored by Sonia Domingo, receiving honors, and later, highly commended.

Maritoni Rufino was a PBT ballerina from 1990 to 2000. Her most significant roles are Kitri in Don Quixote, which she ably performed in 1993 partnered by ABT star Wes Chapman, 1993; and Cio Cio San partnered by Quincy Jacinto, in Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, which Rufino considers a highlight of her career, 1999. Other noteworthy performances include the title role in Eric Cruz’s Carmen, 1991; Odetteand Odile in Swan Lake, 1994; the title roles in Jean Paul Comelin’s Cinderella,1995,and Raymonda, 1996; in Giselle,1997; and Mercutio’s concubine, 1994, and Juliet, 2000, in Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet. In the 2012 restaging of Romeo and Juliet, Rufino performed the dramatic role of Lady Capulet.

A gifted actor, Rufino thoroughly researched and internalized every role she played, giving the character her own signature. She was in the original casts of Tony Fabella’s Beautiful Girls, Nonoy Froilan’s Stone Figures, Eli Jacinto’s Magdaragat (Seafarer), Edna Vida’s Thatness, Thereness, and Gener Caringal’s Prism,and Vinta, eventually dancing the lead in later stagings. In 1997, Rufino played Gregoria “Oryang” de Jesus in the first cast of Caringal’s Andres KKK, where she was partnered by Melvin Martinez as Andres Bonifacio.

A faculty member of the PBT Conservatoire from 1995, Rufino was appointed school principal from 1998 to 2000. She opened Danspace Manila in 2000, later offering a scholarship program to deserving students with Sayaw Foundation, notably having PBT ballerina and 2011 NAMCYA winner Lobreza Pimentel as a graduate. The school won an honorable mention in the Junior B Classical Category and 2nd place in the Open Trio category at the 2012 Philippine Dance Cup.

Rufino has also appeared in several theater plays, notably in Anton Juan’s King Lear, Repertory Philippines’ Beauty and the Beast, Carousel, and A Christmas Carol. She is also a yogini, graduating from the Centered Yoga Institute in Thailand, and cofounding Yoga Manila, a pioneer yoga school in the Philippines. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Odon Sabarre

(Photo from facebook.com/odon.sabarre)

Odon Sabarre

(Photo from facebook.com/odon.sabarre)

text:
SABARRE, ODON b. Calbiga, Samar 13 Jan 1950. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. He is the older brother of dancer Tomas Sabarre. His initial training was with Joji Felix-Velarde, Eddie Elejar, Cesar Mendoza, Julie Borromeo, and later with Poul Gnatt, Tony Llacer, and Israel Gabriel. He was a member of Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP), taking the lead role of Tasmi in the premiere of Mir-i-nisa in 1969. In 1970, on a study grant from Dance Arts Studio, he attended Robert Joffrey’s American Ballet Center in New York. He became a member of Harkness Ballet I, and later, of Pittsburgh Ballet Theater. In these institutions, he trained with David Howard, Maria Vegh, Perry Brunson, Vitale Fokine, Edward Caton, Franco Jelinsic, Nicholas Petrov, and also with jazz maestro, Luigi.

After four years, he returned to the Philippines and teamed up with his brother Tommy as the Sabarre Brothers on television. They conducted jazz and ballet classes at the University of the East and the Philippine Women’s University. In 1976, Odon briefly stayed in Moscow as a scholar, extending his studies in Denmark, Switzerland, Germany, Canada and, again in the US. He trained further with Finis Jhung, Valentina Pereyaslavec, and Gabriela Taub Darvash. On his return home, he danced occasionally with Dance Concert Company (including for a tour of Guam in 1980) and DTP, and often for television. Acknowledged as a ballet virtuoso and natural jazz dancer, Sabarre is back in Tacloban to help develop regional dance from his base at the People’s Center School of Dance where he is the artistic director. He is the first artist in residence of Region 8. In 2003, he conducted the Samar dance scholarship program in Catbalogan and Calbayog. Assisted by his daughter, Pearly Dawn, he has continued conducting several dance scholarship programs that include ballet, jazz, hip-hop, Hawaiian, and ballroom in Leyte and Samar.

In 2003, he was honored as the Most Outstanding Taclobanon on Tacloban City’s 50th Charter Day Anniversary, and in 2011, as the Most Outstanding Samareño for the fifth time.Written by Paul G. del Rosario, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
SABARRE, TOMMY ( Tomas Sabarre )b. 1955. d. Mindoro 20 Dec 1987. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. The younger brother of dancer-choreographer Odon Sabarre, he was trained by Joji Felix-Velarde, Eddie Elejar, Julie Borromeo, Tony Llacer, Israel Gabriel, Alice Reyes, and visiting choreographer-teachers Norman Walker, Pauline Koner, Poul Gnatt, Robin Haig, Luminita Dumitrescu, and William Morgan. He became a member of Dance Theater Philippines and Ballet Philippines, danced as the Cavalier in The Nutcracker,Franz in Coppelia,and the title role in Felix-Velarde’s Kulas na Batugan (Lazy Kulas).

Among his notable choreographies was Puntan dosAmantes (Two Lovers’ Quarrel) for the Guam Ballet Arts Theater. He taught at dance workshops in the University of the East and the Philippine Women’s University, and conducted jazz and ballet classes with his brother Odon.

In 1983 Sabarre returned to his native Tacloban to teach ballet, jazz, and moderndance for the creative dance workshop sponsored by the Ministry of Social Welfare and Development. He died in Dec 1987 together with hundreds of others when their passenger ship, the MV Doña Paz, sank off the coast of Mindoro.Written by Paul G. del Rosario

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Hazel Sabas

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Hazel Sabas

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Hazel Sabas

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
SABAS, HAZEL ( Hazel Escalante Sabas )b. Manila 21 Apr 1961. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. She is the daughter of Leon Sabas and Luz Escalante, and the sister of dancer Irene Sabas and singer Janet “Jai” Sabas-Aracama. She started ballet in 1971 at the Academie of the Performing Arts, and continued at Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s school, 1973-79, where she completed the intermediate Royal Academy of Dance training in 1977. From 1975 to 1979, she was a soloist with Dance Theater Philippines, and from 1980, with Ballet Philippines (BP) where she became a principal dancer. In 1985 she received her dance diploma from the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, and in 1991, a master’s degree in fine arts from New York University-Tisch School of the Arts, USA. In these schools and companies, she trained with Sony Lopez-Gonzalez, Layag-Radaic, Basilio, William Morgan, Alice Reyes, Norman Walker, Armin Wild, Luminita Dumitrescu, Lawrence Rhodes, Cerylyn Lacagnino, Betty Jones, Lucas Hoving, and Risa Steinberg. In 1990 she attended the International Choreographers Workshop at the American Dance Festival in Durham, New Hamsphire, USA. She also trained in STOTT pilates mat and reformer.

In the Philippines, she taught at the UP, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School, and for BP. In the United States, she was an instructor at Texas Ballet Theatre Academy, assistant professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, lecturer at the University of North Texas (UNT), ballet faculty at Texas Christian University (TCU) and Ballet David Campos in Barcelona, guest ballet professor at the Taipei National University of the Arts in Taiwan, and artistic director of Ballet Lubbock. As ballet mistress with Ballet Memphis, she created highly-praised choreographies such as Dracula, Firebird, and Deconstructing Gershwin.

Sabas danced lead roles in Armin Wild’s Veranderungen; William Morgan’s Encounters, Classical Symphony,and AngPilya (Naughty Girl); Alice Reyes’s Cinderella, Carmen, and Rama,Hari (Rama, King); EdnaVida’s PeterPan; and in the ballet classics Don Quixote, LaBayadere (The Temple Dancer), and Giselle.

She started choreographing at the CCP Summer Dance Workshop and the UP College of Music. She choreographed Sina Banahaw, Makiling, at Juan (Banahaw, Makiling, and Juan), 1985, to music by AntoninoBuenaventura for the PhilippineMusic Festival; Six to Borodin,1988, for BP’s Five Young Choreographers series; Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), 1991, for the CCP; and Padyak Tadyak (Stamp, Kick) for the UP Dance Company in the First Manila Contemporary Dance Festival, and IllustratedDialects for BP. While abroad, she choreographed Beat-Les Six, La Belleza de laFilipina (The Beauty of the Filipina), Pinay-I,and collaborative works like Match 17 and Diving into the Wreck for the Second Avenue Dance Company, all in 1990. In 2011, her work Green, dedicated to her parents particularly her mother who was an advocate of zero-waste program in the 1970s, premiered at Central Pennsylvania Youth Ballet’s ChoreoPlan and has since then been part of the repertoire of Dance Theatre of Tennessee, Ballet Manila, and Steps Dance Studio. Her Synchronicity, which she completed at the Ballet Academy East, premiered at the Ailey Citigroup Theater in New York City in 2012.

Besides receiving the LuvaAdameit Choreographic Award in Dance from the UP College of Music, 1977, she won grants from the CCP, the Asian Cultural Council, and a Fulbright fellowship. She later moved to Singapore for a teaching career.Written by Emilie B. Capulong and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Irene Sabas

(Photo courtesy of Escola Ballet David Campos)
Irene Sabas
Irene Sabas
Irene Sabas

text:
SABAS, IRENE ( Irene Escalante Sabas ) b. Manila 11 Aug 1955. Sabas is the daughter of Luz Escalante and Dr. Leon Borja Sabas, and sister to soprano Janet Sabas-Aracama, and dancer/choreographer Hazel Sabas. She is married to choreographer David Campos; they live with their daughter, dancer Karina Campos, in Barcelona, Spain. Sabas took up BS Nursing at the University of the Philippines, Diliman. She trained with Sony Lopez-Gonzalez from 1962 to 1966; Cesar Mendoza, 1967-68; and Felicitas Radaic, 1971-75. Through Layag-Radaic and Dame Margot Fonteyn, she was a British Council scholar at the Royal Ballet Upper School in London, 1975-77.

She joined Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP) from 1973 to 1979, performing Pas de Quatre, Basilio’s Mosque Baroque,Robin Haig’s Tryptich and Radaic’s The Prey, which she also performed at the Aberdeen festival in Scotland. She also performed Swanilda in Coppelia,1977, and the lead roles in Cinderella, 1978, and La Fille Mal Gardee and Other Ballets, 1978, with Ballet Federation of the Philippines , where she was mentored by William Morgan. On visits to the Philippines, she and David Campos danced in Basilio’s Paean to Pavlova and Testament for DTP.

She danced with Hagen State Ballet in Germany as a demi-soloist, 1979 to 1983, dancing in Der Pfau and Firebird, 1979-80, and Lady of the Camelias,and as Juliet in Nikolai Beriosov’s Romeo and Juliet, 1981-82. With the Royal Ballet of Flanders, Belgium, 1983-86, she danced the role of Masha in Valery Panov’s The Three Sisters, and the pas de deux from Ben Stevenson’s Three Preludes, as well as a variety of roles in works by Nils Christie, Frederick Ashton, and George Balanchine. She was first soloist with Ballet de Barcelona from 1986 to 1987, where she danced the title role in Paquita, as well as the lead in Galina Samsova’s Walpurgis Nacht and Beriosov’s Spectre de la Rose.

She became school director and professor at Escola Ballet David Campos in Barcelona, Spain, from 1987, and has served as associate artistic director, ballet mistress, and repetiteur at Compañia David Campos from 1988 to 2013. During visits to the Philippines, Sabas was invited to give master classes at Philippine Ballet Theatre in 1995, and assisted Campos when he was commissioned to create original works for Ballet Manila between 1996 and 1997.

With the Ballet David Campos, she designed costumes for Petrushka,Rock Requiem, Masque of the Red Death, 2002, Ne Neh le Dej, 2004, Eurasia, 2004, The Nutcracker, 2004, Don Quixote, 2005, Turn Me On, 2006, Sleeping Beauty, 2009, and Giselle, 2010. She also coproduced the Spanish-Philippine Dance Project with Ballet David Campos, bringing Campos’s Giselle and The Sleeping Beauty to the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2012.Written by Desiree P. Medina

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
SACLAG, ALONZO b. Lubuagan, Kalinga 4 Aug 1942. Kalinga musician, dancer, and performance artist. Saclag is also a cultural worker who advocates for the continuity of Kalinga culture in modern contexts. As expected of someone who grew up in a village in which culture was learned face-to-face among kindreds, Alonzo Saclag was exposed to Lubuagan music traditions that are deeply shared collectively and that have indissoluble link to calendrical and life cycle rituals. He learned his particular Kalinga culture by imitation, mastering instrumental music and dance, the latter of which is an essential ingredient in village ceremonies being a profound expression of sociability in a close-knit community.

As a passionate advocate of his own cultural heritage, Saclag had extolled members of his community to preserve their traditional material culture, archaeological sites, and even reinvented a new form of bodong (peace pact) in which customary retribution or justice is not applied at the tribal group level but is individually addressed. Clearly a modern subject with an individual consciousness, Saclag’s aspiration to move his culture beyond static tradition is manifest is his advocacies. He convinced the provincial government of Kalinga to convert and finance the transformation of an abandoned Capitol Building into a museum of heritage, which is now a branch of the National Museum. Moreover, in 2009, he founded a School of Living Tradition that was partly supported by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

He also tirelessly campaigned in schools to press the issue on maintaining a strong ethnic identity despite the modern origin of the institution of formal schooling, so much so that he introduced the practice of children wearing the Kalinga costume during important events like graduation ceremonies and even during the Catholic rite of first communion. Another innovation that was consistently a part of his effort to bolster indigenous expressions has been mission of intensifying the singing of folk songs in Kalinga classrooms and, remarkably, putting up skits and other artistic performances that mix old and new elements in a number of schools. In addition, he aspired for the broadcast of traditional Kalinga music alongside contemporary music in the local radio station.

To concretize his effort in moving his culture in a sustainable manner in modern contexts, he founded the Kalinga Budong Dance Troupe where he teaches the youth their local music and dance. Since this dance company now tours in cities beyond the village, i.e., it now circulates beyond its traditional place of origin, it is envitable that artistic hybridity has resulted in Saclag’s projects.

For his artistry, cultural advocacy, and influence, Saclag was conferred the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan in 2000. Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Fe Sala-Villarica

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
SALA-VILLARICA, FE ( Fe Escaño Sala-Villarica ) b. Barcelona, Spain 16 Oct 1922 d. 11 Apr 2015. Choreographer, director. Born in Spain to Juan Sala and Bernabela Escaño, she grew up in Cebu. She began to study ballet there with Mara Selheim, a Russian emigré, then moved to Manila, took lessons with AnitaKane and later became a member of her Anita Kane Ballet. She earned her degree in commerce, summa cum laude, from St. Scholastica’s College in 1941 and her master of arts in literature from the University of San Carlos in Cebu. She did graduate work in accounting, and trained in TV production at New York University and stage lighting at Hunter College, USA.

In ballet, Sala-Villarica trained abroad with Thalia Mara at the National Academy of Ballet, at John Barker School (Vaganova method), and the Royal Academy of Dancing, all in New York. In 1990 she attended a teachers’ workshop at the Vaganova Choreographic Institute in Leningrad.

In 1951 she founded the BalletCenter in Cebu which, in 1956, came up with a full production of Giselle,six years after the first Philippine production in Manila. She also produced the complete Nutcracker in 1962, four years after Kane’s production in Manila. In 1962 she organized the Queen City Junior Ballet, a spin-off from BalletCenter. She also founded the Arts Council of Cebu in 1962; the Teatro Folklorico in 1981; Balletcenter West in San Diego, California, in 1986; and Queen City Metropolitan Ballet Theatre, a performing company envisioned to stage classical ballet pieces and raise the level of skills of dancers by offering workshops in different levels of ballet and contemporary dance.

Among her important works are the neoclassical The Diadem to music by Mendelssohn; the contemporary Zodiac to Gershwin; The Santo Niño, 1965, with libretto and direction by James Reuter, SJ for the quadricentennial of Catholicism in the Philippines; and Philippine Panorama,1969. The last is made up of “Recuerdos de Maria Clara” (Souvenirs of Maria Clara) on the genteel social life in the Spanish era, “Irisan,” on customs and dances of the Mountain Province, Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura) based on Francisco Balagtas’s metricalromance, and Cross and Crescent, depicting the struggle between Muslims and Christians that is the material of thekomedyaandmoro-moro. She continued to create ballet productions just before she died at the age of 92.

Sala-Villarica has been cited in World Who’s WhoofWomen,Cambridge, 1981, and by the American Biographic Institute for her leadership in the arts. For “exerting the longest and most consistent effort among ballet teachers in the Visayas to raise the art to its highest achievement in the southern Philippines,” she has been cited by the City of Cebu as one of its Outstanding Women. Her achievements have also been cited by the Zonta Club, the Arts Council of Cebu, the Cebu Jaycees, Malacañan Palace, 1977, by way of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines, and the Philippine Ballet Theatre, 1988.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ballet dancer training with Jun Samblaceño, right, 2011, New Zealand

(Photo by Melissa Irving)

Jun Samblaceño with Maiqui Mañosa in Philippine Ballet Theatre’s Camille

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
SAMBLACEÑO, JUN ( Vivencio Manalang Samblaceño Jr ) b. Manila 01 Feb 1965. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. He is the eldest child of Vivencio Bonani Samblaceño Sr and Remedios Largo Manalang. His mother was a retired government midwife and a part-time piano teacher. His only sibling, Medge Samblaceño, is a graphic designer. Jun Samblaceño is married to dancer Sonya Kaye Behrnes. He finished elementary and high school education at the Ateneo de Manila University in 1978 and 1982. He then took a premedicine course in biology at the University of Santo Tomas which he did not complete because he decided to pursue a dance career. At age 14 he was accompanying his sister to ballet classes when Vella C. Damian saw his potential and persuaded him to take up ballet. In 1997 he enrolled in Damian’s School of Ballet and Dance Arts where many boys had joined ballet classes as part of their training in figure skating. From 1979 to 1985, he rose to become the principal dancer of the Dance Concert Company under the tutelage of Eric V. Cruz and Damian. His other mentors were Felicitas Layag-Radaic and Basilio Esteban Villaruz under Dance Theater Philippines, where he was a lead dancer. He joined workshops organized by the Royal Academy of Dance with Ballet Philippines in the early 1980s.

In 1981, he was principal dancer ina Visions in Blue and Mosque Baroque, choreographed by Cruz and Villaruz respectively; and danced the role of King of the Sea Creatures in The Black Pearl by Damian. In 1983-84, he interpreted the roles of Conde de Luna in La Gitana, Armand Duval in Camille, Don Jose and Escamillo in Carmen, all choreographedby Cruz. In 1988, he danced as Albrecht paired with Liza Macuja in Philippine Ballet Theatre’s Giselle by Radaic and Sonia Domingo.

Passing the evaluations of major ballet companies in Singapore and New Zealand in 1988 was a turning point in his career. He opted to join the Royal New Zealand Ballet (RNZB) which became his resident company for 20 years. In 1988-89, he was Bluebird in Aurora’s Wedding and danced roles in Bliss, Do-Wack-A-Do, Romeo and Juliet, and A Servant of Two Masters. He gained “full marks” among critics as Death in Orpheus. In the early 1990s, he was praised in act 2’s grand pas de deux of the Nutcracker; the pas de trois in Hamlet; and portrayals of Herald of Death in Wolfgang Amadeus and Blackamoor in Petrouchka.In the company’s tours to Europe and the USA critics hailed his range “from gentle naïveté to brutality with terrifying intensity” as The Man in Tell Me a Tale.In 1995, he was Romeo in Romeo and Juliet.In the 2000s, Samblaceño was among the RNZB’s senior dancers recognized for hisdepth of technique and appeal in any given role, like Lord Capulet in Romeo and Juliet, 2003 and 2008, and Cinderella’s Father in Cinderella, 2007.

After his retirement from the RNZB in 2007, he became active in the promotion of Philippine history, arts, and culture sponsored of the Philippine Embassy or spearheaded by Filipino expats. He began teaching at the RNZB’s studios in the St James Theatre, the Whitireia Performing Arts Centre, and the Chilton Dance Centre in Wellington. He is recognized as one of the prominent Filipino New Zealanders orKiwiPinos.Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Georgette Sanchez in Ballet Philippines’s Encantada

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Georgette Sanchez and Karl Schreiner performing Noces at the Festspielhaus in St. Pölten, Austria, 2003

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Georgette Sanchez, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
SANCHEZ, GEORGETTE ( Georgina Johanna Garcia Sanchez-Vargas )b. Bacolod City 28 Dec 1974. Dancer, choreographer. The daughter of George Sanchez and Jane Frances Garcia. Her mother, a dancer, inspired her to dance. Sanchez is also related to choreographer and mentor Agnes Locsin, dancers Caesar “Sonny” Locsin and Ma. Gileanna Janella S. Sanson (Gianne Sanchez). She is married to Luis Vargas. In 1993, she graduated from St. Scholastica’s College with a degree in Hotel and Restaurant Management.

She trained under Noordin Jumalon and William Morgan at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School in Manila from 1991 to 1992, and at the same time joined Ballet Philippines (BP) II from 1991 to 1995. She became a company member of BP from 1995 to 2001. In 2001 she obtained her bachelor of performing arts, major in dance and minor in ballet, from De La Salle University-College of St. Benilde, Manila. Sanchez went to St Poelten, Austria to join the ABC Dance Company from 2002 to 2005, and again danced with the company in Geneva from 2006 to 2007. She returned to the Philippines in 2008, performing with BP once again for one year. In 2009, she went to Darmstadt, Germany, to join Tanztheater Darmstadt for two years, 2009 to 2010, and then joined the Staadtheater Klagenfurt in Austria in 2011. From 2012 to 2013, she became a member of Staatstheater Am Gaertnerplatz in Munich, Germany. She is currently teaching at the Garcia-Sanchez School of Dance in Bacolod.

Sanchez has performed many principal roles in works by important choreographers in the Philippines. These include: Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress) as shaman, 1993, and Encantada, 1992 and 2012; Roll Over Beethoven, 1993; Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1993; Noche Buena, 1994; Elias, 1996; Four Last Songs and Igorot both in 1998; Sayaw LikhAng Kiukok, 2005; Balyan (Shaman),2006; La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution),1996, 1997, and 2008; September, 2009; Sayaw Sabel (Dance of Sabel),2010; and Alay sa Puno Series, Ikalawang Galaw “Dahon” (Tribute to Trees Series, Second Movement “Leaf”)and Ikatlong Galaw “Puno” (Third Movement “Tree”), 2012, a collaboration between Locsin, Sanchez, and Gaye Galiluyo.

For choreographer Denisa Reyes, she performed in Rites of Spring, 1993; Sama Sama: Dance and Video (All Together: Dance and Video), 1997; Te Deum (God, We Praise You), both in 1999; Fire Water Woman, choreographed with Alden Lugnasin, 2002; and Realizing Rama as Sita, 2002. She also danced in Dwight Rodrigazo’s Ideal Reality and Women Unbound,1994; Rheda Beintefor’s Les Petite Mots D’Amour (Small Words of Love), 1994; Lionel Hoche’s Petite Piece d’Exterieur (Small Outside Room), 1995; Alden Lugnasin’s Swimming, the Ilog Pasig (Swimming, the Pasig River), 1997, Swans, Fluttering Disturbances, 1998, Aku (I), 2009, and Ulaging (Epic), 2009; Tony Fabella’s Prince of the Pagodas, 1998 and 1999; Myra Beltran’s Payatas, 2001; Boi Sakti’s Before the Coming of the Dark, 2001; Paul Morales’s Stilleto, 2001; Alan Hineline’s Coppelia, 2008; Max Luna’s KatiTaog (a combination ofkati,or low tide, andtaog, or high tide), 2009; and Alice Reyes’s Amada, 2009.

Sanchez danced in works by various choreographers during her stay in Austria and Germany. Some of these works are Claudi Bombardo’s Approximate Waltz, 2003, The Loop, 2004, and Supper, The Last, 2005; Nicolas Musin’s Tristan and Isolde, 2002, Carmen, 2004, The Magic Night, 2004, Concerto Barroco, 2005, and Trans-Warhol, 2007; Jo Stromgren’s Halfway to Ural, 2003; Gustavo Ramirez’s One For All, 2003; Karole Armitage’s 10 Poems, 2003; Angelin Prejlocaj’s Noces (Wedding), 2003; Montalvo-Hervieu’s Les Mitrailleuses en etat de Grace (Machine Guns in State of Grace), 2003; Karl Schreiner’s Blame It On Gavrilo, 2005, Der Nussknacker (The Nutcracker), 2011, and Dornroschen (Sleeping Beauty), 2013; Willam Forsythe’s The Vile Parody of Address, 2005; Mei Hong Lin’s Swanengesang (Swan Song),2009, and Blind Date, 2010; Jorhan Kresnik’s Ulrike Meinhof, 2010; Karl Schreiner and Edward Clug’s Memento Mori (Remember Death/Remember to Die), 2013; and Karl Schreiner, Jo Stromgren, and Georg Reischl’s Minute Made, 2013.

She was awarded the Silver Medal during the 9th Concours International de Danse de Paris (Paris International Modern Dance Competition), 2000, the Most Outstanding Benildean Alumni by De La Salle University-College of St. Benilde, Manila, 2007, the Gawad Buhay Award of Philstage for Best Female Lead Performer in Agnes Locsin’s Encantada,2011, and the Trudl Dubsky-Zipper Special Award for Choreography by the National Music Competitions for Young Artists, 2011.Written by Angella Betina Carlos

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Katherine Sanchez-Trofeo, center, in Ballet Philippines's Don Quixote, 2011

(Photo by Paul Morales, courtesy of the artist)

Katherine Sanchez-Trofeo

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
SANCHEZ-TROFEO, KATHERINE ( Katherine Cuello Sanchez-Trofeo ) aka Kit Sanchez, Kit Trofeo. b. Manila 27 Jul 1978. Dancer. Daughter of Aniceto Celzo Sanchez and Imelda Cuello, she is the wife of sound recordist Raymundo “Ari” Trofeo, with whom she has a son. Sanchez-Trofeo studied dance at the Ballet Repertory in San Juan, 1986 to 1992, with Amelia Garcia-Yulo, and as scholar of the Philippine High School for the Arts in Los Baños Laguna, 1991-94. She turned professional at 15, performing in Enrico Labayen’s experimental Lab., Projekt Philippines,1993-94 and 2003-05; and Myra Beltran’s Dance Forum,1994-95 and 2003-05. Their mentorship was critical to the kind of dancer Trofeo would become.

She performed in much of the repertoire of the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) between 1998 to 2007, including Tom Pazik’s Tzigane in Morroco, and Jean Paul Comelin’s Daughters of Mourning, in Madrid, Spain. Other important roles include Esmeralda in the Asian premiere of The Hunchback of Notre Dame, 2003, Nikiya in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer),2004, Cio Cio San in Pazik’s Madame Butterfly,2004, Odette/Odile in Swan Lake,2005, and Clara in The Nutcracker,2007.

Moving to Ballet Philippines (BP) in 2008, Trofeo was initiated into the company with Agnes Locsin’s La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution),2008. She was cast as Swanilda in Coppelia,2008, and the Tadtarin in Alice Reyes’s Amada,2008. Trofeo premiered Carlo Pacis’s Shifting Wait,2010, and Mithi (Ambition), 2011, performed Aurora in Sleeping Beauty,Babaylan in Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress), Kitri in Don Quixote, Maria Clara in the restaging of Paul Morales’s Crisostomo Ibarra, 2012, and Sita in Alice Reyes’s Rama, Hari (Rama, King).She also danced with Nicolas Pacaña for his swan song performances in Romeo and Juliet, 2012. In 2013, Trofeo created the role of Titania for Pacis’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, and was highly praised by critics, as was her portrayal of Giselle.Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

text:
SANDOVAL, LUCIO b. Manila 7 May 1911. d. Quezon City 3 Nov 1990. Dancer, choreographer. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP), major in fine arts, in 1937. From its beginning in 1937, he danced with the FranciscaReyes-Aquino’s UPFolkSongandDanceClub. Later, he danced with the US Armed Forces’ Filipiniana group, touring many military camps. He was famous for his Manobo eagle dance. He also performed for TrudlDubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne, 1929 to 1941, and her post-World War II productions for the ManilaSymphonySociety. During the war, Sandoval danced with Patria Panahon in LambertoAvellana’s stage shows at the Avenue Theater. At the Metropolitan Theater, he choreographed the dances for Verdi’s Rigoletto in 1943.

With the Far Eastern Entertainment Enterprises and along with KatydelaCruz and his partner Aida Angeles, he danced in an extensive national tour in 1948, called Fil-Americana under the direction of Donna Murphy and Dolores Gregory. He continued to dance at the ManilaGrandOperaHouse in the 1950s in the choreographies of Bobby Salvador and Jack Jacinto.

On his own, Sandoval directed the Sinagtala Philippine Dance Group in the 1960s, creating folk-based choreographies, such as Mindanao Orchids in Bloom, Luzonian Moods, Visayan Vintages, Maria Clara Wentto Town, and Moderne Maria Claras Dancing.

He also appeared in films, dancing the tinikling in American Guerrilla in the Philippines and in DanceBeat,a 20th Century Fox short feature. Much later, he choreographed for various presentations.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayaw

(Photo courtesy of Philippine High School for the Arts)

Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayaw

(Photo courtesy of Philippine High School for the Arts)

Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayaw

(Photo courtesy of Philippine High School for the Arts)

text:
SANGHIYAS PANGKAT MANANAYAW ( SPM ) Founded in 1992, Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayawis the resident Folk Dance Troupe of the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA), a secondary school devoted to arts education and located at the National Arts Center in Mount Makiling, Los Baños, Laguna. The students are scholars through six years in their field of specialization. It is administratively under the Department of Education, while its artistic programs are under the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

When it was founded in Jun 1977, the PHSA focused on classical ballet training but realizing the need for traditional dance, Josefina B. Guillen, then deputy director for dance of the CCP, developed and implemented the school’s program for folk dance starting in 1986. In 1992, Victor Emmanuel L. Flor, resident dance faculty, established the SPM composed of folk dance majors. It was named “Sanghiyas,” fromisangandhiyasmeaning “one gem.” Since then, SPM has travelled locally and internationally to showcase the cultural traditions of the Filipinos. They have performed in Taiwan, Italy, Monaco, Belgium, Brunei Darussalam, Vietnam, Singapore, and Korea.

SPM joined or facilitated workshops with some of the leading dance groups, like Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo, Sining Kumintang of Batangas, UP Dance Company of University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, CCP Dance School of Ballet Philippines, Leyte Dance Theater, and Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company. Through their program called Bisita Guro (Visiting Masters), SPM members and staff meet important personalities in Philippine dance, such as the late National Artist Ramon Arevalo Obusan, Corazon G. Iñigo, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Teresita Pil, Jess de Paz, and Larry A. Gabao.

SPM has continuously performed Filipino folk dances to preserve and promote them. It provides dance students the necessary skills and discipline to empower them as artists.

When possible, members of SPM train in basic ballet and modern dance and other dance forms like flamenco, hip-hop, and ballroom. They also venture into creative dance, new traditions in folk dance theater, retro folk, and neo-folk withkatutubo(indigenous) perspectives. Sanghiyas alumni go into higher education in dance in UP Diliman, De La Salle-College of St. Benilde, and Hong Kong Academy of the Performing Arts, or join dance companies in the country.

In 2013, SPM won first prize in the 2013 Sayaw Pinoy Folk Dance Competition among 20 groups in the country.Written by Josefina B. Guillen

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Tina Santos as the title character in Ballet Federation of the Philippines’s Cinderella, 1978

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Tina Santos with Eddie Elejar

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)
Tina Santos in Christensen's Scarlatti Portfolio, 1979

text:
SANTOS, TINA ( Florentina Revilla Santos-Wahl ) b. Manila 12 Jun 1948. Dancer, teacher. Daughter of Ernesto Santos and former movie actor Teresita Revilla, she has three sisters in the arts: Cecile, a Broadway dancer-singer, Ditas and Joji, both dancers. She married premier danseur Gary Wahl in 1975.

Santos started ballet with JojiFelix-Velarde and EddieElejar, who became her longtime dance partner, and later with Poul Gnatt, TonyLlacer, and IsraelGabriel. For a time before becoming a full-fledged dancer, she acted and danced in musical comedies at St. Paul’s College and for RepertoryPhilippines, toured as a fashion model, and appeared on television.

In the 1970s, she was the prima ballerina of Dance Theater Philippines while dancing lead roles in the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company (now Ballet Philippines). She played lead roles in Julie Borromeo’s Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila) and Kalingan,Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s Oy, Akin ’Yan! (Hey, That’s Mine!) and Tanan (Elopement), Elejar’s Katakata Sin Rajah Indarapatra (Stories of Rajah Indarapatra), Llacer’s Les Patineurs (The Skaters) and In the Beginning,Robin Haig’s La Valse, Gnatt’s Peter and the Wolf and Prismatic Variations, Bournonville’s Flower Festival at Genzano pas de deux, and Alice Reyes’s At a Maranaw Gathering and Amada. She also did William Morgan’s Cinderella for Ballet Federation of the Philippines.

In 1970 she also went to New York, USA, and joined the Harkness Ballet on an extensive European tour. She trained with David Howard, Ben Stevenson, Perry Brunson, Hector Zaraspe, Finis Jhung, Maria Vegh, Elizabeth Carrol, Vicente Nebrada, and the jazz teacher Luigi. With Harkness she rose to principal rank. In 1973 she joined the San Francisco Ballet with her husband, trained with Richard Gibson, Tatiana Grantzeva, Terry Westmoreland, and Alexander Minz and danced with the company until 1980. While with San Francisco Ballet, she inspired Michael Smuin to create the Japanese ballet Shinju, 1975, for her and Wahl.

Aside from dancing in many other Smuin, Lew Christensen, and George Balanchine ballets, she distinguished herself in the works of Jerome Robbins, Robert Gladstein, and Todd Bolender.

Before moving to Florida, USA in the late 1980s, Santos taught in various schools in the San Francisco Bay Area and at Richard Gibson’s Pacific Dance Center. She was a teacher and coach at the Harid Conservatory from 1988 to 1997; one of her pupils won a gold medal in a ballet competition in Helsinki, Finland in 1991.

In the late 1990s she taught ballet and jazz at the New World School of the Arts in Miami where she retired as assistant professor of dance in 2015. Santos has periodically visited the Philippines and taught master classes.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
SANTOS-LANG, SHIRLEY ( Shirley Regalado Santos-Lang )b. Manila 1 Nov 1940. Dancer. Santos-Lang is the daughter of Pablo Santos and Trinidad Regalado. She is married to Heinz Lang with whom she has a daughter. She studied at the Philippine Women’s University for two years. She started ballet training with Kaethe Hauser when she was three and went on to AnitaKane at eight.

She later joined the Anita Kane Ballet for which she danced the role of the Forces of Evil in ReconstructionBallet, 1952. She was a soloist in LaTraviata and Princess Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty, both in 1953. She also danced with Remedios de Oteyza’s ballet company from 1954 to 1956. In 1957 she started dancing with Al Quinn, Jacinto Matunan, and Ric Marcial at the Manila Grand Opera House where they were billed as “Shirley and the Modernaires.” Their signature dance was The Mambo Blues,as choreographed by Jamin Alcoriza. They eventually formed the nucleus of a Filipiniana dance group. Santos-Lang also choreographed and danced in the movies, like MariaWent to Town with PanchoMagalona andTita Duran and Medaliong Perlas (Pearl Medallion) with Nida Blanca. In Jun 1957, she joined Katherine Dunham’s dance company on its Asian tour of Singapore, Hong Kong, Bangkok, and Manila. She and Dinky de la Cruz were the only Filipinos in the show. In 1961 she toured Hong Kong, Japan, Taipei, and Bangkok where, together with Dom Ontaiko, Ramon Zamora, and Al Villegas, they were billed as “Shirley and the Almons.” As one of Heinz Conti’s “Conti Girls,” she toured the Middle East in 1962 and Europe until 1973. In 1979 she returned to the Philippines where she taught ballet from 1980 to 1981 and managed several dancers until 1986. She has retired in the Philippines.Written by Ma. Cherish M. Garcia, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Raul Sauz

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Raul Sauz

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
SAUZ, RAUL ( Raul Leopoldo Figueroa Sauz ) b. 15 Nov 1957 Lipa City, Batangas. Dancer, choreographer, teacher, ballet examiner. He is the son of Antonio Maralit Sauz and Preciosisima Tayting Figueroa. He finished primary education at Our Lady of the Rosary Academy and De La Salle Lipa and completed secondary education at the University of the East (UE) High School. He took AB Sociology in UE. Sauz started ballet training with Joji Felix-Velarde and Exequiel Banzali at the Philippine Women’s University. He took further training with Vella Damian at the School of Ballet and Dance Arts. His other mentors were Tita Radaic, Steve Villaruz, and William Morgan. He also trained as Royal Academy of Dance (RAD) Vocational Examiner with Paula Hunt in Wellington, New Zealand.

Sauz was lead dancer of the UE Dance Troupe under Cora Iñigo and Gener Caringal from 1973 to 1975; at the same time, he was also principal dancer of the Dance Concert Company of Vella Damian and Eric Cruz until 1977. Then he joined Dance Theatre Philippines as lead dancer under the direction of Steve Villaruz and Felicitas Layag- Radaic until 1982. He partnered with Lisa Macuja in Testament, 1980, and in Ode to Boticelli, 1981, bothchoreographed by Basilio.

As choreographer, he created dances for the major recitals of Steps Dance Studio since the mid-1990s that included the restaging of Swan Lake in 2008 and Blue Bird in 2009. He choreographed competition pieces as the ballet master for both Senior and Junior Division of the National Music Competition for Young Artists Ballet Competition.

His teaching career started in 1984 when he taught in various ballet schools like MJM School of Dance, Pink Toes, Perry Sevidal Ballet, and Dance Centre Philippines. In 1995, he became a pioneer faculty member of the Steps Dance Studio. In 2009, he started teaching in Academy One Music and Dance Center. In 2011, he also conducted outreach dance training for teachers in Cagayan de Oro City and Iloilo City under the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

Sauz has mentored award-winning dancers like Marcelino Libao Jr, Mary Beatrice Saludares, Monica Amanda Gana, Anna Margarita Reyes, and Jennifer Olayvar. In 2006, Sauz qualified as examiner of RAD. He is the only Filipino examiner in the prestigious institution which is considered one of the world’s most influential organizations in dance education. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac
