text:
SICANGCO, CECILE ( CeciliaVarela Sicangco-Ibarrola ) b. Bacolod City 25 Nov 1957. Dancer, teacher, director. Her parents are Jose Sicangco Jr and Gloria Varela. Eduardo, her brother, is a New York-based stage and costume designer. She is married to dancer Jinn Ibarrola. She began training at age 5 under Mellie Hojilla and later with Lydia Madarang-Gaston. In 1969, she started attending the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance Workshop, and in 1973, became a member of Ballet Philippines (BP). In 1976, she studied at the American Ballet Center in New York, where she trained with David Howard. She rejoined BP in 1980, and started to dance the lead roles in Swan Lake, Giselle, Firebird, Coppelia, La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), The Nutcracker, and in modern works like Songs of a Wayfarer, Season of Flight, Amada, Nuances, Ang Sultan (The Sultan), Love Lies Bleeding, and Encantada (Enchantress).

In 1986, Sicangco was appointed BP’s rehearsal mistress. In 1987, with Osias Barroso, she attended the pedagogical seminar in dance in Varna, Bulgaria. In the same year, she was among the featured artists who performed with the Stars of the American Ballet at the CCP. In 1989, she became BP’s associate artistic director and its artistic director in 1996-99. In Jul 1990, along with Brando Miranda and other artists from the San Francisco Ballet, Royal Swedish Ballet, and Paris Opera Ballet, she guested in a tour of the Royal Ballet of New Zealand. In 1995, BP sent her to New York to study the Pilates Method of body conditioning at The Pilates Studio and Drago’s Gym, under the guidance of master teacher Romana Kryzanowska. In the same year, she became the country’s first certified Pilates instructor. She now owns and manages with her husbandthe first Pilates studio in the country, Integrated Body Arts, established in 1996 in Makati City. In 1997, she danced Juliet in Agnes Locsin’s Romeo and Juliet, a production with sets and costumes designed by her brother Eduardo. In BP’s Giselle, 1999, she and Lisa Macuja alternated with Toni Lopez Gonzalez as Giselle. In 2002, BP presented a tribute to her, Joie de Danse that featured its best performances directed by French choreographers. Sicangco’s final performances include a solo titled Au Fille duMes Nuits (Woman of My Nights) choreographed for her by Redha, and a new pas de deux, Eden, choreographed for her by French artist Guillaume Compain, both in 2002.

In 1990 she was conferred the Negros Occidental Centennial Medal of Honor for her contributions to dance. She received the City of Manila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award in 1993. In 2010, she was the recipient of the Outstanding Negrenses Artists Award for dance.Written by Emilie B. Capulong, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Silliman University Dance Troupe

(Photo from facebook.com/SUDC071213/)

Silliman University Dance Troupe

(Photo from facebook.com/SUDC071213/)

text:
SILLIMAN UNIVERSITY DANCE TROUPE ( SUDT )It was founded in 1962 by Lucy Patrimonio-Jumawan and based at the Silliman University (SU) School of Music’s ballet studio which Jumawan instituted. She directed SUDT until 1968, after which she migrated to Australia. She attributes her training to Anita Kane and Ricardo Cassell in the Philippines, and to Ted Shawn’s famous Jacob’s Pillow in Massachusetts, where Silliman dancer Ted Leyson had also trained. After Jumawan, there came choreographic contributions from Shona MacTavish from 1968 to early 1970s. From New Zealand, MacTavish trained in Central European modern dance called Ausdruckstanz (expressive dance). She also choreographed for Dance Theatre Philippines and several interfaith productions in Manila, Cebu, and Dumaguete, and did some field research in ethnic dance in Mindanao. When she left, Gwen Schofield from Australia briefly directed SUDT. Like MacTavish, she was also schooled in Ausdruckstanz through Austrian Gertrude Bodenweiser who had migrated to Australia. (Bodenweiser was the main teacher of Trudl Dubsky-Zipper who, with Kaethe Hauser, brought that school and style to Manila in the 1930s.) In an interview in 1978, Schofield confessed how SUDT’s local choreographers were “healthily different” from her. Among these were Miguel Braganza (now in the US) and the Serion sisters, Luwalhati and Liwayway. Later becoming directors, the sisters got to be respectively known as Campoy and Arabe by their married names. In those early days, the troupe toured the Visayas and Mindanao, and joined the First National Ballet Festival in 1976 at the Folk Arts Theater in Manila. Liwayway Serion-Arabe directed SUDT up to 1996, after which the group went moribund. In its active years, it had Junix Inocian and Lu Decenteceo among its technical directors.

In 2004, Dean Joseph Basa of the SU College of Performing Arts revived the group. It was renamed SU Kahayag Dance Troupe (SUKDT) and was under the direction of Ronnie Mirabuena, assisted by Swyline de Jesus. It set a folkloric and contemporary dance repertoire. Among these were Tala Na, Biyahe Ta (Let’s Go on a Trip), 2005; Sandurot (Unity and Sharing), 2007; Panata (Pledge) on Filipino spirituality, 2007; Mansuba: Sentinel of Paradise,2008, based on Manobo and Inagta (of Negros Oriental) practices. Through those years, SUKDT performed in the Visayas, Bicol, and Mindanao, and joined festivals like the CCP’s Sari-Saring Sayaw, Sama-Samang Galaw (Varied Dances, Together in Moves). It also joined festivals in Macao, 2006 and Nanning, China, 2007; CCP’s Pasinaya (Inauguration),2008; and the Contemporary Dance Network’s WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festivalat the CCP, 2010. At the end of 2011, Mirabuena left and Engel Boen Zerna became director up to 2013. Around that time, the group went back to its original name SUDT. In 2014, a new director took over—Angelo Sayson, former director of Kabilin Dance Troupe of the Negros Oriental State University.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Sining Kumintang ng Batangas performing at a town fiesta in Balayan, Batangas, 2017

(Photo courtesy of SKB)

Sining Kumintang ng Batangas on tour in the United States, 2010

(Photo courtesy of SKB)

Sining Kumintang ng Batangas

(Photo courtesy of SKB)

Sining Kumintang ng Batangas, 2017

(Photo courtesy of SKB)

Bayanihan Show, Cultural Center of the Philippines, 2017

(Photo courtesy of SKB)

text:
SINING KUMINTANG NG BATANGAS ( SKB ) Conceived by Engr Vicente P. Cordero, President of the Bauan High School of Bauan, Batangas, the Sining Kumintang ng Batangas was formally organized as the official group of the school in 1992. Cecile Cordero Diaz, a former member of the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company and current artistic director of SKB, initiated the training of the students with some Bayanihan dancers. Bayanihan dancer Delfin Novencido was the first artistic and dance director of SKB. The group was further guided and inspired by National Artist Dr Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, artistic director of Bayanihan, who developed and shared Bayanihan’s repertoire and style with them. In 1992, the group was granted an official Certificate of Affiliation with the Bayanihan Folk Arts Association. SKB is composed of high school students and alumni of Bauan High School. The students have to maintain above-average grades to be retained in the group. The alumni stay to assist rehearsal masters, teach the dances to the new members, and dance the difficult roles in the repertoire.

In 1994, SKBperformed for the Ramon Magsaysay Awards.In 1995, the group had its premiere performance at the CulturalCenter of the Philippines (CCP) with its first full production, Herencia: AngKumintang (Heritage: The Kumintang).SKB is active as a performing group in thedifferent projects of the CCP, such as Pang-alay (Offering),1995-96; HiyasngLahi (Gems of the Race), 1997-98; World Folklore Festival,1998; IndayngBayanihan,Indayng Bayan (Inday of Bayanihan, Inday of the Nation): Tribute to National Artist for Dance Dr.LucreciaReyes-Urtula, 1999; Sari-SaringSayaw, Sama-SamangGalaw (Different Dances, Moving Together), 2006; and Pasinaya: CCP Open House Festival (Inauguration: CCP Open House Festival), 2010-14. The group was proclaimed the 1997 National Champion in Folk Dancing in the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports Folk Dance competition.

SKB has toured Asia, Europe, and the United States of America. It has participated in folk dance events such as the Conseil International des Organisations de Festivals de Folklore et d’Arts Traditionnels in Israel, 1997; the World Folklore Festival Manila, organized by CIOFF Philippines and the CCP, 1998; International Folklore Festival in the USA, France and Italy, 2000; World Folkloriada in Tokyo, Japan, 2000, where they were proclaimed the Best Performers out of the 73 groups; International Folklore Festival and Folk Arts Fair in Szazhalombatta, Tokol, Rackeve and Budapest, Hungary, 2003, where they received the Best Performing Group Award, and the People’s Choice Award; Beijing International Cultural and Tourism Festival, 2004; World Expo in Aichi, Japan, 2005; performance tours of various cities in the USA, 2006, 2008, 2012; the Italian Festival Tour, 2011; and the Singapore ASEAN Festival, 2012.

SKBoffersfree training workshops on Philippine dance to children in the communities, parishes, and school organizations, fostering cultural awareness among them and developing them into responsible artists and citizens. The group continues the repertoire and legacy of the National Artist Urtula.Written by Josefina B. Guillen

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Sining Palawan Dance Troupe
(Photo courtesy of the troupe)

Sining Palawan Dance Troupe

(Photo courtesy of the troupe)

Sining Palawan Dance Troupe

(Photo courtesy of the troupe)

text:
SINING PALAWAN DANCE TROUPE Founded in 2003, the troupe is based at the Palawan State University (PSU). Considered one of the cultural arms of the Social and Cultural Office of the University, the Palawan Dance Troupe’s aims are to develop and showcase the talent of its performers, to explore and expose Palawan’s traditions, and to experience learning through music and dance. The troupe’s name, “Sining Palawan” or Palawan Art, conveys its vision for cultural development through folk dance performances. Since its establishment, the group has undergone a series of transformations that has allowed it to achieve the status of “Palawan’s premiere university-based dance troupe.”

The group’s repertoire consists of indigenous dances in Palawan, countryside dances, and dances from the southern Philippines. Its productions include Kulta,a contraction ofkultura(culture),tradisyon(tradition), andantolohiya(anthology), 2004; Saut (Dance), 2007; Pamana,(Heritage/Legacy), 2009; Pagdiriwang (Celebration), 2010; Sining… Galing! (Art … Great!), 2011; Pagsilang (Birth), 2011; Naglalakbay (Journey), 2012; and Pagtitipon (Gathering), 2013. The group focuses its research on the dances and cultural practices of the Cuyunon, the primary ethnolinguistic group living in the islands.

From 2006 to 2007, the troupe toured the United States, upon the invitation of the Sam Houston State University in Texas, the Palawan Associations in Las Vegas, Miami, and the Philippine Consulate Offices in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

In 2008, the group was invited to perform for the Department of Tourism in Manila. In 2012, the group also performed at the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ Filipiniana Sunsets at the CCP, a weekly cultural show featuring community-based and school-based folk dance groups. In 2013, the dance troupe was invited to be one of the performers in Dance Xchange: The Philippine International Dance Festival and Workshop organized bythe National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and held in Puerto Princesa City. The following year, the group joined the Philippine Arts Festival held in Palawan.

The troupe has participated in competitions. In 2006, it joined the 3rd Philippine Association of State Universities and Colleges (PASUC) National Cultural-Literary Festival in Bulacan, winning 1st runner up in the Maria Clara category and 2nd runner up in the Indigenous dance category of Philippine Folk Dance. In 2008, it once again competed in the same festival at the Philippine Normal University, Manila and was declared champion in the traditional dance category. In 2012, the group competed in the Sayaw Pinoy: The National Dance Competition sponsored by the NCCA in Manila and won the Silver Prize. In the same year, the group represented Region IV in the 5th PASUC National Cultural Festival held in Manila and won second place in both the Indigenous and Rural dance categories.

The group’s current Artistic Director is John Christian S. Jardin. The present trainor and dance Mistress are Khristopher de Dios and Luigi Lauron-Marco, respectively.Written by Franz Edric Bangalan

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Sining Pananadem

(Photo from facebook.com/pg/msu.siningpananadem)

text:
SINING PANANADEM Founded in 1988 by SamoSaripBalt. Its first artistic director was RamonObusan and among its choreographers is Khayroden “Marlon” Pangkat. With the return of Maranao religious scholars from the Middle East in the early 1980s, rigid Islamic standards of behavior became the norm in Maranao society. Native songs, dances, and rituals were threatened. Believing this to be contrary to the Islamic ideal of allowing the free flourishing of society, SiningPananadem was organized to save and protect Maranao cultural expressions and heritage. Despite conservative resistance, even harassment, Balt and the group have won regional and national recognition.

In 1988, its songs, dances, and ceremonials were documented by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). In 1989 and 1990, it performed for the CCP’s annual Pang-alay festival in Manila. Its programs there were also aired on television. In 1989, it earned a local touring grant from the CCP’s outreach and exchange program; it visited communities in Marawi and the rest of Lanao del Sur. In 1990, it conducted lecture-demonstrations in Manila, and, in 1991, toured Luzon and the Visayas.

It was in 1989 that Sining Pananadem gained recognition from the Mindanao State University in Marawi as a performing group under the Office of Cultural Affairs. In 1991, it ventured into the preservation of Maranao music with the Development Education Media Services Foundation of Davao City. Recorded songs from the project were distributed worldwide. The group also helped organize Inandang Fokloric, a dance group under Ismael Cali, and Sowara Maranaw, a choral group under Macaangkos Tocalo. These two serve local artists in different communities in Lanao del Sur.

In its established repertoire are: Sindao sa Gagawii (on Maranao courtship and lifestyle), Pananadem (remembrance), Kambae (crowning a noble lady), Kapranon (Maranao songs, dances, games, rituals, chants, and music), Sinar (Maranao music fused with Western music), Kariala (feast), Khakawing (wedding), and Kandatu (crowning a king), all staged between 1988 and 1990.In 2015, the troupe performed during the 25th anniversary of the Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao.Written by Samo Balt, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
SISON-FRIESE, JOVITA ( Jovita Abdon Sison-Friese )b. 16 Feb 1921. Director, scholar, choreographer. Born to Ricardo Sison and Valeriana Abdon, both of Lingayen, Pangasinan, Sison-Friese graduated from the Philippine Normal School and the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), major in home economics. She shifted her interest to physical education after training at the National College of Physical Education. She went back to PWU for graduate work. Her master’s thesis was on unpublished Philippine folkdances.

Inspired by the work of FranciscaReyes-Aquino, Sison-Friese mingled with the old folk of her home province to learn their dances. Out of many years of study and observation, she wrote a book, Philippine Folk Dances from Pangasinan,published in 1980. Serafin Aquino, former superintendent of physical education at the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports, introduced the book, saying it opened another dimension in Pangasinan dances.

Sison-Friese was an outstanding teacher of physical education, especially of folk dances, in the city schools of Manila and the National College of Physical Education. After migrating to the United States in the late 1960s, she continued to teach folk dances with unwavering commitment to authenticity. In 1971 she organized the Fil-Am Family Cultural Group in Los Angeles, California. In 1991, on its 20th anniversary, the group gave a grand show with her as overall director and choreographer.In recognition of her efforts to promote Philippine culture in the US, Sison-Friese has been accorded the Lifetime Achievement Award by the Tri-Media Group of Companies. She has also received the Meritorious Service Award for the Promotion of Philippine Culture, Merit Award on Children’s Dance Group, the Fil-Am Cultural Group’s Outstanding Civic Service Award, and a citation from Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles.Written by Prosperidad M. Arandez

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
SOKKONG, BENICIO (Benicio Damagon Sokkong) aka Benny or Beni Sokkong. b. Lepanto, Benguet 23 Aug 1955. Kalinga dancer, musician, music instrument-maker, researcher. His family originated from Tabuk, Kalinga, Northern Philippines. He had his early schooling in the public schools in Lepanto, then took dentistry at De Ocampo Memorial College. A performer and arranger of Kalinga indigenous music and dance, and maker of Kalinga musical instruments, he has been a lecturer at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music from 1986 to early 2000. Through the UP College of Music, he had the chance to participate and perform in international conferences and festivals. This was the time he realized the importance of his culture, and led him to establish the Cordillera Music Tutorial and Research Center (CMTRC) based in Baguio City in the 1990s. He was the organizer and leader of “Pasiking I & II.” He also served as project coordinator of two documentaries on the Kalinga, both produced by the Philippine Information Agency. He has written a manual on the playing of Kalinga bamboo instruments and Kalinga music.

Sokkong has performed as guest artist in the Black Current Aboriginal Arts Festival in Taiwan, 1986; the Asia-Pacific Music Festival in Germany, France, Switzerland, and Italy, 1988; the Seventh Tokyo Music Joy in Tokyo, Japan, 1991; and the Asia-Pacific Festival in Wellington, New Zealand, 1992. In 1999, he represented the Kalinga at the Philippine Folk Festival at the Smithsonian Institute, Washington, and received grants from the Asian Cultural Center in 1999 for a project with the University of Hawaii at Manoa, and in 2000, for Asia Society.

Benny Sokkong and the Pasiking Ensemble performed in Tawag ng Bantula (Bantula's Call),a three-day National Bamboo Music Festival sponsored by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and the Musicological Society of the Philippines (MSP) in 2005. In addition, he performed and conducted several workshops with the CMTRC members in Ani ng Sining (Art's Harvest),2006; in Tam-awan International Arts Festival in Baguio City, Gyeongju World Traditional Piri Festival (“Manpasikjeok”) in Korea, at the UST (with Aga Mayo Butocan), and at the 22nd Conference on Western Visayas History and Culture in Oton, Iloilo, all in 2011; in the First International Bamboo Festival at Maasin, Iloilo in 2013; and in the international conference, The Folk Performing Arts in the Asean, held at the Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn Anthropology Centre, Bangkok, Thailand in 2015.

Sokkong collaborated with other singers in workshops and concerts in Secret Sounds, a project in throat-singing and mouth harps with Leo Tadagawa from Japan and Mark van Tongeren from Netherlands in 2011. The project was exhibited at the Adam Art Gallery in Victoria University of Wellington. He also collaborated with the Cordillera Fusion Collective and CMTRC performers, St Louis University Cultural Performance Group, and Sagada High school teachers and students in the music video Echoes, which was created by Toby Finlayson and Joel Westlake, and which was an outcome of a three-week cultural development program with indigenous peoples in Baguio City and Sagada in 2012. Music majors from the UP College of Music also trained with Sokkong in Baguio City in 2015 as part of a Jose Maceda Project Series. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Josephine Baradas

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ricardo Cassell’s Studio Dance Group, 1950s

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
STUDIO DANCE GROUP Established in 1953 by RicardoandRobertaCassell. During that time, students studied ballet only to gain a social grace and/or to teach ballet. The Cassells recognized that the development of the full potential of Philippine ballet dancers depended on professionalizing ballet. To encourage ballet as a career, it was, and still is, necessary to provide an environment in which not only the wealthy and socially prominent participate, but more importantly, gifted persons dedicated to the art are provided opportunities to dance. The aim of Studio Dance Group was to help these dancers grow to take their rightful place as professionals and mature artists.

The StudioDanceGroup developed a substantial repertoire during its relatively short life, 1953 to 1955. Giselle, Swan Lake, GraduationBall, The Transgressor, Beauty and the Beast, FifthSymphony, The MerryWives ofWindsor,and others were performed by the group.Written by R. Cassell

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Dolores Suzara
Dolores Suzara

text:
SUZARA, DOLORES ( Dolores Morales-Suzara )b. Manila 6 Sep 1935. Teacher, director. The daughter of Damaso and Engracia Morales, she is married to Jose Suzara with whom she has six children. As chairperson of the University of San Carlos (USC) Physical Education (PE) department in Cebu City and director of the USC Dance Troupe, Suzara has been active in the promotion of Cebuano dance, particularly the sinulog.She has judged the annual Sinulog street dancing contests since the 1980s, and the long experience enabled her to draw up workshop materials for the PhilippineFolk DanceSociety (PFDS). From 1987 to 1991, she was a resource person for Cebuano dances of the PFDS, of which she has also been vice-president. She also served as vice-president of the Philippine Association of Physical Education and Sports for Girls and Women, president of the Cebu PE Club, treasurer of the Olympic Society of Cebu, chairperson for dance of the Cebu Federation of the Arts Foundation, and was an active member of the World Dance Alliance (Asia-Pacific area). She compiled a collection of group games in 1975.

Suzara has retired from the USC but continues to advise the university’s dance group. Still active in the Sinulog festival, she has coached a number of choreographers coming from different parts of Cebu. She was also the festival’s project director in 2013.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz and Prosperidad M. Arandez, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Paul Szilard

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Paul Szilard with Nora Kaye

(Photo courtesy of the Dance Magazine Archives)

text:
SZILARD, PAUL b. Budapest, Hungary 24 Aug 1912. d. New York 26 Jul 2013. Dancer, teacher, impresario. The son of a stockbroker, he studied ballet in Budapest, toured with his teacher’s troupe, and then moved to Paris where he trained under prominent émigré teachers Olga Preobrajenska and Roussane Sarkissian, and in London with Stanislas Idzikowski. He married Ariane Pulver, a Swiss modern dancer, and eventually became an American citizen.

In the Philippines, he taught ballet during the Japanese occupation, and staged and danced in ballets and operatic dances in Manila during World War II. Upon the return of the Americans, Szilard opened an officers’ club with a bar which he called Blue Elephant.

As dancer, he performed with Nora Kaye, Colette Marchand, and Sonia Arova worldwide. He presented SwanLake, Sylvia, The Four Seasons, “Dance of the Hours” from La Gioconda,and The MadThinker,among others, at the MetropolitanTheater under the auspices of the Volunteer Social Aid Committee. Among his dancers were RemediosdeOteyza, Cecile Yulo-Locsin, Nadine Vantchuran, and ChloeCruz-Romulo. In 1953 he organized Philippine Art Theater for a production called Ballet Philippines that stylized Philippine folkdances into a ballet theater presentation.

Back in New York, in the mid-1950s, he taught ballet, was invited as a guest artist by Komaki Ballet in Japan, created his company that presented French celebrities Colette Marchand and Milorad Miskovitch in their tour of Japan, and established his production outfit in 1954. His West Side Story was the first English-language musical that toured Japan. In 2007, he was behind the production of the same show in Paris.

Szilard was not only a prominent impresario in New York but also a personal agent of popular ballet dancers such as Violette Verdy. He brought the New York City Ballet to Manila in 1958, the Martha Graham Dance Company in 1974, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in 1977, and Ballet Nuevo Mundo de Caracas, with Filipino dancers ManuelMolina and Gloria Tobilla de la Casa, in 1982. Later, he was the representative of the Martha Graham Dance Company in the United States and eventually became part of the company’s board. For 40 years, he maintained close ties with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, booking the company’s international performances. Although dealing mostly with American companies, Szilard also handled foreign groups performing in the US such as the Dancers of Bali, Madrid’s Ballet Victor, Universal Ballet, and the Bunraku Japanese Doll Theater.

In 1978 he was awarded by the BalletFederationofthePhilippines during the Third National Ballet Festival for his wartime work in the Philippines and his impresario work thereafter. In 2010, for his support for the School of American Ballet, he was given a tribute by the New York City Ballet, and for his invaluable contribution to the world of dance, he was honored by the mayor of Gyor, Hungary. In 2012, the French Ministry of Culture decorated Szilard for his cultural contributions to French society. His autobiography, titled Under My Wings: My Life as an Impresario, was released in 2002.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Carmen Tabije-Andin

(Photo courtesy of Samuele Andin)

text:
TABIJE-ANDIN, CARMEN ( Carmen Evangelista Tabije-Andin ) b. Paoay, llocos Norte 20 Feb 1924. Teacher, scholar. She was born to Pedro Tabije and Antonia Evangelista. She holds an elementary teacher’s course degree from Northern Luzon Teachers’ College and a bachelor of science in education from Northwestern College. Even as she began teaching, she pursued higher studies, obtaining a master of arts in education administration from Arellano University in 1979 and a doctorate degree from Philippine Normal College (PNC). She taught at the National College of Physical Education and Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. She was chairperson for graduate specialization in dance and sports at the PNC and consultant on curriculum and textbook writing for the Department of Education, Culture and Sports (DECS). She is a professor emeritus of the Philippine Normal University.

As a writer, she published Foundations of Physical Education, 1985; The Teaching of Physical Education in Philippine Schools, 1980, revised edition 1985; Organization and Management of Physical Education and Sports, 1982; Aerobics for Fitness and Fun: A Scientific Approach, 1984; Philippine Folk Dance (in animation), Vols I and II, 1987; the MAPE (Music, Arts and Physical Education) series for Grades I-VI, 1990; Philippine Dances: Compiled and Written in Annotations Form, 1993; Teaching Physical Education in the Philippines, 1999; and Teaching Physical Education in Philippine Schools, 2004.

Tabije-Andin founded the Dance Education Association of the Philippines and the National Association of Physical Education and Sports and heads both organizations. She is a board member of the Philippine Folk Dance Society and the Philippine Association of Physical Education and Sports for Girls and Women, and was secretary for the Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation. She was vice-chairperson for the National Committee on Dance of the Presidential Commission on Culture and the Arts for two terms. She is a member of the International Society in Comparative Physical Education and Sports.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Tambuli Cultural Troupe in Bongao, Tawi-Tawi, 2016

(Photo by James Singlador)

Tambuli Cultural Troupe in Bongao, Tawi-Tawi, 2016

(Photo by James Singlador)

Tambuli Cultural Troupe in Bongao, Tawi-Tawi, 2016

(Photo by James Singlador)

text:
TAMBULI CULTURAL TROUPE ( TCT )It was founded in Jun 1974 at the Mindanao State University (MSU) Tawi-Tawi (formerly the Sulu College of Technology and Oceanography), a unit of the MSU in the Sulu archipelago. It is the first dance group in Tawi-Tawi which was organized at the height of martial law in the 1970s when armed conflict also led to the youth’s loss of interest in tradition. Thus, the formation of the group was a positive development, with its aim to revive, stimulate, and sustain interest in Tausug, Sama, Sama Dilaut (Badjao), and Jama Mapun dance, music, and ritual. Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa was the troupe’s founder and director who initiated the granting of academic scholarships to TCT members. Subsequent TCT directors were Mahail Hajan and Sakinur-ain Mugong.

The troupe’s repertoire was based on Fernando Amilbangsa’s field research on dance forms such as the pangalay / igal, lunsay, and langka. Having little more than native talent and enthusiasm to start with, the troupe resorted to borrowing costumes and musical instruments for its early performances. In 1975, its first repertoire was well-received when the TCT toured various universities and government institutions in Manila. The success of the first performance tour enabled the group to get support for a bigger repertoire. In 1976, the TCT mounted its first major show at the Cultural Center of the Philippines that presented many of the little-known dances of the Sulu archipelago. After the group’s exposure to media and mainstream dance companies, the indigenous dances became part of the repertory of professional and amateur folk dance groups in the Philippines and abroad. These include dances for wedding ceremony such as pangalay pangantin perfomed by the bride and groom. The TCT also popularized pangilok (courtship dance), pamansak or igal/pangalay ha pattong (pangalay/igal atop twin bamboo poles), tawti (fishermen catching catfish), bula’bula (bamboo or shell clapper dance), tariray (clapper dance tokulintangan’s tariray beat), igal buwani (male dance about gathering honey), langka baluang (monkey dance), langka silat (male martial dance), langka budjang (female martial dance), mag-jin (ritual dance to drive away evil spirits), linggisan (bird dance), and lunsay (song-dance).

The troupe’s repertory based on Fernando Amilbangsa’s choreography and research was later published in a book titled Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions, 1983. In the 2000s, Fernando Amilbangsa, who went back to Manila in 1987, remains a unifying and influential figure in Tambuli, especially with the decline of interest in cultural heritage brought about by modernization and other external sociocultural influences. Meanwhile, many of the founding members of the troupe continue their mission as dancers, choreographers, teachers, and advocates of the culture and art of the Sulu archipelago. They are Filemon Romero, Ernesto Baird, Sakinur-ain Mugong, Mahail Hajan, Johnny Lee, Abraham Sakili, Nurnahina Aquino Alfad, and Faujia Ikkao. Since the 1970s, TCT has produced numerous dancers and choreographers who continue to propagate the traditional dances through the programs of schools, communities, and government agencies.

The TCT has travelled extensively on goodwill missions and performances; it is considered an institution in Tawi-Tawi, playing a significant role in generating and renewing interest in the Sulu archipelago’s traditional dances.Written by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, updated by Rosalie Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Abigail Tan-Gamino in Vinta

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Abigail Tan-Gamino

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Abigail Tan-Gamino

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
TAN-GAMINO, ABIGAIL ( Faye Abigail Castro Tan-Gamino ) b. Manila 23 Aug 1983. Dancer. Tan-Gamino is the daughter of Expedito Demiao Tan and Thelma Castro. Her brother is dancer Jared Jehowil Tan. She is married to dancer Pedro Antonio Gamino III. She has a BA in Communication Arts from Angelicum College, 2004. She started her dance training with Jeng Halili and Shirley Halili-Cruz at the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in Quezon City (HCSD) in 1989, then withPerry Sevidal, Noordin Jumalon, Victor Ursabia, and Edward Malagkit at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance School from 1992 to 1993. She reenrolled at HCSD in 1993-95. In 1995, she joined Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) as a scholar and was appointed company member in 1997. With PBT, she trained with Anatoly Panassiukov and regular visiting guest teacher Maiqui Mañosa, both of whom she counts as her main mentors.

From an early age, Tan was seen as a technical virtuoso. Her talent was tempered by an artistry nurtured through her performances with PBT from 1997 to 2009. She became known as the gypsy queen in Don Quixote, 2001; Russian girl in George Balanchine’s Serenade, 2002 and 2003; and soloist in his Concerto Barocco and Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux, 2002. She came into her own in the title role of Julie Borromeo’s Merry Widow, 2002, and as Nikiya in the Kingdom of the Shades in La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 2002. Her performance as Nikiya in the full-length La Bayadere in 2004 marked her artistic growth from promising technician to complete artist. With PBT, she has also performed the roles of Esmeralda in Panasyukov’s The Hunchback of Notre Dame, 2003; Cio Cio San in Tom Pazik’s Madame Butterfly, 2004; Odette/Odile in Swan Lake, 2005; the title role in Cinderella, 2005; and leads in Gener Caringal’s Prism, Vinta, Andres KKK, and Darangen ni Bantugen (Epic of Bantugen), 2008, for which she created the role of Diwata.

She was engaged to teach children’s ballet at Dance Arts in 2004-07; Center for Movement and Music in 2004-09; and every summer at Perry Sevidal Ballet School in 2005-09.

In 2009, Tan and her brother, Jared, joined American Repertory Ballet, and a year later, the Atlanta Ballet in Georgia, USA, where she was quickly singled out for her fluent and joyous dancing as Snow Queen and Dewdrop Fairy in The Nutcracker, and as the Lilac and Candide Fairies in The Sleeping Beauty. In 2012, she was also praised in Christopher Wheeldon’s Rush, and in 2014, in Alexei Ratmansky’s Seven Sonatas. Tan also teaches ballet at the Georgia Academy of Dance and Atlanta Ballet Center for Dance.

In 2006, Tan won first prize in the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA) Senior Ballet competition.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
THE FRONTIERETTES Founded in 1966 as a precision dance group of 44 women, it realized business magnate J. Amado Araneta’s desire to form a Philippine group patterned after the 36-member Rockettes of Radio City Music Hall in New York. The Frontierettes performed between film screenings at the New Frontier Theater, in Quezon City. (Araneta was also the owner of FilippineFilms during the 1930s, and a producer of stage shows in Life Theater throughout the Japanese Occupation.) The theater was then one of its kind in the Philippines, with multi-sized elevators and a revolving stage.

Early auditions were conducted by Alcuin Pastrano and Delia Javier; Corazon Generoso-Iñigo later took over as dance director. When the theater began functioning exclusively as a cinema house, the Frontierettes lost their home. They continued to perform again at the Araneta Coliseum, dancing in shows with other featured international artists. Among the Filipino dancers who became most prominent were Lulu Puertollano, Vella Damian, and Bella Dimayuga. Consequently the group disbanded.Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Maureen Tiongco, 1965

(Photo from The Sunday Times)

text:
TIONGCO, MAUREEN ( Maureen Miles Tiongco )b. Manila 27 Sep 1935. Dancer, actor, director. She is the daughter of Felix Tiongco and Phyllis Miles. Her sister is Carmen Tiongco-Enriquez, an actor, and she is married to the tenor Harry Theyard. She studied ballet as a child with LuvaAdameit, and matured as a dancer under the tutelage of AnitaKane. She obtained her bachelor of arts, major in English, from the University of the Philippines where she appeared in musicals produced by the Sigma Delta Phi sorority.

In 1957 Tiongco studied ballet in New York, USA, with Vladimir Dokoudovsky and Nina Stroganova, later with Richard Thomas and Barbara Fallis. She also studied jazz with Luigi, Matt Mattox, and Peter Nelson, and danced for Jun Taylor and the legendary Jack Cole in a tour of Chucham. She also learned kabuki under Madame Asuma, and some Indian dancing. She studied acting with Larry Blyders at Northwestern University, and voice with Arrigo Pola and Harry Theyard, whom she later married.

In 1957 to1958, she joined the Broadway musical Flower Drum Song,choreographed by Gene Kelly and Carol Haney, taking the lead role of Mei Li after an open audition. She also played the lead roles in Kismet and The World of Suzie Wong, Liat in South Pacific,and Tuptim in The King and I.She choreographed for and appeared in touring industrial shows, danced and sang in clubs in Puerto Rico, and performed in a year’s musical revue tour of Europe in 1967.

Back in Manila in 1966, Tiongco gave master classes for Kane’s school, and restaged and directed FlowerDrum Song to raise funds for the proposed CulturalCenterof thePhilippines (CCP). Later, in 1976, she directed two operas at the CCP: I Pagliacci and Cavalleria Rusticana,featuring Theyard.

Tiongco is also in the real estate business in the United States .Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Alvin Tolentino, portrait for OrienTik, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
TOLENTINO, ALVIN ( Alvin Erasga Tolentino )b. Caloocan City 14 Oct 1969. Dancer, teacher, choreographer, visual artist. Alvin Tolentino is the son of Rolando Tolentino and Zenaida Erasga. In 1983, his family moved to Vancouver, Canada. He travelled to several places in North America to study art and dance. He trained professionally at The Royal Winnipeg Ballet, York University, Limon Institute, and Toronto Dance Theater.

Tolentino’s choreographies include his trilogy of solos titled Sola, 1998; Bato/Stone, 2000; Volt,2002; and, ADAMEVE/Man-Woman,2009. In 2003, he choreographed Field 1 for Ballet Philippines’ Neo-Filipino 2003: Balikbayan.Field 1 was inspired by his memories and farming experiences during his childhood years in Cabanatuan. The commissioned work captured his idea of land and rice as a representation of cultural heritage. In 2011, he returned to the Philippines with his full-length Paradis/Paradise, one of his contemporary dance projects done in collaboration with visual artists, whichoriginally premiered in 2008 at the Vancouver International Dance Festival. In 2012, he performed his full-length solo Colonial at the University of the Philippines, Los Baños. Colonial explored his roots as a Filipino and expressed his journey to the ceremonial enlightenment.

Tolentino founded Co. ERASGA Dance Society in Dec 2000, a contemporary dance company dedicated to promoting diversity in dance, making regular collaborations with local and international artists, in multimedia arts and other artistic practices. Broken Mirror Productions, King Arthur Productions, and The Western Front have collaborated with him and produced his works for Bravo, a local Canadian channel. Sola,one of his dance films, was nominated for an award at the Canadian Gemini in 2000. The video was also an entry at the 2002 Grand Prix International Video Competition for UNESCO in Paris.

He received grants from several institutions including Canada Council, Manitoba Arts Council, BC Arts Council, and the City of Vancouver. He won scholarships from Paddy Stone, The Royal Winnipeg Ballet, and York University. In 2010, he was the recipient of the Vancouver Mayor’s Arts Award in Dance. In 2014, he offered the Alvin Erasga Tolentino Koreograpiya Award as a special incentive for Filipino contemporary choreographers at the 7th WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival, Cultural Center of the Philippines.Written by Nicole Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Bianca Trocino
Bianca Trocino

text:
TROCINO, BIANCA ( Bianca Beatriz Villadolid Trocino ) b. 12 Jul 1988. Dancer. Bianca Trocino is the daughter of Dr Romulo Auza Trocino and Dr Maria Corazon Rarang Villadolid, the niece of ballerina Anna Villadolid-Mayr, and cousin of singer Abigail Blanco-Viduya. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of the Philippines with a degree on molecular biology and biotechnology in 2011.

Trocino started dancing at the age of four in Nagasaki, Japan. In 1998, she enrolled in Steps Dance Studio where she received her first formal education in ballet. At Steps, she trained under the Royal Academy of Dance Syllabi with Sofia Zobel-Elizalde and Raul Sauz, and finished all major exam levels, from Intermediate Foundation to Advanced 2, with a mark of Distinction. Also mentored by Anna Villadolid-Mayr, Thomas Mayr, and Agnes Locsin, she won third place at the 2004 First NAMCYA Junior Ballet Category. A year after, she essayed the title role of Giselle for the Steps’ Summer Dance Workshop. Throughout her years of training and professional work in dance, she was guided and honed by many other notable dance educators and choreographers such as Alice Sangco-Ledesma, Enrico Labayen, Gener Caringal, Julie Alagde-Carretas, Jun Saagundo, Noordin Jumalon, Monette Victoria, Herbert Alvarez, Carlos Garcia, Ida-Lucila Beltran, Nonoy Froilan, Valerie Bayley (dual examiner of RAD), David Campos, Irene Sabas-Campos, and Tony Fabella.

While a student at Steps, she was invited by Anatoly Panassiukov to guest with the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in 2003. Completing her RAD levels in 2006, she joined PBT as a company member. As lead dancer, she is known for her expressiveness, seen in major roles that include Fleur de Lys in Esmeralda,2006; Maria in Tanan (Elopement), 2008; soloist green girl in Caringal’s Vinta; Oryang in Andres KKK, 2008; Princess Maguimar in Darangen ni Bantugan (Epic of Bantugan), 2009; Lisa in Ang Pasaway ( La Fille Mal Gardee ), 2009; the Black Pearl in Mir-i-Nisa, 2009; Paquita in the Paquita grand pas de deux, and Death in Carmina Burana, 2010; Fairy Godmother in Cinderella, 2011; Swanilda in Coppélia, 2012; Eliza in the Small House of Uncle Thomas in Resorts World Manila’s Rogers and Hammerstein’s King and I, 2012; 2nd Odalisque in Le Corsaire (The Pirate), 2013; the Snow Queen and Dew Drop Fairy in The Nutcracker, 2011 and 2013; and the title role in Ronilo Jaynario’s Carmen, 2014. She originated the principal role in Jaynario’s Beatles Revisited, 2010, and Marguerite in Serye at Sayaw (Series and Dance), 2013.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

text:
UNIVERSITY OF SAN CARLOS DANCE TROUPE(USC) serves as the cultural arm of the University of San Carlos in Cebu City. It is composed of students from the different colleges in the university. It performs in most of the school’s celebrations and events, athletic meets, and the annual Sinulog Festival. The troupe also represents the city of Cebuin programs and receptions for international guests.It performs in festivals of the Philippine Folk Dance Society , Cebu Echo Folk Dance Workshop, and International Dance Xchange of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Since the 1990s, the troupe has had at least 15 major productions.

The USC Dance Troupe has performed in Hong Kong, 1989; Singapore, 1991 and 2002; Netherlands, 1991, 1994, and 2002; United States, 1993 and 2000; Canada, 1993; Germany, to celebrate Philippine Independence Day, 1995; South Korea, 1996; Taiwan, 1997; Malaysia, 2005; Hainan, China, 2006; and Vietnam, 2010.

For promoting Philippine Culture, the troupe was given recognition by the City of Cebu as the Most Outstanding Cultural Group during the Cebu City Charter Day in 1996. It also received the Cebu Mayor’s Special Award for the Promotion of Filipino Culture in 1996, and the Parangal Sayaw Bulawan Award from the Philippine Folk Dance Society in 1999. Again, it was declared the Most Outstanding Institution in the Field of Performing Arts for the Promotion of Philippine Culture by the mayor of the city of Cebu in 2006.

The USC Dance Troupe strives for excellence in performance and faithfulness to Philippine Culture. It is directed by Francita P. Pacaña, with Jose Miguel T. Cabasagan as dance master and Dolores Suzara as adviser.Written by Josefina B. Guillen

article_title: University of Santo Tomas Salinggawi Dance Troupe
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Salinggawi Dance Troupe at the National Cheerleading Championship-ALL GIRLS 2018

(Photo courtesy of the group)

Salinggawi Dance Troupe performing for Pasinaya, CCP, 2018

(Photo by Vianney Olaguer, courtesy of the group)

Salinggawi Dance Troupe in SIBOL: 48th Annual Dance Concert, UST, 2016
(Photo by Aldryn Cedric Encarnacion, courtesy of the group)

text:
UNIVERSITY OF SANTO TOMAS SALINGGAWI DANCE TROUPE The Salinggawi Dance Troupe (SDT) is the official dance group and cheerdance team of the University of Santo Tomas (UST). SDT is known for showcasing various dance genres such as folk, ballroom, hip-hop, contemporary, and cheerdance. Two groups of dancers constitute the troupe: the folk dance group and cheerdance group. It is supported by Fr Ermito G. De Sagon OP, director of the UST Institute of Physical Education and Athletics (IPEA) and Edna B. Sanchez, adviser of the troupe.

The troupe was established in 1968 by Emerita E. Basilio, then directress of the women’s section of UST’s Physical Education Department and expert in Philippine folk dance. Delly Nabong, Carmen Cruz, Arce Garcia, and student volunteers joined Basilio in establishing the University’s cultural group. It was named “Salinggawi,” a contraction of the Filipino phrase “salin ng mga dating gawi at lahi,” or “transfer of customs and traditions.” SDT seeks to hone performers who excel in promoting the nation’s cultural heritage through dance, and to develop dynamic, well-rounded, and empowered students by integrating the core values of discipline, respect, honesty, and integrity in their dancing.

The range of dances that SDT performs underscores the rich store of dances in the Philippines. After Basilio, Rene Hofileña directed the group and expanded its repertoire to include jazz dance. Later, under choreographer Ramon Pagaduan IV, SDT updated its training routine with guest choreographers like Robert Stephen R. Biadoma of the Philippine Normal University and Franco M. Velas, a former SDT member and current treasurer of the Philippine Folk Dance Society. On the other hand, mastery of modern dance techniques is of prime importance to the group’s cheer dance performances. STD has also conducted workshops and launched into research projects to explore and enrich the field of Philippine dance and culture.

STD’s “Rural Suite” highlights the revelry in Philippine fiestas. It includes the traditional Philippine dances bakya, maglalatik, tinikling, sakuting, and sayaw sa bangko. The group also performs ethnic dances like malong, pig-apir (fan dance), pamansak, asik, and singkil. The latter were seen in SDT’s 2015 concert, Enchant II, with its Muslim Suite, one of its most famous repertoires.

In another dance mode and working with the Yellow Jackets, UST’s official pep squad and drumline, the SDT regularly performs at basketball games played by the University’s Growling Tigers Men’s Basketball Team, as in the annual University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP).

The SDT has also participated in dance festivals in Pangasinan and Zambales, and in international dance festivals and competitions in Singapore, Malaysia, and Brunei. It was featured on television shows such as SOP, Myx Mo! (Your Mix), Wish Ko Lang (My Wish), Unang Hirit (First Strike), GMA 7’s Siete Palabras (Seven Last Words), and Umagang Kay Ganda (What A Beautiful Morning).It has staged full concerts all about Philippine culture and society, such as Banyuhay (New Life), 2005; Deja vu,2006; Almost Home, 2007; Salin ng Dating mga Gawi at Lahi, 2008; Musuo, 2009; Footnotes,2010; Eterno,2011; Memorabilia, 2012; Eros,2013; Enchant, 2014; and Enchant II,2015.

The SDT won the following awards: Champion in the UAAP Cheerdance Competition, 1994-96 and 2002-06; 1st runner-up in the UAAP Cheerdance Competition, 1999, 2000, 2007, and 2008; champion in the 2012 Philippine National Games (Cheerdance Category and All Girls Group Stunts); and 1st runner-up in the 2013 Philippine National Games (Cheerdance Category, Co-Ed Group Stunts, and Team Tumbling Category).Written by Kristine May D. Martinez

article_title: University of The East Dance Company
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
University of the East Dance Company

(Photo from facebook.com/UESilangananDanceTroupe/)

text:
UNIVERSITY OF THE EAST DANCE COMPANY ( UE Dance Company )It was founded in 1951 as the UE Dance Troupe by Maggie Shea, a second-generation disciple of Francisca Reyes-Aquino and Trudl Dubsky-Zipper. Shea was assistant director of physical education (PE) at the UE, where she organized a ten-member group of PE majors to perform folk dance numbers on and off-campus. The troupe received official recognition from Socorro Espiritu, dean of UE’s College of Liberal Arts, and financial support and scholarships from Francisco Dalupan, university president.

When Eloisa de Leon, with the assistance of Aurora Tonibio, took over as director from Shea, she added a repertoire of modern dances choreographed by Manolo Rosado, a principal dancer of Kaethe Hauser and Dubsky-Zipper. In 1964, CorazonGeneroso-Iñigo became dance director and focused on dances for the University Athletics Association of the Philippines or UAAP basketball seasons. The troupe also had a heavy schedule of performances in university functions, Metro Manila, and the provinces. In 1970 it was invited to the Osaka World’s Fair for Philippine Day. Under the administration of Romeo Protasio, who took over in 1972, moderndance classes were started under Betsy Escandor. In 1974, GenerCaringal, principal dancer and choreographer of BalletPhilippines (BP), became director and strengthened the modern dance repertoire. He also contributed some of his choreographic pieces. The group’s performances abroad included those in Europe in 1984 and 1987, and in the United States in 1988. One of its directors was Constantino “Jojo” Lucila, a former BP member and artistic director of the Chameleon Dance Company, and Contemporario Ethnico Filipino with NonoyFroilan. Lucila continued the training in modern dance and added his own works to the repertoire.

Among the noted dancers trained by the UEDanceCompany are Nonoy Froilan, ManuelMolina, Gener Caringal, Jinn Ibarrola, and LitoCalzado. Some alumni became dance entrepreneurs who train and send dance groups for performances abroad.Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

article_title: University of The Philippines Dance Company
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Pasundayag, University of the Philippines Dance Company’s 30th anniversary concert, 2017

(Photo from facebook.com/UPDanceCo/)

University of the Philippines Dance Company

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

University of the Philippines Dance Company at the 7th International Youth Dance Festival in Macau, 1999

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES DANCE COMPANY ( UPDC ) Founded in 1987, UPDC is the performing arm of the University of the Philippines (UP) Dance Program. The company compliments the country’s most comprehensive four-year diploma course in creative performing musical arts and five-year baccalaureate degree in music, major in dance.

Founding artistic director, now professor emeritus, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz set up UPDC for the apprenticeship and professional training of dance students. It aims to develop the technique and creativity of student dancers and choreographers. It was through his leadership that UPDC was designated one of UP’s official performing groups, widening the company’s duties to cover the entire University’s choreographic needs not only in dance, but also in the allied arts and other programs. The company’s mission is to promote dance as a serious form of study and profession and as public and communal expression.

UPDC is the only company known to have deconstructed dance classics, like Cinderella into Mariang Sinderela, ang Bagong Bayani (Maria Cinderella, the New Heroine)by Joelle Jacinto and Angela Lawenko Baguilat, 1996; Nutcracker into Cracked Nut, Maria Clara’s Colonial Dream by Veronique Duma Berdin, Desiree Peralejo Medina, and Jesusa Noveno Noel, 1997; Giselle into Ang Higanti (The Revenge) by Ava Maureen Ong and Joyce Comia Banal, 2003; Swan Lake into Sa Itim, Sa Puti (The Black Swan and the White Swan) by Yasnina Jumalon and Gianella Reyes, 2009; and the most notable of all, Petroushka into Pedro Kusinero (Peter the Cook) by Herbert Alvarez and Ma. Elena Laniog, 2004. Pedro Kusinero,perhaps one of UPDC’s landmark pieces, was featured in the WiFi Body Festival in 2009 with a live performance of Igor Stravinsky's musicby the UP Orchestra under the baton of Professor Edna Marcil Martinez.

Notable choreographies of UPDC are works of Flordeliza Fernandez such as her translation of Stravinsky’s Les Noces into Ang Kasal (The Wedding), 2004, Femina (Feminine), 1995, and Souvenirs, 2004; and works of Ma. Elena Laniog like Mata Sa Damgo (Eye in the Dream),2006, Sa Se Si, 2007, Class Menu, 2009, Feet of Clay, 2012, and On the Wings of 44,2015. Contributions from young student choreographers like Japhet Mari Cabling’s Flight, 2013, and Layag (Sail), 2014, and Sarah Maria Samaniego’s Bilang (Count), 2010, as well as the restaging of Basilio’s classics Misa Filipina (Philippine Mass), Mosque Baroque, Paean to Pavlova,and Exultations constitute the landmark pieces of UPDC’s wide repertoire.

Sonia Domingo Orevillo and Flordeliza Fernandez Punzalan served as associate artistic directors in the 1980s. In 2007, Villaruz appointed Angela Lawenko Baguilat and Herbert Alvarez as co-artistic directors. Together with resident choreographer and ballet mistress Ma. Elena Laniog, Baguilat and Alvarez, as organizers of the annual Contemporary Dance Map in Quezon City and the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, were able to strengthen the UDPC as one of the forerunners of contemporary dance in the country.

Members of the UPDC have received the UP College of Music Student Council Awards, a grant from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts to teach in all UP campuses, and invitations to festivals in Taiwan, Malaysia, Macau, and Hong Kong, workshops and residencies, as well as scholarships in Asia and Europe. Over the years, some of the company’s members and choreographers like Al Bernard, Elena Laniog, Herbert Alvarez, and Japhet Cabling have become prominent figures in the Philippine dance scene.Written by Angela Lawenko-Baguilat

article_title: University of The Philippines Filipiniana Dance Group
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
UP Filipiniana Dance Group

(Photo courtesy of the group)

Tanglaw, UP Filipiniana Dance Group’s 80th Anniversary Homecoming Dance Concert, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the group)

Tanglaw, UP Filipiniana Dance Group’s 80th Anniversary Homecoming Dance Concert, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the group)

Tanglaw, UP Filipiniana Dance Group’s 80th Anniversary Homecoming Dance Concert, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the group)

Tanglaw, UP Dance Group’s 80th Anniversary Homecoming Dance Concert, 2015

(Photo courtesy of the group)

text:
UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES FILIPINIANA DANCE GROUP ( UP Filipiniana DanceGroup )In 1948, UP physical education (PE) majors supervised by Luz Einsiedel performed as the PE department’s dance group. Eventually the Filipiniana Dance Group was formally organized under Cynthia Villa (now Abad Santos). Subsequently, the group was directed by Lourdes Saniel, Lydia Buendia, Nelly Zafra, Teresa Miraflor-Agsalud, Linda Kimpo, CorazonGeneroso-Iñigo, Leilani Gonzalo, Von Manalo, and Peter Alcedo.

UP artist-in-residence Generoso-Iñigo was responsible for its artistic growth for 18 years. Some of the group’s popular pieces include the uyaoy from the Ifugao, the dugso and pagapir from Mindanao, tinikling, and festival dances such as the Ati-Atihan. From an all-Filipino folk repertory, the group began to include moderndance, light ballet, and jazz. Their pieces include AliceReyes’s BungkosSuite,EdnaVida’s Pagsamba (Worship), DenisaReyes’s The Last Flower, GenerCaringal’s AngSultan (The Sultan) and SimpleSymphony,TonyFabella’s Changes,DouglasNierras’s Maglalatik,and Generoso-Iñigo’s Baile deAyer (Dance of Yesteryears), Lam-ang From the Cordilleras, Fantasia, Correlationsand Celebrations, and Sisa. With Manalo, it acquired a more diversified repertory, fusing jazz and folk styles.

The group has represented the Philippines in festivals and concert halls in France, United Kingdom, Spain, Italy, Portugal, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, Yugoslavia, Romania, the United States, Canada, Australia, Malaysia, Thailand, Jordan, and Egypt. In the decade of the 2000s, the group’s presence was strongly felt in Asia, particularly during the Midosuji Parade in Osaka, Japan in 2007, and the Surin International Folklore Festival from 2006 to 2010.

In the Philippines, the group is a regular performer during university events such as the 2009 UPCentennial concert tribute, Isang Daan (One Road), which was also performed in Misamis Oriental General Comprehensive High School, Cagayan de Oro. It has likewise shared its repertoire with a wider audience by performing in Cavite, Laguna, Ilocos Norte, Cebu, and Mindanao, and conducting workshops in Baler, Quezon.

On its first trip abroad, the UP Filipiniana won the Collier d’Or (First Prize for Dance) and Disc d’Or (First Prize for Music) at the 33rd International Wine and Folkloric Festival held in Dijon, France, 1978; it was the first time in the festival’s history that two first prizes were won by a single country. In the commemorative TV documentary of the opening of the United Nations city in Vienna in 1979, the UPFilipinianaDanceGroup was chosen to give the finale presentation, a choice over 54 countries representing the five continents of the world.

Under the leadership of its director Peter Alcedo Jr, the performers undergo intensive training in folk dance and jazz, complemented by aerobic forms of dance.Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, with notes from Ruth Jordana L. Pison and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article_title: University of The Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club Troupe
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Francisca Reyes, center, seated, with the UP Folk Song and Dance Troupe, 1934

(Photo courtesy of Rosalia Merino-Santos)

“Rigodon con Aire,” the First Anniversary Party of the UP Folk Song and Dance Club, 11 Sep 1938

(Photo from Parangal kay Francisca Reyes-Aquino, 1991)

Francisca Aquino and husband Ramon Tolentino Jr, both standing, with the UP Folk Song and Dance Club, 1934

(Photo from CCP Library)

text:
UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES FOLK SONG AND DANCE CLUB/TROUPE ( UP Folk Songand Dance Club/Troupe )Organized in 1937 by Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Reyes-Aquino) and UP president Jorge Bocobo, the objective of the troupe was to revive and popularize Filipino songs and dances. The president’s committee on folk songs and dances composed of Francisco Santiago, H. Otley Beyer, Cecilio Lopez, Antonio J. Molina, Antonino Buenaventura, Ramon Tolentino, and the then Reyes-Tolentino, fully supported by Bocobo, documented Philippine songs, dances, costumes, musical instruments, and customs.

The first touring group included 24 dancers and ten musicians. Typical of their repertory were the Kalinga wedding dance, abaruray, aetana, alcamfor, anuncio, areuana, ariguinding-guinding, bailes de ayer, bakya, ba-o, kandingan, kuratsa, dugso, esperanza, garambal, habanera, la jota, lawiswis kawayan, magasik, maglalatik, palay, pandang-pandang, pandanggo, pasakat, purpuri, rogelia, sakuting, sagayan, salakot, salampati, siring, sua-sua, subli, tadek, tiklos, ti liday,and urukay. Besides performing the songs and dances, Reyes-Tolentino lectured on Filipino dances, and Buenaventura on Filipino music. They performed in Luzon provinces and in Iloilo, Bacolod, and Cebu cities in the Visayas.

In 1939, when Bocobo was named Secretary of Public Instruction, he asked for Mrs Tolentino to be transferred to the Bureau of Education. The club or troupe thus “hibernated” for the next nine years. Then, in 1948, Luz Einsiedel informally organized physical education majors of UP to continue the work of Reyes-Tolentino and to fulfill requests for folk dance performances. This group became the nucleus of the UPFilipinianaDanceGroup.

The club or troupe attracted an impressive list of charter members, many of them socially prominent. The officers, headed by Ricardo Bahia, president, and LucioSandoval and Milagros Lucas, vice-presidents, were PazCieloAngeles-Belmonte, Patria Panahon, Eugenia Eleazar, Ramon Fajardo, Bernardo Capili, Ramon Tolentino, and Jose Generoso.Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Victor Ursabia

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
URSABIA, VICTOR ( Victor Gamosa Ursabia )b. Manila 4 Mar 1965. The son of Antonio Solon Ursabia and Angela Gamosa, Ursabia is married to Maria Nimfa Maligaya, with whom he has two sons, Vincentzo Mari and Ian Mari. He has a BFA in Interior Design from Philippine Women’s University, 1997. He trained with Noordin Jumalon at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School (CCPDS) from 1982 to 1986 as a scholar, and with William Morgan, Edna Vida, Norman Walker, and Agnes Locsin with Ballet Philippines from 1986 to 1998. He was awarded a scholarship in 1988 by Maniya Barredo to attend the Atlanta Ballet School. He was also able to train at the Boston Ballet School in 1988 and at Center de Danse du Marais in France in 2005.

With Ballet Philippines (BP), Ursabia danced the Bluebird pas de deux in The Sleeping Beauty; Jester, pas de trois, and Neapolitan in Swan Lake; pas de trois in Giselle; Benvolio in Romeo and Juliet; and other roles in Les Sylphides, Don Quixote, Midsummer Night’s Dream, La Fille Mal Gardee, and La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution).

He became a faculty member of the CCPDS in 1989 and its school director in 2011. He also taught at the Philippine Women’s University from 1997 to 1998, Philippine High School for the Arts from 2001 to 2009, Ateneo de Manila University in 2010, Jean Wong Ballet School in Hong Kong in 2011, West Lake School for the Performing Arts in Daly City in 2012, and De La Salle-College of St. Benilde from 2012 onward.

He did costume and stage design for several productions of BP, most notably for La Revolucion Filipina in 1998. Ursabia served as production designer for the CCPDS from 1998, and was appointed as production manager for Ballet Philippines in 2006. He has done stage designs for Steps Dance Studio since 2002, and was product designer for SKM Art Craft Corporation in Intramuros, Manila from 2000 to 2005.

Ursabia coached several National Music Competitions for Young Artists finalists and winners, namely Ronelson Yadao, Victor Maguad, Philip Sicat, Veronica Ylagan, Rita Winder, Cyril Fallar, and Denise Parungao. He also coached Candice Adea and Jean Marc Cordero in their participation in various international competitions, winning top awards.

As a dance photographer, he founded the Marikina Digital Photographer’s Club in 2010, and was the official photographer of Steps Dance Studio since 2002. In Feb 2000, his works were exhibited as Dancescape at Gallery 27.He was nominated for a Gawad Buhay Award for production design in La Revolucion Filipina in 2009.Written by Desiree P. Medina

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Edna Vida, 2002

(Photo by Rupert Jacinto, courtesy of the artist)

Edna Vida as Carmen

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Edna Vida in The Nutcracker, 1975

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

Edna Vida and Nonoy Froilan in Black Swan, 1982

(Photo courtesy of the artist)
Edna Vida and Nonoy Froilan in Itim Asu, 1984 (Photo courtesy of the artist)

Edna Vida in Alice Reyes's Carmina Burana, 1975

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
VIDA, EDNA ( Edna Garcia Reyes-Froilan ) b. Manila 14 Nov 1954. Dancer, choreographer, director, actor. She is the youngest of the six children of Ricardo Reyes, dancer, and Adoracion Garcia, singer. She is married to dancer-choreographer Nonoy Froilan, with whom she has two children. Their son, Rafael, is a filmmaker. Her older sisters, Alice and Denisa Reyes, are choreographers and dance teachers. She began lessons at age five with Greta Monserrat and later with Joji Felix-Velarde. At 11, she created dance numbers for school productions in Maryknoll. In 1970 she joined the first Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) summer dance workshop.

From 1974 to 1989, Vida was principal dancer of Ballet Philippines (BP). Vida danced the principal role of Myrtha to Natalia Makarova’s Giselle with Patrick Bissell in Manila in 1979. She performed numerous other leading roles for which she earned critical acclaim. Her most memorable was the title role in Firebird, choreographed for her and Froilan by Armin Wild in 1975.

In 1977, Vida choreographed her first work, Pagsamba (Worship) for the CCP summer dance workshop; this work has since been included in BP’s repertoire. Her other contemporary ballets are Vision of Fire and The Little Tailor,1982; Ensalada (Salad), 1981; Gardenia,1979; Romeo and Juliet; and Portraits,1987. She did a series of children’s full-length ballets, such as The Nutcracker,1987; Peter Pan,1983; Alice in Wonderland,1985; and Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1990. She also created dances for Magsimula Ka (You Begin), 1987, and Corregidor, Revisited, 1992, both for the CCP; Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden),1987, El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1991, and Pilipinas Circa1907, 1992, for Tanghalang Pilipino; Jesus Christ Superstar, 1984, for the Folk Arts Theater; West Side Story, 1985, for a TV special; Mutya ng Pasig (Muse of Pasig), 1983, for Toni Lopez Gonzalez (semifinalist at the Varna Competition in Bulgaria); and Ang lbon (The Bird), 1987, for Lisa Macuja (silver medalist at the Asia-Pacific Ballet Competition in Tokyo). Recent choreographic works include Walang Sugat (Not Wounded) for Tanghalang Pilipino’s 26th season, 2012-13, and A Christmas Carol for BP in 2013.

She became BP’s associate artistic director in 1983 and coartistic director in 1988. She taught at the National Arts Center’s Philippine High School for the Arts and directed the CCP Dance School from 1983 to 1989, heading the school’s participation in the Hong Kong International Festival of Dance Academies in 1989. She was artistic director for the national tour of the Stars of Philippine Ballet in 1988, the Yugyugan CCP Jazz Festival in 1989, and the CCP annual Pasasalamat program in 1992. In 1988, the United States Information Service awarded her a grant to the 52nd American Dance Festival in Durham, North Carolina. She wrote articles in Dance Philippines from 1981 to 1983, and for various magazines and newspapers. She likewise wrote a column for the Manila Times. Also a painter, Vida held two solo exhibits of her pastel and oil paintings and drawings in 1993: Grand Fete at SM Megamall Gallery and Why Dance? at Penguin Cafe, Malate, Manila.

She received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinagan from Manila, 2002; Bulacan’s Gawad Dangal ng Lipi Award, 2004; and Maryknoll College Amazing Alumni Award, 2004. She was a fellow of the Asian Cultural Council in the US in 2012.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz and Emilie B. Capulong, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Anna Villadolid

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

Anna Villadolid and Dinko Bogdanic dancing an excerpt from Ballet Philippines’s Giselle, 1990

(Photo courtesy of Ballet Philippines)

Anna Villadolid and Jan Broeckx in Romeo and Juliet

(Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz)

text:
VILLADOLID, ANNA ( Anna Colet Villadolid-Mayr ) b. Mandaluyong, Metro Manila 9 Mar 1964. Dancer. Her parents are Oscar Villadolid, journalist and ambassador, and Alice Colet, journalist. Her sisters Hilda and Tina are writers, and brother Joey was a dancer, dance company manager, and photographer. She is married to Thomas Mayr, a balletmaster of the Bavarian National Ballet in Munich, and they have two children. She graduated with honors from St. Theresa’s College High School, and was briefly in the diploma dance program of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music.

Villadolid started ballet with Felicitas Layag-Radaic until she became a member of Dance Theatre Philippines. She also trained with Basilio, Enrico Labayen, William Morgan, Eddie Elejar, and Antonio Fabella whose Manila Metropolis Ballet made her a full-fledged ballerina. Abroad, she trained with Melissa Hayden, David Howard, Robert Denvers, Edward Villella, and with the Eglevsky Ballet and Boston Ballet. In 1982, director Konstanz Vernon of Germany’s Munich Ballet Academy offered her a Heinz Bosl Foundation scholarship. In less than a year, Villadolid became a member of the Bavarian State Ballet in Munich where she became a principal dancer.

In Manila, she was featured in ballets by Basilio, Elejar, and Fabella. She created the adagio in Basilio’s Ode to Botticelli, 1981, and Antonina in Tchaikovsky Fantasy, 1982; the girl in Elejar’s Mask, 1981, and in his collaboration with Joji Felix-Velarde, Sylvia, 1985, after Louis Merante; the girl in Fabella’s Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches), 1981, Love Like the Moon, the Inconstant Moon, 1982, and “Impossible Dream” in Four Songs, 1987. With Manila Metropolis Ballet, she danced Giselle, 1983, and Odette-Odile, 1984. She also guested with Ballet Philippines in Giselle, 1987, Alice Reyes’s Romeo and Juliet, 1988, Swan Lake, 1991, and in several gala performances.

In Munich, she danced the girl in Fokine’s Le Spectre de la Rose, Marie in J. Neumeier’s The Nutcracker, Juliet in J. Cranko’s Romeo and Juliet and the elf in his Jeu de Cartes, the title role in T. Shilling’s Undine, and in U. Scholz’s Jeunehomme (Young Man). She danced Giselle several times in Munich, Berlin, and Leipzig, plus the title role in Bournonville’s La Sylphide, Cupid in Petipa’s Don Quixote and Princess Aurora in his Sleeping Beauty. In all these, she gained critical acclaim, including being called “the diva of dance.” She had been a regular guest artist with the Birmingham Royal Ballet essaying lead roles in many of its ballets.

After retirement, she completed a teacher’s training course at theCenter Circle Pilates Studio, where she conducted private and group classes. In 2004, she conducted a workshop titled Enhancing Classical Ballet Technique with Pilates-based Exercises, at the Body Control Teachers’ Development Weekend in London, UK, and a dance workshop for young dancers of the School of Dance in Burghausen, Germany. She also pursued advanced certificates and attended workshops related to Pilates methods in Germany and the United States. Since 2005, she has been teaching private classes at the Osteopathiepraxis Tino Pohlmann in Munich. She also conducts dance-specific Pilates group classes at the BallettSchule Benedict-Manniegel.

In 1991, she was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award by the City of Manila. In 1996, she received the Münchner Merkur Award given by a Munich newspaper. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

text:
VILLANUEVA-ONG, AVA MAUREEN b. Bay, Laguna 01 Jul 1982. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Villanueva is the daughter of Ma. Magdalena Bonita and Teodoro Reyes Villanueva, and is married to Robert Joseph Ong. She attended the Philippine High School for the Arts, and earned her certificate diploma in Creative Performing Musical Arts (DCPMA) in 2004 and bachelor’s degree in music in 2006, both major in dance, at the University of the Philippines (UP), Diliman.

She danced with the UP Dance Company, joining them on tour to Kuala Lumpur in 2002. She also performed with the UP Filipiniana Alumni Dance Group in France, Belgium, and Switzerland; the Edwin C. Duero Dance Company in the US, both in 2002; and participated in dance festivals in Macau, China, and Monaco.

Villanueva choreographed Higanti (Revenge), a contemporary deconstruction of the ballet Giselle, with Joyce Comia for their graduation recital in 2003. She started to seriously pursue choreography after college, producing In Side, 2007; My Body, Your Body, Sepia, and Unit Manila (a multimedia collaborative work with Yoshiaki Inatsugi), 2008; Fall In, Stealing Image (a video collaboration with Ruelo Lozendo), Fools, and Trapped Inside a Stained Glass, all in 2009; Confession and Con Furia (Re-choreographing Myra Beltran’s original for Re-performing ),both in2010; Walk with Me, 2011, Dian lang sa may Kanto (There in the Corner), performed in Kobe City, Nagata, Japan, and Nang Wala Pang Mundo (Before the World Came to Be), both in 2012.

Villanueva became a lecturer of dance technique for contemporary and classical ballet at the UP College of Music in 2007, a teacher at the CCP Dance School, and opened her own studio in Los Baños, Laguna. Beginning in 2008, Villanueva worked as the artistic director of Airdance. Early in her career, Villanueva won the first Emerging/New Choreographers Competition at the WiFi Body Festival in 2007 with In Side, and was given the WiFi Japan Foundation-CCP NeXtage Young Choreography Award (First Place). She also worked with other contemporary dance artists Myra Beltran, Vinia Pamplona, Elena Laniog, Alden Lugnasin, and Rhosam Prudenciado Jr, and with the UP Dance Company and Green Papaya Arts Project.

Villanueva danced and created works in Kyoto and Kobe, Japan, in 2008, and attended a workshop in Sydney, Australia. In 2012, Villanueva was in Kobe again in a residency from the Japan Foundation, spending two months under the JENESYS Creators Program.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
VILLANUEVA-PIÑON, REMEDIOS b. Manila 26 Feb 1916 d. Quezon City. Dancer, teacher, choreographer. Villanueva-Piñon is the sister of painter-writer Lydia VillanuevaArguilla and half-sister of dancer-choreographer BenjaminReyes, aka Benny Villanueva. She is the mother of dancer, choreographer, and gymnast Trudl Piñon. From 1951 until her retirement in 1981, she taught physical education at the University of the Philippines (UP). Between 1945 and 1975, she also taught ballet at the Young Women’s Christian Association in Manila. From 1951 to 1956, she successively set the rhythmic floor exercises for the National Gymnastic Competitions. She went on to run her own private dance studio in Quezon City until her full retirement. She remained active in dance as a member of the Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation, until her death.

Villanueva-Piñon studied dance under prominent teachers here and abroad and attended classes and workshops of visiting dancers and choreographers. A member of Trudl Dubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne, she danced in Petite Suite, Peer Gynt Suite, The Iron Foundry,all in 1939; Pictures at an Exhibition and PolovetskyDances, both in 1940; and L’Arlesienne Suite,1941. On her own, she interpreted Filipino folk songs such as “Sitsiritsit,” “Leron-leron Sinta” (Leron-leron Beloved), “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), and “Paruparong Bukid” (Country Butterfly), and local legends, the last with the UP Contemporary Dancers. She choreographed the life of Maria Orosa for the Girl Scouts; Our Father,for the Cosmopolitan Church; War and Peace for a UP festival, 1951; and an interpretation of Saint Paul’s Letters to the Corinthians for the UP education alumni, 1991.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
