text:
VILLARUZ, BASILIO ESTEBAN S. ( Basilio Esteban de los Santos Villaruz )aka Basilio, Steve Villaruz, B. E. S.b. Ma-ao, Bago City, Negros Occidental 15 Mar 1940. Choreographer, scholar, critic, historian, dancer, teacher. The son of Basilio Camilo Villaruz and Ester de los Santos, Basilio received his bachelor of arts in English and history from West Negros College (now university), Bacolod in 1960. After graduating, he taught literature and ballet at the Central Philippine University, Iloilo City, 1962 to 1965, then English at the University of the Philippines (UP), 1966 to 1968. In between, he gained graduate credits in Asian studies at the Far Eastern University from 1960 to 1962 and Comparative Literature at UP from 1965 to 1968. He finished his advanced diploma in choreology from the Benesh Institute of Choreology in London, England, 1980.

He studied dance under Pancho Uytiepo and Elsie Torrejon in Bacolod and then later with RemediosdeOteyza, IndayGaston-Mañosa, JulieBorromeo, FelicitasLayag-Radaic, EddieElejar, Antonio Llacer, IsraelGabriel, and AliceReyes. He joined the then-incipient Hariraya Ballet Company, then DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) from 1968 to 1969.

In 1970, Villaruz decided to leave academe and completely immerse himself in dance. Thus, from 1970 to 1972, he became part of the Alice Reyes and ModernDance Company, which later expanded to become the CCP Dance Company and is now known as Ballet Philippines. Later he returned to DTP to become its ballet master and resident choreographer responsible for the bimonthly Ballet at the Park shows, 1975 to 1978, and eventually its artistic director, 1980 to 1987. As “Basilio,” he danced and choreographed with all the Manila studios and with Teatro Amakan and Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company in Iloilo, and the Alejandro Dance Theatre in New York, while teaching in various schools. In between these commitments, he received more training from Norman Walker, Pauline Koner, and Mary Hinkson in modern dance; Miro Zolan, Garth Welch, Peter Appel, Rochelle Zide-Booth, Leon Danielian, and Larry Burgoon in ballet; and at schools and companies in Germany, the Netherlands, Great Britain, and New York, supplemented by tours and observation in Russia, Indonesia, and the United States.

Villaruz later returned to academe and together with Dr Ramon Santos and Dr Corazon Dioquino, established a four-year dance diploma degree at the UP College of Music in 1980, which later expanded into a five-year program bachelor in music major in dance. In 1987, Villaruz also founded the UP Dance Company and became its artistic director and choreographer.

His major choreographic works numbering more than a hundred have been noted by critics for their imagery and maturity. Set to music ranging from Bach to Bartok, Cayabyab to Kasilag, and folk to pop, they include Bach Ballabile, Rooms, BailesFil-Hispanos (Filipino-Hispanic Dances), Dark Night of the Soul, We Were Moonlight, and Rooms, all in 1965; Diurnal andthe Dream,1970; The Rebel and The Resurrection of Lazarus,1971; Royal Sonnets,1972; The Elements,1972; Between Sky and Sea,1973; Morang Tarjata (for Reynaldo Alejandro Dance Theater, New York), 1974; An Oddysey,1975; MosqueBaroque,1975; Perjured Hearts,1976; TropicalTapestry, 1978; Testament and LaLampara (The Lamp), 1980; Id, Salutations,and Ode to Botticelli,all in 1981; A Chair, Sweet Warfare, Paean to Pavlova, A DivineAnthology, Domain of Peace, Awit (Song), and TchaikovskyFantasy,all in 1982; Paglalang (Creation), Crystal Concerto, andCanto toCanaletto,all in 1983; Exultations and MisaFilipina (Filipino Mass), 1984; Sa Baybayon (By the Shore), 1986; Muling Pagsilang (Rebirth) and A Betrothal,1986; MgaAwit ni Basil I,II (Basil’s Songs I, II), 1987; Ritual Bonds and OrientalFantasy, 1990; Spiritual Canticle:An Eclogue-Operatorio,1991; War Requiem (premiered in Beijing, China), and Pahinungod,both in 1994; Bantayog, 2001; and Invocation and From Antonio P to Abu (staged at the University of Michigan), 2002.

His two major works using materials from the Visayas Regions are AngBabaylan (The Shaman), 1988, a full-evening dance-drama with visual artist, sculptor, and writer Ed Defensor, and Tinagong Dagat (Hidden Sea), 1994, on a Hiligaynon legend, with composer Christine Muyco, for the Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company in Iloilo.

He is one of the few critics and historians of dance in the Philippines but also wrote reviews on music and the visual arts, and edited various magazines. His dance writings and criticism have been compiled in Treading Through: 45 Years of Philippine Dance, 2006, and Walking Through Philippine Theater, 2012, which won the National Book Award and Alfonso T. OngpinPrizefor Best Book on Art in 2013. Outside the country, he served as dance correspondent and contributor to international dance periodicals and magazines and to the Oxford Concise Dictionary of Ballet, 1982.

Villaruz also wrote the three monographs on dance for CCP’s Tuklas Sining series,1992, as well as the scripts for its video-documentary versions— Sayaw:A Video Documentary on Philippine Dance, which won the Prix de Reportage and the Best Documentary Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1990, and Sayaw: A Video on Philippine Ethnic Dance, which was given a Special Mention in the 1992 Grand Prix International Video-Dance in France. Both video documentaries were directed by RamonObusan. In 1998, his entry “Philippine Dance” appeared in the ASEAN Dance, a survey of dances of the ASEAN nations.

From 1989 to 1990, Villaruz chaired the national dance committee of the National (then Presidential)Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). Between 1991 and 1993, he served on the executive board of the dance committee, International Theater Institute. He has served as judge in different local and international ballet competitions such as the Asia Pacific International Ballet Competition, in Tokyo. He was an external examiner of the University of Malaya, a professor emeritus at the UP, and artistic director emeritus of the UPDC. He is also a Commissioner of the UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines, a member of the technical panel for dance and theater of the Commission on Higher Education-Philippines, and president of the World Dance Alliance-Philippines.

He has been given grants by the German International Theater Institute, Goethe Institute, British Council, JDR III Fund, Asian Cultural Council, Southeast Asian Education Ministries Organization, USSR Ministry of Culture, and the NCCA.

Among the many awards he has received are: Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinagan Award from the City of Manila, 1995; Alab ng Dangal Life Achievement Award from the NCCA, 2002; Outstanding International Researcher in Dance from the US Congress on Research in Dance, 2003; National Research Council of the Philippines Life Achievement Award, 2005; Association of Ballet Academics-Philippines, 2006 and 2011; National Book Awards, 2006 and 2012; UP Arts Productivity Award, 2010; Philstage Natatanging Buhay Life Achievement Award as critic, 2014; the Lifetime Achievement Award during the First Choreographers Festival International Award, Bacolod City, the Manuel L. Quezon Parangal of Quezon City, and the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for Cultural Research and Leadership, all in 2015.

photos.photodesc:
Marta Victor

(Photo from facebook.com/PatnubayngAngono/)

text:
VITOR, MARTA(Marta Vocalan Vitor) b. Angono, Rizal 19 Jan 1932. d. Angono, Rizal 17 Mar 2017. Dancer and teacher of bati, the devotional dance style unique to Angono. She is the daughter of fisherman Clemente Vitor, and homemaker, Potenciana Vocalan. An elder brother, Primitivo aka Tibong, is a band musician and also a bati dance teacher. Her nieces, Estelita Perez-Gil and Valentina Perez-Villamayor, were chosen as bati dancers and from then on assisted Vitor in teaching the dance.

Vitor dedicated her life to the faithful transmission of the devotional dance since 1955 when she was randomly chosen to become thekapitana(female captain). She emerged as a natural bati dancer owing to years of observation since childhood when she watched the dancers train during rehearsals inside the church convent and during Holy Week rituals where bati is traditionally performed. Her mentor was Emilia San Pedro, a former kapitana and a choir conductor, who is also the sister of Lucio San Pedro, later proclaimed National Artist. From 1955 up to the 2010s, Vitor took on the task of teaching the bati variants of the kapitana and thetenyenta(female lieutenant)—the two main performers of the bati. Through her long teaching experience that spans six decades, she developed her simple but unrecorded instructional method. Bati dancers are randomly chosen from a council of women devotees who are amateur dancers. Her teaching technique trains even the non-dancer to gracefully perform the back-breaking postures of the bati along with the continuous waving of the flag. She teaches how the specific dances of the kapitana and the tenyenta are performed to the accompaniment of their respective band music. Her simple system also teaches the kapitana how to recite the 20-minutedicho(long poem) which is rendered with precise stances, body movements, and gestures.

Vitor received recognition for her commitment to preserve the local dance form. In 2001, the province of Rizal awarded her the Gawad Pagkilala at Pagpapahalaga for her effort to carry on the enduring traditions of Angono. In 2007, she was named Outstanding Senior Citizen of Rizal for her exemplary role in keeping alive the local art and culture. She was given the Gawad Likas na Galing at Yaman ng Angono in 2011 by the Regional Pilot School for the Arts and the Likas na Galing at Yaman ng Angono, Inc. A municipal resolution in 2012 by the local government of Angono bestowed on her the Dangal ng Bayan Award.Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
WISNUSUBROTO, SUNARDI b. Solo Surakarta, Indonesia 12 Apr 1926. Dancer, musician. He is married to Suharsini Wisnusubido with whom he has three sons and a daughter. He studied at Cokroaminoto University in Jakarta where he received a bachelor of arts degree in education. For about 15 years until 1990, he taught Indonesian dance and music, including the playing of the gamelan, at the University of the Philippines College of Music. He also produced the Indonesian dance drama Ramayana several times, and portions of Mahabharata, as well as other music and dance concerts and shadow-puppet plays.

Among those who have danced for him are Arsenio Nicolas, RamonP.Santos, Nes Gatus, Coralie and Carissa Dioquino, Leni Bala, AnnaVilladolid, Rebecca Rodriguez, Susan Atizado, Maria Veronica Restituto, and Joanne Solis Ko, often in the company of other Indonesian dancers. Sunardi was also associated with the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music and the Sekola Indonesia Manila. In 1997, he published a book titled Sri Lestari: An Introduction to Gamelan. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article_title: World Dance Alliance/World Dance Alliance- Philippines
description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
World Dance Alliance-Philippines represented by Angela Baguilat and Joelle Jacinto

at the World Dance Alliance Asia-Pacific Annual General Meeting in Taipei, 2013

text:
WORLD DANCE ALLIANCE / WORLD DANCE ALLIANCE-PHILIPPINES Originally founded in 1986 as the Asia Pacific Dance Alliance (APDA), World Dance Alliance (WDA) expanded globally, thus its change in name. It was founded in Asia by Carl Wolz at the Hong Kong (HK) Academy for the Performing Arts. As legally formalized, WDA had Wolz as president and Nestor O. Jardin as vice-president. Its first member-countries were mainly from Asia which later formed WDA’s Asia Pacific (WDA-AP) global center. The other centers are made up of the Americas (North and South) and Europe. Periodically, some African countries join WDA events. WDA aims to gather dance artists, scholars, educators, producers, and promoters around the world. This was initially coursed through conferences and festivals in HK, which are now held annually in member countries or in global centers (Asia Pacific for the Philippines). Biennially, there is an overall global event which was held several times in Asia or Australia, the Americas, and Europe. The Philippines was a host to events in 1991 and 1998 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

The WDA-Philippines’s (WDA-P) first president was Jardin. In 1980, he called for an election constituted by a national board. Elected were Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz as president, Corazon G. Iñigo as vice-president, Prosperidad Arandez as secretary, Shirley Halili-Cruz as treasurer, and Larry Gabao as public relations officer. With the death of Arandez, Halili-Cruz became secretary-treasurer. As a member country, the Philippines pays annual dues to WDA-Asia Pacific and joins conferences and festivals of WDA-AP, and global ones in Asia, the Americas, and Europe. In 2000 in Tokyo, Villaruz succeeded Miki Wakamatsu as president of WDA-AP. After him came Mohd Anis Md Nor of Malaysia, and the current president, Yunyu Wang Cheng of Taiwan. WDA-AP publishes a biannual journal, Asia Pacific Channels.

Among WDA-P’s activities is its annual participation in the World Dance Day (Apr 29) of the United Nations Education and Scientific Organization (UNESCO), in conjunction with UNESCO’s Council International of Dance (CID), Dance Committee of International Theater Institute (ITI), Council International of Organizations of Folklore Festivals and Traditional Arts (CIOFF-TA), UNESCO-daCi (Dance for Children), and the Dance Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. WDA-P helped the formation of the Contemporary Dance Network that organizes the Contemporary Dance Map, a consortium event for dance groups and studios in Metro Manila, and the WiFi Body Dance Festival, a contemporary dance festival and competition at the CCP. In 2014, WDA-P certified Dance-Pull’s choreography workshops in Bacolod and Quezon City, and drew more regional members into the organization.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
YADAO, RICHARDSON ( Richardson Petate Yadao )b. Manila 18 May 1988. Dancer. Richardson Yadao is the son of Nelson Barris Yadao and Erlinda Petate, and the brother of dancers Ronelson Yadao and Nanilyn Yadao. He graduated from the De La Salle-College of St. Benilde in 2009, with a Bachelor of Arts in Arts Management.

He was first exposed to dance through the theatrical dance program at the Aurora A. Quezon Elementary School. Through the school’s partnership in the institution of Manila Dance Center with Manila Mayor Lito Atienza in 2000, he received formal training in classical ballet under Luther Perez, Tony Fabella, and Eddie Elejar. A year later, he entered the Philippine High School for the Arts as a ballet major where he trained with Nonoy Froilan, Victor Ursabia, Veronique Duma-Berdin, and Ronilo Jaynario. Graduating in 2005 with an Artistic Excellence award, he entered St. Benilde and joined the Filipinescas Dance Company. The company was later renamed Romancon Dance Company under Christine Crame-Santillan, of which he was a founding member.

He joined Ballet Philippines (BP) in 2009 and has since portrayed most the major roles in company productions until his departure in 2015. A versatile dancer, he has portrayed principal roles in modern and classical productions both as protagonist and antagonist. His strength and command on stage are evident in his portrayals of antagonist roles such as Captain Hook in Edna Vida’s Peter Pan,2010, the Frayle in Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress), 2011, and Ravana in Alice Reyes’s Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 2012. His portrayals of protagonist roles also ascertain his princely characteristics and technical abilities in modern works essaying one of two male leads in Carlo Pacis’s Shifting Wait, 2010,Luyong in Alden Lugnasin’s Pusong Wagas (Pure Heart),2011, Oberon in Carlo Pacis’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 2012, all of which were created on him, and Rama in Rama, Hari for which he won a Gawad Buhay Award; and in classical roles as Prince Desire in Sleeping Beauty, 2011, Albrecht in Giselle, 2013, Prince Charming in Reyes’s Cinderella, 2014, and the man in George Birkadze’s R/J, 2014, which was created on him. He extended his versatility in roles that required acting abilities such as Emilio Aguinaldo in Locsin’s La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), 2014, and Apolaki in Paul Alexander Morales and Lugnasin’s Manhid (Numb), 2015.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Ronelson Yadao

(Photo courtesy of the artist)

text:
YADAO, RONELSON ( Ronelson Petate Yadao )b. Manila 7 Jul 1990. Dancer. Yadao is the son of Nelson Baris Yadao and Erlinda Petate; his older brother, Richardson, is also a dancer. He has a bachelor’s degree in performing arts, major in dance, from De La Salle-College of Saint Benilde (DLS-CSB) School of Design and Arts, 2010. He started with street dance at Manila Dance Center, 2001, and eventually enrolled at the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) where he furthered his training in ballet. His mentors include Tony Fabella, Luther Perez, Eddie Elejar, Noordin Jumalon, Augustus Damian III, Veronique Duma Berdin, Ronillo Jaynario, Nonoy Froilan, and Victoria Ursabia, in the Philippines; and Bulareyaung Pagarlava and Huang Yi, in Taiwan.

Yadao joined Ballet Philippines (BP) after high school, and was featured in several productions, in both national and international tours. He was chosen by Agnes Locsin to portray the role of Andres Bonifacio in the restaging of her La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), 2008; an injury prevented the consummation of the role, though he did capture critical attention in the Malolos Congress scene in Act 2. His roles typified him as an unconventional heroic lead and an intimidating villain, in ballets such as The Nutcracker, 2008;Alice Reyes’s TalesoftheManuvu, 2009; and Vicente Nebrada’s OurWaltzes, 2009.He performed the pas de deux from Reyes’s Romeo and Juliet in the 2010 Masterworks gala, and created the lead role of Baybayan as iconic hero of the people in Alden Lugnasin’s Ulaging, 2009.Exploring choreography, his works have been featured in DLS-CSB’s arts month productions, and in BP’s Neo-Filipino, presenting You, Me, Us in 2009. He was commissioned to create Introduction for the Seven Dance Company, 2013.

In 2010, Yadao joined Cloud Gate Dance Theater 2 in Taiwan, performing nationally and in international tours in the USA, China, and Germany. He shone in the company’s diverse repertoire, particularly in Tantalus by Kuo-chu Wu, Uncertain Waiting by Bulareyang Pagarlava, and Symphony Project by Huang Yi.

He won the PHSA’s Artistic Excellence award, 2006, and placed second in the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NMCYA) Junior Ballet Division, 2008. In 2009, Philstage Gawad Buhay awarded him the Outstanding Male Lead Performance in Dance for his role as Baybayan in Lugnasin’s Ulaging.Written by Chantal Primero

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc: Sofia Zobel
Sofia Zobel

text:
ZOBEL, SOFIA ( Sofia Miranda Zobel de Ayala-Elizalde )b. Makati City 4 Nov 1968. Sofia Zobel-Elizalde is one of the six children of businessman and noted photographer Jaime Zobel de Ayala and Beatriz Miranda. She is married to Francisco Elizalde, with whom she has three children. She graduated high school from Elmhurst Ballet School in Surrey, England, 1985, receiving the Sylphide Cup for most outstanding performance. She has a BA in Mass Communication from Assumption College, Manila, 1992.

She trained with Felicitas Layag-Radaic, then with Effie Nañas at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Dance School (CCPDS) from 1977 to 1981, and was cast as Clara in CCP Dance Company’s The Nutcracker for three consecutive years. At Elmhurst, she trained with Marcia Herrington for four years and completed Elementary Executant from Royal Academy of Dance (RAD), Ingreso from Sociedad de Baile Español, and Elementary Cecchetti from Imperial Society of Dancing, 1982; Elementary Modern from ISD, 1983; and Intermediate and Advanced Executant from RAD in 1984 and 1985, respectively. She briefly trained with the School of American Ballet in New York in 1987–88, and joined Ballet Philippines upon her return, where she trained with William Morgan.

With Ballet Philippines, she performed notable roles in The Nutcracker and La Bayadere (The Temple Dancer), 1987; the title role in Effie Nañas’s Snow White, 1988; Swan Lake, 1989 and 1991; the title role in Alice Reyes’s Itim (Onyx Wolf),1990; Myrtha in Giselle,1991; and Titania in Reyes’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1989. Most of the roles she is cast in are strong, imposing characters, due to her regal bearing, and strong, imposing technique. She was particularly exceptional in the title role of Reyes’s Carmen, 1990, which toured Hong Kong and in Russia. She retired from the stage in 1993.

She opened Steps Dance Studio in 1994, and was registered as a RAD teacher in 1995, under the mentorship of Sonia Domingo. She received her RAD teaching certification in 2005, and ensures that her faculty members are certified in RAD. In 2007, she established the Steps Scholarship Foundation, which provides dance training for several deserving scholars each year.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto and Desiree P. Medina

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines

photos.photodesc:
Christine Crame as Darna in College of Saint Benilde’s Ding, Ang Bato!, 2018

(Photo by Filipino Educators of Tomorrow, courtesy of the artist)

Christine Crame, 2016

(Photo by Jun Crame, courtesy of the artist)

text:
CRAME, CHRISTINE (Christine Flores Crame) b. Caloocan City 22 Jun 1974. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. She is the daughter of Amando Crame Jr and Gertrudes Flores. She has a son, Uno Diego Crame Santillan. She finished her bachelor’s degree in performing arts, major in dance, at the De La Salle-College of Saint Benilde (DLS-CSB) in 2000. Currently, she is taking up her master’s degree in educational management at the Philippine Women’s University.

Crame joined Ballet Philippines (BP) first as a scholar from 1988 to 1990, then an apprentice from 1990 to 1994, before becoming a company member and soloist in 1994 until 2006. She has danced for some of BP’s major productions including Paquita, Giselle, La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), Elias, The Taming of the Shrew, La Bayadere, Romeo and Juliet, and Encantada (Enchantress). She played the title role in Darna, Snow White, Edna Vida’s Peter Pan, Alden Lugnasin’s Peter Pan’s Neverneverland, and Cinderella. Other key roles in BP productions include Cita in Noche Buena (Christmas Eve Celebration), Little Swan in Swan Lake, and Clara in The Nutcracker. She has joined BP’s touring productions in Davao, Bacolod, Iloilo, Cebu, Zamboanga, Iligan, Cagayan, Baguio, and Dumaguete, as well as in France, Australia, Germany, Indonesia, China, Japan, Hong Kong, United States, The Netherland, United Kingdom, Portugal, and Austria.

Crame has performed and choreographed dance pieces both for BP’s Neo Filipino series and WiFi Body Contemporary Dance Festival. In 2007, she became the artistic director and choreographer of Saint Benilde Romançon Dance Company (SBRDC) and has since taught contemporary dance at CSB. In 2009, she became senior faculty member of CSB’s School of Design and Arts (SDA) as well as chairperson of its academic dance department. The following year, she spearheaded the founding of Seven Contemporary Dance Company (SCDC), which is composed of seven choreographers and dancers who are all graduates of Saint Benilde Romançon Dance Company. Both SBRDC and SCDC have been invited to participate in a number of cultural events as well as local and international dance festivals, with Crame as choreographer or performer or both. Crame has also conducted dance workshops and dance classes both locally and abroad.

Crame’s most recent dance performance was in 2018 when she played Darna once again in SDA’s production of Ding, Ang Bato! (Ding, Give Me the Stone!), directed by Chris Millado, which was a reworking of the BP production in 2003 (also directed by Millado). “Flamenco,” a dance piece she has choreographed, won a gold medal in the 2018 Hong Kong Challenge Cup Dance competition. SBRDC previously won two gold medals in this competition for the dance pieces “Little Swans,” “Brothers,” and “Bounce,” which were all choreographed by Crame. Aside from teaching at SDA, Crame also choreographs and/or directs corporate events, cultural shows, and school-based productions. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian

description: Profiles of dance personalities and institutions in the Philippines
text:
PACLIBAR-MAMANGUN, KRIS-BELLE (Kris-Belle Leyba Paclibar-Mamangun) b. Davao City 12 Aug 1980. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. She is the daughter of Santiago Paclibar and Belinda Leyba. She is married to dancer and photographer Jojo Mamangun with whom she has a son. She finished her secondary studies at Davao City National High School in 1996, took Liberal Arts for one year at the University of the Immaculate Conception in Davao City, and then moved to Manila where she finished her bachelor’s degree in performing arts, major in dance, at the De La Salle-College of Saint Benilde in 2004.

Paclibar-Mamangun started her ballet training when she was eight years old under the tutelage of Carmen D. Locsin whose Davao-based Locsin Dance Workshop was instrumental in Paclibar-Mamangun’s formative years as a dancer. In 1994, she became a full scholar of the CCP Dance School, later graduating in 1998 as the school’s Most Outstanding Scholar. She joined Ballet Philippines (BP) first as an apprentice in 2001, and a year later, as company member. She has trained and performed with dance artists such as Alice Reyes, Denisa Reyes, Agnes Locsin, Edna Vida, Nonoy Froilan, Noordin Jumalon, Cecile Sicangco, Ida Beltran-Lucila, Camille Ordinario, Brando Miranda, Rami Levi, Boi Sakti, Frank Ohmann, Gina Katigbak, Alden Lugnasin, and Norman Walker. She has played lead roles in some of BP’s acclaimed productions including Cinderella in Alice Reyes’s Cinderella, Celise in Noordin Jumalon’s La Fille Mal Gardee, and Anna Trojana in Jumalon’s A Forest Tale, 2002; Sugar Plum Fairy in Edna Vida’s The Nutcracker and Darna in Denisa Reyes and Alden Lugnasin’s Darna, 2003; Tinkerbell in Alden Lugnasin’s Peter Pan’s Neverneverland and Lisa in William Morgan’s Ang Pilya (La Fille Mal Gardee), 2004; and Titania in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 2013.

Her other dance credits include: Redha Benteifour’s Les Petits Mots D’Amour, 2002; Christine Crame’s Butterfly and Alice Reyes’s Carmina Burana, 2003; Denisa Reyes’s Asong Ulol (Mad Dog) and Agnes Locsin’s Igorot and Taong Talangka (Crab Man), 2004; Tony Fabella’s Maalala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), Bam Damian’s Hindi Kita Malimot (I Cannot Forget You) and Minamahal, Sinasamba (Loved, Adored), Irish Abejero’s Usahay(Sometimes) and Dalagang Pilipina (Philippine Maiden), and Christine Crame’s Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal (How Much Do I Love You), 2005; Agnes Locsin’s Arachnida, 2007, Salome and Sanga (Branch), 2013, and Bunga: Huling Galaw (Fruit: Last Movement), 2015; and Lugnasin and Locsin’s Swans, 2017.

Paclibar-Mamangun became a performer at Hong Kong Disneyland from 2005 to 2008. She was an artist of Cirque du Soleil’s first resident show in Asia titled Zaia, staged in Macau from 2008 to 2012, where she appeared as a contemporary dancer and an alternate for the title character. She returned to the Philippines in 2012 and became a dance lecturer at College of Saint Benilde’s dance program. She has also given dance classes at the CCP Dance School, Perry Sevidal Ballet, JNA Dance Center, Academy One Music and Dance Center, and Effie Nañas Ballet School.

Paclibar-Mamangun’s choreography has been featured in ARKILAHAN, Ballet Philippines Young Choreographers’ Showcase, as well as in Tanghalang Pilipino’s San Andres B., 2013, and Ibalong, 2016. Currently, she is based in Davao where she works as guest artist and teacher for the Locsin Dance Workshop. She is also a certified Romanas® Pilates instructor. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian
